Back of a length from Cummins, seaming back in. Azam tries to steer the ball to third man for one. The inward movement helps the ball rap the glove and just lob to Smith at slip. An easy catch. But well bowled too. Got some bounce and extra oomph in his delivery. Head to Rizwan, 1 leg bye on the pads, off the pads for one to fine leg 9.05pm And that is that. Australia go 1-0 up in the series, and showed they have what it takes to win even when their powerful top order fails to click. How will Pakistan respond? Join us day after tomorrow at the MCG to find out. Until then, goodbye! Player of the match is Matthew Wade, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 9 for 268 (Wade 100*, Maxwell 60, Hasan Ali 3-65) beat Pakistan 176 (Faulkner 4-32, Cummins 3-33) by 92 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Matthew Wade performed a commendable salvage operation for Australia to put up a total that proved well beyond the reach of Pakistan in the first ODI at an enervating Gabba. Defeat may be particularly ruinous for the visitors given an apparent hamstring tear to the captain Azhar Ali, who must now be in grave doubt for the rest of the tour. Azhar suffered the injury early in Pakistan's ultimately doomed pursuit, and did it no favours when coming back out to bat at the fall of the sixth wicket. Brisbane's hot and humid weather also claimed an Australian casualty, with the debutant Billy Stanlake appearing in some distress and unable to add to his initial three overs. Fortunately for Australia's captain Steven Smith, he had plenty of other bowling options to call upon, including the exceptionally-tidy Travis Head.

Commentary_Highlights: 8:44pm Looks like Australia will start with spin. Ashton Agar has the ball and is positioning his long-off fielder. Zampa to Boult, 1 wide legbreak tossed up wide outside off, probably hoping Boult stepped out. He doesn't, lets it go Kane Richardson to Jamieson, 1 wide full and down leg side, left alone I thought with ball we adapted really well, we learnt from the way NZ bowled. Pace off the ball was going to be important, the way Agar bowled in that powerplay was important. He's such a dynamic player (Maxi), he always wants to be in the action - he's a great player to balance out your side. We've been trying to be a bit more aggresive with the batting but when you lose wickets, it gets tougher, so we looked to take it deeper [today] and got some good momentum going into the 10:23pm And that is all from our live coverage of this game. See you for the decider on Sunday! Player of the match is Aaron Finch, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 156 for 6 (Finch 79*, Sodhi 3-32) beat New Zealand106 (Jamieson 30, K Richardson 3-19) by 50 runs A crucial innings from captain Aaron Finch on a tricky pitch, as he became Australia's leading scorer in men's T20Is, followed by a tight display in the field enabled them to take the series to a decider in Wellington on Sunday as the home side's batting disappointed for the second game running. On a surface being used for the fourth time in three days (with two more matches to come), scoring was much tougher than when Australia put more than 200 on the board in the previous game. New Zealand had control for the majority of the time in the field - Ish Sodhi and Trent Boult taking five wickets between them - but Finch took full toll in the final over of the innings as Kyle Jamieson was plundered for 26. New Zealand were under pressure from the start of the chase and could not make a dent on the target in the powerplay. Australia's three spinners - Ashton Agar, Adam Zampa and Glenn Maxwell - produced combined figures of 11-0-49-6.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.50pm Sri Lanka win the toss and bowl for the third time this series. Malinga to Klinger, (no ball) Malinga apologies, Klinger acknowledges it. Full-toss above the waist, the line is outside leg, the batsman ducks under it. That probably slipped out of Malinga's hands Malinga to Head, SIX runs This is even better from Head. Malinga can't get the yorker right again. Full on off stump, right in the slot, launched over Siriwardana at long-on Malinga to Turner, OUT Kapu pulls off a cracking catch now. He dashes in from long-on, dives forward, and takes it. Turner backs away outside leg. Malinga chases him and cramps him with a full-toss which is dragged away to Kapu. He did well to attack the catch Jhye Richardson to Munaweera, SIX runs back of a length on middle, Munaweera ventures deep in the crease and biffs it over long-on for a six Cummins to Upul Tharanga, 1 leg bye 145.4ks missile on the leg stump, Tharanga is beaten for pace. The ball grazes the thigh and rolls to the leg side Cummins to Prasanna, 1 wide bouncer on middle, ducks under it. Too high, called a wide Faulkner to Prasanna, 1 wide slower on from Faulkner, slips down the leg side for a wide, Prasanna looked to thwack that behind square leg for four Player of the match is Adam Zampa, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 6 for 187 (Klinger 62, Finch 53) beat Sri Lanka 146 (Faulkner 3-20, Zampa 3-25) by 41 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Adam Zampa's dismantling of Sri Lanka arrived too late to salvage the series for Australia, and also too late for his skiddy, accurate wristspin to be considered for the Test team to face India in Pune from Thursday. The frequent omission of Zampa from Australia's ODI and Twenty20 sides - despite an excellent record in both formats - has been a mystery for quite some time, and there appeared to be thinly veiled frustration on the part of the bowler as he accounted for the series' pivotal player Asela Gunaratne, Chamara Kapugedara and Dasun Shanaka in quick succession to push a target of 188 beyond the reach of the visitors. His wickets came not from any extravagant turn but instead useful changes of pace and unrelenting attack on the stumps, winning a pair of back foot lbw verdicts from the umpire Paul Wilson either side of another slider that bowled Kapugedara between bat and pad. Australia's selectors had admitted to choosing an "attacking" spinner in Mitchell Swepson over what the panel's chairman Trevor Hohns called a more "defensive" operator in Zampa. Sri Lanka made a rapid start to their chase but a sturdy Australian effort with the bat meant that they did not have much room to lose momentum.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.55pm Sri Lanka captain Upul Tharanga wins the toss and chooses to bowl again. Sanjaya to Finch, OUT No fireworks from Finch in front of his home fans. Sanjaya has his man. Good length ball, angled in and kicks up at the batsman again. Finch is early into the shot, looking to work to leg. He jumps off the ground, and ends up lobbing a return catch. This surface has something in it for the seamers Kulasekara to Klinger, 1 wide full and drifting down leg for another leg-side wide Munaweera to Dunk, SIX runs Dunk makes room outside leg, opens up the off side. Takes this length ball from outside off and launches it over cover for a six Munaweera to Dunk, SIX runs Dunk goes downtown now. Tossed up and outside off, Dunk moves away outside leg again. He smashes it disdainfully over the long-off fence. This Munaweera experiment has backfired for SL Gunaratne to Dunk, OUT bowled'em. Just 88ks, the lack of pace does 'em in. Looks like another slower cutter, dips, creating distance between the bat and the pitch. Dunk aims a big swipe and does not touch it. Asela kisses the off stump Sanjaya to Klinger, OUT a big appeal for caught behind from the bowler and the keeper. Nogajski takes his own sweet time and then raises his finger. Good length and outside off, Klinger reaches out with his hands, swishes and snicks behind. The snicko detects the outside edge. End of a sluggish knock from Klinger Kulasekara to Head, OUT The drop costs Sri Lanka nothing. Munaweera will be relieved. Length and angling away outside off, bounces at the batsman. Head simply steers it into the gloves of Dickwella Prasanna to Turner, OUT Excellent catch from Siriwardana at long-off. Starkly contrasts with those drops from Kapu and Munaweera. Tossed up and spins away outside off, Turner flat-bats this legbreak in the air. Siriwardana moves swiftly to his right, dives across, and snaps it up Malinga to Faulkner, OUT 114.1ks slower dipping yorker from Malinga. How does he do that? Slings in on middle, dips and kisses the front pad. Nogajski rules him out. Hotspot picks up an inside edge. Faulkner has to go, though Sanjaya to Henriques, SIX runs slower short ball on off stump, hip-high ball, moves back and swats it powerfully over midwicket Malinga to Paine, OUT Malinga implores, Paine given out lbw. Another slower full ball from Malinga. Dips in front of Paine, who was shaping up for a cute little scoop over Dickwella's head. He is pinned in front. Second wicket for Malinga. It was crashing into leg stump. The ball looped off the pad into the gloves of the keeper Kulasekara to Cummins, OUT Kulasekara can bowl yorkers too. Yorker, tails in late into the leg stump. Pings the toe and disturbs the leg stump. Too good for a lower-order batsman. It would have even dismissed a top-order batsman Kulasekara to Tye, OUT appeal for lbw, Simon Fry now raises his finger. Full and swerves in to beat the inside edge - Tye was looking to work it across the line - traps him in front of leg. But I guess this was heading down leg Kulasekara to Jhye Richardson, OUT bowled'em. Kulaseakara closes the innings with a wicket. Very full on the leg stump, kisses the pad and hits the stumps. Richardson does not connect with the wild slog. He bags a golden duck on debut. Three wickets in four balls from Kulasekara Faulkner to Dickwella, OUT Dickwella attempts the scoop and the ball balloons into the gloves of the keeper. It bounces more than Dickwella expected. He pre-meditates, going low, and attempting to dink it over his shoulder. The ball misses the bat, misses the glove, grazes the shoulder on its way to Paine Jhye Richardson to Mendis, OUT Third-ball wicket for Richardson on debut. His team-mates mess his hair up. Back of a length and outside off, skids through in the corridor. Mendis swishes a long way away from hid body and nicks it behind. The outside edge flies to the right of Paine. He stretches across and completes a fine catch Henriques to Prasanna, 2 wide full cutter drifting down leg, off the thigh and rolls to the keeper. Given as a wide, though Henriques to Gunaratne, SIX runs back of a length and outside off, wrong length again. Asela clears his front leg again, slamming it high over midwicket Tye to Gunaratne, SIX runs Asela clears mid-off, again. Goes all the way. Good length and outside off, hoisted flat over the fielder. What a key strike 11pm Phew, look the celebrations in the Sri Lanka camp. Asela sets off on a celebratory sprint. His team-mates finally track him down and mob him. SL slid to 40 for 5. They needed 79 off the last seven overs, and 48 off the last three. Asela said no problem and caught fire, lacing three successive sixes off Henriques and then muscling three boundaries in the Sri Lanka won by 2 wickets Player of the match is Asela Gunaratne, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 8 for 176 (Gunaratne 84*, Tye 3-37) beat Australia 173 (Henriques 56, Klinger 43, Kulasekara 4-31) 2 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Asela Gunaratne orchestrated a remarkable heist to seal the T20 series for Sri Lanka with a match to play, stealing an outrageous victory over Australia in the first international match ever played at Geelong's Kardinia Park. For the second time in three days, Sri Lanka reached their target from the final ball of their chase, but whereas at the MCG they had needed only 18 off the last three overs, here they needed 48. Gunaratne ensured that they did it in style. Forty-eight off 18 balls became 36 off 12, and then came the over that turned things firmly in Sri Lanka's favour. Moises Henriques, who earlier had struck an unbeaten half-century to set Sri Lanka a target of 174, failed to find the right lengths and was plundered for three consecutive sixes by Gunaratne, as well as a four, and it left them requiring 14 from the final over, to be bowled by Andrew Tye.

Commentary_Highlights: 7.10pm Upul Tharanga wins his first toss as Sri Lanka T20I captain and chooses to bowl first. Sandakan to Klinger, OUT wrong'un, full on off stump, Klinger looks to slog it over the leg side. He did not pick the wrong'un I guess. Wanted to heave over the leg side, and ended up slicing an outside edge in the air. Malinga ventured in from point and clasped it, sliding on his knees Malinga to Henriques, 1 wide full and slung down the leg side, past the attempted flick Sanjaya to Henriques, OUT First international wicket for Sanjaya! Length ball on off, Henriques can't clear the long boundary. #MCGisbig. Holes out to Kapu at long-on. The shot was on, but the execution was bad, with the bat twisting in Henriques' hands 9.20pm Good workout for Malinga on return. He snapped up two catches in two overs, took two wickets. The wristspinners - Prasanna and Sandakan - slowed Australia down in the middle overs with combined figures of 8-0- 53-1 after Klinger and Finch added 76 for the first wicket. Sri Lanka's fielding, though, was sloppy. They need 169. Be back soon for the chase. Stanlake to Dickwella, 1 wide starts off with a wild leg-side wide. Paine makes a sprawling save behind the stumps Faulkner to Gunaratne, 1 leg bye Asela ventures across off, misses the sweep, and takes it on the pad outside the line Cummins to Gunaratne, FOUR runs four boundaries in six balls for Asela. Short of a length and outside off, Asela ramps it in the air to the right of deep third man now. Celebrates his maiden T20I fifty Turner to Siriwardana, OUT Two wickets in three balls for the debutant. Pushed through flatter and quicker, Siriwardana plays back and is pinned in front of leg stump. Was it heading down leg? I am sure this is missing the stumps. The umpire doesn't think so, and raises his finger. The tracker suggests it was heading down Faulkner to Prasanna, 1 wide back of the hand slower one again, this is too wide outside off. Past the tramline. Prasanna swishes and does not connect Faulkner to Prasanna, 1 leg bye 110.8ks slower ball on middle and leg, he eyes up the leg side and misses. The ball grazes the thigh and rolls to the off side Sri Lanka won by 5 wickets Player of the match is Asela Gunaratne, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 5 for 172 (Gunaratne 52, Munaweera 44) beat Australia 6 for 168 (Finch 43, Malinga 2-29) by five wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Australia's "best of the Big Bash League" took Sri Lanka to the final ball. The hosts and their three debutants fought to the finish against the visitors in front of a raucous crowd at the MCG, but a win offered Sri Lanka the chance to wrap up the series at Kardinia Park on Sunday. The Perth Scorchers' Andrew Tye was left with six runs to defend from the final over, and one from the final ball. Chamara Kapugedara surveyed the ring field then punched the winning boundary through the covers to secure the result. His composure ensured Sri Lanka finished in the ascendant after looking the more likely victors throughout their chase, largely due to a boundary count that outstripped the hosts, 21 to 13.

Commentary_Highlights: Cummins to Brownlie, 1 wide 140 kph, goes for the bouncer, but it soars over Brownlie's head, even though he is ducking. Umpire Brown at square leg signals wide and his partner Palliyaguruge follows suit Cummins to Williamson, OUT what a beauty! Extra bounce, and darting in off the seam too. It's that movement that does him. The ball begins as a short one outside off so Williamson gets a late cut ready, but he is caught off guard because it rears up, cramps him for room and takes a little tickle off the inside edge through to the keeper. Great reward for a probing spell from Cummins. Cummins to Taylor, 1 wide digs it in short, and outside off, gains a little too much height off this hard pitch and is penalised for it Cummins to Taylor, 1 wide way too high, and way too far outside off. That's the third wide of the over. Walks back with a disheartened smile Faulkner to Broom, OUT huge nick and umpire Brown says off you go. Hits the seam and kicks up off the pitch. Takes the outside edge at the shoulder of Broom's bat as he comes forward to try and defend. Beautiful bowling, with just a little help from the pitch Faulkner to Taylor, 4 leg byes that's out of his T20 playbook, shuffling across to off stump and swinging across the line of a length ball. Misses it completely, of course, and gets leg byes to long leg Faulkner to Taylor, OUT pummels it... straight to deep square leg. Taylor walks off to a rousing ovation, but without him, New Zealand have no hope of getting to the kind of score they want. Good bowling from Faulkner, hitting a stump-to-stump line, changing his pace as often as possible Faulkner to Southee, SIX runs gets length and Southee winds up... this looks like six.. this should have been six a lot more easily... but Stoinis almost pulls off the most miraculous effort. He is on the edge of the deep midwicket boundary, leaping back sticking his right hand high and behind him to try and take a catch. Does so one-handed and sees Cummins running in from square leg on his peripheral vision, tries to toss it to him to complete the wicket. No luck there. And worse, the back of his boot stamps on the advertising triangles as he got hold of the ball. Great effort, though. Starc to Ferguson, OUT another yorker and the stumps are in disarray again. Ferguson's bat just doesn't come down quick enough. Starc just turns around after seeing the bails fly. He wants to get this over with, put his feet up, bag the trophy and go home. Seems to be getting some late away swing as well Starc to Santner, SIX runs finishes off with a six. This is length again from Starc and Santner is able to get under it with a slog over deep midwicket Southee to Finch, SIX runs glorious stroke! Full and swinging away, Finch gets to the pitch of the ball and lofts him through the line. The ball sails over the ropes at long-off. Just an extension of his arms but the timing was outstanding. Little or no followthrough on that occasion. Big, broad blades, yes, but the timing was super too Southee to Finch, 1 wide slower delivery but he gets the angle wrong, way down leg and on the bounce to the keeper. 111 kph Santner to Finch, 1 run pulled to wide long-on, six off the over Williamson to Finch, SIX runs into the hospitality area at deep midwicket. Sure, it was the longer boundary but this was a full toss that had to be hit. Connected cleanly Williamson to Finch, 1 wide fired down leg, Finch lets it go Ferguson to Stoinis, 5 wide digs it in short, Stoinis ignores it, Latham can't hope to move quickly enough to his left Ferguson to Stoinis, 1 wide too short and way over the batsman's head. Correct decision from the umpire Neesham to Cummins, 1 wide short and way down the leg side. Not quick enough too to induce fear in the batsmen Santner to Starc, SIX runs he's clobbered that over cow corner. Tossed up on leg stump, Starc takes him on and gets enough muscle on the slog. Big over, this isn't over by any means 6.50pm I wouldn't want to be picking the Man of the Match award, folks. Ross Taylor came up with a special century and two outstanding slip catches. Trent Boult ran in fast, swung the ball late and kept chipping away at the wickets every time his captain threw him the ball. Who is your pick? For the record, New Zealand have moved above India to No. 3 in the ODI rankings as a result of this win. Celebration all around. Williamson is being presented the trophy by Sir Richard Hadlee. They're all smiles, this has been a series win well-deserved. Hope you enjoyed our coverage, but New Zealand's home season is far from over. They host South Africa now for one T20I at Eden Park (17 February) followed by an ODI series and three Tests. Do join us then. There's plenty of cricket elsewhere to keep you connected. Hope to see you soon. Cheers and thanks for joining us. Player of the match is Trent Boult, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 281 for 9 (Taylor 107, Brownlie 63, Faulkner 3-59, Starc 3-63) beat Australia 257 (Finch 56, Head 53, Boult 6-33) by 24 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details This was some sort of day for New Zealand. Ross Taylor equalled Nathan Astle's record for the most ODI hundreds for New Zealand. Trent Boult completed a career-best six-wicket haul. New Zealand regained the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy. They jumped to No.

Commentary_Highlights: Ball to Head, 1 leg bye flicked away Wood to Maxwell, OUT caught in the deep! Brilliant from Roy! Short ball from Wood, hit hard and flat, it's six all the way, but round swoops Roy, plucking the ball above his head, foot a millimetre from the line, then in that now-typical-but-still-awesome manner, tosses the ball up as his momentum takes him over, then gathering when back in play. Rashid to Wade, OUT googly! Wades reads it about as well as I can read Hindi. Three fielders converge but Rashid calls for his own catch as the ball loops straight up in the air, and England are really taking control in the slog-overs now Rashid to Starc, OUT that's terrible! An attempted googly, comes out as a leg-stump full toss, Starc slaps across the line as if substituting his bat for a damp tuna-fish, and up loops another facile catch, this time for Root behind the stumps! Wood to Cummins, 1 leg bye a slip in place as Wood hammers out a threatening length, but deflected away, Rashid to Cummins, OUT too easy for Rashid, who finishes his spell with a four-for! A lollipop push straight back to the bowler, neither forward nor back, and utterly unsure of which direction that would spin. England are rampant! Wood to Zampa, OUT full toss, and bowled! Zampa didn't fancy staying in line one little bit, gave himself room, and was in no position to protect his timbers as Wood splattered his off pole! Ball to Maxwell, 1 leg bye good delivery, nibbling off the seam and tucking up the right-hander. A deflection into the off side 2.03pm Well, that was a tale of two halves. Australia had visions of 340 at one stage, but Mark Wood's extraction of Steven Smith was a game-changer, before Adil Rashid got stuck into a lower-middle-order that has been confined to the nets for most of a very soggy tour. Eight wickets between them and great support from the rest. England will need 278 to Starc to Roy, OUT struck in front, Roy in a tangle... and after an age to think about it, Kumar Dharmasena raises his finger! Roy doesn't consult with his partner but quickly requests a review, but straight away this looks optimistic Hazlewood to Morgan, SIX runs dug in short and Morgan dumps the ball into the crowd! Always worth testing him with the short ball but Morgan is seeing it like Bravestarr (eyes of the hawk) and swings it up and away over the rope Hazlewood to Morgan, SIX runs huge. Simply huge. A round-house bottom-handed dump-truck of a shot, down the track, into the stands! "The bashing about Aussies is unfair, they didn't have a full game in the tournament. If rain wasn't a problem, Aussies, NZ and Bangladesh all would have ended up with 2 points," points out chotu. True, but even that's worthy of a little Aussie-ribbing, no? They're ranked No. 2 in the world "So the last time Australia won a game in CT was way back in 2009." That is spot on, Nilesh, as they were knocked out with only one point, from a washout, in 2013. "Why are 90% of comments about Bangladesh? This win is a very big deal for England, and an exceptional performance all round!!" Well, Jez, crushing England victories are so de rigueur nowadays. But you're right, they have made another big statement about their white-ball capabilities... Player of the match is Ben Stokes, ENG
Match_Report: England 240 for 4 (Stokes 102*, Morgan 87) beat Australia 277 for 9 (Head 71, Finch 68, Smith 56, Wood 4-33, Rashid 4-41) by 40 runs (DLS method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details As per a chorus in the Eric Hollies Stand cribbed from Three Lions and directed at Aaron Finch, Australia are going home. That they are doing so has less to do with damp English weather than the verve of the home side, personified by the pace of Mark Wood, the guile of Adil Rashid, the leadership of Eoin Morgan and the raw power of Ben Stokes. This was a meeting between a confident, aggressive England favoured to lift the Champions Trophy and an out-of-season Australia playing their first completed match of the trip. With the bat and then the ball, Steven Smith's side hinted at their full capability, but were unable to follow through as Morgan's men proved much the more resilient team when challenged. Having themselves knocked out New Zealand, a delighted Bangladesh are into the semi-finals.

Commentary_Highlights: 10.18pm And that is all from our live coverage tonight. We'll see you soon for the fourth T20I. Player of the match is Ashton Agar, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 4 for 208 (Maxwell 70, Finch 69, Philippe 43, Sodhi 2-32) beat New Zealand 144 (Guptill 43, Agar 6-30, Meredith 2-24) by 64 runs Aaron Finch emerged from his T20 slump with his first half-century in 27 innings, Glenn Maxwell turned on the pyrotechnics with some thrilling strokeplay, and Ashton Agar bettered his own record for Australia's best T20I figures as they kept the series alive with a 64-run victory in the third game at an empty stadium in Wellington. Riley Meredith made an eye-catching debut with his pace helping take crucial early wickets even as New Zealand initially managed to keep up with the steep asking rate, but couldn't maintain it to make a serious dip at the target. In the first half, the foundation for Australia was laid by a stand of 83 between Finch and Josh Philippe, and the latter part of the innings was powered by Maxwell's 31-ball 70 of which 62 runs came in boundaries. The eight overs from 10 to 18 brought 105 runs before New Zealand pulled it back somewhat. Martin Guptill and Devon Conway played well in the chase, but Agar took three wickets in the 13th over to end the contest on his way to a six-wicket haul - just the fourth bowler to achieve that feat in T20Is while also becoming the sixth to take multiple five-wicket hauls in the format.

Commentary_Highlights: 1.00pm Australia win the toss and elect to bat Yadav to Finch, 1 wide drifts down leg this time, wide. 137 kph, Umesh struggling. Bowling two lengths and two lines Hardik to Warner, 1 wide wow, that was waaay down leg, wide. Dhoni saved four by moving quickly Hardik to Warner, 1 wide another poor delivery, starts it too straight, drifts down leg. Dhoni stops the ball but rolls over it as he falls over. Ouch Axar Patel to Warner, SIX runs picks the length early and smashed. Short on middle, Warner picks the length early and nails his pull over midwicket. Six Chahal to Warner, SIX runs tossed up on leg stump, and Warner gets down low, front leg planted just next to the line, to slog-sweep hard and flat over midwicket Jadhav to Warner, OUT flat, shortish, angling into leg stump, and Jadhav has broken the partnership! The low release means there isn't too much bounce. Clears his front leg and looks to heave it over wide long-on, but it skids on and he hits it straighter than he'd like, and doesn't get the power he'd like, ends up hitting it straight to long-on Yadav to Finch, OUT looks to clobber it, such bad timing that mid-on takes a sitter. A slower ball outside off, Finch looks to drag the ball from well outside off, but it's right off the toe end, and straight to mid-on. So wide that it may have been a wide had Finch let that go Jadhav to Smith, 1 wide Smith backs away, then gets back inside the line, Jadhav follows him and concedes the wide Yadav to Smith, OUT chipped into the hands of midwicket. Australia are falling apart quickly. On the pads from Umesh, Smith gets outside the line and just clips it into the hands of midwicket, where Kohli is lurking. This game turning around quickly again Shami to Head, 1 wide drifts down leg, another wide Yadav to Head, 1 wide full and very wide outside off, left alone, wide called Yadav to Handscomb, OUT and bowled him off the next ball. Full and straight, seaming back in, Handscomb misses a big slog and the ball uproots off stump. Yikes. Just enough reverse swing for Shami. That's a fine cameo by a fine, young batsman 4.58pm All in all, that's quite a fine innings from Australia. But depending on which camp you are in, you'd be a little disappointed or slightly happy with that total of 334. When Warner and Finch were going, it looked like Australia were set for 360, maybe more. But India pulled it back nicely in the end through wickets. These are short boundaries, and a decent surface, and a fine batting unit. Cummins to Rahane, 1 leg bye ooh. Maybe a bit of inward nip. Back of a length, and he was looking to work that from just outside off stump through square leg. The ball beats his inside edge and rolls towards third man off his back thigh Zampa to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs doesn't matter what this ball was, legbreak, googly, flipper or a new invention. Just sees a bit of flight outside off and he gets down on one knee, moving his front leg out of the way to give him some swinging room, and slog-sweeps high and hard over wide long-on Head to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs shot! Fantastic execution from Rohit. Runs down, gets to the pitch, gets underneath and goes through with a clean swing, right over the bowler's head. Lovely stroke Coulter-Nile to Kohli, OUT happens again. Kohli has done it again, it was always going to happen and I think Coulter-Nile was playing for that. Good length outside off, the ball seaming back in, Kohli tries to dab this down to third man, but it takes the inside edge and hits the off stump. That's another error from Kohli, and the worst thing is he has repeated the mistake from Kolkata. It Cummins to Jadhav, 1 wide strays down the leg side, another wide, another extra Zampa to Pandey, 1 leg bye a touch short, angling down leg. Not short enough to pull. Looks to help it fine but can't put bat to ball. Only hits his upraised front pad, and rolls away for a leg bye towards fine leg. Belatedly, Smith as decided to review for lbw, but no way is that lbw. I haven't even seen the replays,and I know impact was outside leg stump and it was missing leg by a lon Cummins to Jadhav, 1 leg bye out of his crease again and he gets a bit of inward nip with this back-of-a-length ball. Sneaks under the attempted horizontal-bat swat and hits his pad, high up 9.55pm And that is that. A good win for Australia, turns around some pretty ordinary away form, and a few things to ponder for India ahead of the final ODI, which is in Nagpur on Sunday. Be sure to join us for that game. Until then, goodbye! Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 334 for 5 (Warner 124, Finch 94, Handscomb 43, Umesh 4-71) beat India 313 for 8 (Jadhav 67, Rohit 65, Rahane 53, Richardson 3-58) by 21 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details It is tough to imagine an Australian side of the old 3-0 down in a series after the dominant positions they got themselves into in the three preceding games. In failing to capitalise fully on a 231-run opening stand, they left themselves susceptible to a fourth such reversal, but better fielding than India and excellent bowling from their quicks made sure India's ODI juggernaut was halted at nine wins in a row, still their longest streak. David Warner scored a hundred in his 100th ODI, Aaron Finch biffed his way to 94 and to the top of the runs chart this series despite playing only two matches, but Australia managed just 102 runs in the last 15 overs, setting India 335. For a good part of the chase, India seemed on course to add to their record of five successful chases of 330 or more and Australia's unwanted record of eight unsuccessful defences of 330 or more, but their fielders and bowlers redeemed themselves on a damp outfield where it couldn't have been easy to grip the ball. The moment of magic came from the captain Steven Smith, who has so far had an ordinary series in the field, dropping two catches in Chennai and one in Indore.

Commentary_Highlights: Hardik to Warner, OUT Pandya's quick offcutter provides India with the breakthrough! Back of a length, skids in, then swerves away. A crease-bound Warner aims to punch it away through the covers, playing for the angle. Pandya beats the outside edge and hits the top of middle Chahal to Finch, SIX runs liberally tossed up outside off, breaks in, Finch sizes up the flight of the googly and launches it straight of long-on for a six Kuldeep to Finch, SIX runs a mis-timed six. Wanted to go over long-on or midwicket but the ball turns, takes the outside half and travels straight over the bowler for six. Just clears the boundary too Kuldeep to Finch, OUT taken at deep midwicket. Finch's belligerence ends. It's full and Finch sees an opportunity to hit it over midwicket, but Finch can't get underneath the length, which means his heave goes straight and flat to Jadhav at deep midwicket, who takes it awkwardly. A white towel falls off, and Finch thinks it's the ball. But has to walk off. Fine innings from Finch, has put Australia in command Kuldeep to Maxwell, 1 wide the seam-up delivery, took everyone by surprise but it's down leg. 90 kmph. Kuldeep to Smith, OUT easily taken at long-off. It's the googly outside off, Smith wanted to get closer to the ball and hit it straighter but the ball skews off the outside half and lobs to Bumrah at long-off. Looking into the sun is Bumrah, but he has his sunglasses on. Kuldeep has been a touch expensive, but has got two big wickets when they're trying to go after him. Kuldeep to Stoinis, SIX runs enough muscle behind that to clear long-off. A googly outside off, Stoinis got underneath it and swung cleanly over long-off. He may have read that well Bhuvneshwar to Stoinis, 1 wide full and too wide outside off, called. A few too many extras here Bumrah to Handscomb, OUT sensational catching from Pandey. A slower delivery outside off is hit nicely to long-off, it looks like six for the entirety of its trajectory until Pandey gets around to his right, takes a reverse-cupped catch, realises he was stepping over the boundary and threw it back up in the air. Then, he nonchalantly got back in and took the catch, no fuss, no trouble. Bhuvneshwar to Stoinis, 1 wide a wide knuckle ball outside off, well outside the tramline too, wide called Bumrah to Stoinis, 1 leg bye skiddy, 132 kph, full around leg, beats Stoinis' inside edge and hits him on the back leg Bumrah to Head, OUT goes straight through , 119 kph, it's a slower ball on middle and leg, the offcutter. Head plays with an angled bat, trying to find midwicket, but that means the ball has enough room to go through his flick and hit the stumps. Middle stump is uprooted. Australia losing their way Bumrah to Stoinis, 1 wide the wide slower delivery that is too wide. Called a wide 5.43pm Hello, again. Thanks, Nikhil. From 224 for 1, Australia had slumped to 275 for 6. The visitors managed only 38 in their last six overs to finish with a below-par 293 for 6. Will the pitch play better under lights as India's captain Virat Kohli suggested at the toss? India need 294 to wrap up the series. Rohit walks out to bat with Rahane. Cummins is armed with the new ball. He tears in from over the wicket with two slips to back him up Coulter-Nile to Rohit Sharma, 2 wide very full and veering down leg, beats the glance, beats the keeper too Coulter-Nile to Rahane, 1 leg bye skidding into the thigh, 142ks, Rahane misses the flick, as the ball kisses the pad and rolls to leg Cummins to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs 145ks bouncer outside off, Rohit picks the length early. Rocks back and crunnnnnches a pull over long leg. Sends the ball to the second tier. Whoa, what a shot!. He had scooped a similar rapid ball from Chameera for a six in Sri Lanka Coulter-Nile to Rahane, 1 leg bye leg-side ball, deflected down to long leg Coulter-Nile to Hardik, 1 leg bye short on off, Pandya misses a pull, the ball creeps underneath and hits him in the midriff. Ouch. A leg bye, more a groin bye Cummins to Hardik, 1 wide strays down leg for a wide. 140 kph 9.18pm Not many ODI chases have been as clinical and as convincing as that this year. Chasing 294, India got a fine start via fifties from Ajinkya Rahane and Rohit Sharma, and that was it really. Australia just did not have the depth or personnel to challenge India's strong batting thereon. India did stutter, but they now have nine wins on the bounce, consistency that has earned them the tag of the best team in the world in this format. Australia were well short, 350 may have been a par score but as soon as they India won by 5 wickets (with 13 balls remaining) Player of the match is Hardik Pandya, INDIA
Match_Report: India 294 for 5 (Pandya 78, Rohit 71, Rahane 70, Cummins 2-54) beat Australia 293 for 6 (Finch 124, Smith 63, Bumrah 2-52, Kuldeep 2-75) by five wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Between January 2013 and the start of this series, India-Australia ODIs had produced an average first-innings score of 321. The first two ODIs bucked that high-scoring trend, with India defending 281 and then 252, but a belter of a pitch in Indore seemed set to catalyse a return to the old order. Coming back from a calf injury, Aaron Finch scored his eighth ODI hundred and put on 154 for the second wicket with Steven Smith to project visions of 350 into Australia's minds. But thanks to their wristspinners, and then their two expert death bowlers, India kept them to 293 for 6, taking five wickets and only conceding 77 in the last 14 overs. Australia didn't get a sniff thereafter, as seventies of varying moods and tempos from Rohit Sharma and Ajinkya Rahane at the top of the order and Hardik Pandya at No.

Commentary_Highlights: Stoinis to Rahane, 1 wide the bowler doesn't help by bowling a length ball down leg, he dives low to collect it. Wide called. Rahane had an opportunity to tickle it fine Agar to Pandey, OUT goes through. Pandey has struggled against pace this series. That's not a good shot. Hurried for pace again, goes back and looks to cut a straight ball. There is a hint of turn too. Both his feet are in the air as he missed the cut. A nothing shot, an awful shot. The ball clips the top of off. Put himself under pressure with so many dot balls, when he felt he needed a scoring shot, he needed to play it off a good ball Stoinis to Jadhav, 1 bye Kohli steals a bye. Wade is in the wars. A slower delivery outside off, bounces in front of Wade and hits him somewhere near the groin. Wade can't move. Kohli realises that and gets one, sensational game awareness. The ball was by his feet Stoinis to Jadhav, SIX runs don't give him width. It's short, it's wide, it's an invitation and Jadhav accepts. He gets underneath the length intentionally and carves a cut over backward point for six Coulter-Nile to Jadhav, OUT and gone. Jadhav tries to get underneath and cut again but it was too full for that. He may have been better off trying to play that down, instead he brought his bat from down to up, which means the ball will only go up. The full length means there isn't enough elevation and Maxwell, at backward point, gobbles it up. Coulter-Nile to Kohli, OUT and chopped on! Kohli falls for 92. The ball has been seaming back in, Kohli chooses the wrong option of playing a dab down to third man, the ball takes the inside edge and hits the stumps. Maybe his first mistake of the day. Fantastic innings anyway Cummins to Kuldeep, OUT oh yes. Wade will feel a lot better now, mentally at least. Full and wide outside off, Kuldeep wafts with his weight firmly on the back foot. Gets a thick outside edge that flies towards Wade, who wanted to go with both hands, but improvised midway through knowing that he can't get there. So he stuck out his left hand, behind his back and hung on. One of the better catches you'll see Kane Richardson to Hardik, OUT smashed! But straight down to long-off. A slower full toss outside off, and intentionally bowled that wide outside off. Pandya hits it decently but not well enough. Finds Warner Ajinkya Rahane: We were looking to get 260-270, but 250 is decent. I knew if I take my time, I could play my shots. We wanted to disrupt their plans. We were looking to get 290, in between was not easy to rotate the strike, wicket was two paced. Really challenging conditions. 5.43pm This isn't exactly what India would have wanted, a score of 252. But this is not a batting surface, it's slow and two-paced. Australia will definitely take that, especially when Kohli and Rahane were going so well. But Kohli's wicket, after a typically fluent 92, slowed down India to the point where all they could aim for was close to 270. They fell short of that too. Australia, despite their batting struggles, will fancy their chances in this game. Shashank will be back with Bumrah to Cartwright, 1 leg bye late on the attempted flick, this length ball comes back in and hits him on the pad and deflects wide of Dhoni as they steal a leg-bye Bhuvneshwar to Cartwright, OUT this is almost like how he got Hafeez on his T20I debut. String of dot balls may have played on Cartwright's mind. This is a good length delivery just around off, Cartwright isn't sure if this one's going away or coming in. Pokes at the delivery without any conviction and sees the ball beat the inside edge and crash into the stumps. Bhuvneshwar's foot was very close to the line, but Cartwright has been told he can continue walking. Chahal to Maxwell, 1 wide tosses this up outside off to beat Maxwell in flight as he looks to slap this away. Harsh call from the umpire, who thought this was way outside off Chahal to Maxwell, OUT there's the magic ball. Dhoni isn't generally pumped up but boy, is he animated or what? Outstanding work by Chahal. Tossed it up but slowed it down nicely, he saw Maxwell charge down so lobbed this towards middle and leg, Maxwell, who senses he may not have gotten to the pitch of the ball, looks to turn this to the leg side, but the ball deflects off his right pad as the ball went between his legs, Dhoni collects it and smashes the stumps to leave Maxw Hardik to Stoinis, 1 wide full and very wide outside off, left alone, wide called Kuldeep to Stoinis, 1 wide drifts down leg for a wide Player of the match is Virat Kohli, INDIA
Match_Report: India 252 (Kohli 92, Rahane 55, Coulter-Nile 3-51, Richardson 3-55) beat Australia 202 (Stoinis 62*, Smith 59, Bhuvneshwar 3-9, Kuldeep 3-54) by 50 runs Live scorecard and ball-by-ball details New-ball swing; awkward, hit-the-deck seam; a pair of wristspinners turning their stock ball in opposite directions; a hustling, bustling, bouncer-happy allrounder. Seldom has an Indian ODI attack contained this much variety. Seldom has it all come together so spectacularly. During the innings break, India may have felt they could defend 252 on an Eden Gardens pitch that had been a little two-paced through their innings. They may have expected even more help for their bowlers under lights - it was one of the reasons Virat Kohli had cited for choosing to bat first.

Commentary_Highlights: Cummins to Rahane, 1 wide The direction is wrong from Cummins. He spears a back-of-a-length delivery down the leg side. Left alone Coulter-Nile to Pandey, OUT Is Pandey out nicking behind as well? Australia are sure they have their man and keep celebrating... but umpire Erasmus asks them to hold on. Was it a bump ball? He refers it to the TV umpire. Very, very full and swinging away so very late outside off, Pandey jams his bat down on the ground. The ball did not touch the ground, though Faulkner to Jadhav, (no ball) Jadhav races down the track, Faulkner drags his length back and cramps the batsman for room. He might have eked out an inside edge onto the pad. Faulkner's front foot is on the line - harsh call - no-ball Faulkner to Rohit Sharma, 1 leg bye good length, slight tail down leg side. Thuds him on the pad as he looks to flick Stoinis to Rohit Sharma, OUT holes out to deep square leg. An ordinary shot. Stoinis has been easily picked off with short bowling. But this one is 5 kph quicker than the last ball. Rohit goes for the hook, but the ball is way outside off. It's a regulation top edge and a regulation reverse-cup for Coulter-Nile. Umpires check for no-ball, but the crowd has already begun shouting Dhoni! Dhoni! Faulkner to Dhoni, OUT Dhoni forays down the track again... this time holes out to long-off. Faulkner's front foot is fine. Faulker pulled his length back, seeing Dhoni step out, on off stump. Dhoni gets it high on the bat and splices it to Warner for a head-high catch Hardik Pandya: It feels pretty amazing to be honest. They were on top, and the pressure was there. We lost wickets, and it was important for me to make a partnership with MSD. I mean, I have learnt a lot from him, still learning. We were speaking how we needs to change things up. It is a pleasure to play with him. I was trying to hit out before the Zampa over as well. Generally my plan is hitting straight - I don't care if long-off is there or long-on is there. If I connect well, I know 7:26pm You can scream the expletives on my behalf. There's some confusion. India are still on the field. For a moment, the groundsmen pause as they come on with the cover. The umpires ask them to stop. Then Kohli pesters them. Then Smith walks out and shrugs, aggressively. Then, the covers come on anyway. India are still on the field, though. 8:19pm India are out on the field. We're hearing of an 8:30pm resumption. The revised target will be 164 in 21 overs in that case. Hardik to Wade, 1 wide full cutter, floats down the leg side as Wade falls over a paddle sweep. Leg-side wide 10.15pm After Hardik Pandya and thala MS Dhoni thrilled the Chennai crowd and revived India to 281 for 7, rain cut Australia's chase to 164 in 21 overs. Bumrah sent Cartwright's off stump cartwheeling in his second over, then took an excellent catch to dismiss Smith. Warner flickered briefly as did Maxwell and Faulkner, but Australia were all at sea against India's wristspinners. Kuldeep and Chahal claimed combined figures of 9-0-63-5. Pandya, meanwhile, followed his career-best 83 with Player of the match is Hardik Pandya, INDIA
Match_Report: India 281 for 7 in 50 overs (Pandya 83, Dhoni 79, Coulter-Nile 3-44) beat Australia 137 for 9 in 21 overs (Maxwell 39, Chahal 3-30, Pandya 2-28) by 26 runs (DLS method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Hardik Pandya, who has one century and one five-for in professional cricket, continued to make mockery of conventional selection principles as he single-handedly won India the first ODI of the series. On a pitch with more bounce than an average Indian ODI surface, Pandya's sensational six-hitting combined with MS Dhoni's pragmatism to lift India from 87 for 5 to 281, but persistent drizzle converted the 282-run target into a theoretically-easier 164 in 21 overs. Pandya then introduced the world to his knuckle ball to send back Steven Smith and Travis Head. Smith had a rare shocker of a match, dropping two catches at slip, including Pandya, who went on to score 83 off 67 balls, and made Adam Zampa his fourth victim of three successive sixes in three months in international cricket. When Smith came out to bat, he looked to blast everything out of the ground, displaying uncharacteristic panic before failing to pick the knuckle ball and falling to an excellent catch by Jasprit Bumrah at short fine leg.

Commentary_Highlights: Andrew McGlashan will step in for the start of the chase. Southee to Stoinis, 1 wide length ball outside off, tight to the guide line and called wide! Southee is furious because Stoinis had set up outside off Southee to Stoinis, SIX runs launched over deep midwicket! Short slower ball sat in the surface, he was back waiting and he muscled it way back over deep midwicket! Neesham to Stoinis, SIX runs launched over long on! Finally nails a full toss! Low full toss on middle, he used the bottom hand to lift it over long on That concludes our coverage from Dunedin. A fantastic game of T20I cricket. New Zealand go 2-0 up in the series. The two teams will meet again in Wellington for game three next Wednesday. Thanks for your company today. Goodbye and stay safe. Player of the match is Martin Guptill, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 219 for 7 (Guptill 97, Williamson 53, Neesham 45*, Kane Richardson 3-43) beat < b=""> 215 for 8 (Stoinis 78, Philippe 45, Sams 41, Santner 4-31) by four runs <> New Zealand effectively won this game twice. For most of the day they dominated Australia with the bat and then the ball, to a point when the game looked to be heading for an early finish. Left in a hopeless position, Marcus Stoinis and Daniel Sams chanced their arms to close things up to a realistic scenario, only to lose their poise when the way to victory had re-opened, allowing Kane Williamson's men to hold their nerve in the tight finish that eventuated. New Zealand's momentum began with an overdue return to runs for Martin Guptill, swinging sweetly through the full ball as though on the golf course, with a pair of terrific supporting innings from Williamson and Jimmy Neesham - he and Guptill coshed no fewer than 14 sixes in Dunedin's first game between Australia and New Zealand since 2000. The Australia chase began fairly, stuttered and collapsed at the hands of Mitchell Santner, before getting the latest of revivals from Stoinis and Sams.

Commentary_Highlights: This is Australia's final chance to walk away from Indian shores with a series win from this tour. A victory tonight will keep their chances alive heading into the third and final match. Australia have written a new and the most comprehensive chapter yet on collapses. It has been the overriding theme of their tour, and sadly, with two matches remaining before they fly back, they are yet to find answers. Here's Alagappan Muthu's preview to set things up while we wait for the toss. Behrendorff to Rohit Sharma, OUT just like that, Barsapara has gone quiet. Not for long, though, as out comes the ever-popular Indian captain. Rohit pays for a lack of feet movement. Comes half-forward to this length ball that pitches around middle and off and beats him bu nipping in ever-so-slightly. Pings him plumb in front Behrendorff to Pandey, OUT oh, lovely delivery! Jason Behrendorff, you beauty! What a spell he's having! Short of good length, gets it to move away just enough and later still to find the outside edge of Pandey who is culpable of sticking his bat away from the body. Clear noise as he sent a nick through to Paine who holds on to a straightforward offering Behrendorff to S Dhawan, OUT that's a stunning catch from David Warner. Take a bow, skipper! He had to pedal back, and by no short distance, mind you. Falls over as he snaffles it having judged to perfection. Dhawan simply presented the full face of his bat to this fuller ball. He chips it over the in-field but it needed impeccable timing for the ball to carry all the way over the boundary. That's not to so, but this was always a 50-percent chance converted into a definite wicket by Warner's brilliance Zampa to Dhoni, 1 wide advances down and Zampa fires it wide of the batsman. Dhoni is equal to the task and manages to halt in his tracks and keep the backfoot planted. Had to really stretch there Zampa to Dhoni, OUT no cheeky work this time from Dhoni. He has been stumped clean and Zampa lets out a roar. Length ball, Dhoni advances again. It spins sharpy away from him and there is little the batsman can do from that position. Gets nowhere close to the ball and Paine completes a simple stumping Stoinis to Hardik, OUT straight into the hands of long-off. Pandya seemed like he could haul India to a decent total but he's gone now with 15 deliveries remaining. Tries to launch this fuller ball but it's just too full and that doesn't allow him the chance to get under it Zampa to Jadhav, OUT googly, and the stumps are a mess! Jadhav clears his front leg, seeing a loopy delivery in line with off stump. He shapes to launch it straight over Zampa's head, but the ball dips on him, it breaks the wrong way, and topples the stumps. Australia on the rise. On a massive rise. Coulter-Nile to Kuldeep, 1 wide short of a length, sprays it down the leg side and called a wide as the batsman misses the glance Tye to Kuldeep, OUT goes for a big slog and gets a top-edge that goes very high and Paine behind the stumps moves to his right and settles under it "It was unbelievable.Bowling four upfront doesn't happen too often and I was lucky to do it.Bowling upfront and swinging the new ball is a strength and it is an honour to be opening the bowling for your country. The wicket was good, it was a little slow. Worked really hard for a long time. My first experience was just one over, my second one here has been very good. I'm taking nothing for granted. I have full faith in our batsmen chasing this down." 8.45pm So India lose all their wickets. Jason Behrendorff set the template with his early burst and India never recovered. Australia exploited the early movement well and never let India to gather steam. This pitch still has something for the bowlers, so don't count India out yet. But remember that the dew has set in which will make India's job harder. Alagappan will be with you shortly for the chase. Over and out from me. Bhuvneshwar to Finch, 1 wide good length ball, darting down the leg side. Finch aims a flick, but can't connect. Would've been a great ball to Warner, who is at the other end, and who has been struggling against Bhuvi this tour That's all we have for you here from Guwahati, but there is plenty happening elsewhere in the world of sport. The Indian football team will have a chance to qualify for the AFC Asian Cup when they take on Macau tomorrow night. Head right over to ESPN.in to follow that, as well as the ongoing FIFA Under-17 World Cup Australia won by 8 wickets (with 27 balls remaining) Player of the match is Jason Behrendorff, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 122 for 2 (Henriques 62*, Head 47*) beat India 118 (Jadhav 27, Behrendroff 4-21, Zampa 2-19) by 8 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Like governments, Jason Behrendorff lured India with freebies up front before taxing them with four top-order wickets, a spell of play India never recovered from. Adam Zampa, who has not had the best of times on this trip, had his own back with two big middle-overs wickets to make sure Australia finally snapped their seven-match losing streak in T20Is against India. On a tacky pitch, with spin, seam and early swing on offer, India's batting seemed to fail to reassess what a good total was and fell 22 short of the 140-mark that might well have made for a tight chase. The way the match started, though, you might have thought of a score much higher than 140. The first ball was a gentle full toss that Rohit Sharma caressed to the point boundary; the third was a long half-volley that was crashed straight of mid-off.

Commentary_Highlights: Bhuvneshwar to Warner, OUT chops on! Bhuvi roars in delight. Warner looks up at the heavens with a wry smile Ranchi just bellows. This is a good length ball, but the batsman continues to play with a horizontal bat shot. And though he tries not to power the ball at all, the fact that he made that miscalculation results in the inside edge and a blaze of red behind him Bumrah to Maxwell, 1 wide short ball, sliding into the right-hander, Maxwell tries to pull it over fine leg, but doesn't connect. Umpire calls wide for the line straying down leg Chahal to Maxwell, OUT that's the fourth time in four games that Chahal has toppled Maxwell, but he hides his face in his hands and flashes an embarrassed little grin. He knows this ball didn't deserve a wicket. Rank long hop. Destined to be smoked. Instead Maxwell pulls it straight to short midwicket Chahal to Head, 1 leg bye pushes it through off the front of the hand, so the ball simply skids straight on. Head looks to flick it, but has to settle for a leg bye towards fine leg Kuldeep to Finch, OUT bowled im! This is splendid bowling from Kuldeep. He's assessed that Finch has decided it will be sweep or nothing tonight against spin and loads up for the shot again. But this ball is a too full. it's too close. It demands a straight bat but by the time the alarm bells ring in Finch's head, he sees red behind him. The other thing Kuldeep did well is bowl it quicker so Hardik to Head, OUT keeps low, or at least lower than Head thinks and he chops on. Back of a length ball, from around the wicket. Head keeps leg side of the ball to whip it through midwicket, but he doesn't account for the low bounce that the experts predicted to happen on this pitch. Bumrah to Paine, OUT through him! Bowls him! Completely destroys him! Paine is hunched over with his stumps in disarray. He eventually drags himself off, perhaps wondering how he was so comprehensively beaten. It was a straight ball, but it swings just a tiny bit in. Then after pitching, it lurched at his leg stump with a vengeance. That it kept a little low wouldn't have helped the batsman Bumrah to Coulter-Nile, OUT ripper! Ranchi roars in appreciation of the perfect Bumrah yorker. Starts on middle and off. Curls in through the air. And Coulter-Nile is certainly not expecting that. Tries to block the ball from its target, but that late swing is too much to handle Coulter-Nile to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs lifts it over the long leg boundary! It's fair that he was set up for the shot with Coulter-Nile bowling length and down leg. But the ease with which Rohit dismissed it. Sheesh. Zampa to Kohli, no run drives to extra cover. Now its six off six for India to win. Good come back after conceding a boundary first ball Much of this win was the result of Kuldeep Yadav and Jasprit Bumrah's bowling - 2 for 16 and 2 for 17 respectively. Kuldeep was especially impressive, countering Aaron Finch's premeditated plans of sweeping him by bowling the perfect ball - quicker, fuller and tighter on the stumps to bowl him - setting the stage for Bumrah to take two wickets in one over in the death 11.00 pm That's all we have from the game. Thanks for joining us. Good night. India won by 9 wickets (with 3 balls remaining) (D/L method) Player of the match is Kuldeep Yadav, INDIA
Match_Report: India 49 for 1 (Kohli 22*) beat Australia 118 for 8 (Finch 42, Kuldeep 2-16, Bumrah 2-17) by nine wickets via DLS method Australia's batsmen had a dire time coping with a slow and low surface at the JSCA International Stadium and never recovered from the early muddle, eventually conceding the first T20I by nine wickets to India. Rain came down after Australia had limped to 118 for 8 in 18.4 overs, and by the time it subsided, India's chase had been shortened to six overs. They mowed down the 48-run target with minimal fuss despite the loss of Rohit Sharma. It was a pitch that had everything a batsman does not desire to see in a T20 game - variable bounce, lack of pace, grip, turn, and early on some movement in the air.

Commentary_Highlights: Hardik to Finch, OUT mis-timed and gone. Australia's man in touch is gone. A full delivery outside off from Pandya, Finch tries to go over mid-off, the right ball to hit, but can only skew the ball off the outside half towards Bumrah at mid-off, who rusn to his left, takes the catch, but the ball pops out. The ball is rolling all over his legs like an insect, but Bumrah uses his feel, not his sight, to hold on somehow. Jadhav to Warner, 1 wide flat and quick, but far too wide outside off, wide Jadhav to Smith, 1 wide drifts down leg, Smith tries to paddle but doesn't make contact Jadhav to Smith, OUT gone! Jadhav does it again! A dangerous, dangerous shot, sweeping from the stumps - because of Jadhav's low arm, the ball follows a stump-to-stump trajectory right from the time it leaves his hand, when he's bowling from over the stumps. It's fairly flat, and it doesn't give him too much time to get down on one knee, and he's in a half-crouch when he swipes at it and misses, and he's struck absolute Jadhav to Stoinis, SIX runs down the track, and he's just cleared the leaping long-on fielder. Gets into a great position for the lofted drive, and hit it straight, so long-on had quite a distance to move to his left. Went a fair way over his head too Axar Patel to Head, OUT 94 kph, Head is gone. Premeditating the sweep, Axar is all too familiar with it. He fires it full and straight, Head tries to bail out of his sweep, but is in no position to improvise, the ball finds the gap, a big gap, between bat and pad and hits the stumps Bumrah to Stoinis, OUT given by umpire Erasmus. Stoinis reviews again. Umpire's call will decide this. Full on off, the ball has seamed back in prodigiously and struck Stoinis in front of off, beaten by discernible late lateral movement. No bat. Impact is umpire's call so Stoinis has to walk back. Fell over his stroke slightly Bumrah to Wade, OUT 135 kph, straight to the sweeper cover. Just five off that. A low full toss outside off, Wade gets underneath that but can only slice it away to the man on the sweeper boundary. Wade tried but that's a slightly under-par cameo Bhuvneshwar to Coulter-Nile, OUT misses a full, straight ball. 138 kph, full on off, Coulter-Nile winds up and looks to unfurl a big swing, but fails to connect at all. The off stump is uprooted 4.57pm Australia have continued to struggle in the end overs. All they could muster is 32 runs off the last six overs, substantially below par, even though this surface is slightly two-paced. It seemed, after the start, that Australia set themselves up for 300 again, but yet again, another absolute struggle towards the end overs. Pace off the ball, cutters, the quicker delivery, that's what Australia need, and hope that it can 5.40pm Hello again. In these conditions, 243 might not be an entirely straightforward target to chase, but do Australia have an attack that can exploit this slow, low and grippy pitch? Rohit Sharma and Ajinkya Rahane are out in the middle now, as are the Australian players. It's Pat Cummins to bowl the first over. Coulter-Nile to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs there it is. Finally a short ball gets up to a reasonable height, on or around off stump, and he pulls it away over midwicket and it carries all the way to bring up his 14th ODI hundred. This has been a superb innings in difficult conditions for someone who really relishes the ball coming on to the bat Faulkner to Kohli, 1 wide back of a length, angling down leg, Kohli can't connect with the flick. Faulkner's reviewed umpire Erasmus's not-out decision for caught behind. Interesting. The third umpire's checking for stumping as well. Is there a slight deflection? Can't really tell. Nothing on ultra-edge. And he hasn't lifted his back foot either 9.15pm That's it for this ODI series - this was a good Australian team that got into a lot of good positions, but it ends with India winning 4-1 and sitting on top of the ODI rankings. A lot of good cricket from a lot of players to get them there. The T20 series begins in Ranchi next Saturday. Until then, good night! India won by 7 wickets (with 43 balls remaining) Player of the match is Rohit Sharma, INDIA
Match_Report: India 243 for 3 (Rohit 125, Rahane 61) beat Australia 242 for 9 (Warner 53, Stoinis 46, Axar 3-38) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details India took back their No. 1 ODI ranking by shackling Australia after yet another good start and then chasing down the possibly tricky 243 with apparent ease. India won the series 4-1 - a reversal of the scoreline in the ODIs in Australia early last year - with just one century from their batsmen, that too in the last innings by Rohit Sharma, but a third successive hundred-run opening partnership between Rohit and Ajinkya Rahane. India won the final match on the dry and slow Nagpur track through spin. India's spinners pulled back a bolted horse, conceding 134 for 4 in 30 overs between them; Australia's Adam Zampa released all the pressure exerted by the quicks with the new ball, conceding 48 in six insipid overs before getting Rohit out with a long hop when the match was over for all practical purposes.

Commentary_Highlights: Trent Boult around the wicket That's it from Christchurch tonight. New Zealand far too good. The two teams meet again in Dunedin on Thursday. Hope you can join us then for game two. Goodbye and stay safe. Player of the match is Devon Conway, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 184 for 5 (Conway 99*, Phillips 30, J Richardson 2-31) beat Australia 131 (Marsh 45, Sodhi 4-28, Southee 2-10, Boult 2-22) by 53 runs New Zealand utterly humiliated Australia's BBL XI in the opening T20I on the 10th anniversary of the Christchurch earthquake, hammering the tourists by 53 runs at Hagley Oval, the biggest ever margin of victory for them over their rivals across the Tasman in the shortest format of the international game. Devon Conway was calmness and poise personified to maintain his outstanding start to representing New Zealand, compiling an unbeaten 99 to lift his side to 184 for 5 after the Australians had made the swifter start to claim three wickets inside the first four overs. Australia's early success gave way to rather more pedestrian bowling and fielding during the back half of the innings. Chasing at least 20 runs more than they should have been, Aaron Finch's team were never a chance after being left completely bereft by the swinging new ball in the hands of Tim Southee and Trent Boult. Together, they reduced the Australians to 19 for 4, leaving the wrist spinner Ish Sodhi with a mop-up operation that handed him his best figures in T20Is.

Commentary_Highlights: Nehra to Khawaja, OUT and Khawaja is gone. Lovely delivery from Nehra. Khawaja goes without facing a dot. It's the first time he might have got out for under fifty in a long long time. Nehra gets this length ball to hold its line, Khawaja's defensive push is not the greatest, and the outside edge carries to Dhoni. Just the right ball: not dri Bumrah to Watson, (no ball) FOUR runs Bumrah misses his length by six inches, and he has been punished. Low full toss, Watson makes room to drive it between mid-off and extra cover. He has overstepped again Ashwin to Marsh, OUT slower through the air, tempting Marsh, who pays for it. Looks for the big slog sweep, but the ball doesn't quite arrive. He is well early into the shot, and is bowled Yuvraj to Maxwell, OUT and Yuvraj has found a new bunny after KP. First ball Maxwell looks to will a shot over extra cover, but the thing with Yuvraj is, he gives you no pace to work with. Maxwell gets no power behind this shot, and finds the man at extra cover Hardik to Watson, 1 wide wide length ball, but unlike Lynn in game one, Watwon has the presence of mind to not go chasing Yuvraj to Head, SIX runs short square boundary on the leg side, and Head has slog-swept a length ball for six over straight midwicket Hardik to Watson, 1 wide too wide, and this Watson doesn't go for it. He will have to rebowl it Hardik to Watson, 1 wide another big wide outside off. Perhaps a change of plan? Jadeja to Watson, SIX runs low full toss and with a short leg-side boundary for Watson. That is asking to be hit. He has slog-swept this for a six Jadeja to Head, OUT fires in a yorker at 102ks, and squeezes it under Head's bat to knock the middle stump over. Some solace for Jadeja after he was put on a hiding to nothing bowling to a set Watson with the short leg-side boundary Bumrah to Lynn, 1 leg bye quick, into the pads, nearly a yorker, goes just for the leg-bye Bumrah to Lynn, OUT lovely bowling by Bumrah and a lovely catch by Jadeja. Follows Lynn with a full ball as Lynn back away. Lynn manages to scoop it towards cow corner, but Jadeja makes a lot of ground to his right from deep midwicket and takes this with a dive Tait to Rohit Sharma, 1 wide and there is the bad Tait. Wide down the leg side Tait to Rohit Sharma, 1 wide nudges 150ks, but bowls a leg-side wide at 149ks Tait to S Dhawan, 1 wide another wide down the leg side. Looks to cramp him up with a short ball, but goes too far down leg Tait to S Dhawan, SIX runs this is carnage. Gentle length ball on the pads, whipped away for a six Boland to Kohli, 1 wide that is unlucky. Short slower offcutter, but it turns too much from outside off to be called a wide down leg Boyce to Kohli, OUT Kohli is bowled in a roundabout way. Boyce has kept Australia in the contest. This has been a good contest between him and Kohli. Kohli has been charging at Boyce who has still been managing to york him with some dip on his deliveries. This one takes the cue end, hits the pad, ricochets into the stumps Watson to Raina, 1 wide slower bouncer, Raina doesn't play at it, and it is called wide for height. Fairly so. This is well high Surely there are thousands of Twitter jokes about Yuvraj being deleted furiously right now? But boy did he dig himself a hole here? The wheel turned with two gentle length balls at the start of the last over, but to hit them clean out of the crews under such pressure... India have moved from No. 8 at the start of this series to No. 1 after this whi That is the end of a hectic Indian tour of Australia. Those bowlers can rest a bit now. Batsmen have got flat pitches and good bats, but they deserve some of the credit for their ruthlessness too. It was good fun bringing it to you. Cricinfo bids goodbye now India won by 7 wickets Player of the match is Shane Watson, AUS
Match_Report: India 3 for 200 (Rohit 52, Kohli 50, Raina 49*) beat Australia 5 for 197 (Watson 124*) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details A thrilling chase and a cruel missed chance saw India seal a Twenty20 series sweep over Australia at the SCG, as the more settled side was victorious once again. Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli laid the groundwork for India's pursuit before Suresh Raina was able to finish things off with the help of Yuvraj Singh, who looked out of touch before finding his timing at precisely the right moment as the pair took 19 off Andrew Tye's final over of the innings to finish off the win. Victory also lifted India to No.1 in the ICC T20 rankings; they were eighth before the series began. Raina was fortunate to be there, having escaped a stumping chance second ball.

Commentary_Highlights: 7.10pm Aaron Finch has won the toss, and has decided to bowl. He says if there is going to be any help in the pitch, it is going to be up front. Apart from the three debutants, John Hastings and Glenn Maxwell come in for Australia. Shaun Tait is out Maxwell to S Dhawan, OUT first wicket for Australia. Dhawan tries the reverse-sweep, a shot that is on because the point and third man are inside the circle, but Dhawan has found the man at point. Still doesn't have a fifty in T20 internationals, but a good start for India Tye to Rohit Sharma, 1 leg bye short of a length, outside off, looking to work this to leg, is beaten and hit on the pad. He is outside the line of off Boland to Kohli, SIX runs that is a mis-hit that has cleared long-off comfortably. A mix of the short straight boundary and quality of bats. Kohli has withdrawn from the stumps and toe-ended this length ball for a six over long-off Ashwin to Marsh, 1 wide wide, too far wide outside off Hardik to Watson, 1 wide short, down the leg side, beats the pull, but will be called a wide Jadeja to Watson, OUT if Yadav's fielding last ball was good, this is nothing short of sensational. Watson has absolutely drilled this right back at the umpire's head. All eyes on the ducking umpire and the boundary but Jadeja gets both his hands in the air and takes this fuss free. It takes a brave man and an excellent fielder. Jadeja is both. Watson is impressed with Jadeja's effort. He is bemused but he is impr Bumrah to Tye, 1 wide tries the short-ball variation... wide down the leg side That's bring an end to what we had to offer for tonight. India men and women have both won their T20 series 2-0. Congratulations India. Thanks for joining us Player of the match is Virat Kohli, INDIA
Match_Report: India 3 for 184 (Rohit 60, Kohli 59) beat Australia 8 for 157 (Finch 74, Jadeja 2-32, Bumrah 2-37) by 27 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details 5:00 Agarkar: India's top three the best in T20 cricket India's first series victory of any kind in Australia since the summer of Monkeygate is proving an unmitigated disaster for the hosts, who now face real uncertainty over their captaincy. Aaron Finch twanged a hamstring as his side fell apart under the pressure of a chase for the second time in as many matches. The game evolved in a near action replay of the opening match in Adelaide, as Australia were unable to capitalise on a strong start by Finch and Shaun Marsh in pursuit of a strong Indian total built upon the batting of Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli. Steven Smith and David Warner are set to fly to New Zealand on Saturday, leaving a considerable leadership vacuum should Finch be unfit for the third T20 in Sydney on Sunday. His likely absence may at least mean an opportunity for Usman Khawaja, the outstanding batsman of the summer so far.

Commentary_Highlights: Tait to Rohit Sharma, 1 wide full and wide at 148ks, Sharma's drive is beaten by the outswing Tait to Rohit Sharma, 1 wide short and wide, very wide, called a wide Watson to Rohit Sharma, OUT Welcome back Watto. He is celebrating again. He got a big wicket for Sydney Thunder in the BBL final not long ago, and he has got the big one. Sharma, who had nine lives, doesn't get another. The slower offcutter has been driven straight down the lap of mid-on Tait to Kohli, 1 wide line goes wrong again. Wide down the leg side Boyce to Kohli, SIX runs Kohli is not quite to pitch f this legbreak, he has not got this clean out of the screws, but he has backed his bat to send this over long-off. It just about evades that fielder Watson to Raina, 1 wide slower bouncer, 123ks, called wide for height. Has to be touch and go on that Faulkner to Raina, SIX runs Raina targets the short square boundary, and he has absolutely smashed this. Slower ball, on a length, and he has slogged this right out of the screws Tait to Raina, 1 wide Raina moves inside the line anticipating the bouncer. Tait bowls one but well down the leg side Tait to Raina, 1 wide Raina moves inside the line again, Tait bounces him down the leg side. Another wide Faulkner to Raina, OUT Raina moves too far across and is bowled by a straight full toss. He has premeditated the ramp, but as he is bringing his bat across it hits the ground and gets a bit stuck there. Too late on the ball then Nehra to Finch, 1 leg bye appeal for lbw but this is pitched outside leg and beats Finch's attempt to work it to leg Bumrah to Warner, OUT Bumrah has the wicket. He has clearly looked like India's most impressive bowler. Just difficult to read his pace with that unorthodox action. Warner sees a short ball, looks for the pull, but it hurries on to him, and he drags it from outside off and is caught at mid Hardik to Smith, 1 wide starts with a wide down the leg side Hardik to Finch, 1 wide wide down the leg side again. Short of a length and headed down. Bowled at 136ks Ashwin to Finch, OUT the umpire didn't get to watch the previous delivery so Finch gives him an action replay sans the inside edge. He moves well across the stumps to try to sweep an offbreak, and is beaten again. Pitches within, straightens to hit middle. Dead plumb. Not so sure about the Jadeja to Head, OUT Jadeja has got another wicket. India have Australia where they want them. Like rabbits in headlights against spin. Head has not got a loose ball so far and tries to manufacture a sweep. Misses. Looks pretty dead. The umpire has no hesitation. Replays show impact is out Ashwin to Watson, OUT Nehra takes the nervous catch. India must think they are home and dry. Watson, under pressure, goes for the big sweep, and Ashwin's bounce takes the top edge. It is a skier, and Nehra somehow manages to never look comfortable under those. At short fine leg, he makes Hardik to Lynn, OUT Pandya has his wicket. The wide line has worked. This is another wide he has ruined. Second time in this over he has gone and played a delivery that would have been called a wide. The last time he nearly got caught at deep cover, this time he finds extra cover. Yuvraj So that brings an end to our coverage of the first Twenty20 international of the series. India's women and men both won on their Republic Day. We will be back again with the second game on Friday Player of the match is Virat Kohli, INDIA
Match_Report: The maiden over Maiden as in first. Definitely not as in free of runs. Debutant Hardik Pandya was waiting for his first over, and then he was waiting for his first over to end. The eighth of India's innings and the first of Pandya's career began with three consecutive wides down leg side as Steven Smith walked inside the line, and two more followed later in the over. It meant the over lasted 11 deliveries, and given that a six and a four came off two of the legal balls, he finished with figures of 1-0-19-0 and five wides.

Commentary_Highlights: R Dhawan to Marsh, 3 wide starts the spell with a full ball slanted down leg. Misses the flick and Dhoni can't collect, the ball deflects away into the fine leg region Sharma to Warner, OUT gone! That was the slower ball, back of a length on off stump, and Warner backs away to manufacture room to cut. No pace on it, and the sliced uppercut drops towards backward point, where Jadeja takes a simple catch while falling to his right Bumrah to Marsh, SIX runs short, angling into off stump, and Marsh absolutely loves it there. Plants his front foot forward and pulls fiercely over the midwicket boundary Bumrah to Wade, 1 leg bye sees him coming down the pitch and follows with a full ball at his feet. Jams down and can't get bat to it, but it hits his foot and rolls away to the right of the keeper Yadav to Wade, OUT got him. That's a fullish ball slanting away wide of off stump. Wade looked to thrash his arms through it, having taken a big step back to shorten the length, and only succeeds in top-edging to Dhoni Bumrah to Faulkner, OUT oh, Bumrah, what a delivery. Takes out Faulkner's off stump with a perfect yorker that the batsman plays all around Hastings to Rohit Sharma, OUT back of a length outside off, a bit of extra bounce, and Rohit goes for 99! It hurried through quicker than he expected, perhaps, as he looked to dab it towards third man, and he looks distraught when the caught behind appeal is upheld. Snicko shows the faintest of nicks, though. Faulkner to Dhoni, 1 leg bye in the blockhole and Dhoni misses the flick. Hits him low on the pad, and ricochets into the off side. Huge appeal, but it isn't given. Pitched maybe just outside leg. Marginal Marsh to Pandey, 1 wide takes guard on off stump this time and Marsh looks to bowl it even wider, full and wide. This time it's adjudged wide as Pandey reaches out and fails to connect Faulkner to Dhoni, 1 leg bye full, down the leg side. Dhoni misses the flick and it deflects off the pad to the diving Wade, who appeals for caught behind. Good early call from Pandey to sneak a leg bye Faulkner to Dhoni, 1 leg bye sees him making room and follows him. Slogs at it, misses, and it ricochets off the pad into the off side 10.12pm This is the first successful 300-plus chase against Australia in Australia. India will feel they should have crossed off that achievement in the previous game itself, but they've done it here, and they've done it with six wickets in hand.
