Wade pulls off a pretty good take there Watson to de Kock, 1 wide banged in short, a little too short to elicit a shot from the batsman Cummins to Rossouw, 1 wide goes short and it's got a little too much height on it, conveys the square leg umpire to the one at the bowler's end Cummins to Rossouw, OUT and Rossouw cannot capitalise! It was back of a length and outside off, he was looking to baseball-whack it into the leg side. Gets it off the bottom of the blade to present a simple catch to mid-on. One of the first false strokes he has played today, was it because of the powerplay? Cummins to du Plessis, OUT first ball after the break and Faf's gone! It was a slower ball just outside off length, Faf pushed the ball back, but played early and had to check it in the end, the ball went slow and lobbed towards mid off where Bailey had to dive low and in front to his right for a good catch Starc to de Kock, 1 wide but neither are in business as Starc slides a length ball down the leg side Smith to Miller, OUT down the throat of deep fine leg! He's out off a full toss, would you believe it? Goes into a sweep way too early, gets a top edge that is easily pouched by Cummins. South Africa are slipping now, that powerplay has thrown their innings out of balance Cummins to Parnell, 1 wide goes over the top with a bouncer and the ump calls it a wide Faulkner to Parnell, 1 leg bye another slower ball, fuller on middle and leg. Parnell had to check his shot after looking to flick too early. Single towards midwicket Starc to Behardien, SIX runs What. A. Shot! AB would struggle to match that as he backs away and lifts a length ball cramping him for room and lift it nonchalantly over extra cover. Very classy! Faulkner to Behardien, SIX runs heeeeeave, and it clatters into the crowd behind midwicket. Slower ball first up and Behardien went deep in the crease and clobbered it Faulkner to Behardien, OUT length and Behardien goes for the hoick again! He had nailed it, but Steven Smith skirts the rope and picks up a lovely catch to his left and over his shoulders. Top innings, this. The kind that will decide a match Parnell to Watson, SIX runs drags the ball short and Watson is all over it. Swivels on his back foot and unleashes the lot of his power. What did that ball ever do to him? Pulled off the front foot, even as he only needed to shift his balance back McLaren to Watson, 1 wide goes short and slides down leg, looks to pull but can't connect Morkel to Smith, 1 wide banged in short and slips away too far outside off. Smith looks to cut, but can't reach it Australia won by 2 wickets (with 5 balls remaining) (D/L method) Player of the match is Quinton de Kock, SA
Match_Report: Australia 8 for 275 (Watson 82, Finch 76, Smith 67, Peterson 4-32) beat South Africa 6 for 280 (De Kock 107, Behardien 63, Rossouw 51, Cummins 3-54) by 2 wickets (D/L method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Quinton de Kock's sixth ODI ton featured 14 fours Getty Images Australia will enter the World Cup year ranked as the game's top ODI team and with the likes of Steve Smith, Aaron Finch and Shane Watson all running into ominous form, following a fourth victory in five matches over a sloppy South Africa at the SCG. The hosts had more to play for in this fixture than the visitors, and it showed during their chase of 275, reduced from 281 by the second of two brief showers for the day. Finch, Watson and Smith all struck the ball cleanly, though the latter's sublime run of scores was maintained partly by some ordinary work in the field by a South African side missing AB de Villiers and Dale Steyn. Morne Morkel's confidence ebbed away, as epitomised by a dreadful misfield to concede a boundary to Smith, who was also bowled off a Kyle Abbott no-ball and edged Morkel behind though the South Africans did not deign to appeal. Finch and Watson gave less chances, both working their way into decent touch after slow starts to the summer.

Commentary_Highlights: Maxwell to de Kock, OUT Maxwell strikes! It's a good ball, tossed up and angled in towards off stump. He looked to play it towards mid-on, with the angle, but didn't get to the pitch and closed his face too early. Leading edge pops back to Maxwell for the simplest of c&bs. Cummins to de Villiers, 1 wide bouncer outside off. AB simply stands there and lets it go through to the keeper. Bounced comfortably over head height Cummins to du Plessis, OUT gone! That was a good ball, rising uncomfortably from back of a length outside off, and he pokes at it while hopping across and gets an outside edge through to the keeper Faulkner to de Villiers, 1 leg bye down the leg side and AB can't quite connect with the glance. Off his pad towards square leg Starc to Behardien, 1 leg bye looks for the yorker, and Behardien looks to flick. Can't connect, gets a bit of foot on to it through to the keeper Starc to McLaren, OUT got him! That was the slower bouncer again, and he was caught between trying to pull and trying to avoid the ball. Ended up getting a thin edge that looped into Wade's gloves Faulkner to Peterson, OUT gone! That was the slower ball, full and straight, and Peterson looked to slog it across the line, over the leg side. He was through his shot too quickly and the ball sneaked through and crashed into middle stump 6.35pm Here we go again. Australia need 268 to seal the series win. Aaron Finch and David Warner stride out with that aim in their heads, and Dale Steyn is hell bent on preventing them from getting off to a good start. Parnell to Smith, 1 wide down the leg side now and Smith politely moves his bat and body out of the way McLaren to Maxwell, 1 leg bye full, angling down the leg side, and he can't connect with the flick, gets a leg bye down to square leg Behardien to Wade, 1 wide looks to go fuller, ends up sliding down the leg side McLaren to Smith, 1 wide full-toss wide outside off, and that nearly ran away for four wides. De Kock must have stretched a couple of muscles to breaking point in diving across to his right to stop that Steyn to Faulkner, 1 bye shortish slower ball outside off and he plays and misses. de Kock misjudges the bounce behind the stumps and they sneak a quick bye. Steyn, needless to say, is livid 10.35pm Short and sweet presentation ceremony there. No interviews with the captains and so forth. Just how it should be, methinks, but I'd say that, having been typing all this while and being grateful to avoid any more transcribing and whatnot. So that brings an end to our coverage as well. Australia have taken the series 3-1, and South Africa have a lot of Australia won by 3 wickets (with 6 balls remaining) Player of the match is Steven Smith, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 7 for 268 (Smith 104, Wade 52) beat South Africa 8 for 267 (de Villiers 91) by 3 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details 1:09 Steven Smith seals series for Australia Steven Smith started this series in form but out of the side. Matthew Wade started it out of form but in the side. Together, they set up a series victory by plotting one of Australia's most remarkable one-day international chases, in front of one of the MCG's most remarkably small international crowds. Smith's 104 was reminiscent of Michael Bevan's heroics at the SCG on New Year's Day 1996, delivering victory from a position where defeat seemed inevitable. Smith and Wade came together with Australia's score at 5 for 98 in pursuit of 268.

Commentary_Highlights: Morkel to Warner, SIX runs that's high in the air, has he timed it well enough, he has and it's gone for six! Fullish outside the off stump, he got under it and lofted it over long off for six Philander to Finch, SIX runs too short, that's another six from Finch! He spotted the short ball outside off, rocked back and smacked it with a pull over deep square leg Philander to Finch, (no ball) back of length outside off, pulled to midwicket and that's another no ball Philander to Warner, OUT taken at midwicket! It was a length delivery on middle and off, Warner slogged it without much footwork and AB at midwicket had to jump a bit to take the flat catch Steyn to Watson, 1 wide slides it down the leg side for a wide de Villiers to Watson, SIX runs too short this time and Watson pulls it for six! Watson had enough time to see the length and crash it wide of deep midwicket Behardien to Watson, OUT he's got Watson again! Behardien pitched it slightly shorter outside off, Watson slogged on the leg side but didn't get enough of it and long on went to his right to take the skier Morkel to Marsh, OUT he's played the wrong line and lofted it high for an easy catch to AB at long off! It was angled in a bit towards middle and leg, but he lofted it inside out, very high and AB took it with rather ease de Villiers to Finch, OUT AB's got the big wicket of Finch! Regular length delivery on the off stump, Finch went for a wild slog on the leg side and missed it completely. The ball crashed in to off and middle stumps Steven Smith: The wicket slow down in the end and the ball became softer. I tried to get a few boundaries and managed to get a few away. The start we got was perfect and the openers set the foundation for a good score. Kane Richardson to du Plessis, 1 leg bye another lbw appeal, the umpire says no again! It came in sharply from outside off, Faf went back and on his toes and the ball was mising leg for sure Kane Richardson to de Villiers, OUT that's a loud appeal for lbw, umpire says it's out and AB reviews it! Bowden says there's nothing on Hot Spot, it's hitting him in line and is hitting the stumps too, AB has to go. AB had moved across a long way to the off side to slog the deli Hazlewood to Behardien, 1 leg bye angled in towards the pads, tucked to backward square leg for one Starc to Miller, OUT inswinging yorker does it, the finger goes up! Miller was struck on the crease as the yorker dipped and swung in, hit him on the front shoe in front of leg stump, was it going down leg? The umpire says it's out and Miller has a few words with the huddle that' Hazlewood to Philander, 1 wide bangs in the bouncer outside off and it's too short, called a wide Starc to Behardien, 1 leg bye shuffles across to the off side to scoop the ball behind square on leg and gets an inside edge on the pads. Umpire says it's a leg bye Player of the match is Steven Smith, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 5 for 329 (Finch 109, Smith 73*, Warner 53) beat South Africa 256 (Amla 102, de Villiers 52, Starc 4-32, Hazlewood 3-51) by 73 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details 0:47 Finch steers Australia to 2-1 lead Centurion Aaron Finch, Steven Smith, Josh Hazlewood and Mitchell Starc were central figures in Australia's commanding 73-run victory over South Africa in Canberra, despite a pair of sparkling innings by Hashim Amla and AB de Villiers. In front of a crowd of 10,583 at Manuka Oval, Finch set the platform and Smith capitalised fully upon it against a South African bowling attack that found less assistance than they enjoyed in Perth but also did not help their cause with a quartet of no-balls. Dale Steyn was the lone exemplar of parsimony for the visitors, but even his 10 overs ultimately yielded 53 runs, and he was unable to take the wickets he had yearned for when describing a new attack role for himself on match eve. Aaron Finch and David Warner added 118 for the opening wicket Getty Images A target of 330 was always going to be difficult for the visitors given Australia's selection of a deep and varied bowling attack that in Starc and Hazlewood had relevant experience of Canberra climes. Hazlewood and Starc both bowled piercingly with the old ball, the latter gaining sharp reverse swing to bring a swift conclusion to the match.

Commentary_Highlights: Behardien to Watson, OUT well, well, the part-timer has taken out Shane Watson, and he is not reviewing, Behardien angles it in on a length, it moves in late a bit too, Watson's bat has to come around that big front foot, it cannot do so quickly enough, and he is given straight away, tracker says that is hitting middle and leg near the top Morkel to Bailey, 1 leg bye this climbs in to him, he walks across, and fends it off one hand down to fine leg Morkel to Smith, OUT that is probably not the best stroke to play at this stage, Morkel bangs it in short of a length, Smith tries to force a pull, and Tahir takes the steepling top edge after moving to his left from mid on, mid off was around too, but Tahir hung on in the end, wasn't really the length for the pull Behardien to Marsh, 1 leg bye angled into the pad, rolls to backward square leg Behardien to Marsh, 1 leg bye moving into the pad again, and worked behind square Philander to Wade, 1 leg bye full and outside leg, clipped off the pads to fine leg Morkel to Wade, OUT Keeper and bowler are convinced about the caught behind, umpire isnt, de Kock is pushing for the review immediately, and South Africa are doing that, Wade on the hop to a short of a length ball into the ribcage, it has brushed his shirt, third umpire says that is close to the glove, and wants to look at HotSpot, there is Morkel to Johnson, OUT five for Morkel, and he jumps in celebration, Johnson stuck on the crease to one that leaves him with the angle close to off, and nicks it through to the keeper Steyn to Coulter-Nile, OUT nine down, Faf in business at mid on again, a length ball around middle and off, Coulter-Nile whips it for a tumbling Faf to take his second catch, not easy to pull off these shots with the pace and bounce in the pitch Philander to Bailey, OUT Philander strikes immediately on comeback, and that is a fine catch by Faf, another one falls to the pull, Bailey wasn't on top of the stroke as he hit it off the front foot low to Faf at mid on, and he went down to pouch it Tahir to Marsh, SIX runs he connects big this time, fetches this full and wide one and slogs it over the long on boundary Steyn to Marsh, OUT it is hard to clear Morne Morkel wherever he is, he is at short fine leg, this is a slower one into the pad, and Marsh has flicked it for Morkel to take it over his head Five wickets and two catches for Morne Morkel, who has demolished Australia for 154 on a fast and bouncy WACA pitch. From the moment he had Warner hopping in his first over, Morkel has been difficult to play. South Africa were a bowler short, but Behardien took out Watson and bowled eight decent overs. Morkel returned to crush Australia with three 3.35pm Out come Hashim Amla and Quinton de Kock to chase 155. And here's Mitchell Johnson with two regular slips and a fly slip Coulter-Nile to Rossouw, 1 wide flies outside leg stump as he bangs it in short again Maxwell to de Villiers, 5 wide turn and bounce, but down the leg side, and goes between keeper and leg slip Maxwell to de Villiers, 1 wide bounces and spins down the leg side Johnson to Miller, 1 wide Johnson pings in a bouncer, Miller lets it pass over Johnson to Miller, 5 wide Johnson digs in the bouncer too short with plenty of effort, and it flies over Wade's who only gets some glove on it as he jumps Johnson to Miller, 1 wide another bouncer, Miller sways inside the line, it is called a no-ball as Johnson has bowled one too many for the over That is all from this game. Good bye South Africa won by 3 wickets (with 134 balls remaining) Player of the match is Morne Morkel, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 7 for 157 (de Villiers 48, Hazlewood 5-31) beat Australia 154 (Marsh 67, Morkel 5-21, Steyn 3-35) by 3 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Morne Morkel took a career-best 5 for 21 Getty Images Morne Morkel wreaked havoc and together with AB de Villiers, wrecked Australia's chances of taking a 2-0 series lead in the second ODI at the WACA. Morkel's career-best 5 for 21 helped to skittle Australia for 154, a total that was barely half of what they made in the first game on Friday and showed how fortunate they were that South Africa dropped so many chances on that occasion. A brisk 48 from 41 scored by de Villiers confirmed the result. The chase was not entirely straightforward for South Africa, who were 2 for 21 after losing both openers early, and wobbled towards the end as Josh Hazlewood completed his first five-wicket haul in ODI cricket. But Hazlewood's efforts were offset by a leaky display from Nathan Coulter-Nile, whose six overs cost 54, and South Africa reached their target with three wickets in hand and 22.

Commentary_Highlights: Philander to Finch, 1 leg bye appeal for lbw, the length delivery seamed in from outside off and hit Finch above the knee roll in front of the stumps and he was a step outside the crease too. HawkEye says that was going over Tahir to Warner, SIX runs too full, Warner goes down on a knee and slog-sweeps it for a massive six to the cow corner boundary. He was playing it with the turn and absolutely middled it Philander to Warner, OUT that's a great catch in the deep from McLaren and the stand is broken! Warner pulled the short ball in the air again, McLaren ran to his left from square leg but the ball was dipping on him and he made sure he swooped down with a dive to get his hands under the ball comfortably to complete the catch Philander to Finch, OUT oh another, Philander gets Finch too! He moved the delivery away from Finch from outside off, the batsman pushed at it away from the body and the ball did enough to take an edge for an easy catch for de Kock Steyn to Clarke, OUT there you go - Steyn gets Clarke's wicket! Steyn banged in a short ball around off, Clarke took a step towards off and pulled but didn't time it properly and the ball ballooned off the glove towards de Kock. You won't see an easier catch than that Steyn to Bailey, 4 leg byes what a delivery to welcome a new batsman! Nast short delivery angled towards Bailey's head, he sways out of the line a bit, then takes his eyes off the ball and it deflects off the back for four over the keeper Tahir to Watson, OUT a catch has been taken - finally! Watson swept the full delivery on the pads to short fine leg and Morkel did well to get low and get his hands under the ball just in time Philander to Marsh, OUT that's gone through, what a delivery from Philander! It pitched outside off and seamed in a bit, Marsh looked to guide it on the off side but left a big gap between bat and pad and the ball sneaked through that to make the bails fly! Steyn to Wade, 1 wide strays down the leg side for a wide Morkel to Bailey, 1 leg bye towards te leg side and it goes off the pad towards square leg for one McLaren to Bailey, 1 wide this slower delivery goes down the leg side as Bailey looked to pull. Wide called for the width now Morkel to Maxwell, OUT it's full this time and it's worked, taken at mid-off! Maxwell made room, got it full and wanted to clear mid-off with a lofted drive but Faf did well to dive forward and to his left for a good low catch. They are checking with the third umpire if it was taken cleanly, it has. And a part of Morkel's heel was marginally inside the crease or it Philander to Wade, OUT outside the off stump, Wade makes room to slice the ball from outside off but finds a fielder in the deep, as Rossow ran in from sweeper cover. He's a sub for Behardien Philander to Johnson, 1 wide full and swinging down leg for a wide Morkel to Johnson, 1 leg bye full and outside off, tapped a bit wide of de Kock for another Morkel to Coulter-Nile, 1 wide too short and wide outside off, called a wide Johnson to du Plessis, 1 bye wider outside off, it's left alone. But they sneak in a bye after Wade fumbles Marsh to de Villiers, 1 wide strays down the leg side past the batsman with a wide Johnson to Miller, 1 wide starts with a bouncer that is too high, and is called a wide Coulter-Nile to Miller, OUT the bowling change as done it, Miller is gone and this strong stand is broken! the length delivery was angled in towards the pads, Miller looked to flick it towards cow corner but played the shot early and even though he looked towards wide long on, the ball went straight to mid on. Marsh takes a few steps back to complete the catch and Johnson to Morkel, 1 wide sends in a short ball down the leg side, it's a wide Johnson to Morkel, 1 wide short ball down the leg side for a wide, good take by Wade down leg Johnson to Morkel, 1 wide another attempted yorker goes down leg for a wide Player of the match is Nathan Coulter-Nile, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 8 for 300 (Bailey 70, Philander 4-45) beat South Africa 268 (de Villiers 80, Miller 65, Coulter-Nile 4-48) by 32 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details 0:55 George Bailey rebuilt Australia's innings with 70 from 75 balls Getty Images It was a tale of three captains at the WACA, where Michael Clarke was injured while batting, his deputy-cum-replacement George Bailey rebuilt Australia's innings, and their South African counterpart AB de Villiers threatened to pull off a record chase. Ultimately the difference was in the fortunes of Bailey and de Villiers: Bailey was dropped four times on his way to 70; de Villiers made a chanceless 80, then was run out in a mix-up with a tail-ender. The loss of de Villiers ended any hope South Africa had of overtaking Australia's 8 for 300. Never before had a team made that many to win a one-day international at the WACA, and in the end South Africa didn't get especially close. A 46-run last-wicket stand could not disguise the lower-order collapse - the previous five wickets fell for 20 runs - and South Africa were dismissed for 268, giving Australia a 32-run win and a 1-0 lead.

Commentary_Highlights: 7.05pm: Australia have won the toss and will field, they have made one change to their side: Nic Maddinson coming in for Nathan Reardon. South Africa have shaken things up after being hammered in Melbourne, with David Wiese, Robbie Peterson and Marchant de Lange all coming into the XI. Cummins to de Kock, OUT got him, Cummins makes the breakthrough with a fast short ball! Banged in, little bit of cut on the ball and de Kock was hurried trying to pull, just a tickle of glove and it's safely pouched by Dunk Boyce to Rossouw, OUT tossed up, Rossouw charges... and picks out long-on! Success for Boyce, he keeps tossing it up, Rossouw was trying to clear the short, straight boundary - the ball was a little wide, he wasn't to the pitch and dragged it straight to the fielder Bollinger to Hendricks, OUT Dougie does it, Hendricks drags on! The ball was short and there to pull but maybe Bollinger had rolled his fingers over it, the batsman misjudged the stroke, bottom-edged the ball on to his body and then down to shiver leg stump. Falls just short of the fifty mark, like his opening partner Faulkner to Behardien, OUT shortish and taken on... only to pick out deep midwicket! Behardien's brief, painful sally is brought to a close, slogging across the line but never had to the distance to that part of the ground Cummins to Duminy, 1 bye another slower-ball bumper, down the leg side - maybe lucky not to be a wide - Duminy swings and misses but the low bounce foxes Dunk and they take a bye Faulkner to Duminy, OUT tries to get to the pitch, Duminy lifts a length ball to deep midwicket! Another one goes, the SA innings is dribbling to a close... He was hitting across the line and didn't really get hold of it Faulkner to Wiese, OUT gone first ball, edging a pull through to the keeper! Two in three balls for Faulkner, the slump continues. It was another back-of-a-length delivery, Wiese hadn't got his eye in and succeeded only in feathering it through to Dunk Right, take your seats and hold on to your hats. Aaron Finch and Ben Dunk are out in the middle. Kyle Abbott has the new ball Peterson to Dunk, OUT on the attack again - but he's hit it straight into Peterson's bread basket! Really sharp catch and he squeals in celebration... Dunk didn't get to the pitch this time, the ball maybe gripped a little and hit higher up the bat, still flew pretty quickly but Peterson was alert to grab the chance Peterson to Watson, 1 wide fired through, down the leg side as Watson attempts to sweep Peterson to Maxwell, SIX runs ho ho, here we go, that's a beaut of a strike down the ground, many a row into the stand! Skipped out and smashed down the ground, such a clean strike Parnell to Faulkner, 1 wide short again, sprayed across as Faulkner made room for himself, can't reach it and called wide Wiese to Abbott, 1 wide slower ball, Abbott has a swish and misses - but it was just outside the tramline Australia won by 2 wickets (with 1 ball remaining) Player of the match is Cameron White, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 8 for 146 (White 41*, Peterson 3-28) beat South Africa 6 for 145 (Hendricks 49, de Kock 48, Faulkner 3-28) by 2 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Cameron White's composure guided Australia to a fighting, if occasionally flawed, series victory over South Africa in the third and final Twenty20 at Sydney's Olympic Stadium. Another underwhelming crowd - this time 24,187 against a capacity of about 80,000 - confirmed that cricket is more readily appreciated on television than at the ground in early November, irrespective of the format, but Australia's steady improvement after a heavy loss in the first match in Adelaide was a vindication of a somewhat experimental squad and their interim coach Trevor Bayliss. White is not yet a part of Australia's ODI squad with the World Cup now a matter of months away, but Mark Waugh, the selector on duty, could file a glowing report of his cool head to seal this result when others, including Glenn Maxwell and Shane Watson, may have chosen wiser strokes in pursuit of a modest total. Handy stands with Maxwell and James Faulkner, who also bowled neatly in helping restrict South Africa to a mere 6 for 145, allowed White and Australia to creep within sight, though the late wickets of Pat Cummins and Sean Abbott left South Africa in with a chance of stealing a tie or even a win. In the end a pair of white-knuckle singles off the accurate bowling of Kyle Abbott took Australia home, with White now waiting eagerly to see if he will be considered for further limited-overs duty this summer.

Commentary_Highlights: Bollinger to de Kock, 1 wide left-arm over the wicket, starts on a shortish length but this slides down the leg side Bollinger to de Kock, OUT got him, extra pace and bounce and de Kock feathers through to Dunk! Nothing stroke from de Kock, just hung his bat out - but the ball fair zipped through off the surface, seamed a fraction, took a small but visible deflection off the edge and South Africa are one down Faulkner to Rossouw, OUT got him, slower ball and this time the leading edge is snaffled by Faulkner! He's a canny lad in this form of the game, Faulkner, although his back-of-the-hand delivery was heading down the leg side. Rossouw was done by the lack of pace, heaved to leg again, the edge ballooned back down the pitch and the bowler clutched it diving to his right Faulkner to Duminy, SIX runs fetch that! Length ball from Faulkner and Duminy finally sends one over the ropes, meaty swing to leg and the ball sailed h-i-i-i-i-i-g-h over deep square leg Faulkner to Miller, OUT scooped high into the leg side, there's a man under this... gottim! Miller's time is up, aiming for the same boundary that Duminy cleared a few balls ago, got under it but didn't have the distance, taken comfortably a few yards in from the fence Boyce to Hendricks, OUT done him, Hendricks is down the river and stumped without a paddle! Superb work from Boyce, lured the batsman out but the ball dipped and he was nowhere near the pitch, just enough spin to go past the outside edge and he had no chance of regaining his ground Australia won by 7 wickets (with 44 balls remaining) Player of the match is Cameron Boyce, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 3 for 102 (Finch 44*, Parnell 2-17) beat South Africa 7 for 101 (Duminy 49, Faulkner 3-25, Boyce 2-15) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Australia cruised to one of their most comprehensive Twenty20 wins and kept the series alive after their bowlers restricted South Africa to 7 for 101 at the MCG. Cameron Boyce, Pat Cummins and James Faulkner were all key members of the attack and left little work for the batsmen, who cruised past their target for the loss of only three wickets, with 44 balls remaining. A slightly disappointing crowd of 21,415 saw their fellow Victorian Aaron Finch register his first home victory as the national T20 captain as he steered the chase with an unbeaten 44 from 30 deliveries. Ben Dunk was promoted to open with Finch and moved to 23 from 20 balls before he was caught at mid-on off Wayne Parnell, who also picked up the wicket of Shane Watson for 30. Watson crunched four boundaries off one Ryan McLaren over and gave the fans some entertainment before he was caught trying to launch Parnell over mid-off with 10 runs needed.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.40pm News trickling in that Australia have won the toss and have chosen to bat. Rabada to Finch, 1 leg bye length ball angled down the leg side and Finch gets a bit of pad on it down to square leg as he misses the flick McLaren to Finch, OUT and he strikes first ball. It's a slower ball outside off, and Finch goes hard at it, looking to drive on the up, and pops a simple catch to short cover Parnell to White, OUT taken! It was short, wide, and it deserved to be smashed, and White duly smashed it, but Behardien at cover point leaped in the air, arms at full stretch, and plucked it out of the air Duminy to Dunk, 1 leg bye full on middle and leg and he clips it away towards midwicket Tahir to Dunk, OUT tossed up wide outside off. Dunk goes hard at the drive and hits it in the air, and Duminy takes it well at short cover, going down on one knee and taking it above his right shoulder Abbott to Reardon, OUT whatacatch! That was short and rising outside off and he crouched to play the ramp shot. Got a fairly big chunk of bat on it and it went at high pace over de Kock. He leaped high in the air, at full stretch, and came away with the ball stuck in his right glove Abbott to Watson, OUT gone! Yet another batsman hits it in the air at catching height, straight to a fielder. It was full outside off and Watson hit that cleanly but picked out the man at cover, right on the edge of the circle Tahir to Watson, SIX runs short again, on off stump, and Watson clears his front leg and slugs that over the gap between long-on and deep midwicket Abbott to Cutting, OUT gone. Cutting goes deep in his crease and gets under this blockhole delivery, strikes it cleanly, but the straight boundaries here are long and he holes out to Miller at long-on. It's an easy catch but he makes sure there are no stuff-ups, tossing the ball in the air, stepping out of the boundary and back in to re-take the catch Kane Richardson to Rossouw, 1 leg bye down the track now and he follows him down the leg side. Can't get his bat around his pad to flick, and it goes off the pad towards square leg Kane Richardson to Rossouw, 1 wide starts this spell by angling a full ball down the leg side Cutting to Rossouw, 1 wide sees him coming down the track and bounces him. Was well above his head, so it was a fair call of wide from the umpire, but good thinking nonetheless from Cutting Cummins to de Kock, 1 wide bouncer slanted outside off, too high for the batsman to reach Cummins to Miller, 1 wide now he looks to bowl a bit straighter and ends up overdoing it, slants it wide down the leg side 10.17pm And that's as dominant a win as South Africa could have hoped for. They were simply the better side today. Australia went too hard at the ball while batting, trying to mow everything over long-on or midwicket, their bowling was a little one-dimensional and quite often all over the place, and their fielding was ragged. South Africa, in comparison, bowled very goo South Africa won by 7 wickets (with 6 balls remaining) Player of the match is Rilee Rossouw, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 3 for 145 (Rossouw 78, de Kock 46) beat Australia 6 for 144 (Watson 47, Faulkner 41*, Abbott 3-21) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Kyle Abbott harried Australia's batsmen and Rilee Rossouw achieved the rare feat of putting Quinton de Kock in the shade during a stand of 129 as South Africa secured a vast opening win in the Twenty20 match at Adelaide Oval. Three days after they were comfortably beaten by a Cricket Australia Invitational XI in Sydney, the tourists combined impressively with ball and bat to deliver Australia's third consecutive international defeat, albeit against two distinctly different teams in two vastly different formats on opposite sides of the globe. The likes of David Warner, Mitchell Johnson and Glenn Maxwell were missed by the Australians, but it must also be acknowledged that Dale Steyn and AB de Villiers were among South Africa's absentees. Abbott and Rossouw were highly capable substitutes, the former's 3 for 21 and the latter's 78 from 50 balls the most telling contributions for JP Duminy's men. Reeza Hendricks was out to a well-pitched delivery from Doug Bollinger in the first over of South Africa's chase, but Rossouw and de Kock had very few difficulties in rattling towards the target and ensuring that by the time they departed the asking rate was negligible.

Commentary_Highlights: Agar to S Dhawan, SIX runs down the wicket, and chips this over the long-off fence. Use of the feet the key, as the line of the ball was wide, but all he needed to do was clear the infield, with the man stationed at mid-off Agar to Rahul, OUT GONE! Chips a length ball in the air, just doesn't get to the pitch of one floated around off. Perhaps gripped a bit on the pitch too, and he just drives this straight to Steve Smith at cover. Loud cheers, as the crowd prepare for Virat Kohli Agar to S Dhawan, 1 leg bye length, and he tries to flick this. Off his pads, towards short fine-leg and they quickly switch ends for a leg-bye Cummins to Iyer, 1 wide dug in short, and Iyer ducks out of the way. Called wide for the length Zampa to Kohli, SIX runs very short ball, and gets the right treatment! Rocks back, and swings this over the long leg fence. Just went over, in the end, but good enough to fetch half a dozen Zampa to Kohli, OUT he's gotten his revenge! Kohli falls to Zampa again! Driven hard, to a ball that was floated around off, and he just couldn't keep it away from Zampa, who takes a sharp chance and then punches the air. Important breakthrough for Australia at this stage, as it exposes the relatively soft underbelly of the Indian batting, with a good way to cover in this innings Starc to Iyer, OUT and the move to bring Starc back has worked. Don't think it was a special delivery though, a length ball angling away, Iyer pushes away from the body and gets an outside edge, a simple catch for Carey behind the stumps Starc to Pant, 1 wide 144kph, attempted yorker but down the leg side, given a wide Kane Richardson to Jadeja, 1 wide length ball down the leg side, Jadeja looks to flick it fine but misses. Called a wide Agar to Jadeja, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, misses the flick but hares down to the other end for a leg-byw Cummins to Pant, OUT a short one hurries onto the Pant who goes for the pull, gets a top edge onto the helmet and it lobs towards point. An easy catch but umpire Shamshuddin is unmoved as everyone looks towards him. Meanwhile, the batsmen are sneaking in single, no direct hit but then the umpire raises his finger. Pant departs after a bit of drama Starc to Thakur, OUT nails the yorker, it was just a matter of time, Shardul fails to get anything on it and the off stump has been knocked out from its groove. The fact that Shardul was looking to play across the line didn't help either t Starc to Kuldeep, 1 wide fuller but way down the leg side Starc to Shami, OUT a direct hit from Smith and Kuldeep has to go back. Fuller outside off, Shami steered it towards backward point and set off, Smith had all the time to nail the direct hit and he does Kane Richardson to Shami, OUT length ball at the stumps, backs away and looks to smash across, gets a top edge that goes high and behind the stumps, Carey positions himself under it as it comes spiralling down, the ball pops out of his gloves but he does well to cling to the rebound, between his chin/neck and the glove Starc to Hendricks, 1 wide full and leg side, 140kph/87mph... but off beam Cummins to de Kock, SIX runs smoked! Length ball from Cummins and de Kock mows it into the crowd at deep midwicket! Carved brutally over the leg side for the first boundary of the day Zampa to de Kock, 1 run smashed over deep midwicket for six SMITH!! You cannot do that... Brilliantly caught on the boundary as he dives beyond the rope, and then hurled back in before touching the ground! Keeps them to one! Amazing Kane Richardson to Hendricks, OUT short ball, pace off... and pulled to deep square leg! Laboured innings from Hendricks, who was done by the legcutter from Richardson, bowling well to his field. Safely taken by Dre Russ/Sir Jaddu in the outfield Agar to de Kock, 1 leg bye darted on the stumps, straightening a touch and skids into the pads as de Kocks sweeps... not given and there'll be no review Kane Richardson to van der Dussen, OUT Rassie holes out to deep square leg! The legcutter does the job again, nothing for van der Dussen to work with as he swings for the pickets, safely taken a few yards in from the rope Starc to Rohit Sharma, OUT Warner takes a low catch at mid-off. Cross seam and not that full, was angling away from the batsman. Rohit looks to hit it down the ground but it comes slower off the surface. The bat faces closes a touch too early as well. As a result it goes tamely towards Warner, just carrying to him. Think Rohit was looking to go over extra cover Agar to Rahul, OUT GONE! Chips a length ball in the air, just doesn't get to the pitch of one floated around off. Perhaps gripped a bit on the pitch too, and he just drives this straight to Steve Smith at cover. Loud cheers, as the crowd prepare for Virat Kohli Cummins to Iyer, 1 wide dug in short, and Iyer ducks out of the way. Called wide for the length Zampa to Kohli, OUT he's gotten his revenge! Kohli falls to Zampa again! Driven hard, to a ball that was floated around off, and he just couldn't keep it away from Zampa, who takes a sharp chance and then punches the air. Important breakthrough for Australia at this stage, as it exposes the relatively soft underbelly of the Indian batting, with a good way to cover in this innings Starc to Iyer, OUT and the move to bring Starc back has worked. Don't think it was a special delivery though, a length ball angling away, Iyer pushes away from the body and gets an outside edge, a simple catch for Carey behind the stumps Kane Richardson to Jadeja, 1 wide length ball down the leg side, Jadeja looks to flick it fine but misses. Called a wide Agar to Jadeja, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, misses the flick but hares down to the other end for a leg-byw Agar to Pant, SIX runs 102kph, uses his feet and hoicks it over deep midwicket, all the way for a six Cummins to Pant, OUT a short one hurries onto the Pant who goes for the pull, gets a top edge onto the helmet and it lobs towards point. An easy catch but umpire Shamshuddin is unmoved as everyone looks towards him. Meanwhile, the batsmen are sneaking in single, no direct hit but then the umpire raises his finger. Pant departs after a bit of drama Starc to Thakur, OUT nails the yorker, it was just a matter of time, Shardul fails to get anything on it and the off stump has been knocked out from its groove. The fact that Shardul was looking to play across the line didn't help either t Starc to Shami, OUT a direct hit from Smith and Kuldeep has to go back. Fuller outside off, Shami steered it towards backward point and set off, Smith had all the time to nail the direct hit and he does Kane Richardson to Shami, OUT length ball at the stumps, backs away and looks to smash across, gets a top edge that goes high and behind the stumps, Carey positions himself under it as it comes spiralling down, the ball pops out of his gloves but he does well to cling to the rebound, between his chin/neck and the glove Starc to Thakur, OUT nails the yorker, it was just a matter of time, Shardul fails to get anything on it and the off stump has been knocked out from its groove. The fact that Shardul was looking to play across the line didn't help either t Starc to Shami, OUT a direct hit from Smith and Kuldeep has to go back. Fuller outside off, Shami steered it towards backward point and set off, Smith had all the time to nail the direct hit and he does Kane Richardson to Shami, OUT length ball at the stumps, backs away and looks to smash across, gets a top edge that goes high and behind the stumps, Carey positions himself under it as it comes spiralling down, the ball pops out of his gloves but he does well to cling to the rebound, between his chin/neck and the glove 5.15pm A decent start followed by a middle-overs collapse before a brief rescue act by the lower order. Dhawan top-scored with 74 but India were all out for 255 in 49.1 overs. Starc picked up 3 for 56, and bowled eight yorkers in the game. He has never bowled that many in an ODI, Bharath tells me. Starc reckons the dew may make the ball come easier onto the bat in the second innings. We will be back with the chase 5.40pm Back for the chase, not long from now. KL Rahul has the wicketkeeping pads on. That's an interesting update. India will look for quick wickets, and I also think scoring becomes a bit tougher on this pitch once the ball softens a bit. Lots to play for just yet Bumrah to Finch, 1 leg bye length, and he whips this towards fine leg. Off the pad, says the umpire Shami to Finch, 1 leg bye length, jags back in, and he looks to play this towards the on side. Off the pads, and going down leg, but drops towards square leg Thakur to Warner, 1 wide short, but down the leg side. Warner lets this pass Jadeja to Warner, SIX runs length, around off, and he has swung this wide of deep mid-wicket. All the way, and hits the boundary skirting on the full Jadeja to Warner, 1 wide length ball sliding down the leg side, Warner was over-balanced while going for a flick, Rahul fails to collect but it brushed only the pad. The umpire though signals wide Kuldeep to Finch, 1 wide length ball down the leg side and spinning further away, called a wide Kuldeep to Warner, SIX runs flighted outside off, Warner skips down the track, wasn't to the exact pitch of the ball but with the mid-on up, he goes for it and makes a good enough connection to clear the boundary on the full Thakur to Finch, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, misses the flick but gets another leg-bye Jadeja to Finch, 1 leg bye fuller on the toes, misses the flick but gets a leg-bye to short fine leg Shami to Warner, 1 wide short, called wide as it bounces well over his head Bumrah to Finch, 1 leg bye length, and he whips this towards fine leg. Off the pad, says the umpire Shami to Finch, 1 leg bye length, jags back in, and he looks to play this towards the on side. Off the pads, and going down leg, but drops towards square leg Thakur to Warner, 1 wide short, but down the leg side. Warner lets this pass Jadeja to Warner, SIX runs length, around off, and he has swung this wide of deep mid-wicket. All the way, and hits the boundary skirting on the full Jadeja to Warner, 1 wide length ball sliding down the leg side, Warner was over-balanced while going for a flick, Rahul fails to collect but it brushed only the pad. The umpire though signals wide Thakur to Finch, 1 wide and he starts with a wide down the leg side Thakur to Finch, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, misses the flick but gets another leg-bye Kuldeep to Finch, 1 wide length ball pitching on the leg stump and spinning down. Called a wide Shami to Warner, 1 wide short, called wide as it bounces well over his head This is just the third time in ODI history, that a team has won a match by 10 wickets when chasing 250 or more. Interestingly, the teams to suffer each time have all been Asian ones! 8.49pm Well, that spanking out of the way, let's look ahead to the second ODI, which now provides Finch and his men a chance to wrap this series up in just two games. It's goodbye for now, from Chandan Duorah, Hemant Brar, and myself, Debayan Sen. We'll see you in Rajkot on January 17 to see if India can bounce back and keep this series alive. Australia won by 10 wickets (with 74 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Bangladesh 127 for 9 (Mahmudullah 52, Ellis 3-34, Hazlewood 2-16) beat Australia 117 for 4 (Marsh 51, McDermott 35, Shoriful 2-29) by ten runs Bangladesh marched to an unassailable 3-0 lead to register their first series win against Australia across formats by defending 128 in a close finish during the third T20I in Dhaka. While Mahmudullah led from the front by scoring 52 and batting deep to ensure the hosts had some firepower left late in the innings, Mustafizur Rahman, Shakib Al Hasan and Nasum Ahmed combined to apply the brakes on Australia's run chase. Debutant Nathan Ellis' hat-trick went in vain for the visitors, for whom Mitchell Marsh continued his fine form and contributed 51, while Josh Hazlewood and Adam Zampa chipped in with the ball. The Fizz delivers again Rahman followed figures of 2 for 16 and 3 for 23 in the series with an exceptional return of 0 for 9 from his four overs. In what was the joint second-most economical effort for a Bangladesh bowler in a completed spell, Rahman turned the game around when he conceded just a single in the 19th over of the Australia innings when they needed an entirely possible 23 from 12 balls with Alex Carey and Dan Christian at the crease.

Commentary_Highlights: Ashwin to Johnson, OUT he has missed this one completely! Johnson steps out early to slog it over the leg side but this drifts in and slides through the gap. Dhoni does the rest. Johnson doesn't even look back. Knows he is gone the moment his misses it Ashwin to Harris, OUT and he misses a straight ball to be given out lbw! He went for the big sweep and missed it completely. That would have hit the stumps Shami to Lyon, OUT swings and misses a straight one, that one hits the leg stump. Lyon doesn't really care. He has done the job of rubbing it in. Yadav to Smith, OUT he has lost his middle stump! He goes all the way to the off side to play a ramp shot, but misses a straight delivery. It strikes the top of middle stump. To be frank, the bowlers never looked like taking that wicket and it was up to Smith to do something crazy to give it away Hazlewood to Rahane, 1 leg bye this one is slipping down the leg side, rolls on to fine-leg after hitting the pads. Those are your first extras in this innings Lyon to Rahane, OUT and there is the breakthrough! Rahane looks to repeat the sweep shot but this is much straighter and fuller from Lyon, he misses and his hit on the back pad. The umpire takes time and then raises his finger. Rahane gets a pat on the back from Kohli and a standing ovation from the crowd as he walks back. Superb innings from him. Lyon to Rahul, OUT he's gone next ball, it was full and well outside off, hitting the rough as well, Rahul goes for an expansive sweep, top edges that towards backward square leg, simple catch and it is not put down this time, there's plenty of hype around Rahul, but he's played a couple of strange shots in his short debut innings Harris to Ashwin, OUT and here's another one! Harris takes a tumbling catch in his follow through. Ashwin drives at this fuller delivery and is not able to keep it down, Harris stretches his right hand out, is not able to cling on. Luckily the ball doesn't get away from him and he is able to make a second grab at that Johnson to Kohli, OUT and he gets the big wicket! After 29 overs of toil, Johnson has something to show. But check that out for a catch from Haddin. He dives full length to his right and plucks it in front of first slip. It was going straight into Watson's hands. Kohli tried to chase that full and wide delivery, but got a thick outside edge. Innings Start Jared: "Brad Haddin sledging Kohli by shouting "It's all about you!" at him on TV. The irony is palpable."
Match_Report: Australia 530 (Smith 192) and 9 for 318 dec (Marsh 99, Rogers 69) drew with India 465 (Kohli 169, Rahane 147, Harris 4-70) and 6 for 174 (Kohli 54) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Australia did not need to win, and India never really thought seriously about doing so. A curiously muted final day of the Boxing Day Test petered out with four overs still to bowl; on recent evidence more than enough time to winkle out the visitors' last four wickets. A draw was enough for Australia to regain the Border-Gavaskar Trophy under the stand-in captaincy of Steven Smith, and also enough for MS Dhoni's India to avoid a series whitewash. So hands were shaken, backs slapped and stumps drawn. Despite the odd moment of rancour - Virat Kohli versus Brad Haddin - or transcendence - Mitchell Johnson's ripping cutter to bowl Cheteshwar Pujara - this always seemed the most likely result.

Commentary_Highlights: Lyon to Vijay, OUT ... and it's paid off. Vijay comes down the track and goes for the big hit again. Was making room to go over mid-off and it went with the angle past his outside edge and Haddin makes the easy stumping. Hang on, they've had another look at it, and there was a thin edge through to the keeper, so it's a caught behind and not a stumping. Hazlewood to Rahane, OUT that is the best ball of the Test match. Lovely length, caught Rahane on the crease, angling in towards off stump and curling away late. Rahane had to play at it, and it kissed his edge through to Haddin, who takes his fifth catch of the innings Starc to Ashwin, 1 wide this one's dug in very short and Ashwin leans away and watches it through to the keeper Hazlewood to Ashwin, OUT got him! That was a beautiful length outside off, a bit of movement away off the pitch. Ashwin's bat comes down at an angle as he looks for the drive, and Watson takes a waist-high catch at first slip Hazlewood to Dhoni, OUT that's five on debut! A bit of inward movement from a good length. Dhoni was looking to leave, made the decision late, and the ball clipped his inside edge as the bat went up and Haddin takes a sixth catch Lyon to Aaron, OUT that's a stunner at short leg! Classic offie's dismissal, loop and dip, turn and bounce from outside off as he pushes forward to defend. Pops up into the leg side, and the substitute fielder at short leg, Marnus Labuschagne, moves in in a flash and dives forward to take it with his right hand, inches off the ground. I'm not sure whether it was bat-pad or bat tucked Lyon to Yadav, OUT And that is that. Umesh goes for the slog-sweep from outside off, and he picks out Rogers at deep midwicket 12.11pm Lunch, and Australia will feel much better than they did at the start of the day's play. Hazlewood bowled quite beautifully to finish with a five-for, and he looked like taking wickets whenever he hit that right length. India's seamers will have watched that, but will they be able to bowl in those right areas? If they do, they could put Australia under pressure, considering they have around the wicket now Aaron to Starc, 1 wide another bouncer, and Dhoni has to leap and stretch his right arm way over his head to catch that after Starc moves his head away from the line Aaron to Starc, 1 leg bye full, angling down leg. Misses the flick and it pops off the pad into the off side Innings Start 2.05pm Warner and Rogers are out in the middle. Ashwin gives Warner a pat on the back, and Warner pats Ashwin back on his back. Lots of backs in there. Who's coming in with the new ball, to bend his back? It's Ishant.
Match_Report: Australia 505 (Smith 133, Johnson 88) and 6 for 130 (Rogers 55) beat India 408 (Vijay 144, Rahane 81) and 224 (Dhawan 81, Johnson 4-61) by four wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details 3:03 Is there a way back for India? Australian resilience was writ large across a four-wicket victory over India that will look a little fortunate in the scorebook without reference to the dressing-room scenes on day one, when India seemed set fair for a mighty first innings and Mitchell Marsh, Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood were all either lost to injury or weakened by fatigue. Hazlewood's recovery from full-body cramps to prise out India on the second morning set-up the match, and the combined efforts of the new captain Steven Smith, Mitchell Johnson, Chris Rogers, Starc and Nathan Lyon ultimately allowed the hosts to overwhelm India by a greater margin than the first Test in Adelaide. For Smith it was a significant triumph, emerging victorious after a first day he described among the toughest he had ever endured, as either player or captain. MS Dhoni's men were adequately placed to fight their corner when day four began, but they crumbled in the face of concerted pace and pressure from Johnson on a pitch that had begun to deteriorate. Only Shikhar Dhawan, who did not walk out to bat at 10am because he had been struck on the wrist in the practice nets, offered any sustained resistance, and his dismissal lbw to Lyon after lunch heralded a swift end to India's innings.

Commentary_Highlights: Aaron to Marsh, OUT taken at gully and Kohli throws the ball high up in the air. Extra bounce gets rid of Marsh. Tight line just outside off to force the batsman to push and the variation that a new cherry provides takes care of the rest. India desperately needed that Shami to Lyon, OUT through him! Shami has made an important break. It was a good length ball targeting middle. Lyon did not move forward enough to counter the ball moving back in and it takes an inside edge, gets the top flap of the pad and hits timber Shami to Haddin, OUT there it is, India have ended the day on a high! Haddin was struggling around the off stump and this time the edge carries through to the keeper. Beautiful delivery, and that is what the new ball can do and then placing it in the right areas - on and around off stump with some late seam away Karn to Clarke, OUT no mistake this time. Clarke goes for a sweep and has found square leg. Adelaide stands up to appreciate their captain. The coach pats him on the head as he walks back, his family is there as well. Looks quite weary as he walks off. Steven Smith has continued making a name for himself in Test cricket, and at times batted like he was two different people. A polished strokemaker for much of the innings and then a slog-overs specialist in the latter half. Michael Clarke strode out at the start of the day, back injury and all, and his sudden appearance seemed to have wilted Johnson to Kohli, OUT down the throat of deep fine leg and Johnson has picked the big wicket! It's the bouncer again, it's on middle, it came at the batsman too early and the top edge swirls to Ryan Harris who rushes in and dives forward to take it. The front-foot check looks scary, but Johnson has a couple of millimeters behind the l Lyon to Rohit Sharma, OUT he's caught it! What a soft dismissal! It was a loopy delivery outside off and Rohit has come down the track to try and nudge it away. But all he's managed is return the ball back into the bowler's hands. Lyon had to dive to his right off his followthrough and just about holds on. Australia badly wanted that Lyon to Saha, OUT he's gone! Lyon keeps troubling everyone. But did it hit the bat? It was a gorgeous offspinner that brought the right-hander forward to block. The turn beats his inside edge, hits the pad and umpire Gould must think it kissed the glove on the way to first slip. I didn't see anything though... Innings Start Shri: "As India gets to 100, can't help but think that throughout this game, India has lost one more wicket than they should have (100/1 at lunch was good, 100/2 is Australia's session). I think this is going to prove one wicket too many in the end."
Match_Report: Australia 7 for 517 dec (Smith 162*, Warner 145, Clarke 128) and 5 for 290 dec (Warner 102) beat India 444 (Kohli 115, Lyon 5-134) and 315 (Kohli 141, Vijay 99, Lyon 7-152) by 48 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details A gladiatorial battle between bat and ball took place on the final day at Adelaide Oval, where a Test that had begun in sorrow a week after the death of Phillip Hughes was given a dazzling finish that highlighted the greatness of this game. India's champion was Virat Kohli, a debutant captain with his sight fixed on a formidable target while all but one of his team-mates failed to show similar steel. For Australia, it was the spindly Nathan Lyon, suffering unsympathetic umpiring to single-handedly drag his team back into the contest, making up for the bluntness of his faster colleagues. The Test was decided when Kohli pulled Lyon and was caught at deep midwicket, leaving Australia with 60 to defend and three wickets to take. They won by 48 runs.

Commentary_Highlights: News from the 'G' is that Australia have won the toss and asked Sri Lanka to bat first. It's the first time in seven limited overs matches that the tourists will bat first, if I'm not mistaken. They have built each of their three victories on bowling first, so it will be interesting to see how they react to having to set a score, and indeed, how A Faulkner to Dilshan, OUT slower ball again, and this time he bowls him! Dilshan tried to pull that one, but it didn't bounce as high as he expected. It takes an under edge and clips off stump. I think the slowness of the ball did him in there. Starc to Perera, 1 wide way down leg, and Wade dives well to stop that from being only one wide Laughlin to Chandimal, OUT that is an awful looking shot. Short outside off stump, Chandimal tries to heave that over mid on with a cross-bat shot, but is too late on the stroke, and ends up scooping it to Bailey at mid off. Didn't look too comfortable, despite the boundary Faulkner to Perera, SIX runs great hitting from Perera. Short of a length slower ball on the stumps, Perera clears the hip and smashes that high over cow corner. Laughlin to Perera, SIX runs top edged six! No luck there for Laughlin, but it's been that kind of day for Perera. Length outside off stump, Perera tries to wallop that over mid on, but it gets a thick outside edge and flies over the fine leg rope Good innings by Mahela, to hold things together after three wickets fell quickly. Perera played a blinder, as Australia's bowlers shied away from bowling yorkers at the death. But the good start for Australia means that 161 is probably just about par. Kulasekara to Warner, OUT beautifully bowled by Kulasekara. That was right on a good length and moving away off the seam, Warner tried to hit that through the leg side, but the movement means he got a leading edge which lobs to Thisara Perera at mid off. Sri Lanka silence Warner early. Kulasekara to Finch, 1 leg bye length on the legs, deflects to square leg In the end, you've got to say Sri Lanka deserved to take it out. The D/L recalculation made things a touch tougher for them, but they gritted it out well, even with a damp ball. A valiant effort from Marsh and Bailey, but Australia just gave away too much ground in the early overs. That's about it for our coverage for this cracker of a match. Glad you could be with us. So Sri Lanka finally have something to take away from the tour, even if it was just in the Twenty20s. Until next time, ciao! Player of the match is Thisara Perera, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 4 for 161 (Jayawardene 61*, T Perera 35*) beat Australia 3 for 119 (Marsh 47*) by 2 runs (D/L method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Mahela Jayawardene top scored for Sri Lanka Getty Images Thisara Perera was the difference with the bat and then held his nerve, although only barely, with the ball to seal a two-run victory off the final delivery of a rain-reduced chase. In a heated finale, Glenn Maxwell needed four runs from the last ball for victory and was frustrated by a long conference held by several Sri Lanka players before the delivery was bowled, and when Perera sent down the ball wide of off Maxwell missed and all the batsmen could manage was a bye. The Sri Lanka players were jubilant but there were tense scenes as the players walked off, Maxwell clearly annoyed at the Sri Lankans, and even the handshakes involving players who weren't on the field at the end became testy. It became that kind of night when rain interrupted Australia's chase of 162 and despite the shower being short, the umpires did not allow play to restart for 45 minutes due to difficulties drying the outfield. When the rain arrived after 10 overs, Australia were 15 runs behind on the Duckworth-Lewis score at 2 for 60.

Commentary_Highlights: Australia have won the toss and opted to bat at Stadium Australia. We're waiting on the team lists, but news is that Ben Cutting will get a Twenty20 debut. Angelo Mathews to Warner, 1 leg bye back of a length again, Warner misses with his pull and they scamper a leg bye Perera to Marsh, OUT direct hit, and out! Marsh was clearly rattled there, and desperate to get off strike. Lenght outside off stump, Marsh defended that and took off, and the ball dribbled towards Dilshan, who swooped in and underarmed the throw, to beat Marsh back to the Perera to Bailey, OUT Bailey pinpoints Dilshan with an open-faced drive. Poor stroke you've got to say. Fullish wide delivery, drilled straight to the fielder, who gobbles it at waist height. Mendis to Voges, 1 bye full and angled into Voges, who misses the ball, and the keeper can't collect either Warner's has been a good innings, and it may turn out to be a match-winning one as the pitch is a little two-paced. But Sri Lanka's bowlers did very well to contain Australia, and they were backed up well in the field. We'll be here with the second innings in less than ten. Cutting to Perera, SIX runs super shot that. Back of a length outside off stump and he stood his ground and bludgeoned it corss-batted over long on for six. Starc to Dilshan, 1 wide this one is a wide. Short ball down leg side. Doherty to Perera, 1 leg bye pitches outside leg and straightens, Perera tried to glance that, but it hits his pads and they take a leg bye Maxwell to Perera, OUT gone! And Perera's promising innings ends. Length ball spinning away and bouncing outside off stump. Perera rocked back to cut it, and gets a top edge to Wade, who pouches a decent deflection. Good innings from Perera though, while Dilshan struggled. Maxwell to Chandimal, OUT down the track, and he holes out trying to clear the short, straight fence. Didn't quite get to the pitch of the ball there, and mistimed it off the toe end. Cutting takes it securely above his head and Sri Lanka need someone to stand up here, or Doherty to Mahela Jayawardene, OUT bowled! That's a wicket Australia really needed. Mahela is done in by the dip there. Tried to turn it to the on side, but it's full and it sneaks under the bat to hit the pad, and then take off stump. Starc to Thirimanne, OUT backs away and picks out backward with an aerial square drive. It was fullish and on the stumps, Thirimanne gets that on the outside of his bat and it flies to Voges, who takes a sharp chance above his head. Australia still very much in this. Anot Laughlin to Angelo Mathews, SIX runs shot! Overpitched and punished. Mathews stood his ground and struck that clean back over the bowler's head and way over the boundary. So Sri Lanka will retain their no. 1 ranking, regardless of the result of the next match. Daniel Bretting's report has been updated here. Join us again on Monday for coverage of the second Twenty20 in Melbourne. Sri Lanka won by 5 wickets (with 7 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 5 for 138 (Mathews 35*) beat Australia 3 for 137 (Warner 90*, Voges 25*) by 5 wickets Live scorecard and ball-by-ball details David Warner was almost solely responsible for a defensible Australian total Associated Press Sri Lanka's collective effort was enough to overcome an Australian team that left far too much up to David Warner on their National Day with the visitors claiming a five-wicket victory on a pudding of a drop-in pitch at Sydney's Olympic Stadium. After their bowlers had been brilliantly supported in the field to restrict Australia to 3 for 137 - of which Warner made no fewer than 90 - the Sri Lankans made a rapid start to the chase and then steadied against the loss of mid-innings wickets to take a 1-0 lead with seven balls to spare. Angelo Mathews showed the cool head that has him marked as his nation's long-term leader to finish off the innings. There were cameos, too, from Kushal Perera, Lahiru Thirimanne and Thisara Perera, all of whom will be happy that Sri Lanka cannot now lose this series after also tying the ODI matches. Nuwan Kulasekara and Thisara Perera were both exemplary with the ball, though Kulasekara undid much of his good work by turfing the simplest of chances at deep midwicket when Warner had made only 69.

Commentary_Highlights: Perera to Bailey, OUT would you believe it? Perera has conjured a wicket out of nowhere. Fullish ball, seemed to hang in the pitch for a moment and Bailey was too quick on the shot. He ends up lobbing that straight back to the bowler, who takes a decent catch, bending low on his follow through. Malinga to Hussey, 1 wide attempted yorker fired down the leg side. Chandimal does well to collect. McKay to Mahela Jayawardene, 1 wide angled too far down the leg side. Doherty to Mahela Jayawardene, OUT that was somewhat out of the blue. Seems to have stuck in the pitch more than Mahela expected. He was aiming a shot through mid off, but gets an inside edge and it lobs to mid on, who takes a simple catch. Doherty delivers the breakthrough Australia needed. Johnson to Thirimanne, 1 wide fired down leg side, Thirimanne can't get a touch on it Doherty to Dilshan, 1 leg bye on leg stump again, and that collects a pad on its way past Matthew Wade Doherty to Thirimanne, OUT poor option from Thirimanne, and Sri Lanka are throwing away a decent start. He came down the pitch and tried to loft that over midwicket, only he hit it too straight and David Hussey at long on ran around to swallow it. It was the result of some good pressure, but he will feel that tha Henriques to Dilshan, OUT Henriques strikes! Dislhan edges an innocuous delivery behind, and leaves Sri Lanka in trouble. He hasn't looked himself at all in this innings and has taken 48 balls for 19. Pressure on the young middle order now, and Australia will feel they are on top now, the way the pitch is playing Starc to Perera, 1 leg bye angled down the leg side and that is glanced to fine leg for a single Johnson to Angelo Mathews, 1 leg bye hits Mathews on the pads with a length ball and the batsman take a leg bye Johnson to Perera, OUT gone! Johnson gets one to bounce a little more than they have and Perera gets a big top edge as he tries to work that into the leg side. David Warner at mid wicket waits for an eternity for it to come down, and takes the catch comfortably. Another big blow and Sri Lanka are sliding quickly McKay to Jeevan Mendis, no run a slower ball outside off stump, and Mendis tries to run that off the blade, but can't beat short third man. Six off the over again. Not good enough for the visitors by a long shot. Starc to Angelo Mathews, 1 wide fires one down the leg side McKay to Angelo Mathews, 1 leg bye slower again, back of a length, tucked into the leg side Looks like we can't bring the presentation to you today, but thanks for being with us. If I can hazard a guess I'd say Phil Hughes will win the man of the match, and Nuwan Kulasekara is the player of the series, but Hughes has an outside shot of taking that out too. Those would by my two picks anyway. This series is shared, but there's more to come from the tour, when the first of two Twenty20s kicks off on the 26th at the SCG. Join us then for more commentary. Player of the match is Phillip Hughes, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 5 for 247 (Hughes 138*) beat Sri Lanka 215 (Mathews 67, Doherty 3-21, Henriques 3-32) by 32 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Phillip Hughes scored his second hundred of the series Getty Images On debut, Phillip Hughes scored a century to give Australia a 1-0 lead in this series. In the final game, he made another hundred to save Australia from series defeat and salvage a 2-2 result. Set 248 to win the game and the five-match contest, Sri Lanka struggled early, staged a plucky fightback led by Angelo Mathews, and ultimately fell short as Australia's bowlers backed up the fine work of Hughes, whose unbeaten 138 was all the more important in a batting line-up missing Michael Clarke. Australia's captain had been ruled out due to an ankle injury suffered at training on the day before the match and it left the Australians with a flimsy looking batting order that featured the allrounders Glenn Maxwell and Moises Henriques at Nos. 6 and 7.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and they will bat first. Still waiting for word on the SL line-up. Kulasekara to Hughes, 1 wide drifts just wide down the leg side, the batsman tries to clip it away fine Kulasekara to Hussey, OUT Appeal for a caught behind and Hussey has been given not out, and SL are reviewing it. This one nips back in from outside off, Hussey was looking to cut, there was a sound as the ball passes the bat and Perera takes it well diving to his left. Kettleborough didn't pick it up and Mahela wanted it reviewed, Hot Spot s Kulasekara to Bailey, OUT Bailey pads up and Aus have lost two in two! Kulasekara's inswing is really causing trouble to the right-handers, moved back in and Bailey was forward and across to shoulder arms, the ball hits his pads and he was in front of the off stump Kulasekara to Clarke, 1 wide sharp bouncer but Kulasekara is penalised for height Kulasekara to Clarke, OUT The middle stump has been pushed back and Kulasekara has picked up his fourth! He gets the Australian captain, Kula's inswing to the right-handers is causing havoc at the Gabba, Clarke was looking to play down the ground but left a gap between pad and bat, the ball sneaked through and knocked back the stump Kulasekara to Henriques, OUT Five for the road for Kula and Australia are a trainwreck at the Gabba! That inswing again, needs no further mention, Henriques gets across and he too is bowled through the gate, hits the top of the stumps Malinga to McKay, OUT caught behind! This could have sent back even a genuine batsman, Malinga gets this one to move away from the right-hander, McKay was caught at the crease and couldn't move across to cover the line, thin edge and Perera takes it Malinga to Johnson, OUT the attrition rate gets worse for the hosts! Malinga gets this one to move towards middle stump from over the wicket, Johnson tries to work it away to the on side, the ball hits his pad and then heads towards middle stump, almost through the gate Malinga to Wade, OUT Now even that score of 70 looks days away! Soft dismissal for Wade, this was pitched up and moving away from the left-hander, he tries to steer it square on the off side but ends up spooning a catch to backward point Eranga to Doherty, OUT so 74 it is! Soft dismissal to end the innings and fitting too when you look at the scorecard, he was trying to work it to the on side, leading edge popped up to cover McKay to Mahela Jayawardene, OUT Warner takes a brilliant one at backward point! That will lift Australia's sagging spirits, this was short and wide outside off, Mahela was on his toes to cut that, moved quickly to Warner's left and he threw himself to his left and took it with both hands, sharp reflexes Starc to Dilshan, 1 wide that was too short and wide and Dilshan couldn't resist, slashed and missed and he was beaten for pace and bounce Johnson to Angelo Mathews, OUT Sri Lanka have lost two in two and the hosts are smiling again! Mathews gets a brute of a delivery from Johnson, it was short of a length and gaining on his body, he had barely enough time to make up his mend whether to duck or fend it off, took his eyes off the ball and the top edge lobbed tamely to Starc who Sri Lanka are 2-1 up ahead of the 4th ODI, They won't be so happy about the way they chased this, but that's a worry for another day. They can afford to savour 74 all out today. Great performance in the field. Clarke was clearly peeved with himself for the way he and his team played. Nice to see a captain be so honest about his own team. Not all captains in world cricket today can say 'yes we messed up real bad.' You have to admire Clarke for that. Sri Lanka won by 4 wickets (with 180 balls remaining) Player of the match is Nuwan Kulasekara, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 6 for 75 (K Perera 22*, Johnson 3-11) beat Australia 74 (Starc 22*, Kulasekara 5-22, Malinga 3-14) by 4 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Nuwan Kulasekara destroyed Australia with lethal inswing Getty Images A fearsome spell of inswing bowling from Nuwan Kulasekara was the definitive performance in a bizarre third ODI at the Gabba, where both captains would have batted first, but 100 may have been a winning total. Kulasekara took a career-best 5 for 22 as he damned Australia to 74 all out, with the aid of Lasith Malinga, who tore down the tail. Sri Lanka's run chase shaped as a straightforward one, but they lost six wickets before they reached their target, meaning 16 wickets had been lost in the day for 149 runs. Had Australia held early chances off Tillakaratne Dilshan and Lahiru Thirimanne, they may have won early the momentum to spark a heavier collapse, but instead the visitors limped home in the 20th over, with their last recognised batting pair at the crease. Having rested several key players for the first two matches, Australia returned to near-full strength at Brisbane, with Michael Clarke, David Warner and Matthew Wade arriving to bolster the batting, but none of them could make it to double figures.

Commentary_Highlights: Mendis to Hussey, 1 wide slides that one down the leg side and it's called a wide, goes straight on, no spin there Angelo Mathews to Maxwell, OUT Six down! Mathews strikes, lovely delivery, just outside off stump, drew the batsman forward with a good length and got it to nip away just a touch, Maxwell was committed to the drive as he walked forward, got a thin edge and Perera made no mistake behind the stumps Mendis to Haddin, 1 bye what a beauty, tossed up, lured Haddin forward for a defensive push, batsman leaves a massive gap between and pad, the ball spins in and bounces, somehow contrives to miss the stumps Malinga to Cutting, OUT gone! Malinga strikes, Perera takes his third catch, pitched up outside off and Cutting tries to drive it through cover, gets a thick edge and Perera dives to his right to snap that one Malinga to Kane Richardson, OUT Oh dear, a first baller on debut, a deceptive slower one from Malinga, Richardson didn't spot it, it died low on the batsman and Richardson missed it to be struck low on the pad, perhaps just in line with leg stump, he's got to go Perera to McKay, OUT appeal for a catch, short of a good length outside off, tries to open the face there to play it past point, it's given not out but the Sri Lankans have reviewed it, Hot Spot shows no heat signature, the umpire is taking his time to decide this, no real sound in live motion, the appeal was spontaneous but no strong technical evidence there of a Mendis to Haddin, OUT Haddin holes out, found deep midwicket, pitched on a length and he sensed a chance, swung it hard but flat and straight to Thirimanne in the deep Sri Lanka have an excellent chance of levelling this series now. Australia have been bowled out for a sub-par score, even on a track and in conditions that have favoured bowlers a bit more. Haddin's done a good job but his side has been bowled out with 19 balls to spare in the first innings. A collective bowling display from the visitors. Join us at around 6.30pm for the Hello all, we are ready for the chase now. Tharanga and Dilshan are out in the middle. The target is just 171. Bright sunshine in Adelaide. We start with two slips. McKay is the bowler. Kane Richardson to Dilshan, 1 leg bye sliding on the pads is Richardson, at 134.9kmph, tried to flick it square, didn't connect, did with the pads though Kane Richardson to Dilshan, 1 leg bye slightly short on leg stump, tries to turn it down, think it clipped the pads on the way down to fine leg Maxwell to Thirimanne, 1 wide fires that one down the leg side and it's a wide A comfortable win for Sri Lanka, each team dominating a game this series. The bowlers first did the job, and Dilshan and Thirimanne ensured there were no major hiccups in the chase of 171. Daniel Brettig's report should be ready soon. We don't have any coverage of the presentation. Thanks for tuning in and sending us your feedback, and we'll be back with you for the thir Sri Lanka won by 8 wickets (with 59 balls remaining) Player of the match is Lahiru Thirimanne, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 2 for 172 (Thirimanne 102*, Dilshan 51) beat Australia 170 (Haddin 50, Malinga 3-32) by 8 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Angelo Mathews formed part of a tight Sri Lankan bowling unit at Adelaide Oval Getty Images Sri Lanka's coach Graham Ford expected far better from his men after an abject display in the first ODI, and in Adelaide they duly delivered. A highly disciplined bowling ensemble laid bare Australian frailty against the seaming ball before Lahiru Thirimanne anchored a comfortable chase on a tacky pitch in the second match of the series at Adelaide Oval. The visitors lost Upul Tharanga in the first over of their chase but were largely untroubled thereafter, as the surface eased after earlier offering helpful seam movement for Sri Lanka's bowlers. Thirimanne reached a deserved century by cutting Xavier Doherty backward of point for the winning runs with eight wickets and 59 balls to spare, having been accompanied for much of the pursuit by an uncharacteristically reserved Tillakaratne Dilshan. Particular praise was also due to Nuwan Kulasekara and Angelo Mathews, who took the new balls and set Australia on the defensive by moving the ball just enough through the air and off the seam, while keeping the runs down.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and they will bat first. Mendis to Finch, OUT outside edge! Mendis strikes in his first over of his one-day comeback, it was bowled off the back of the hand, Finch was prodding forward, bounced a bit more and took the edge, no doubts about that Mendis to Khawaja, 1 wide that was too wide of the leg stump and he leaves it alone Mendis to Hughes, 1 wide fires that down the leg side and he doesn't offer a shot Starc to Upul Tharanga, 1 wide drifts down the leg side and wide called McKay to Mahela Jayawardene, OUT the captain goes! Good delivery by McKay, lands on a good length outside off, Jayawardene pokes his bat out and the edge goes to Finch at first slip Johnson to Dilshan, 1 wide short ball down the leg side and he shoulders arms Hussey to Dilshan, 1 bye beats him! Slower through the air from Hussey, drives and misses Starc to Chandimal, 1 wide strays too wide down the leg side Doherty to Jeevan Mendis, SIX runs take that! Tossed up on middle and leg and Mendis chips down the track and lofts him about 15 rows over deep midwicket Johnson to Jeevan Mendis, OUT soft dismissal! Length ball skids through and Mendis tries to launch it over the bowler's head, not in control and he miscues it to mid-off, easy catch to Bailey McKay to Chandimal, OUT superb catch by Haddin!
