That they got so close owed much to a considered half-century by David Hussey and a wrathful late assault by Brett Lee, who was struck on the arm by a beamer from Kemar Roach and, despite fulsome apologies, was sore enough in mind and body to take 24 from Roach's next over, following three fours with two sixes flayed over long-on.

Commentary_Highlights: Starc to Bairstow, OUT edged, gone! 90mph/145kph, pushed across the right-hander, and Bairstow nicks off. Starc had been hooping the ball into the batsmen but this one held its line and took the edge of Bairstow's apologetic prod. Australia get their breakthrough Marsh to Root, 1 leg bye fuller sliding down leg, misses the flick but it takes the pad to backward square leg and they get a single Zampa to Root, OUT caught at slip. The move works, both to bring in Zampa and to have a slip for the right-hander. Nicely tossed up, Root's taking a step forward, but the ball dips before he can get to the pitch and turns just enough to take the outside edge. Smart take from Finch, to his right. Cummins to Buttler, OUT trapped in front but Buttler reviews immediately. Inside edge? After moving the last one away, Cummins brought this one back in. Buttler was pushing at it and it beats his bat. No inside edge. Hits in line and umpire's call on hitting the stumps! Buttler will have to go, what a great bowling change once again from Finch. Zampa to Morgan, OUT huge shout not given and Finch reviews. Great loop on this, pitches on a length on middle and turns past his forward defensive to hit him on the knee roll. and it's three reds so that's a fabulous review and an extremely critical wicket. Excellent bowling. Drew him forward, got the ball to dip and turn enough to beat bat but not enough to be missing the stumps Zampa to Billings, OUT chopped on! Billings gave himself room to cut but this was too straight and cramped him for room. A flat legbreak, just a hint of turn and it zipped through, taking the bottom edge and diverted onto the stumps. Slightly fuller than Billings anticipated Starc to Sam Curran, OUT nicks him off! Or does he? Gough, standing in his first game since the third Test vs Pakistan, isn't sure if it carried through to Carey. Starc ran his fingers down the side of this, hitting a length on fifth stump, and drew an outside edge as Curran looked to steer towards third man. The catch is a tight call, but it looks like it's going to be given, as Carey had just about got his gloves under the ball. Curran Hazlewood to Woakes, OUT length ball in the channel, and Woakes is the latest man to nick off! Classic Hazlewood, banged in on a length on fourth or fifth stump, and there's just a fraction of movement away off the seam. That's enough to take the edge as Woakes shapes to punch through the covers, and Carey gobbles up an easy chance. England reeling at 149 for 8! Cummins to Rashid, 1 wide short ball, which Rashid ducks underneath, and Saggers says it's too far down the leg side, much to Cummins' chagrin Cummins to Rashid, SIX runs banged in, back of a length, and Rashid swats at it, sending it over the rope for six! Didn't quite get up as he'd have liked, and Rashid cleared the front leg, hooking towards the shorter boundary. The wind carried it over Labuschagne on the rope, and it's half a dozen more! Marsh to Tom Curran, 1 wide slower ball bouncer at the left shoulder, Curran swings at it but can't get bat on it. Gough has a long think, and belatedly calls wide Archer to Stoinis, OUT that is just amazing fast bowling Short leg was put in place so the batsman was expecting a short one, but Archer is so quick and so accurate that he manages to get a wicket with a short ball anyway. Banged in back of a length and hisses up like a cobra towards Stoinis who is all in a tangle against that. Fends awkwardly and it takes the shoulder of the bat to loop up for an easy catch behind him. Archer's bowling w Sam Curran to Labuschagne, 1 wide loopy bouncer outside the off stump at 84mph/135kph. Labuschagne lets it go, and it's called wide Archer to Labuschagne, 1 leg bye cross-seamer which nips away from Labuschagne as he looks to work to leg. He yelps in pain as he is struck on the back thigh pad, and Archer lets out a wry smile Woakes to Labuschagne, OUT trapped on the pad, Woakes lets out a desperate appeal but Gough says no. Morgan reviews immediately. This struck both pads as he looked to work a length ball to leg, but crucially hit the front one first. No bat, Ultra-Edge confirms. Hits him in line, and would have smashed into middle two-thirds of the way up! Marnus has to trudge off, and Woakes has the breakthrough Tom Curran to Cummins, 1 leg bye back of a length on leg stump, takes the pads to roll towards leg gully Rashid to Hazlewood, 1 leg bye quick single taken. Tossed up googly that Hazlewood didn't read, was trying to tickle it fine, goes into the offside Player of the match is Jofra Archer, ENG
Match_Report: England 231 for 9 (Morgan 42, Zampa 3-36) beat Australia 207 (Finch 73, Labuschagne 48, Woakes 3-32, Archer 3-34, S Curran 3-35) by 24 runs England's bowlers answered every question asked of them to snatch an unlikely victory and level the series 1-1 as Australia capitulated in the second ODI at Emirates Old Trafford. Chris Woakes and Jofra Archer gave England every hope of avoiding their first bilateral ODI series defeat at home since 2015 by claiming three crucial wickets each before Sam Curran chimed in with three wickets of his own after a staggering Australian collapse to seal the win and keep the series alive going into Wednesday's final encounter. Aaron Finch and Marnus Labuschagne put on 107 for the third wicket to build on the solid foundation set by Australia's bowlers, who restricted England until a late partnership worth 76 between Rashid and Tom Curran gave the hosts something to bowl at. Chasing 232 for victory after England had won the toss, Australia stumbled to 37 for 2 and then lost four wickets in the space of 21 balls - three of them to Woakes - to give England more than a sniff of the victory which had seemed so distant after their performance with the bat and again when Finch and Labuschagne were cruising. Archer defied a used pitch which had been keeping low with devastating speed and bounce in an excellent five-over opening spell which delivered 2 for 22.

Commentary_Highlights: Sammy to Warner, OUT this time the edge finds a man and Warner is gone! He leaned into a cover drive but the ball didn't quite reach him as quickly as he expected, Warner stretching and the ball flying off the toe to the safe hands of Pollard at point Roach to Hussey, 1 leg bye outside leg, pushed through midwicket Samuels to Bailey, OUT swings hard on the pull - but he's sent it straight into the hands of square leg! It was a clean connection but unfortunately for Bailey he picked out Dwayne Bravo, who coolly pockets the ball Samuels to Hussey, OUT got him! Cannily done by Samuels, dragging his length down as Hussey advanced, getting a bit of bounce past the bat and leaving Hussey stranded. Baugh does the handiwork Roach to Hussey, OUT Another one goes - a fabulous slower ball from Roach castles the younger Hussey! The batsman backed away, aiming for a swipe down the ground, but Roach rolled his fingers over it, the ball dying as it reached the crease before spinning into middle stump, half way up Roach to Lee, OUT two in the over! Lee plays on! Roach sent down another slower ball, this not as well-directed, but the pace did for Lee who was through his windy drive too quickly, getting a thick bottom edge on to the timbers Roach to McKay, 1 leg bye steered into the leg side Roach to Christian, OUT Darren Bravo shows footballing skills Dwight Yorke would be proud of to run out Doherty! Christian dropped it short on the off side, Bravo hared in and side-footed the ball into the stumps from about six yards. GOOOOOAL! Narine to Christian, SIX runs this time he connects! That's huge six - though he was nowhere near the pitch. He simply stood and smoked it over long-on Narine to Christian, OUT Christian is given out lbw - but he calls for the review. It hit the batsman full on the toe, in front of leg stump. Christian was hoping it was sliding down leg ... but it didn't have far to go and the replays suggest the ball would have thunked into the stump. He has to walk and West Indies have rounded up the last six 1.05pm: That's a quite remarkable comeback from West Indies, after toiling for so long in the heat of the Hussey-Bailey axis.They claimed the first three wickets for 58 and the last seven for 50 - but the filling in Australia's sandwich was pretty meaty. Have the hosts' bowlers done enough for the batsmen to win it? Find out with me and George in about We're all set to begin. Johnson Charles and Kieran Powell to open for West Indies. Brett Lee with the new ball, from over the wicket. West Indies will need to score the highest total of the series to win this game. Australia are playing the extra spinner today as well. It won't be easy for the hosts. Doherty to Powell, SIX runs shot! Powell goes down the pitch, didn't get to the pitch of the ball but still hoisted it off his pads over the midwicket boundary Doherty to Powell, OUT he's been stumped now! He came down the track again, once again didn't get to the pitch of the ball, and was beaten by the straighter one. He pushed forward to try and defend but was beaten as the ball skidded past his outside edge. Wade whipped off the bails with the batsman well short Watson to Samuels, OUT that looks plumb lbw and the umpire agrees. Samuels is on his way, he's decided not to review. Watson pitched full and straight, Samuels defended from his crease, as he usually does. He missed and was hit around the knee roll on the back pad. Absolutely plumb. That held its line instead of angling into the right-hander Lyon to Charles, SIX runs that is a colossal hit into the stands beyond long-off, Charles came down the track, wasn't to the pitch of the ball, but still swung hard, freeing his arms. He made good contact and timed it beautifully Lee to Pollard, SIX runs full toss and BOOMED out of the ground! Pollard set his shoulders and swung straight through the line, sending the ball whistling back over Lee's head - and over the roof of the stand at long-on Lyon to Russell, 1 leg bye straighter line, pops up off the pitch and loops past short leg off a pad Christian to Baugh, 1 wide fuller length but the line is down leg side Watson to Baugh, 1 leg bye shorter length angling into the body, Baugh fends towards square Doherty to Baugh, 1 wide he's fired that down leg side and Wade yelps in pain because that ball's smacked him on the knee cap Watson to Russell, (no ball) Watson's 150th wicket is likely to be a game-breaking one. The pressure tells on Russell, he backs away and slogs at a good length and straight ball. He misses and Watson hits the stumps. Russell begins to walk off but then waits, the umpire wants to check if Watson has over stepped. He has! Huge break for West Ind Lee to Narine, OUT splendid catch at short cover! David Hussey throws the ball in the air in celebration. Length delivery angling into the right-hander from round the wicket, Narine drove at it and hit the ball on the up, he middled it but the ball went straight to Hussey who took a low catch 5.30 pm West Indies were out of this contest having lost five wickets for very little but they've fought back admirably. They couldn't quite get over the line though, so the series remains 1-1 with two to play. Match tied Player of the match is Michael Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 220 (M Hussey 67, Bailey 59, Narine 3-32) tied with West Indies 220 (Charles 45, Watson 3-30) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Shane Watson and Darren Sammy shake hands - but neither was satisfied by the result Associated Press Any lingering thoughts of a Caribbean holiday were swept decisively away from Australia by a thrilling and courageous West Indies chase to force a dramatic tie at a heaving Arnos Vale Ground. Tuesday had been declared a public holiday in St Vincent and a sold-out crowd was kept on its feet throughout as the two sides finished locked on 220 apiece on a pitch almost as lively for spin bowling as for dancing at the boundary's edge. The West Indies needed only one run from the final three deliveries to be bowled by Brett Lee, but a mix-up between the captain Darren Sammy and the last man Kemar Roach saw both stranded at the striker's end as Lee broke the stumps at his. However, the hosts' fight to level the scores having been mired as deeply as 78 for 5 will provide plenty of belief for Sammy's men, while also showing Australia's players that they cannot afford to misstep quite so badly as they have done at times in the three matches so far. This time the fault lay with the batsmen, who squandered the best of the conditions and failed completely to cope with the crafty spin of Sunil Narine.

Commentary_Highlights: 9.20am: The coin has been tossed - and Darren Sammy has won it (for the first time in 10 attempts, no less). He's decided West Indies will have a bowl, perhaps influenced by the conditions. I'm presuming he has not based his decision on the success of his team's chasing a Roach to Warner, OUT bowled him! The delivery was back of a length but shot through low, clipping Warner's pad as he tried to play back before rattling into the stumps halfway up. The batsman was done by the bounce (or lack thereof) - but he had already misjudged a c Roach to Forrest, OUT another one gone! Roach lures Forrest into a jab outside off, the bat well away from his body, and a thick edge is safely pouched by second slip Bravo to Hussey, 1 wide down the leg side, Bravo losing his radar Sammy to Watson, SIX runs shot! Sammy was a fraction short and Watson seized on it like a prizefighter spotting a gap in his opponent's guard, swinging an uppercut over the deep midwicket fence for a Dorothy Sammy to Watson, OUT Watson falls to the slower ball! Sammy rolled it out of the hand again - though it almost turned into a full toss - and Watson's clip flew off the toe of the bat to Devendra Bishoo, the substitute fielder, who took a low catch at midwicket Narine to Hussey, OUT he's been caught behind! Narine bowled it quicker and pitched it fuller, Hussey came forward to drive and edged it as the ball spun across him. Baugh took a sharp catch. He had little reaction time. Bravo to Bailey, OUT caught at point! Bailey's cut the slower ball straight to the fielder. Bravo pitched it short of a length outside off and got the ball to bounce a bit more - tennis-ball type bounce Narine to Hussey, 1 leg bye lots of turn into the right-hander but the ball ends up on the pads, allowing the batsman to work it behind square Narine to Wade, OUT Wade lunged on to the front foot and tried to slog sweep, top-edging the ball in the air to Roach at square leg Narine to Hussey, OUT bowled him! Two in the over. Hussey went back to cut and the ball spun back into him, inducing the bottom edge on to the stumps Narine to Lee, 1 bye Lee backs away outside leg and then tries to hit through midwicket. He misses and the ball goes between body and leg stump and beats the keeper Narine to McKay, OUT McKay's been stumped. He charged out of his crease and swung hard, the flat and quicker ball sped past the bat, and Baugh had an easy job to do Lee to Powell, OUT that's an abysmal leave! Lee's first ball is straight, on a good length and Powell shoulders arms! He's stuck in his crease, smack bang in front and that's the easiest decision Gregory Brathwaite has ever had to make, I imagine. What a start - West Watson to Samuels, OUT full ball ... yorked him! Looked like Watson might have rolled that out the back of the hand but Samuels played over the top of the ball and the bails pinged into the air as if popped from a toaster Watson to Bravo, 1 wide slanted down the leg side - another extra to the West Indies total Doherty to Bravo, OUT this was inevitable. Darren Bravo has been bowled off the inisde edge trying to drive the ball through cover. Doherty tossed the ball up outside off stump from round the wicket, drawing the batsmen into driving away from his body. Bravo reached Christian to Pollard, SIX runs after five dot balls, Christian drops one short and Pollard is quick to capitalise, staying back and heaving the ball over the midwicket boundary So, we now have a contest, with episode three scheduled for Tuesday; do join us again then. Bye! West Indies won by 5 wickets (with 10 balls remaining) (D/L method) Player of the match is Sunil Narine, WI
Match_Report: West Indies 163 for 5 in 38.2 overs (Pollard 47*) beat Australia 154 for 9 in 40 overs (David Hussey 37, Narine 4-27) by five wickets on D/L method Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Dwayne Bravo's 30 was an important contribution to West Indies' victory Associated Press Kieron Pollard blazed West Indies to a first ODI victory over Australia since 2006, his stand with Dwayne Bravo swallowing up the tourists' modest total in a rain-affected match at the Arnos Vale Ground. Set the Duckworth/Lewis-adjusted target of 158 from 40 overs after holding Australia to 154 for 9, the hosts made the worst possible start when Kieran Powell shouldered arms to Brett Lee's first ball of the innings and was palpably lbw. But from an uncertain 74 for 4, Pollard and Dwayne Bravo constructed the most assured stand of the match, and took West Indies to a deserved win with five wickets and 11 balls to spare. Pollard's innings was punctuated by three sixes in one critical four-over burst, and it was a spell of scoring that would prove decisive.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss, 9.00 am Shane Watson has won the toss and Australia are going to bat. Bravo to Watson, 1 wide short ball and far down leg side, that's the first extra of the day Bravo to Watson, 1 wide that's another wide down leg side, two in as many overs for Bravo Bravo to Watson, OUT this time the umpire's given Watson lbw and Australia have asked for a review. It's quite similar to the appeal in Bravo's first over, which the umpire said was not out and West Indies reviewed unsuccessfully. Watson came half-forward to a delivery that nipped into him off the pitch. He was beaten on the front-foot defence and hit in front Russell to Warner, 1 wide a wide down leg side, the third of the innings Samuels to Forrest, OUT breakthrough for West Indies. Forrest's struggles are over. He came down the pitch and the ball beat the outside to provide Baugh the chance of a simple stumping. Samuels to Warner, OUT gone! Superb catch from Pollard and two in the over for Samuels. Warner punched it off the back foot and Pollard flung himself low to his left at cover to grab it inches from the turf. Anything in the air near Pollard is always dangerous, he's an incredible fielder. Roach to Hussey, 1 leg bye wow, where did that come from? An excellent bouncer from Roach which really climbed and took Hussey on the shoulder as he tried to sway out of the line. Baugh took the catch and West Indies were confident, but a good decision from umpire Dharmasena Roach to Hussey, OUT West Indies right on top now. In the channel outside off from Roach, Hussey pushed without much footwork and got a thin edge to the keeper Roach to Bailey, OUT Bailey's fallen two short of a half-century on debut. He backed away towards leg to create room and hit on the off side. He ended up scooping the ball high in the air and the fielder from the cover-point boundary came in to take a well-judged catch Doherty to Samuels, SIX runs that's been dropped beyond the long-off boundary! Samuels stepped out of his crease and blasted the ball flat and far, hitting it with a lot of power Doherty to Samuels, SIX runs that's the biggest of them all, Samuels has stepped out of his crease, got to the pitch of the ball, and lofted it straight over the bowler's head again, I don't think we'll be seeing Doherty during the Powerplay any more Christian to Bravo, OUT and there's his reward! A lovely delivery from Christian, another off-cutter which bites in the surface and zips between bat and pad to take off stump. Bit of a loose shot, but credit to the bowler for his consistency. Just what Australia needed as West Indies had settled nicely with this stand Lee to Roach, 1 wide pushed too far outside leg stump and an easy call for a wide McKay to Sammy, 1 wide starts with a slower-ball gone wrong that loops out well wide of off stump Australia, though, will be delighted with the winning start on a tricky surface. The batting wasn't and its best but they mustered a decent total. Early wickets then gave them a lift then Doherty responded superbly from a tough first over that cost 18. Player of the match is George Bailey, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 204 for 8 (Bailey 48, Bravo 3-58) beat West Indies 140 (Sammy 35, Samuels 35, Doherty 4-49) by 64 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details George Bailey's 48 on debut proved very important for Australia AFP Xavier Doherty enjoyed his first taste of cricket in the West Indies, playing a key role in Australia's 64-run victory in the first ODI in St Vincent. After the debutant George Bailey top scored in Australia's 204 for 8, a total that was difficult to assess at the halfway point on a sluggish pitch, West Indies capitulated to be all out for 140, and their failure was all the more disappointing for the self-inflicted nature of several of the dismissals. Batting was clearly not easy on a surface with such little pace, but too few of the West Indian batsmen showed the discipline required to stick around and chip away at the target. Darren Sammy displayed some late fight and compiled a 36-run partnership for the last wicket with Kemar Roach, but until that point they had lost their previous six wickets for seven runs. Prior to that collapse, the chase appeared to be going well as Dwayne Bravo and Marlon Samuels built a confident 64-run stand and went after the spin of Doherty and David Hussey.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Sri Lanka have won the toss and they have opted to bowl first. They are not playing a second spinner, so Dilshan should bowl his quota. Watson says he would have batted anyway. He will continue to bat at No.3. Forrest returns. Kulasekara to Wade, 1 wide Sanga has done well to stop four certain wides there, too wide down the leg side Maharoof to Warner, OUT Sri Lanka will be mighty relieved at that because it's Warner! Things get a little tasty as Maharoof walks past the batsman, Maharoof angles it across the left-hander, the batsman gets a thick outside edge and it's well taken by Sanga falling to his left, Maharoof says something to Warner who Dilshan to Watson, 1 wide that was too wide down the leg side, poor ball Kulasekara to Wade, OUT direct hit and he's gone! Excellent work by Dilshan there, Wade sliced it down towards short point and wasn't sure about the single, Hussey was off the blocks but Dilshan was too quick for him, picks up and throws flat at the stumps in one motion, just short of his ground and the third umpire Kulasekara to Hussey, 1 leg bye drifts on the pads and he tucks it towards square leg Herath to Wade, OUT can't keep Herath out for too long! Strikes with ball No.1, comes round the wicket, Wade makes room to cut but he ends up getting a thick outside edge, good reflexes nevertheless as he takes it in the second attempt. Good knock by Wade Herath to Forrest, OUT Forrest looked quite flummoxed there! Herath got it to grip and Forrest was looking to drive towards mid-off but the ball spun just a bit and hit the off stump, Forrest playing down the wrong line Maharoof to Hussey, OUT hits him a touch high but Asad Rauf's convinced! Maharoof gets it to nip back in off the pitch, the ball skids through and hits his thigh but Rauf was convinced with the height, took a few seconds before raising the finger Malinga to Lee, 1 wide loses control of that slower delivery and sprays it wide of the off stump Maharoof to Christian, OUT Maharoof strikes again! He continues bowling the slower ball, Christian chips down the track and has to check his shot, ends up spooning it straight to mid-off, Jayawardene takes it Herath to McKay, OUT McKay perishes trying to go over the top on the on side, he gets on his knee for the slog and he ends up hitting it flat to Maharoof at deep midwicket, he falls forward and takes it Kulasekara to Lee, OUT knocks off the leg bail! Kula bowls another yorker on the leg stump, Lee makes room to flay that anywhere but the ball hits his boot and shaves the leg stump Kulasekara to Lyon, OUT not the best start to Lyon's ODI career with the bat! Kulasekara bowls it full on the pads and Lyon makes room and chips it high over midwicket and Senanayake the substitute times the dive well and takes the catch Still, such is the nature of these teams that even 231 might turn out to be competitive. Don't count Australia out yet. They will come out charging. Whatever it is, we should expect another absorbing chase. Join us in 30 minutes. There was some debate whether SL gambled by not taking the extra spinner, but Maharoof responded well and justified his inclusion. It could have been a lot worse for Australia, if not for their lower order. McKay to Chandimal, OUT and there is no escaping the dreaded finger this time around! Fuller ball on the off and middle line. Chandimal leans across and looks to flick it. He misjudges the length and is struck on the pads.The umpire doesn't waste a second in raising the index finger. Sri Lanka does need the batting de Christian to Upul Tharanga, 1 leg bye drifts on the pads and he clips it off his legs to the on side Lee to Upul Tharanga, 1 wide he ducks under that quick bouncer and the umpire penalises him Doherty to Upul Tharanga, 4 wide slides it down the leg side and it beats the keeper Watson to Upul Tharanga, 1 leg bye full on the pads and he clips it with his legs to deep square leg Lee to Kulasekara, 5 wide big lapse from Lee as he sprays this one wide down the leg side and beats the diving Wade, can't blame the keeper at all Presentation time: Player of the match is Clint McKay, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 231 (Wade 49, Warner 48, Herath 3-36, Maharoof 3-40) beat Sri Lanka 215 (Tharanga 71, McKay 5-28) by 16 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Clint McKay's career-best effort wrecked Sri Lanka's chase AFP Smart stats Australia won the tri-series for the first time since their triumph in 2005-06. In the previous two finals in 2006-07 and 2007-08, Australia had lost to England and India. It is also their 19th win in the tri-series overall. For the first time in the last four finals (when the decider was required), a team went on to win the third final and take the series after losing the second. In their three previous wins against South Africa (1993-94 and 1997-98) and Sri Lanka (2005-06), Australia lost the first final but went on to win the second and third.

Commentary_Highlights: Dilshan to Wade, OUT bowled him! Dilshan's been skidding his balls through to the batsman, and Wade tried to pull this one when it wasn't that short, he missed and Dilshan hit off stump Maharoof to Warner, SIX runs Warner's smashed it! He wound up and swung hard at a length ball on the front foot, clearing the wide long-on boundary comfortably. That's a long boundary at Adelaide Oval and Warner hit the ball into the stands. That was measured at 99 metres. A monster of a hit. Herath to Clarke, 1 wide that's down leg side and a wide Malinga to Hussey, OUT bowled him! Hussey comes out of his crease and towards the leg side, trying to drive through the off. Malinga beats him with a full and fast ball and hits the stumps Malinga to Hussey, OUT bowled him, Malinga lands another perfect yorker and beats Hussey's slog with the swing into the right-hander, the ball clips leg stump 5.20 pm Australia have finished with a strong total on a slowish pitch, with Clarke and Warner scoring contrasting centuries. Warner was the slower one, Clarke was quick and quite terrific. Sri Lanka were poor in the field, several fumbles, some overthrows and five dropped catches. They aren't out of this yet though, because Australia could have easily Brett Lee will opening the bowling for Australia, from over the wicket. Lee to Mahela Jayawardene, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, Mahela plays the glance from his crease towards fine leg McKay to Mahela Jayawardene, (no ball) caught behind! But the umpire is checking to see if it's a front-foot no-ball. It is, McKay had overstepped. It was a wide ball outside off and Mahela slashed at it, reaching far away from his body. He got a thick edge through to the keeper. The Australians began to celebrate but the umpire Bruce Oxenford Pattinson to Dilshan, 3 wide whoa, that's sprayed far down leg side, massive swing past the right-hander and Wade does superbly to dive to his left and get some glove on it McKay to Dilshan, 1 leg bye another slower ball, Dilshan tries to turn the ball towards the leg side but gets hit on the thigh for a leg bye on the off side Pattinson to Dilshan, 1 wide a full ball on the pads, Wade dives to his left to collect 9.30 pm As far as chases of substantial totals go, this is as strong as they come. Sri Lanka, through a poor performance in the field, were faced with a target of 272 and they've gunned it down with eight wickets in hand and 34 balls to spare. It's been a memorable performance from Jayawardene, Dilshan and the rest. Dilshan is the obvious choice for Ma Sri Lanka won by 8 wickets (with 34 balls remaining) Player of the match is Tillakaratne Dilshan, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 2 for 274 (Dilshan 106, Jayawardene 80) beat Australia 6 for 271 (Clarke 117, Warner 100) by eight wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Tillakaratne Dilshan hits ten fours in his 106 Getty Images Mahela Jayawardene and Tillakaratne Dilshan took full toll of a wayward Australia as Sri Lanka forced a third triangular series final in Adelaide. Chasing 272, the visitors galloped to the target with 5.4 overs to spare, benefiting greatly from a rollicking start when the first three overs reaped 30 runs. Dilshan alternated between the brazen and the cheeky, crashing 10 fours and also being struck on the helmet when he attempted his patented Dil-scoop. The captain Jayawardene was more cultured, but outpaced his partner in a princely innings that would have ended in the second over if not for a Clint McKay no-ball.

Commentary_Highlights: Kulasekara to Wade, OUT An outstanding catch by Herath, for a moment it seemed Wade had struck it cleanly to send it over the ropes but it wasn't timed as well as initially thought, Herath was at long-on and Wade had enough on it to get it past him as he was standing a few yards inside the ropes, Herath thou Malinga to Warner, SIX runs Six, Malinga bowls it short on middle with a fine leg up, Warner stays his ground and pulls it well behind square and it has enough on it to clear the ropes, just about Maharoof to Watson, OUT Watson goes, it's been a quiet Powerplay so far, that landed on leg stump, was a slower ball, tried to flick it square but ended up playing uppishly and it appeared to come off the top edge as well, Thirimanne ran in from deep square leg and took a safe catch Prasad to Christian, OUT Christian goes! Reiffel upholds the appeal, bowled on a good length and it nipped back in, Christian walked into the shot, got a faint inside edge and Sangakkara dived to his left to take a good low catch Herath to Hussey, OUT David Hussey's gone! Tossed up and Hussey was drawn into playing the drive, a soft dismissal in the end, pushes it straight back to the bowler who takes it sharply, timing his jump well Herath to Clarke, 1 wide fires it down the leg side and it's called a wide Malinga to Hussey, SIX runs superbly timed, got under it this time, was a length ball and right in the slot, he made room and lofted it cleanly over the long-off boundary Prasad to Warner, OUT bowled'im! Was the offcutter, landed on leg and cut away as he tried to pull that over midwicket, missed and the stumps were pegged back Warner almost batted out the 50 overs, Australia are on top with an imposing score thanks to Warner's knock. There is some swing for the bowlers and some movement, and Sri Lanka face a difficult task to chase this down. Wade led the way with an attacking start and Warner dropped anchor to set up this total. Join us Tillakaratne Dilshan and Mahela Jaywardene are out in the middle, we are set for the chase Lee to Mahela Jayawardene, 1 wide Brett Lee starts with one down the leg side Doherty to Upul Tharanga, 2 wide slightly short down the leg side, Wade fumbles, Maharoof wanted the bye, Tharana sent him back, Wade's throw to the bowler was a slightly wayward one and they managed to steal a single off an overthrow Pattinson to Upul Tharanga, (no ball) a slower ball gone bad, slipped out of his hand and called a no-ball, well above waist height Hilfenhaus to Kulasekara, SIX runs Kulasekara is stepping up now, good length ball on middle, made a bit of room and swung it cleanly over the deep midwicket boundary Christian to Upul Tharanga, 1 leg bye a fullish delivery on leg stump, tried to clip it square, steals a leg bye as it strikes him on the pads Lee to Upul Tharanga, 2 wide Tharanga will be disappointed he didn't get that away, full delivery outside leg stump and all he needed was a bit of bat on it, nevertheless he gets a wide Watson to Herath, OUT Watson has struck, Herath is dismissed as he goes for his favourite slog shot, a length delivery is struck well by Herath, but Doherty had cleverly been placed well short of the rope, it ends up as a simple catch, only one wicket in hand now, Malinga was off-colour with the ball can he Watson to Malinga, OUT Another slower one, Malinga swings it high but not far enough and finds deep square leg where Michael Hussey judges it well, Australia win the first final. Struck that really high did Malinga, didn't get hold but he had no choice but to go for it. Clarke heaves a sigh of relief, his te An exciting finish to a game that appeared to be one-sided when Sri Lanka were reduced to 144 for 6 in the chase. Kulasekara triggered the fightback in the company of Tharanga, the former the aggressor and Tharanga the anchor who was expected to stay on till the end. Prasad kept the fight on with Tharanga but Thara Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 6 for 321 (Warner 163, Wade 64) beat Sri Lanka 306 (Kulasekara 73, Tharanga 60, D Hussey 4-43, Watson 3-33, Lee 3-59) by 15 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details David Warner made 163 from 157 balls Getty Images David Warner chose a fine time to awaken from his one-day international slumber. His first ODI century set up a 15-run victory in the first final for Australia, who will raise the Commonwealth Bank Series trophy if they repeat their success in Adelaide on Tuesday. But Sri Lanka will enter the second final with some confidence after a remarkable, though ultimately futile, fightback in a chase of 322. Warner made 163, the sixth-highest score by an Australia player in an ODI, and he batted through until the last ball of the innings as they made 321, the second-best one-day international total ever achieved at the Gabba. Sri Lanka's batsmen then struggled against the pace of Brett Lee and the canny spin of David Hussey, and the top order left too much work for those who followed.

Commentary_Highlights: McKay to Chandimal, 2 leg byes that's a super slow ball out of the back of the hand at 108kph, Chandimal gets beaten by the change of pace but the ball brushes his pad and goes towards fine leg Pattinson to Sangakkara, OUT caught at deep square leg! Short of a length delivery that hurried Sangakkara who began to swivel pull but then checked his shot, the ball went off the top edge high in the air and straight to Peter Forrest. The partnership ends on 123, it's been a splendid one. Pattinson to Chandimal, OUT caught at mid-off! Chandimal's gone this time. He was on the front foot and he tried to hit down the ground, the length wasn't short enough for that shot and he holed out to McKay at mid-off. He's made 75, an excellent innings. Pattinson's taken his third wicket. Christian to Angelo Mathews, OUT caught, splendidly caught! The ball was a slightly slower one outside off stump and Mathews was on the front foot and into his shot too early. He tried to check it but ended up spooning the ball in the air down the ground. Doherty ran quickly from mid-on towards the boundary, covered a lot of ground, and took the catch as the ball dropped over his head McKay to Thirimanne, 1 leg bye nudged off the pads behind square for a single Christian to Perera, OUT caught on the deep midwicket boundary! Michael Hussey takes a special kind of catch, one that is becoming less rare these days. Perera swung hard and hit the ball high towards deep midwicket, Hussey ran back and settled under the ball and took the catch inside play. He realised he was going to go over the boundary so he threw the ball up, stepped over the rope, stepped back in, and caught the ball again. Christian to Senanayake, OUT lbw! The ball is full and straight, Senanayake moves across his crease and tries to play on the leg side by closing the face of his bat, he misses and is hit in front, that would have clipped leg stump Christian to Kulasekara, OUT a hat-trick for Christian! He bowled a full ball that swung into the right-hander, Kulasekara did what Senanayake did, moved across and tried to flick. He missed and got hit on the pad, this looked like it was missing leg but the umpire didn't think so. Christian is mobbed by his team-mates. Pattinson to Herath, SIX runs Herath swings hard at a length ball outside off and gets a top edge that flies down to third man and clears the boundary. Doesn't matter how they come, eh? That ball landed on the rope Pattinson to Thirimanne, OUT he's been bowled off the middle of the bat! Thirimanne moved across his stumps to try and scoop the ball over fine leg, he made decent contact, but deflected the ball on to his stumps Christian to Herath, 1 bye Herath swings and misses, Wade collects and throws at the bowler's end and misses, he concedes an overthrow towards long-off Christian to Malinga, OUT bowled him! Christian finishes with five wickets. Malinga moved way across his stumps to glance towards fine leg and he missed. The ball was straight and hit middle stump. 6.10 pm Sri Lanka have finished with 238, a score that is less than par on this pitch. They were set for at least 40 more when Sangakkara and Chandimal were steering the innings. But they fell away after that partnership. Christian wrecked the innings with a hat-trick and finished with 5 for 31. Pattinson was making a comeback from injury and he took four wickets as well. Malinga to Wade, 1 wide that is a harsh call for wide outside off stump, it wasn't outside those guiding tram lines Kulasekara to Wade, OUT lbw! Kulasekara pitched the ball in line with the stumps from over the wicket and angled it across the left-hander, Wade moved across his crease to play on the leg side and was hit on the back pad. Height might have been the only issue but that looked pretty good. The umpire thought so too. The MCG comes to life, there are so many Sri Lankan fans today and they are cheering themselves hoarse. Replays indicate that height was no p Kulasekara to Forrest, 1 wide that's down leg side and Sangakkara leaps to his left to collect Malinga to Hussey, 5 wide Malinga loses his line, firing it down leg side, Sangakkara should have stopped that though, but it's cost Sri Lanka five extras Herath to Watson, 1 wide bowled flat and down leg side, that's a wide Dilshan to Hussey, 2 wide his first ball is short and extremely far down leg side Senanayake to Pattinson, 1 wide that's down leg side and a wide Kulasekara to Hussey, OUT Sri Lanka have won! Hussey has been caught at long off, and listen to the MCG erupt! Mahela Jayawardene is ecstatic. Hussey decided to attack Kulasekara and lofted him down the ground, he hit the full ball flat but not far enough, Dilshan was the man at long-off and he held the catch to send the fans at the MCG into wild celebrations. Sri Lanka have played a tremendous game and are in the finals Dinesh Chandimal is the Man of the Match for his half-century. He's the top scorer of the series, and batted with admirable temperament today after Sri Lanka had lost two early wickets. He scored briskly, taking pressure of Sangakkara, and kept Sri Lanka going. 10.25 pm Sri Lanka needed to prevent Australia from winning to make the finals of the triangular series. They were on course for a huge total before the middle and lower order failed and they finished on 238. Mahela Jayawardene then lost two bowlers, Perera to a side strain and Mathews to a calf injury. He kept his nerve and maintained attacking fields throughout to lead his team to a superb victory. They have qualified for the final on top of the league. A f Player of the match is Dinesh Chandimal, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 238 (Chandimal 75, Sangakkara 64, Thirimanne 51, Christian 5-31, Pattinson 4-51) beat Australia 229 (D Hussey 74, Watson 65, Malinga 4-49) by nine runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Daniel Christian picked up a hat-trick, but it was Sri Lanka who finished on top Getty Images Sri Lanka entered this match with their fate in their own hands. It turns out those are pretty safe hands. Not even a hat-trick from Daniel Christian, a four-wicket comeback from James Pattinson, a captain's half-century from Shane Watson or a remarkable, late, fighting fifty from David Hussey could prevent Sri Lanka from winning the last qualifying match at the MCG. Lasith Malinga led a strong bowling performance to complete Sri Lanka's nine-run victory, which propelled them into the tri-series finals. No doubt Australia were disappointed, for they must now enter the best-of-three deciders knowing they have lost their previous three games to their Sri Lankan opponents.

Commentary_Highlights: Shilling to Ponting, OUT inside edge and gone! You have to say that was coming with the amount of turn and bounce that is available here. Ponting was a long way forward, the turn took the outside edge and possibly glove, loopin to leg slip who took an easy Shilling to Clarke, OUT I mentioned more of Shillingford to Clarke and now he's gone caught at short leg once again quick turn, bounce and straight to short leg off the gloves who pouches an easy chance. The home-town boy producing the goods here... Shilling to Hussey, OUT this is edged and taken at slip! A fine diving catch from Darren Sammy going to his left but again the bounce providing the gloved deflection and Sammy leap across to take it. Hussey forward to block but the bounce that Shillingford Shilling to Harris, 1 leg bye big appeal for lbw as Harris comes forward, probably outside the line Roach to Harris, OUT short, hooked at, takes the glove and caught! Another wicket and Harris was late on the stroke and not in control, easy catch for the keeper and the finger goes up straight away Rampaul to Starc, 1 wide bangs it in short and the bouncer sails over him, he's penalised for it Shilling to Wade, OUT caught at the boundary edge and excellent presence of mind by Bravo! And it's a five-for for Shillingford as well, Wade goes another of his slogs but doesn't get the distance, went flatter to deep midwicket and Bravo caught it, threw Shilling to Hilfenhaus, OUT well make that six for Shillingford! Tossed up generously and Hilfenhaus tries to hoick him away over the on side, misses it and the ball hits the middle stump Paul pointed out that England's Phil DeFreitas was also born in Dominica. Lunch: So West Indies just about sneak in the last two wickets before lunch. They really should have done a lot better and the inability to finish things off will be addressed before they leave for England. Warner to Bravo, OUT and he goes to a part-timer! Simplest of catches, Bravo is forward to defend but he doesn't cover the line properly, big inside edge onto the pads, lobs up and Cowan had all the time in the world to catch it Lyon to Powell, OUT short but dragged it on a real bonus wicket for Australia. Maybe it kept a touch low but the cut stroke has dragged a back of a length ball onto the base of off stump and that is a poor dismissal and a major blow for the West Indies Harris to Deonarine, 1 bye bouncer, ducked and fumbled by the keeper Lyon to Baugh, OUT bat, pad and taken at short leg and heavens are the Aussie's on top now! Once again in this game the bounce does for the batsman, playing forward pops up a catch to short leg who pouches a very easy chance and the finger goes up immediat Starc to Chanderpaul, OUT full toss and ran into off side, oh they take a single...direct hit....surely gone! Yes, great work in the covers, Sammy's full length dive is not enough and West Indies slump again and what a silly way to give away another wicket Starc to Shilling, OUT bowled first ball! A fabulous full, inswinging delivery that is far too good for Shillingford, he's so late on it and didn't move his feet, getting a little inside edge onto the off stump Hilfenhaus to Rampaul, 1 leg bye ducks a bumper and off the helmet, flush blow on the lid Lyon to Rampaul, OUT Lyon has his fourth, and Rampaul has gotten himself out needlessly, came down the track to try and hit Lyon over midwicket, against the spin, and with so much turn around for the offspinner, Rampaul manages a thick edge off a heave, wh Starc to Chanderpaul, OUT that looks gone, that was shaping up to be an outswinger to the left-hander, it straightened in the air too from over the stumps after being angled in, Chanders cannot be blamed for pushing at the original line, but it then moves Innings Start Nathan Lyon, whom the left handers played far easier, also opening up...
Match_Report: Australia 328 and 259 beat West Indies 218 and 294 (Chanderpaul 69, Sammy 61, Clarke 5-86, Lyon 3-87) by 75 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Darren Sammy fought hard but couldn't prevent Australia from wrapping up a 2-0 series victory AFP In the end, the final day of the tour followed the same script as the rest of the series: West Indies fought hard and provided Australia with a few headaches, but their efforts came to nought. Instead, Michael Clarke's second five-wicket haul in Tests helped the Australians wrap up a 75-run victory and they took the series 2-0, despite some powerful striking from the West Indies captain Darren Sammy. It took Australia two hours on the fifth morning to take the five wickets that remained after the critical breakthrough in the last over of the fourth day, when Shivnarine Chanderpaul was lbw. With each four and six that Sammy produced the West Indian fans dreamed of a famous win, but too much had been left to the lower order and a steady stream of wickets meant Sammy and the No.11 Shane Shillingford came together with 125 runs still needed.

Commentary_Highlights: Shilling to Pattinson, OUT after one time, it is two time. They have waited hours for one edge, but like buses two have followed each other. Both set batsmen gone. Shilly bowls a slow offbreak on middle and leg, Patto's bat turns early, and it lobs off the leading edge. They nearly make a meal of it as nobody calls for it. Barath has takes a few steps back from silly point to catch, but hang on. Bravo moves in late from cover, and takes the catch. Barath is wondering where the ball is. All's well, though Roach to Hilfenhaus, OUT Bowled'im. No DRS here. This one nips back in from short of a length, from just outside off. Hits the thigh pad outside the line of leg, but the ricochet hits the stumps Roach to Beer, OUT Beer reviews now. He has been given out lbw as he has shuffled too far across. This is short of a length, nips in from outside off, Beer is across, his inside edge is beaten, and he is hit high on the pad, in front of middle and leg. Erasmus gives him out immediately, Beer reviews immediately. The replays show it to be hitting the top of leg, which means he is gone, and Roach gets five 9.35am A good start for Australia. They have answered the first call of duty, which was to take this last wicket. They now have a lead of 54 on a breaking pitch, but do they have enough time to force a result? And do they need to be cautious in the third innings to avoid what happened to West Indies in the last game? We will be back soon to see how approach the third innings Innings Start "This will be an interesting measure of Clarkes captaincy. So far he is doing well, but how does he do under pressure... ?" Asks Lucas. For the moment, Lucas, he brings back Beer. A slip, a silly point, a short leg in
Match_Report: Australia 311 (Hussey 73, Watson 56, Roach 5-105) and 160 for 8 dec (Ponting 41, Roach 5-41) drew with West Indies 257 (Chanderpaul 94, Lyon 5-68) and 53 for 2 Live scorecard and ball-by-ball details Ben Hilfenhaus made early inroads for Australia before rain closed in for the final time AFP As it had threatened to do the weather had the final say in Port-of-Spain and end the prospect of a fascinating finish after both captains took up each other's challenge to force a positive result. Michael Clarke declared to leave West Indies a target of 215 in 61 overs then Darren Sammy promoted himself to No. 3 as the hosts reached 53 for 2 when they were forced off which meant Australia retained the Frank Worrell Trophy. The initial asking rate for West Indies of 3.52 was considerably more than had been managed for a sustained period at any stage of the game.

Commentary_Highlights: Lyon to Chanderpaul, 1 leg bye step across the stumps and off the pad behind square on the leg side Edwards to Lyon, 5 wide but there's no saving this, a short ball way way down leg and it's called as five wides Edwards to Harris, 1 leg bye late in swing for Sammy, appeal for lbw, pitched outside off, hits the back leg in front, given not out. That's okay, but there was hardly any appeal at all. This ball is shown to be clipping leg by technology Edwards to Lyon, 1 leg bye reversing into the pads again, keeps it out Innings Start Even I keep glancing at the clock...the light seems to be holding at the moment after looking dodgy a while ago but it's disappearing behind that stand...
Match_Report: Australia 406 for 9 dec and 192 for 7 (Watson 52, Deonarine 4-53) beat West Indies 449 for 9 dec and 148 (Hilfenhaus 4-27, Harris 3-31) by 3 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Shane Watson made an important half-century Associated Press Five years after Australia won the World Cup in a farcical finish in the dark at Kensington Oval, they again celebrated a victory there in fading light as the first Test went to the wire on the fifth afternoon. Set 192 to win in two sessions, the Australians started their chase slowly and were almost derailed by middle-order wickets, but Michael Hussey's calm and rational approach ensured they narrowly outpaced the setting sun to win by three wickets. In a tense conclusion, Hussey was bowled by Kemar Roach for 32 from 26 balls with three runs still required, but Ryan Harris and Ben Hilfenhaus saw the Australians home and denied West Indies a satisfactory outcome despite them dominating the first three days. Hilfenhaus struck the winning run with a single scrambled to the off side and a direct-hit at the bowler's end was sent to the third umpire, who found Hilfenhaus in his ground by a few inches. All the while, the players were keeping an eye on the umpires, who were keeping an eye on the light and under the new ICC rules have complete authority to determine whether play continues or ceases.

Commentary_Highlights: Wood to Stoinis, OUT edged and taken! Bowls full, tempting Stoinis to drive, but the ball takes the outside edge and Buttler needs to dive to his right to take the catch. That was quick! A good innings from Stoinis in a position he usually doesn't bat in, but with the start he got, he will feel disappointed not capitalizing Rashid to Labuschagne, OUT full just outside off and the googly comes into him. Big stride forward to defend, but hits his front leg, and the lbw appeal is given out! Marnus reviews right away No bat involved, and that's pitched just outside off, and hit off stump. Labuschagne needs to go. Rashid gets the wicket via the googly. Australia in all sorts of trouble Ali to Marsh, no run fullish, on off, and fended off the back foot. Moeen's economy under six for the first time Archer to Maxwell, SIX runs in the slot on the stumps, Maxwell frees his arms looking to go leg side and sends it sailing high and mighty over the rope! Lots of elevation, but enough distance on it to fly over the midwicket boundary Archer to Maxwell, OUT chopped on! Slower ball, slightly short outside off, Maxwell looked to heave over the leg side but only managed to drag it onto his stumps via the toe of the bat. Big moment in this match Archer to Cummins, OUT length outside off, slashed miles up into the air, and the man at cover in the ring holds on! Archer is laughing - did Morgan nearly drop this?! Ooft, yeah, almost slipped out as he went Australian-style with the hands up. This looked like a knuckleball - plenty of room for Cummins to free his arms, but he was through the shot far too early Wood to Marsh, OUT struck on the pad, and the finger goes up! Marsh reviews immediately. Looked pretty good to the naked eye, and Ultra-Edge says there's no bat involved. Hit in-line, and hitting middle-and-leg three-quarters of the way up! Marsh has to depart after a gritty 73. He was looking to get off strike with a push into the leg side towards midwicket, but Wood did him for pace. Wood to Zampa, 1 leg bye length ball, nudged towards the covers as Zampa backs away. They take on a sharp single, Wood kicks towards the stumps at the keeper's end but Starc is comfortably in even as the ball hits the stumps Woakes to Zampa, OUT short ball, back of a length, and Zampa top-edges the pull straight up into the air... Woakes pouches it! Australia lose their ninth, and Woakes has a wicket to show for his efforts 5.12pm Hello and welcome back to the chase. If this was any other side, on a tired batting track, we'd say the chasing team's backs are against the wall, but not when England are the team trying to raze this total down. But the way Mitch Starc ended the Australia innings, if he could bring that momentum into his opening spell and take a wicket or two... then it's game on.Bairstow's doing his final str Starc to Roy, 1 wide back of a length, on leg stump, and shaping further down. Roy considered flicking it fine... Hazlewood to Bairstow, 1 wide good length, outside off, and angling further away. Wide given Hazlewood to Roy, OUT what a stunner! A one-handed grab... on his followthrough, that's epic from Hazlewood! Not full enough for the drive, yet he drives, but the ball comes off the actual middle of the bat - which isn't really the sweet spot - and Hazlewood maintains his balance to stick his right hand out and the ball stays in his palm. Big wicket t Hazlewood to Morgan, SIX runs here we go! Full, outside off and he runs down the ground to smash a six over wide long off! He Zampa to Morgan, 1 wide good length, on leg stump. Sharp turn down the leg side though Zampa to Morgan, 1 leg bye good length on leg, and Morgan comes down the wicket. It hits his pads and rolls away to the leg side Marsh to Billings, 1 leg bye length ball on the pads, clipped to square leg for a leg-bye Marsh to Billings, SIX runs aggressive! In the slot, and he comes down the wicket and then swipes it leg side to hit a six over deep midwicket Starc to Billings, 1 leg bye yorker length, on leg, and hits his boot and dribbles away to short third man Starc to Billings, 1 leg bye hits the grille of his helmet as he misses the pull. They'll need to check up on Billings for a prospective concussion as per new rules. Short ball, angling into leg. Plenty of you rightly pointed out how valuable Starc's cameo - 19 off 12 balls - ended up being for Australia. If Woakes, Rashid or Archer had managed that, it could have been very different. Player of the match is Josh Hazlewood, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 294 for 9 (Maxwell 77, Marsh 73, Wood 3-54) beat England 275 for 9 (Billings 118, Bairstow 84, Hazlewood 3-26) by 19 runs Australia began their World Cup Super League campaign with a hard-fought victory over the world champions at Emirates Old Trafford. A century stand between Glenn Maxwell and Mitchell Marsh helped salvage a stuttering effort with the bat, and the bowlers then closed the door on England despite a characterful maiden international hundred from Sam Billings. Australia's efforts with the ball were exemplified by Josh Hazlewood, whose spotless 3 for 26 helped keep England just beyond social distance. Hazlewood's first wicket came via an instinctive one-handed catch in his follow through, and he later contributed to the removal of Jonny Bairstow, for 84, with a diving take at long-on. Such excellence in the field, maintained until the final ball when Billings was held by David Warner running in from long-on, only served to steepen England's climb.

Commentary_Highlights: Lee to Bell, OUT oh no, Bell MK II suffers a familiar glitch, hit in front of off and he has to go, no matter how attractive his 41 was! It was another testing ball from Lee, nipping back just a shade and Bell tried to drive back down the pitch, looked like a good call from Cummins to Cook, OUT Lord's falls quiet as Cook chases one outside off and nicks off. Cummins has his first international wicket against England (the first of many?) and Australia's bowlers are finally getting the rewards for their disciplined approach Cummins to Trott, 1 wide loses his line this time, attempted slower ball which doesn't come out right and is dragged very wide McKay to Bopara, OUT gone! Strikes first ball with a lovely delivery. Squared up Bopara on off stump and the edge flies comfortably to Michael Clarke at slip who is rewarded for still attacking Cummins to Morgan, SIX runs big blow! Morgan breaks free by launching a full delivery high straight down the ground and it comfortably clears the boundary Doherty to Trott, OUT tossed up on leg stump and bowled him! Trott simply missed with an attempted glance through the on side, almost yorking himself as the ball dipped and slipped under the bat to break the wicket Watson to Morgan, SIX runs length ball on middle and Morgan unleashes again, spearing the ball over the rope on the up out towards deep square leg - this is sixy hitting, all right Watson to Kieswetter, OUT length ball, Kieswetter hits on the up but it goes straight up, long-off comes scampering in from the boundary and takes a well-judged diving catch Anderson to Warner, 1 wide full down leg side Finn to Watson, OUT cry for caught behind as Watson looked to back-cut, given not out and England, who were convinced, refer this, there's a noise...and a mark on Hot Spot, this is going to be out and indeed up goes the finger. Watson stood still and tried to angle the ball Anderson to Warner, 1 leg bye Warner gets a long way across and gets struck on the pad, large appeal from behind the bat, nothing from the bowler, probably too high. pitched just outside too Bresnan to Bailey, 1 wide leg side wide Broad to Warner, 1 wide bouncer over and wide of leg stump...too wide for Aleem Dar's liking Anderson to Warner, OUT edged and that's a fantastic snag behind the stumps! Anderson pitched it up, having pushed Warner back, enticed him to drive and a thick edge flew towards first slip (which was vacant), meaning Kieswetter had to launch himself horizontally to grasp t Finn to Clarke, 1 wide wild delivery, veering away down the leg side as Finn loses control slightly Finn to Hussey, OUT bumper, Hussey gets in a tangle, the ball hits him on the helmet ... and drops on to the stumps! Strange dismissal, that, Hussey mistimed his pull completely, was hit on the shoudler, then the helmet, the ball finally plopping on to the wicket Bresnan to Smith, OUT length ball, in the corridor and Smith fences weakly at it, nicking through to the keeper! That won't convince the doubters, pushing away from his body, perhaps trying to guide the ball to third man ... but failing Swann to Clarke, SIX runs shot! Massive strike into the Tavern stand, picked up from outside off and timed superbly into the crowd Bresnan to Clarke, 1 wide slower ball and a leg side wide Bresnan to Clarke, OUT got him this time! A similar delivery to earlier in the over but this is much straight and up goes the finger! Bang in front this is, he swings across it and caught plumb in front, game over now is it? Bresnan to Lee, 1 wide and now a slower ball wide Broad to McKay, OUT down the pitch, straight up and caught by Kieswetter. McKay went for a leg side heave to a back of a length ball that he tried to step down the track to but it just went up and the keeper went to his left to take it with both hands easily Broad to Cummins, OUT gone! It looked stone dead, missed a full ball that beat the inside edge, he refers it but this is just out and indeed Hawk Eye confirms as such, that was a ridiculous referral! Right in front on the back pad, if that ain't out, nowt is Player of the match is Eoin Morgan, ENG
Match_Report: England 272 for 5 (Morgan 89*, Trott 54) beat Australia 257 for 9 (Clarke 61, Warner 56) by 15 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Eoin Morgan struck four sixes during the latter part of the England innings Getty Images This is surely one of the most inconsequential England v Australia series in history, but it did not lack for intensity or entertainment for all that and long before the end the Lord's crowd was relishing the renewal of old rivalries. First blood in the NatWest series went to England, but the match felt closer than the final 15-run margin would indicate. Australia's chances departed with their captain, Michael Clarke, who had made 61 from 67 balls when he walked across his stumps, not for the first time, and was aghast to fall plumb lbw to a swinging, low full toss from Tim Bresnan. It aggravated the hurt of the previous over when Australia lost Matthew Wade to a run out. Wade had just lifted James Anderson into the Mound Stand, Clarke had deposited Graeme Swann's offspin into the Tavern and another 69 from 49 balls felt just about gettable.

Commentary_Highlights: Lee to Phillips, OUT Player of the match is Reece Topley, ESSEX
Match_Report: Australians 313 for 9 (Clarke 76, Hussey 67, Topley 4-46) beat Essex 134 (Cummins 3-26) by 179 runs Scorecard Michael Clarke retired with Australia's top score as they routed Essex ahead of the NatWest Series Getty Images Australia will hope for similarly brief encounters with Alastair Cook over the next two weeks. So dominant with the bat in his recent appearances as ODI captain of England, not to mention a 766-run Ashes jaunt down under in the last Ashes series, Cook lasted only 15 balls for 5 as the tourists routed Essex at Chelmsford in their final warm-up for the looming NatWest Series which begins at Lord's on Friday. Cook's conqueror here was the Victorian seamer Clint McKay. Cracked to the backward point boundary early on, he persisted with a back-of-a-length line outside off stump and was rewarded when Cook edged an attempted forcing stroke to Michael Clarke at slip. By that point Mark Pettini had already departed, slicing Brett Lee to third man, and the Australians' towering 313 for 9 was never to be threatened.

Commentary_Highlights: 5.15pm England win the toss and bowl, no real surprise there. Tim Bresnan has a sore elbow so misses out and England play both James Tredwell and Samit Patel. No rest for either Stuart Broad or James Anderson. Still no game for Woakes, either. Finn to Warner, 1 wide extravagant seam movement and bounce as Warner is beaten playing another cut...but it's a fraction too wide Broad to Wade, 1 wide loses his fine down the leg side so that's an extra ball Tredwell to Warner, OUT tossed up, misses with the sweep and gone! Warner often looks a little uncertain trying to work slower bowlers around and he falls to a plumb lbw decision, the ball was full and straightening on middle and he didn't get anything on it. Hawk Eye showing pretty big turn Tredwell to Wade, OUT flighted, spinning past the bat as Wade advances and stumped! Lovely dismissal for Tredwell, who lured the struggling Wade out of his crease, beat him with the turn - in fact almost bowled him - and Kieswetter was alert to whip off the bails Bopara to Smith, OUT loosener, down the leg side - and Smith gets a tickle through to Kieswetter! Australia hit another bump in the road and that's a gimme for Bopara, whose gentle medium pace somehow foxed Smith Bopara to Hussey, OUT Bopara strikes again as Hussey feathers through to the keeper! It was another innocuous delivery, slightly short and wide, Hussey tried to dab it through the off side and nicked off. Bopara's golden arm could probably refloat the European economy right now Finn to Pattinson, OUT big appeal and not out...England are convinced Pattinson edged the slower ball as he heaved to leg. No reviews left for England. There was certainly a noise. Oh, hang on, the umpires are conferring about whether this has carried. So it could be out after all. This isn't Anderson to Bailey, SIX runs that's a clean strike! Picked it up beautifully and launched it over long-on...been a very good innings from Bailey. Anderson just missed his length McKay to Bell, OUT full and straight, Bell advances, clips off the pads straight to midwicket! Bailey takes it comfortably and that's a first failure for Bell in his latest incarnation as an opener. Slightly soft dismissal but an early wicket is just what Australia needed Hilfenhaus to Cook, 1 wide pushed through outside off, no swing and that's a wide Clarke to Trott, OUT this one spins, beats Trott's sweep and bowls him! Clarke held it up a bit this time, Trott was through the shot and the ball gripped, straightened and rattled into the top of off. Nice bowling from the captain - if only he could trust the frontline left-arm spinner in his Pattinson to Bopara, 1 wide a bouncer that's too short for Dar's liking and it's called wide...way over Bopara's head Right, this one has dragged on long enough. Thanks for all your comments, we'll be back again for the full works when the first Test against South Africa starts next Thursday. Cheerio for now! England won by 7 wickets (with 11 balls remaining) (D/L method) Player of the match is Ravi Bopara, ENG
Match_Report: England 138 for 3 (Cook 58, Bopara 52*) beat Australia 145 for 7 (Bailey 46*, Bopara 2-8) by seven wickets (D/L method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details James Tredwell took two wickets on his England return Getty Images Australia's coach, Mickey Arthur, had called for more mongrel but the Australian attack dog managed only a growl or two as England ruthlessly completed a 4-0 victory in a NatWest Series that remained in their control until the last. Australia remain top of the ICC one-day rankings solely because of the abandoned match at Edgbaston, spared by Pommie rain. England were set 146 for victory in 32 overs, a target reduced to 138 in 29 as rain tumbled for the last time from churlish Lancashire skies. There was potential for it to be awkward as Australia took two quick wickets, but Alastair Cook, looking more and more like a one-day captain of status, and Ravi Bopara, in one of his most bullish innings in an England shirt, timed England's seven-wicket victory with 11 balls to spare with aplomb. Cook fell with 12 runs needed, caught at slip off Ben Hilfenhaus for 58, but Bopara, his Essex colleague, saw things though.

Commentary_Highlights: Bresnan to Watson, OUT bowled him! Watson tried to steer towards third man but the ball was too full and jagged back sharply into the right-hander. He was cramped for room and ended up bottom edging on to middle stump Bopara to Bailey, OUT that is a terrific ball and it's bowled Bailey! Bopara pitched the ball on a good length around middle stump and got it to straighten and leave the right-hander just enough to beat the outside edge of Bailey's forward push and clip the top of off stump. McGrath Finn to Clarke, OUT cleaned him up now though and this is a cracker, a length ball seams back and takes the off and middle stumps. It's another great length, wasn't right up there to drive and Clarke got in a bad position, missed by a long way and his off stump ended up on the floor Finn to Wade, OUT gone first ball again! And what a catch! Craig Kieswetter has flung himself to his right and taken a blinder on the juggle. It is a super delivery, back of length that zipped through and took an inside edge, Kieswetter took off, parried with the first attempted and Bopara to Hussey, 1 wide stinker down leg side, miles wide Bresnan to Lee, 1 wide bumper and ducked but too short and called wide Finn to McKay, 1 wide leg side Anderson to McKay, OUT smashed up in the air, so high up, miles up and well taken by Bresnan at mid off, fine take diving backwards in the the end, McKay tried to go down the ground with a drive but simply went high and nowhere near long enough Anderson to Lee, SIX runs shot! Picked up from a full length on leg stump and he whacks it with great timing over deep square leg Anderson to Lee, OUT but this time finds the fielder, holing out to long on, was the necessary? It was mistimed and Broad came in to take a comfortable catch. Having just taken a six was another big heave required? Five singles, 11 off the over would do. After a lovely little innings Bresnan to Hussey, OUT caught on the boundary and Hussey falls trying to find the rope again, slugging a length ball towards long off, Anderson comes round and claims the comfortable chance Brett Lee has the first new ball, and will sprint in from over the wicket. Alastair Cook and Ian Bell are opening for England. McKay to Bell, OUT chopped it on. Bell, rather like Wason earlier today, drags a ball onto the stumps as he looked to guide it to third man, maybe just drifted in but it was too close for the stroke probably, Bell didn't go back to make room for the shot and ended up awkwardly crampe Hussey to Trott, 1 wide down the leg side, Wade whips off the bails and they'll go upstairs to look for the stumping but Trott lifted his foot a few hours after Wade had removed the bails, not out A comfortable chase and England win by eight wickets and absolutely hammer Australia, It was a super performance with the ball and a chase that was never in doubt... Today the toss was crucial but England were so good with the ball, once again they ripped out the Australian top order and it was left to Michael Clarke to try and create something which he did. At least today, David Hussey stepped up in the middle order to put some sort of score on the boa England have the series then, can they make it 4-0? Find out on Tuesday for the final match of this series from Old Trafford, 2pm start so join us then. Not the end of the cricket tonight though because West Indies are in action against New Zealand in Jamaica so head across to follow that g England won by 8 wickets (with 13 balls remaining) Player of the match is Steven Finn, ENG
Match_Report: England 201 for 2 (Bell 69, Trott 64*) beat Australia 200 for 9 (Hussey 70, Clarke 43, Finn 4-37) by eight wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Steven Finn was on a hat-trick twice during Australia's innings Getty Images Smart stats The series win is England's second against Australia (bilateral series) since 2000. Their last series win against Australia came in 2010 at home when they won 3-2. Since the beginning of 2010, England have played seven home ODI series and have won all of them. In three of the seven series, they won by a margin of 3-2. This is only the fourth occasion that England have managed a win by a margin of eight or more wickets in an ODI against Australia.

Commentary_Highlights: 10.15am Australia won the toss and will bat Peter Forrest replaces Steve Smith and Johnson confirmed as Cummins' replacement. For England, Jade Dernbach on his home ground comes in for James Anderson. "I'm very sorry to hear that Pat Cummins is out of the tour, injured yet again. The prospect of having discovered a new Dennis Lillee was thrilling, but unfortunately it seems Australia might have discovered a new Ryan Harris." Indeed disappointing John, hopefully he's a young man who will get stronger an Finn to Warner, 1 leg bye too straight now and off the pad wide of Kieswetter for a single Finn to Warner, OUT and there is the wicket! Pulled straight up and into the hands of square leg. It was short and slightly wide, Warner tried to fetch it to leg and was late on the stroke, getting a top edge that looped up to square leg. Big wicket for England and the extra pace of Finn tells again Broad to Forrest, OUT great catch! And Broad strikes, it was dug in and Forrest looked to pull, it came off the face of the bat and a diving Kieswetter snaffled it with one hand, superb take. Seemed to be beaten for pace there Forrest, he looked to help it on its way but ended up brushing it behind Bopara to Clarke, OUT but this is edged behind! Goodness me I did not expect that, a little cutter outside off and Clarke feathers it low to Kieswetter. It was a good length and Clarke pushed at it and got a thing edge through to the keeper, good area from Bopara and a mistake from Clarke Swann to Watson, OUT lofted, high towards deep midwicket and Finn takes the catch low the ground ... Watson goes! Swann tempted Watson out of his crease, maybe dragged the length down a smidge, the batsman heaved high but it's a long boundary and Finn plunged forward to claim it Dernbach to Bailey, 1 wide slides down the leg side - that's a wide Dernbach to Bailey, 1 leg bye good slower ball from Dernbach, hits Hussey on the pads as he tried to work through midwicket, would have missed leg but chalk that up as a victory to the bowler Bresnan to Bailey, OUT another full bunger and bowled 'im! Excellent death delivery from Bresnan, pitched up and asking the batsman to take a chance - Bailey did but his heave-ho was unsuccessful, the timbers sounding a death rattle Bresnan to Wade, OUT another one down, caught a short fine leg trying to ramp the ball over the infield! Bresnan's length has been hard to hit, Wade tried to improvise but couldn't clear the man. Bresnan looks like a man who's found a twinkie down the back of the sofa Bresnan to Lee, SIX runs low full toss and this time Lee middles it, fetching the ball a long way over the rope at long-on. BOOM! Dernbach to Johnson, 1 leg bye length delivery, Johnson has a golf swing at it, hit on the pad and it slides away towards the slip - Dernbach appeals but it probably pitched outside the line Finally out come the umpires for the second half this afternoon...Brett Lee to open the bowling and Alastair Cook on strike... McKay to Cook, OUT and there is a wicket with Cook caught on the crease and plumb lbw. Boy did Australia need that. Excellent delivery, good length around off stump, it shaped back to beat the forward push of Cook and caught him around the knee roll bang in front of middle Watson to Trott, OUT Trott advances on Watson, gets a faint inside edge, and the ball rattles the stumps! The ball was pretty similar to the one Bell hit out of the park but Trott played with an angled bat - where Bell's was straight - and Watson skidded it through the gap to disturb wicket. Trott' Johnson to Bell, 1 wide wide of off stump this time England won by 6 wickets (with 26 balls remaining) Player of the match is Ravi Bopara, ENG
Match_Report: England 252 for 4 (Bopara 82, Bell 75) beat Australia 251 for 7 (Watson 66, Hussey 65, Bresnan 2-50) by six wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Ian Bell made passed 50 for the third time in his last four ODI innings Getty Images It is one of the ironies of England's recent resurgence in all formats of the game that, for all their meticulous planning, two of the crucial ingredients of their success have come through luck. Just as it was only the sacking of Kevin Pietersen and Peter Moores as captain that brought Andy Flower and Andrew Strauss together as captain and coach, so it has only been the "retirement" of Pietersen from limited-overs international cricket that presented another chance to Ian Bell as an ODI batsman. It is not just luck, of course. It is how England have adjusted to circumstance and overcome the obstacles that have arisen. But it remains true that, had Pietersen not departed the England limited-overs set-up recently, it is most unlikely that Bell would have returned to the top of the England order.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and they will bat first. Australia are unchanged. Abdur Rehman replaces the injured Afridi and Junaid Khan replaces Aizaz Cheema. Junaid to Wade, OUT well Umar Akmal needn't beat himself up for that drop! Soon after being let off, Wade chases a full and wide delivery outside off and drags it to his stumps, not exactly a wicket-taking delivery though, the shot didn't come off r Junaid to Clarke, 1 wide drifts down the leg side and wide called Tanvir to Warner, 1 leg bye tucks it away off his thighs to the leg side Tanvir to Clarke, 1 wide struggling with the extras here, this was outside the off stump and he safely left it alone, too wide Ajmal to Warner, OUT and the long, long vigil comes to an end! Pitching on the leg and middle, hitting on the pad and struck low on the pads. Ticks all the boxes required to dole out an LBW decision. Ajmal is ecstatic. Warner is asked,by his captai Ajmal to Hussey, SIX runs Ajmal decides it's time to generous and bowls him a friendly full toss, Hussey moved across and clubbed it across the line and sent the ball sailing over deep midwicket Ajmal to Hussey, OUT Pakistan have struck with two lbws in quick succession! Hussey looked a bit surprised, he was a long way across his stumps and hence exposed the leg stump and a part of middle, the ball spun back in and hit him low on the pads, Abdur to Bailey, OUT soft dismissal! Rehman tossed it up on middle and off and Bailey was looking to chip it to the on side but ended up spooning it back to the bowler Tanvir to Johnson, 1 leg bye full on the pads and squirted away down to midwicket Hafeez to Hussey, 1 leg bye floated on the pads and it skids through, hits the pads and rolls to the off side, there was an appeal but that was missing leg Junaid to Christian, OUT that was a sharp catch by Jamshed! Christian fetched that from outside off and pulled it flat and fast towards deep midwicket, Jamshed ran across to his right and plucked the ball on the dive Junaid to Johnson, OUT ends his spell with two wickets in as many balls! Junaid bowled that full and straight on the stumps, Johnson had a wild swing and missed it completely, crashed onto off and middle Pattinson to Hafeez, 1 wide starts off with a wide and he slides it down the leg side Pattinson to Jamshed, 1 wide another wide down the leg side, Jamshed tried to flick it away Starc to Hafeez, 1 wide pitches it up but down the leg side and wide called Maxwell to Jamshed, 3 wide once again he errs by sliding it down the leg side, tries to sweep, the ball deflects off Wade Christian to Hafeez, OUT Hafeez has fallen for the trap!
