Superb work from the keeper! Watson to Tuffey, OUT Tuffey moves across to outside off stump and it takes him on the thigh pad and Haddin collects it and half-appeals and umpire Baxter gives it out! Unlucky for Tuffey there Mitchell Johnson is named Man of the Match for his three for 19 off four overs. He picked up the wickets of Ingram, Taylor and Guptill which dented any momentum New Zealand would've hoped for up front. New Zealand were undone by the pace of Tait, Nannes and Johnson atth top of the innings and were chasing their tails as a result for the rest of the innings, eventually being bowled out for 118 from the final ball fo the innings. David Hussey is happy with his team's effort and enjoyed the pace in the wicket which allowed him to score 46 off 36 balls. He hit nicely over the top straight down the ground and pulled strongly whenever the bowlers dropped short. Australia just far too good for New Zealand tonight, winning by six wickets with 24 balls to spare. Oram to Clarke, 1 wide bouncer down leg and called wide Vettori to Clarke, 1 wide Clarke uses his feet and it angles dow leg, it yorks Hopkins and he misses a difficult stumping Mitchell Johnson is named Man of the Match for his three for 19 off four overs. He picked up the wickets of Ingram, Taylor and Guptill which dented any momentum New Zealand would've hoped for up front. New Zealand were undone by the pace of Tait, Nannes and Johnson atth top of the innings and were chasing their tails as a result for the rest of the innings, eventually being bowled out for 118 from the final ball fo the innings. David Hussey is happy with his team's effort and enjoyed the pace in the wicket which allowed him to score 46 off 36 balls. He hit nicely over the top straight down the ground and pulled strongly whenever the bowlers dropped short. Australia just far too good for New Zealand tonight, winning by six wickets with 24 balls to spare. Australia won by 6 wickets (with 24 balls remaining) Player of the match is Mitchell Johnson, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 119 for 4 (Hussey 46) beat New Zealand 118 (Franklin 43, Johnson 3-19) by 6 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Mitchell Johnson was a big problem for New Zealand with three early wickets Getty Images It was a different country but the same result for Australia as they breezed to a six-wicket win over an out-classed New Zealand in the first Twenty20 in Wellington. After an unbeaten home summer the visitors started their tour with another convincing display built on very fast bowling and powerful opening batting. New Zealand were knocked over for 118 by the speed of Shaun Tait, Dirk Nannes and Mitchell Johnson and their chances of defending the small total were basically extinguished as soon as David Warner and Shane Watson blasted 28 from the first two overs. The openers were dismissed quickly and Johnson's promotion to No. 4 failed, dropping the visitors to 39 for 3, but the small target allowed them to take their time and the win came with 24 balls to spare.

Commentary_Highlights: Sundar to Wade, 1 leg bye 94kph, angled into leg, back of a length, it comes off the thigh guard and rolls fine for a leg bye Natarajan to Short, OUT Great catch by Iyer at deep forward square. This was a head high short ball, D'Arcy Short pulled flat and hard, he nailed it, but hit it straight to the man and Iyer had to back track a touch, jump up and take the catch above his head. Good catch Natarajan to Henriques, OUT Henriques reviews a catch behind. Given very late by the umpire, presumably because India were celebrating before they appealed. It's a cutter in the corridor. He was looking to slap that over the leg side. There's nothing on the thermal images, but Snicko has a murmur as the ball is adjacent to the bat. The decision will be upheld 9.05pm The players are about to head back out to the middle. Matthew Wade leads Australia out. Shikhar Dhawan and KL Rahul head out to the middle. Daniel Sams has the new ball on debut. He played with Dhawan at Delhi Capitals and bowled to KL Rahul in the IPL. Slip in for Rahul Tye to S Dhawan, 1 leg bye an appeal for lbw given not out. Wade says it's worth a look. Tye was unsure. But Wade reviews. He was hit on the back leg trying to flick over square. No bat. It was pitching outside leg. It was very tight. Part of the ball was in line but not enough. That's why Tye wasn't interested. Australia lose the review. Tye to Rahul, (no ball) he over-steps. It was a good length outside off and Rahul missed trying to heave over midwicket Tye to Rahul, SIX runs launched over cover! What a shot. Full outside off, he set himself and crushed it over the long boundary at cover. That was in the slot Zampa to Kohli, SIX runs just, how? Good length, beats him in flight, grips and turns, He's stepped out to play the lofted drive, he checks it at the last moment, but has got it to sweeper's right from an almost back foot position Tye to Kohli, 1 wide slower ball at a length and very wide outside off 11:08pm And that is all from our coverage of the second match. Good night, and catch you soon! India won by 6 wickets (with 2 balls remaining) Player of the match is Hardik Pandya, INDIA
Match_Report: India 4 for 195 (Dhawan 52, Pandya 42*, Kohli 40, Swepson 1-25) beat Australia 5 for 194 (Wade 58, Smith 46, Natarajan 2-20) by six wickets Hardik Pandya's heavy hitting delivered India a T20I series victory over Australia and their third consecutive win of the tour to give the captain Virat Kohli something to show for his trip down under in an undulating encounter at the SCG. ALSO WATCH: Match highlights - Natarajan, Hardik seal series for India (India subcontinent only) The Australians were led by Matthew Wade in the absence of Aaron Finch due to injury, and he led from the front with a swift half-century at the top of the order. But the remainder of the Australian innings was spasmodic, and without any of Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood or Mitchell Starc, the bowling attack was well and truly below the usual level of expertise. Kohli, KL Rahul and Shikhar Dhawan ensured India would be in the contest until its closing passages, whereupon Pandya lined up his scoring zones with brutal efficiency. Daniel Sams was defending 14 from the final over, but with a pair of towering blows beyond the straight midwicket boundary, India claimed the series with two balls to spare.

Commentary_Highlights: Hello and welcome to Cricinfo's coverage of the second Twenty20 international between West Indies and Australia being played in Sydney. West Indies have won the toss and opted to bat in a game they need to win to deprive Australia of an unbeaten summer. We'll get you the teams in a bit; in the meantime, do Harris to Gayle, 1 wide starts with a wide, slides it down the leg side, false start Tait to Gayle, 1 wide short down the leg side, tries to whip it past fine leg, doesn't get his bat to it, bowled at a fiery pace, 152.6 kmph Harris to Morton, OUT gone! Bowls it on a length outside off, tries to drive it through the line, gets a thick outside edge and Cameron White at second slip makes no mistake, a first-ball duck for Morton Tait to Ramdin, OUT short and wide, makes room to cut that over third man but can't find enough to beat him, got plenty of elevation and Warner ran forward to complete a sharp catch Johnson to Dowlin, 1 wide short of a good length outside off, too wide, tries his best to reach it but can't Watson to Pollard, OUT Pollard's gone, a wild swing to a ball bowled on a good length on the off, misses and the off stump is pegged back, a big blow for West Indies Roach to Warner, SIX runs another one, took his hands off after pulling it behind square, had enough on it to take it past the ropes behind fine leg, came on to him a little too quickly but he got into position early Smith to Warner, 1 wide wide, short, too wide, lots of open spaces in the leg side and he slips it wide of off, given Smith to Warner, SIX runs Smith's turn now, slower one bowled short outside off, a long hop, pulled away for the umpteenth time into the stands, well taken in the crowd A ruthless batting display from Australia has won them this game with 50 balls to spare. Warner was outstanding, and Watson took the lead after his departure to hasten Australia's victory. West Indies offered some fight in the Tests, but wilted after that to end the tour on a disappointing note. Thanks for Australia won by 8 wickets (with 50 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 2 for 142 (Warner 67, Watson 62*) beat West Indies 7 for 138 (Deonarine 36*, Harris 2-27) by eight wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details David Warner's 18-ball half-century set up Australia's victory Getty Images David Warner hammered the second-fastest Twenty20 international half-century to hand Australia an eight-wicket win over West Indies and complete their dreams of an unbeaten summer. Warner raced to fifty from 18 deliveries, beating his own 19-ball effort from last season, as Australia reeled in the target of 139 with a ridiculous 50 deliveries to spare. West Indies' total looked semi-competitive until the first over of the chase when Warner and Shane Watson took 26 off Kemar Roach, who bowled too short and allowed Warner to swing through midwicket. There were three sixes in the over - as many as the visitors hit in their entire innings - and the contest was all but decided. By the time Warner had cleared the boundary off Darren Sammy in the second over, he had 33 from eight deliveries and Yuvraj Singh's 12-ball half-century record was conceivably in danger.

Commentary_Highlights: Hello and welcome to the first of two Twenty20s between Australia and West Indies. The hosts have won the toss and will bat. Gayle to Watson, OUT gets him, finally! Gave it some air this time, tossed up on middle, tried to dispatch it into the stands over deep midwicket, got the top edge and Ramdin, after waiting ages for it to come down, clasped it easily Smith to Warner, OUT full toss on middle, he could have smacked it anywhere but instead played it back straight to the bowler who accepted it gleefully Gayle to Hussey, OUT three down, cleanly struck but hit flat, came down the track and smacked it hard but straight to Roach at long-off who did well moving to his right and holding on to a sharp one Pollard to Clarke, OUT four down, Miller takes a sharp one at point, short and wide, cut away hard and he hurls himself to his right to snap an excellent catch Miller to Birt, OUT stumped, Miller bowled it flat outside off, Birt came down the track and tried to push it on the off side, missed and Ramnarine did the rest Smith to Haddin, SIX runs Haddin continues to punish, picked it off a length and swung it over wide long-on for another six Smith to Smith, OUT caught-behind, off the reverse paddle, full outside off, tries to play it towards third man, gets a faint touch and Ramdin makes no mistake Tait to Gayle, 1 wide short outside leg stump, tries to help it on its way to the fine-leg boundary, misses, gets a wide Nannes to Simmons, OUT another one goes, Tait again in action, bowls it on a good length on middle and off and Simmons has a mindless, needless swipe at it, ends up miscuing it to third man where Tait takes a well-judged catch Nannes to Morton, 1 wide too high a bouncer, that. Working up some good pace, almost hitting 150, but it's given a wide Nannes to Morton, OUT Steve Smith takes another beauty! Even better than the first one, bowled it on a good length on the off, Morton swung it hard and connected well but Smith was there waiting, it appeared as though it would clear him but he timed his jump perf Australia have won this comfortably, though had West Indies prevented that horrendous start to their chase, we would have had a more competitive match. Nevertheless, the crowd would have been entertained, especially in the Australian innings. Join us for the second T20 Player of the match is Shaun Tait, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 8 for 179 (Warner 49) beat West Indies 8 for 141 (Ramdin 44, Nannes 3-21, Tait 3-30) by 38 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details David Warner was entertaining during his 49 Getty Images Shaun Tait and David Warner, two of Australia's Twenty20 specialists, continued the team's unbeaten summer by setting up a 38-run thrashing of West Indies in Hobart. Warner provided the early thrills with a brutal batting display before the Man of the Match Tait destroyed West Indies' top order as Australia's plans for the ICC World Twenty20 took a step in the right direction. Warner and Shane Watson lit up Bellerive Oval, which was hosting its first night international, by taking Australia to 0 for 83 in the eighth over and some late fireworks from Brad Haddin pushed them to 8 for 179. It was a good but gettable total, until two wickets in Tait's first over knocked the life out of the chase. Chris Gayle has failed to spark during the limited-overs portion of the summer and that trend continued when he swung wildly at Tait's fourth delivery and saw his stumps splayed.

Commentary_Highlights: 13.55 Toss Australia have won the toss and will bat. Rampaul to Watson, 1 wide wide down the leg side, just sprayed down Watson's pads Miller to Haddin, SIX runs this time Haddin charges out of the crease, gets to the pitch of the ball and clobbers it over long-on for six Sammy to Watson, OUT well, that was a poor delivery to get out on, a full toss outside off, it was an attempted slower delivery, Watson looks to clear deep midwicket but his hoick can't clear the fielder there, a much-needed breakthrough for the Windes Pollard to Haddin, OUT bowled! not a replay Haddin will like to see again, the ball was miles outside off, Haddin was looking to mow it to the leg side, gets a bottom-edge that sends the ball onto the base of offstump, it's not been a great summer with the bat for Haddin Pollard to Clarke, 1 wide Clarke is greeted with a mis-directed bouncer, going down the leg side Rampaul to Clarke, 1 leg bye tries the shot across the line again but this one is shorter and raps him on the flap as he steps across the sticks, cuing an enthusiastic and optimistic appeal, no chance that was out because of the shuffle and the height, so the result is a leg bye Miller to Voges, SIX runs awesome chip shot from Voges, skipping out to the ball and then lofting high and handsome for a straight six 17.45 Amazing stand of 82 in 43 balls. Stunning late assault. Hopes was devastating, Voges was effective. Australia finish with 324. Don't see Windies chasing this down given the summer they've had. Join us in about 40-odd minutes for the chase. During the meantime, how about checking out what our panelists have decided are the Bollinger to Deonarine, 1 wide lost his radar there, swinging way down the leg side, Haddin dives across to collect, good work that Bollinger to Gayle, SIX runs and another top-edge six, not as short as the previous one, again goes for the pull, another top-edge, soaring over slips and the third man boundary Harris to Pollard, 1 wide pace and bounce, sits up wide off and wide called Hopes to Pollard, 1 wide too fine and it sneaks past leg stump to Haddin Hopes to Pollard, SIX runs lovely shot there, just pirouetting on the short ball and getting a beefy six over midwicket Bollinger to Simmons, OUT short of a length on off stump, Simmons goes back and across and pushes to cover, takes a step forward, then hesitates, at the other end Smith sets off but gets shooed back and that does him in as Clarke nails a direct hit, superbly fielded there in the covers and West Indies lose their sixth Bollinger to Simmons, OUT smacked but straight to Clarke at cover! Bollinger drags it short as Simmons goes to the leg side, looking to smack it down the ground, and the result is a flat-batted slap into the vice-captain's lap, that was hit hard and should leave a sting, but well held Player of the match is James Hopes, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 5 for 324 (Ponting 61, Hopes 57*, Watson 51) beat West Indies 199 (Sammy 47, Bollinger 3-33) by 125 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details James Hopes provided some highlights with a 24-ball half-century Getty Images In a summer of big one-day wins, Australia saved one of their heftiest victories for last. After Ricky Ponting, James Hopes and Shane Watson set up a daunting 5 for 324, Doug Bollinger continued his torment of Chris Gayle and the West Indies top order crumbled - again - to leave the crowd in no doubt about the approaching result less than five overs in to the chase. The 125-run triumph maintained Australia's chances of going through the summer undefeated in all forms of the game, with two Twenty20s against West Indies all that remain. Already they have equalled their effort of 2000-01, the only other home season when they did not lose a Test or ODI. Back then the team boasted Shane Warne, Glenn McGrath, Adam Gilchrist and Mark Waugh, and faced West Indies and Zimbabwe.

Commentary_Highlights: 1.30pm: Good day and welcome to Cricinfo's coverage of the second ODI between Australia and West Indies in Adelaide. The early news is that Chris Gayle has won the toss again and this time he has decided to bat. He had put Australia in at the MCG ... Bollinger to Gayle, OUT ball 1 strike 1! Right on target is Doug Bollinger, gets some late movement inwards and the ball straightens, lands on a good length and thuds his pads in line with the off stump, Gayle was too lazy in getting his bat down on time and he played down the wrong line Bollinger to Dowlin, 1 wide sprays a full toss really wide outside off, the excitement gets to Bollinger Bollinger to Dowlin, 1 leg bye drifts close to the pads and he gently tucks it to the on side off the pads Johnson to Dowlin, 1 wide bowls him the bouncer just wide down the leg side, too high to chase that Bollinger to Morton, OUT tumbling like pins here, excellent delivery there, lands on a good length on middle and straightens a bit, Morton gets a touch forward but he's beaten for pace and gets hit on the pads in line with off and middle Bollinger to Simmons, OUT Doug's on fire! He bowls it on a fullish length and angles it just across the right-hander, Simmons is forced to play at it and he shapes to drive straight, the late movement catches the outside edge and another easy take for Haddin Johnson to Deonarine, OUT on the middle stump and hitting the leg stump or is it? Bowden certainly thinks so as Deonarine who was looking good has to go. There is an air of doubt around the dismissal as Bowden took his own sweet time in giving the decision and then walked over to the square leg umpire to discuss about it Watson to Ramdin, OUT the bowling change works! Watson bowls it dead straight on the channel outside off, the ball holds its line and Ramdin fishes outside the off stump with a half stride forward, thin edge and Haddin's good outing continues McKay to Smith, OUT terrific terrific catch! Hussey's pulled off the spectacular! Smith heaves the ball towards cow corner, Hussey sprints from long-on, he covers about 40 meters to his right at top speed before diving full length and taking the catch inches from the ground Check out the latest Time Out show with Harsha Bhogle, Peter Roebuck and Sanjay Manjrekar. It's about ball tampering. Roach to Watson, (no ball) oversteps first ball, pitches wide of off stump, free hit time Rampaul to Watson, 1 wide down the pads again, Watson flicks and misses, Ramdin leaps Smith to Ponting, 1 wide goes down the wrong line Roach to Clarke, 1 wide short ball to welcome Clarke, sails over and is called wide So that makes it 2-0 in Australia's favour. Ponting seals the win with a pull over square leg to a long hop. Bollinger is the Man of the Match. Thanks for tuning in today. Do come back and see us for game three on February 12. Bye for now! Australia won by 8 wickets (with 141 balls remaining) Player of the match is Doug Bollinger, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 2 for 171 (Ponting 57*, Watson 53) beat West Indies 170 (Smith 43, Bollinger 4-28) by 8 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Shane Watson got Australia off to a strong start in the chase with a smooth 53 Getty Images After the match was effectively sealed from the first ball when Chris Gayle fell, Australia ran over a disappointing West Indies for an eight-wicket victory to earn a 2-0 lead. The tourists were out-classed by Doug Bollinger in the early stages and slumped to 4 for 16 before scrambling to 170, a total which was never going to be large enough. Australia were not intimidated and Shane Watson and Ricky Ponting skipped to half-centuries as the win came in the 27th over. West Indies actually did well to last as long as 39.4 overs in their innings in a poorly timed performance given the current debate over the relevance of the 50-over game.

Commentary_Highlights: 2pm: Toss: West Indies have won the toss and Australia have been asked to bat first. The teams will be up shortly. Roach to Watson, 1 wide this time he doesn't control the radar and the ball slides down the legside Smith to Watson, 5 wide poor delivery, down the leg side and it beats everyone, including short fine leg Gayle to Watson, OUT well bowled there, he bowled it much flatter and dropped it a bit short too on sensing Watson's intentions, he gave him the charge but didn't get to the pitch of the ball, lands down Morton's throat at long-on Pollard to Ponting, OUT Pollard strikes! a back of length ball that jags in and takes the inside-edge with the Australian captain looking to drive off the front foot, and takes out offstump Rampaul to Hussey, OUT another drive away from the body gives a catch to Ramdin, Husset makes a bit of room to slice it hard through the offside, may have been a slower ball, too early on the shot and the thick edge it taken by the keeper after diving forward Rampaul to Johnson, OUT makes room to dig it out to the on side but he misses it, beaten for pace and the yorker ball thuds on to his leg stump Bollinger to Dowlin, OUT Windies are collapsing, Dowlin joins the procession, it was a delivery angling across the batsman, pitching outside off and going away, the batsman gets well forward and wafts away from his body, gets the outside edge to second slip Harris to Deonarine, 5 wide messes up his line this time, well down the leg side, it was a shortish ball but died on its way to the keeper, too low for a diving Haddin to collect Harris to Deonarine, 1 wide another delivery down the leg side Johnson to Deonarine, OUT Deonarine has played some good cuts today, but this time he can only find Ponting at backward point, superb catch from Ponting, timing his jump perfectly as he latched onto that overhead chance, great captaincy as well, Ponting wasn't in that position at the s Bollinger to Pollard, 1 leg bye down the leg side, looks to play it towards square leg, gets it on the pads and the ball dribbles towards backward point Hauritz to Pollard, OUT that's the end of Pollard, this shot would have been a six in many international ground, Pollard clubbed that one powerfully, but gets a bit too much height, Johnson is there at the long-on boundary, positioning himself nicely to take the catch a few metres insi Watson to Simmons, OUT and another big blow for West Indies, with that their slim hopes are gone, Simmons was looking to guide that length delivery towards third man but gets a thick edge to the keeper, the ball kept low but Haddin clings on to it after diving to his right Well, that was clinical from Australia, the bowling looked particularly good, especially with the new ball. The absence of the likes of Lee, Bracken and Siddle is hardly being felt, West Indies being rolled over for 143. Kieron Pollard showed us a glimpse of his all-round skills, and West Ind Player of the match is Shane Watson, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 8 for 256 (Watson 59, Pollard 3-45) beat West Indies 143 (Pollard 31, Harris 3-24, Hauritz 3-28) by 113 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Doug Bollinger's two early strikes were key moments in Australia's win Getty Images Another series, another opponent, same result. Two days after completing a tri-format clean-sweep against Pakistan, Australia continued their unbeaten summer with a 113-run victory over West Indies, set up by Shane Watson's half-century and Doug Bollinger's new-ball efforts. Chris Gayle's prediction of a 4-1 West Indies win can still come true but they have only one day to regroup before Tuesday's second match in Adelaide. The result was understandable given the number of stars missing from West Indies' line-up through injury, but disappointing after Kieron Pollard's career-best bowling performance helped peg Australia back following a strong start from Watson and Ricky Ponting. Keeping Australia to 8 for 256 after they were 1 for 135 having been sent in was a good effort and a brisk start from Gayle would have caused some flutters in the Australian camp.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and they will bat first. We will get the teams up shortly. Mohammad Asif to Warner, OUT fell for the trap! Warner makes a lot of room to crash that over the off side, the ball is there to be hit but he doesn't spot the fielder Imran Nazir at deep point, easy catch Umar Gul to Clarke, OUT good reflexes! Clarke gets slightly forward and beside the line to slash it away over the off side, but Fawad is alert at point and cups his hands behind that screamer, he kept his eyes on the ball which was like a bolt of lightning Umar Gul to White, OUT fabulous cricket from Pakistan! Gul catches White all at sea with a short delivery, the ball lobs off White's body and lobs to Fawad at point, Gul thinks White got some glove on it and they go up for the catch, but an unsettled and dazed White ambles out of his crease and an alert Fawad fires the throw at the Malik to Birt, OUT forgettable debut in the end for Birt, Malik comes round the wicket and fires it flat on the stumps, Birt goes a long way across and tries to paddle it away, the ball crashes on to leg and middle Naved-ul-Hasan to Smith, OUT the slower ball from hell! That was actually a googly! Naved foxes Smith who doesn't quite know whether to play at it or not, the ball cuts back in and slices him in half, he won't want to see a replay of that Umar Gul to Johnson, OUT it gets worse for Australia! Another terrific delivery, Gul bangs it in really short and it's a snorter, Johnson desperately sways backward to evade it and the ball brushes his glove, Kamran knows it Umar Gul to Tait, OUT easy catch for Alam this time, Tait gets forward to a pitched up delivery and ends up spooning it straight to point While we wait for Pakistan's response, check out our It won't be easy because the TV commentators are saying this is the fastest MCG wicket they've seen. Join us shortly. Johnson to Kamran, 1 wide bowls a yorker but its wide of off stump, Akmal backs away and misses and a wide is called Watson to Khalid Latif, OUT gets his man with the incutter! Pitches length, a slower ball it seems, and cuts back off the track to hit Latif on the flap as he shapes to work it away, looks to the naked eye as its headed into leg stump and so the umpire agrees ... but, but, but replays show a thin inside edge so Latif is unlucky, a b Tait to Malik, 1 leg bye full ball well down the pads, gets a bit of boot on the flick Johnson to Kamran, 1 leg bye goes to pull again and gets struck in the underarm, he was into the shot too early, the ball was short and there to be put away Player of the match is Shaun Tait, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 127 (Hussey 40*, Gul 3-20) beat Pakistan 9 for 125 (K Akmal 64, Tait 3-13) by 2 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Umar Gul took three wickets but it turned into Australia's night Getty Images Shaun Tait proved he can still be a force at international level as he helped Australia to a tense two-run win that completed a clean-sweep across all three formats against Pakistan this summer. Tait bowled the fastest ball ever recorded in Australia and grabbed 3 for 13 including the key wicket of Kamran Akmal, who had threatened to end Australia's streak with his highest Twenty20 score. Pakistan's trip has been notable for terrible fielding and the inability to capitalise whenever they got on top of Australia. This time their fielding was sharper than it had been at any stage over the past couple of months but their failure to keep Australia down remained a major issue. Despite dismissing Australia for 127 and being on track at 4 for 98 in the 15th over, they found a way to lose.

Commentary_Highlights: Southee to Hussey, OUT we saw it coming! Southee had beaten Hussey just a short while back outside the off stump, this time he pitches it up outside off and draws Hussey to drive forward, takes the edge which was loud and clear, Rauf confirms it Vettori to Katich, OUT Katich falls just before tea! He shuffle across his stumps yet again and tries to clip it to the on side, but the ball goes straight off the bat and goes to Watling at forward short leg, no doubts about that at all Southee to Haddin, OUT another soft dismissal and New Zealand are taking them all, Haddin shapes to punch it through the off side but checks his shot and ends up tamely tapping it back to the bowler, that fielder at silly mid-off may have played on his mind Vettori to Johnson, OUT New Zealand are chipping away, Vettori bowls it flatter on the off stump, Johnson gets forward and offers a bat-pad catch to McIntosh at silly point who takes it inches off the turf, Aleem Dar sends him on his way immediately Southee to North, OUT North is referring this, the ball lands on middle and goes through with the line, North plays all around it and is hit flush on the pad bang in front of middle, looked obvious to us and Asad Rauf, North challenges it but in the end it's a referral used up by Australia Southee to Harris, 1 leg bye on the leg side and he clips him away down to fine leg Vettori to Harris, OUT Vettori strikes, the Australian collapse continues, the arm ball does the job, Harris is hit on the front foot as he looks to whip it square, in front of middle and leg, Harris is gone Vettori to Bollinger, OUT the bails are down and the innings is over, Vettori bowls this one quicker and flatter, the ball clips the pad and clips the stumps as Bollinger gets forward to defend, leaves a big gap between pad and bat So Southee and Vettori combine to skittle out Australia for 231 after losing the toss. Australia will look back at the innings with a lot of regret because some of their main batters threw it away - Watson, Ponting, Clarke and to a lesser extent, Katich. Having said that, the bowlers were consistent and kept the pressure on and didn't let any Bollinger to McIntosh, OUT McIntosh had no idea where his off stump was! Bollinger lands it on a fullish length just outside off and gets it to nip back in, McIntosh shoulders arms but looks back to see his off stump pegged back, Bollinger kisses the Australian crest and not the VB sponsor logo! Harris to Taylor, 1 wide called wide for height, the bouncer goes over head-high as he ducks under it Hauritz to Taylor, SIX runs what a strike, slog-swept from way outside off, and Watson has no chance of catching this, they have lost the ball behind midwicket, big six Hauritz to Taylor, SIX runs Taylor is on fire here, and this ground is too small, Hauritz - brave man - flights it again, and gets it in Taylor's arc, and watches it sail over long-on Bollinger to Taylor, OUT review, Taylor goes for the boundary with the field up, goes for the pull shot, the ball is too full, Aussies appeal for a bottom edge, Asad Rauf doesn't move. Hot spot shows a faint tickle as the ball passes the bat, and Rauf overturns his decision Johnson to Southee, SIX runs whoa, Southee proving those defensive fields right! 15 rows back over long leg, clears the front leg, Johnson sends in a bouncer and he swings and connects Innings Start Michael Clarke is going to be used with his left-arm orthodox spin just before tea
Match_Report: Australia 231 & 511 for 8 dec beat New Zealand 264 & 302 (Guptill 58, McCullum 51, Johnson 6-73) by 176 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Mitchell Johnson finishes his Test summer on a high with 6 for 73 Getty Images Mitchell Johnson achieved his second ten-wicket match haul in Tests to finish off New Zealand before lunch as Australia swept to a 2-0 series victory. New Zealand resumed at 185 for 5 chasing a record-breaking target of 479, but Johnson and Doug Bollinger dismissed them for 302 to secure a 176-run victory. Johnson was responsible for causing the early damage in the pursuit on day four when his high-speed spells gained three wickets and he backed up with another three. The 6 for 73 followed his 4 for 59 in the first innings and gave him 12 victims for the series. The performance ensured Australia finished an unbeaten summer with seven wins in eight Tests.

Commentary_Highlights: Bollinger steams in but pulls out of the delivery at the last minute Johnson to Southee, OUT length ball and Southee who has no faith in Martin as he swings to mid wicket, big noise as the ball passes the bat. The Australians are confident and Southee is given out but he refers the decision instantly. Clearly a noise as the ball passes the bat but nothing from hot spot. The replay suggests there is no contact with the bat but no concrete evidence to reverse the decision. Unlucky for Southee but great Innings Start Well, Australia will be very happy with a complete performance in this first test match. A magnificant century from Clarke in the first innings, which won his the man of the match award, with great support from North who also made a century under pressure really set up the game. The New Zealanders showed a lack of application in their first innings as Doug Bollinger bowled brilliantly to ensure the follow on was enforced. The second inning
Match_Report: Australia 459 for 5 dec & 106 for 0 (Hughes 86*) beat New Zealand 157 & 407 (McCullum 104, McIntosh 83, Vettori 77) by 10 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Phillip Hughes raced Australia to victory with 86 not out, but he will probably have to make way for Shane Watson in the second Test Getty Images It took Australia longer than they expected, but Phillip Hughes' final-day blast allowed them to finish off New Zealand and gain a 1-0 lead heading into the final Test in Hamilton on Saturday. Brendon McCullum's inspired 104 forced the visitors to chase 106, a target they achieved without loss before lunch thanks to Hughes' aggressive 86 off 75 balls. After spending time in the field over four days, Ryan Harris, the debutant, sealed a quick finish of New Zealand's second innings, taking 4 for 77 as the hosts were dismissed for 407. Hughes, who grabbed 12 fours and a six, was then in a hurry to end the game and sped to the 10-wicket victory in 23 overs. It was left to Simon Katich, who played the anchor with 18, to take the winning single on the final ball before lunch.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.40pm Australia won the toss and will bowl Hazlewood to Rahul, 1 leg bye good length and sliding onto the pads. Looks to whip that over short fine, cops it on the thigh Starc to S Dhawan, OUT knocks out off stump with a trademark delivery! He's back. Starc is back. High 140s, outswinger starting middle and curving viciously towards off. Dhawan's got his front leg in the leg side and his stumps exposed as he creates room for the drive through cover. The late swing and the pace does him and it's a pretty sight as the st Starc to Kohli, 1 wide full and very wide outside off. Searching for that swing, but this is past the tramline. Kohli lets it go Swepson to Kohli, OUT balloons back to the bowler. The only thing going for Swepson this ball is that it has gripped. It's short but it's gripped and turned away and gotten big on Kohli in the corridor. He's shaping to pull but checks himself and it pops back gently to the bowler off the leading edge Abbott to Samson, 1 wide slips this full down the leg side Henriques to Samson, OUT straight to cover! Full outside off, was in the slot for the drive, but Samson couldn't have picked out the fielder on the edge of the ring with any more precision Henriques to Pandey, 1 wide loses his line down the leg side so a bonus ball for India Zampa to Pandey, OUT good catch at short third man! Hazlewood does well to get down to that. Pandey went back to a slightly shorter ball, goes for the cut, it takes the top edge and is dipping as it reaches Hazlewood Henriques to Hardik, 1 leg bye short of a length, gets himself into a tangle here as he looks to pull, hammers into Pandya's hip and loops away. That will be painful Henriques to Hardik, SIX runs into the stands! Pandya had changed his bat before that ball and this one is working nicely. Full outside off, he's able to get underneath and swings high and mighty over long-on Henriques to Hardik, OUT high...very high, and taken at long-off! Pandya is cut off before he can really get going, gets all height on this one, low down on the bat, Smith has plenty of time to get underneath it Starc to Sundar, 2 wide another full toss, sprayed down the leg side, Wade gets a glove on it Hazlewood to Jadeja, SIX runs that's MASSIVE! Full outside off, Jadeja picks it up and swings it miles back over deep square leg. Almost onto the root of the stand Starc to Sundar, OUT straight to long-on...couldn't get the distance on it and a comfortable catch WATCH: Hardik Pandya holes out to Steven Smith at long-off (India subcontinent only) 9:12pm Alright, we're ready for the chase. It's Finch and Short coming out to open. Wade is slated to bat No. 3. Chahar with the ball. Chahar to Finch, 1 leg bye good length and into the pads, looks for the flick and cops it on the pad Natarajan to Maxwell, OUT huge appeal for lbw! And Kohli has reviewed almost before the ball stops rolling away. Where did it pitch? Was smashing the stumps for sure. Maxwell playing back to a short of a length delivery. Beaten for pace. We have a small delay waiting for ball tracking. And now the pitch map is missing from the replay. Here it comes... Sundar to Short, 1 leg bye deflects off the pad to short fine leg as he misses the pull...was a short ball, he missed out Chahal to Short, 1 wide wide outside off, he misses the cut and gets the wide call...Kohli isn't impressed Player of the match is Yuzvendra Chahal, INDIA
Match_Report: India 161 for 7 (Rahul 51, Jadeja 44*, Henriques 3-22, Starc 2-34) beat Australia 150 for 7 (Finch 35, Short 34, Chahal 3-25, Natarajan 3-30) by 11 runs Concussion substitute Yuzvendra Chahal plucked three vital wickets and opened a fresh chapter in cricket's long history of debating topics after being chosen - controversially - to replace Ravindra Jadeja, delivering India a comfortable victory in the opening T20I at Manuka Oval in Canberra. ALSO WATCH: Match highlights - Jadeja, Chahal, Natarajan help India win series opener (India subcontinent only) Jadeja's exit from the contest - he suffered a hamstring injury first and was then hit on the helmet in the last over of India's innings - allowed India to call upon a wristspinner in Chahal, who had been harshly treated during the ODI series but found himself defending a serviceable total on the night and responding grandly. Yuzvendra Chahal made a big impact after coming on as a concussion substitute Getty Images In contrast, the Australians gradually lost grip of a contest that had appeared more or less in their keeping when India were restricted to 114 for 6 with 19 balls of their innings remaining after Aaron Finch sent them in to bat. A target of 162 should still have been well within the grasp of Finch's team, but their innings sank steadily into the mire thanks to Chahal, T Natarajan's zippy left-armers, and Virat Kohli's growing command of the battlefield. Starc returns in finer fettle Something was not quite right about Mitchell Starc in the first two ODIs, and he was missing from the third with what was described as a minor side and/or rib complaint.

Commentary_Highlights: Ricky Ponting has won his 6th toss in a row and Australia will bowl first. McKay to McCullum, OUT good length as McCullum comes down the track, he is hurried up and he pushes in the air to Ponting at mid off McKay to Guptill, 1 leg bye back of a length in at the body and he beats Guptill's bat and it takes him on the body and they take a leg bye into the off side Johnson to Stewart, OUT full outside off and Stewart plays with no conviction and edges through to Haddin, New Zealand in early trouble here at the 'Cake Tin' Watson to Taylor, OUT bumper from Watson outside off and Talylor pulls it high into the leg side and Bollinger moves around from fine leg to take an easy catch in the deep. Watson, once again, makes the important breakthrough Johnson to Vettori, 1 wide bouncer is very short and Vettori goes underneath and it's called wide Johnson to Vettori, 1 wide Johnson tries around the wicket and it doesn't work immediately as he bowls down leg Hauritz to Styris, SIX runs tossed up and hammered over mid wicket for six, that's massive and that's his fifty Hopes to Styris, OUT good length ball and it seams back into him, he gets an inside edge and hits middle and off stump, great delivery Bollinger to Vettori, OUT Vettori steps away to leg, Bollinger hits the perfect channel, Vettori plays and misses and Bollinger cleans him out, well bowled buyt some poor batting from New Zealand here Hauritz to Hopkins, OUT Hopkins looks to comes down the pitch but it's short and he moves but to cut but edges it to Haddin and Australia are jubilant again Watson to Tuffey, 1 leg bye angled into the pads, Tuffey misses out as it takes him on the thigh pad and they take a leg bye Johnson to McCullum, OUT good length and McCullum tries to play through the leg side, he gets a leading edge straight up into the air and Johnson moves back and collects the catch Johnson to McCullum, 1 wide full and wide down leg McKay to Tuffey, OUT low full toss which Tuffey hits high into the air and Ponting moves forward from the mid wicket boundary, gets under it safely and completes the catch Johnson and McKay both took two wickets but it was a good all-round performance from Australia to contain the hosts to 241. Another good performance from Australia in the field and with the ball. They took wickets at crucial times, just as New Zealand started to build partnerships, as they have done right throughout the series. This weekend also sees the start of the 2010 Formula One season. For live commentary, analysis, reports and photos, check out our sister site ESPNF1. This is Marc Ellison saying thanks for joining us this series and see you again soon. Bye for now. Bond to Ponting, OUT good quick bumper to Ponting first up and he is surprised by the pace, shapes to pull but then decides against it, it takes him on the helmet, close to his gloves and it goes through to Hopkins, New Zealand go up a Vettori to Watson, 1 wide angled down the leg side and called wide Southee to White, OUT good length ball and White tries to hit over the top again but closes the face slightly and it goes high in the air and Vettori moves back from mid off to take the catch, important breakthrough from the hosts Southee to Voges, OUT back of a length and he tries to cut but misses and it goes through to Hopkins, the New Zealanders appeal in unison and Asad Rauf gives it out. Voges might be unlucky there McCullum to Watson, OUT quicker delivery and Watson drives, plays a fraction too early and hits it to Taylor at mid wicket That breakthrough is a big one for the home side and is reward for some good tight bowling to Watson over the l Southee to Hussey, OUT yorker length from Southee and Hussey goes down on one knee trying to lap it but he misses and the ball cannons into leg stump, crucial breakthrough for New Zealand as they have the dangerman back in the hut Southee to Johnson, 1 wide bouncer is well down the leg side and it's called wide Southee to Johnson, OUT length ball from Southee and Johnson tries to swing it high into the stands but he mistimes it and Franklin gets underneath it at long on and takes the catch This weekend also sees the start of the 2010 Formula One season. For live commentary, analysis, reports and photos, check out our sister site ESPNF1. This is Marc Ellison saying thanks for joining us this series and see you again soon. Bye for now. Player of the match is Tim Southee, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 241 for 9 (Styris 55) beat Australia 190 (Watson 53, Bond 4-26, Southee 4-36) by 51 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Scott Styris was the highest scorer for the match with 55 Getty Images Tim Southee and Shane Bond ensured New Zealand's series finished on a high but with the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy already conceded, it was only a consolation victory for the hosts over Australia. The 51-run triumph might at least give New Zealand some spark heading in to the Test series, which begins up the road at the Basin Reserve on Friday, and it left the ODI scoreline at 3-2. Ricky Ponting didn't lose a toss for the whole series and again made New Zealand set a target, but this time on a two-paced pitch their 241 for 9 appeared competitive. A double-wicket maiden from Bond early on put Australia on the back foot before Southee ran through the middle-order with 4 for 36 to confirm the win as Australia were dismissed for 190 with 3.5 overs to spare.

Commentary_Highlights: Ricky Ponting has won the toss and Australia will bowl first. Ponting is happy with the formula they used during the last match in Hamilton and he sees that as the best way to win the game and the series. Amazingly, it's his fourth straight correct call with the toss. Harris to McCullum, SIX runs Harris drops short and McCullum is back and pulling over the short boundary at fine leg for six into the construction site Watson to Guptill, OUT Watson is full again and Guptill isn't totally in control of the drive, nonetheless he hits it pretty cleanly but just off the carpet and Ponting swoops at short cover and collects a good catch low down, big wicket for Australia Johnson to Taylor, 1 wide Johnson errs on line and he strays down leg Johnson to Taylor, 5 wide great bumper from Johnson and Taylor just sways inside the line and it really takes off and flies over Haddin for four and it's called too high. Harsh decision going against Johnson there Johnson to Taylor, 1 wide pitched up and far too wide of off stump Johnson to Taylor, 1 leg bye Johnson misses his line again and it takes Taylor on the thigh and falls into the leg side Watson to Taylor, 1 leg bye good channel nips back and Taylor tries to square cut but misses, it takes him on the back pad but he's hit outside the line of off and Asad Rauf says not out Watson to McCullum, SIX runs McCullum advances and seizes the moment by hammering a good length ball over cover to the short boundary for six. He hit that like a tracer bullet. Just so clean. He will need to bat for a long period today if New Zealand are to post a competitive score Hopes to McCullum, 3 wide angled down the leg side and Haddin misses the ball and removes the bails without the ball and they get a couple to fine leg Hopes to Taylor, OUT full on leg stick and Taylor clips it from the middle of the bat out to deep square leg where Hussey moves quickly and takes a good diving catch low down Hauritz to Stewart, OUT Stewart comes down the track, looks to hit it straight down the ground in the air but drags it towards Watson at long on who takes the simplest of catches Hauritz to McCullum, OUT uses his feet and chips it straight to White at mid wicket. Poor dismissal as the pressure told and Australia are extremely happy to remove the dangerman Hopes to Styris, OUT Hopes hits a good fullish length and Styris plays a fraction early, it takes a leading edge and floats back to Hopes who takes a good catch low down in his follow through Johnson to Vettori, OUT full and swings into Vettori who stays on the crease and is trapped dea in front, no problems giving that out for umpire Baxter, that was very adjacent Hopes to Hopkins, 1 wide bumper from Hopes and it's too high and just down the leg side so called wide Hauritz to Franklin, OUT Franklin goes down on one knee and tries to sweep a ball that is down the leg side, he gets a glove on it and drags it back onto the stumps. That is unlucky but when things aren't goin so well those things tend to go against you Hauritz to Tuffey, SIX runs fuller again from Hauritz, Tuffey goes down on one knee and sweeps over deep backward square for six Hauritz to Tuffey, SIX runs full and wide of off stump, Tuffey goes down on one knee and slog sweeps straight down the ground fro six more. That's three in a row for the big fella! Sensational stuff Watson to Hopkins, OUT back of a length and Hopkins tries to play square into the off side but it takes the outside edge and through to Haddin. Crucial breakthrough as it's the first ball of the Batting Power Play Harris to Tuffey, OUT half volley and Tuffey cracks it back at Harris and he twists in his follow through to take a superb grab and Tuffey's cameo is over. That is a superb cacth from Harris, you just can't keep him out of the action, nor the wickets Johnson to Bond, OUT pitched up on off stump, Bond tries to hit it over mid on but gets it low on the bat and Hauritz moves forward and takes a good catch at ground level and New Zealand are bowled out for the third consecutive match 7.40pm The players are on their way back out onto the field with Australia needing 200 to win from just 34 overs. Power Play 1 is 7 overs, Power Play 2 (bowling) is 4 overs and Power Play 3 (batting) is 3 overs long. Bond to begin to Watson 6.55pm The rain has stopped and the ground staff are out in the middle trying to dry the ground which is quite damp without having any areas of the ground clogged with surface water. 6.05pm It is still raining here and while it is not heavy it has been a consistent downpour. There is enough moisture out there to keep the players from the field for a time yet. If we are able to get play before 6.30pm there will be no loss of overs, however, from that time on we will be losing time and overs. I will keep Nathan Hauritz was the pick of the bowlers for the visitors, taking three for 46, with his only blip being hit for three consecutive sixes by Daryl Tuffey. Shane Watson continues to take crucial wickets at vital moments, dismissing Guptill just when New Zealand were starting to gain the upper hand and then Hopkins from the Tuffey to Ponting, SIX runs Ponting advances and hits Tuffey straight back over his head for six. He didn't time it perfectly but he got it well enough to drop just over the rope. Tuffey must be finding this hard to handle after it looked as though he had him LBW just two overs back Bond to Hussey, 1 leg bye back of a length in at the hip and Hussey gets his thigh pad on it and takes the leg bye to fine leg On behalf of the crew here at Cricinfo, this is Marc Ellison signing off. Bye for now, see you in two days time. Nathan Hauritz made the important breakthroughs, nabbing McCullum, Stewart and Franklin in a spell that squeezed the life out of the New Zealand innings. Watson, again, provided the crucial partnership-breaking wickets and finished with for two for 24. Cameron Whites deserves a lot of praise for bringing the game home with 50 not out and his amazing summer continues. Hussey and Voges played important innings too. Australia take the series 3-1 with one game remaining with another comprehensive win here in Auckland. Australia won by 6 wickets (with 17 balls remaining) (D/L method) Player of the match is Cameron White, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 202 for 4 (White 50*, Ponting 50) beat New Zealand 238 (McCullum 61, Hauritz 3-46) by 6 wickets (D/L method) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Mitchell Johnson picked up two wickets in Australia's win Getty Images The Chappell-Hadlee Trophy has remained in Australian hands after Ricky Ponting and Cameron White led their team to a six-wicket win that secured the series 3-1. Rain played some part in the outcome but it was mostly New Zealand's watered-down batting display that left their fans feeling gloomy and consigned Saturday's fifth match in Wellington to dead-rubber status. The hosts had only themselves to blame for failing to bat out their overs and after rain reduced the target from 239 off 50 overs to 200 from 34 overs, Australia found their way home with 17 balls to spare. Cameron White and Michael Hussey completed the chase, which was set up by Ponting and Shane Watson, and despite a couple of quick wickets in the middle from Daniel Vettori the visitors were on track for most of the evening. The Man of the Match, White was cool with an unbeaten 50 and Hussey finished on 28, easing any tension the Australians felt when Adam Voges (34) was caught at midwicket with 50 runs still required.

Commentary_Highlights: Harris to Ingram, OUT cracking delivery from Harris, he hits a good length and Ingram plays without intent and edges through to Haddin who takes the simplest of catches. Great start for Australia Bollinger to McCullum, OUT good length, McCullum moves back and looks to push into the off side, it takes the inside edge back onto his pads and then onto the stumps and Bollinger is rapt with that. Well bowled, the change of angle did the trick Johnson to Guptill, OUT fuller, a fraction slower and Guptill drives from low on the bat in the air to White at short cover who takes a very easy catch, well bowled Johnson and the Australians are delighted Hauritz to Broom, 1 bye nicely flighted from Hauritz and Broom is beaten on the inside edge and Haddin can't hold on and they take a bye. That has turned a mile from outside off Johnson to Broom, OUT cracking ball from Johnson as he spears it into leg stump, it swings away just enough and Broom is squared up trying to play to mid on/mid wicket and it takes the edge through to Watson at first slip. Australia and Johnson break what was a promising partnership Watson to Taylor, OUT bumper from Watson and Taylor takes the bait, pulling off the top edge out to Hussey on the square leg fence, he moves forward and takes the catch low down. Watson has a real knack of taking wickets at crucial times and there's another. Advantage Australia. Taylor absolutely furious Bollinger to Hopkins, SIX runs Bollinger goes short and Hopkins upper cuts over third man for six. Daryl Tuffey, who is not playing due to a calf strain, stands up off his seat and takes a comfortable catch in the stands Watson to Styris, SIX runs back of a length but just a fraction too straight and Styris whips him over backward square for a maximum. Great timing Watson to Styris, OUT fuller from Watson, Styris tires to hit him straight down the ground over the top, he plays too early and gets it high in the air and Harris moves forward from long off to take the catch at mid off Johnson to Hopkins, 1 wide full and too wide of off stump Harris to Hopkins, OUT low full toss and Hopkins drives in the air to Watson at mid off. He got underneath it but got it high on the blade with no timing whatsoever. Important breakthrough for Australia with only Southee and Mason to come Harris to Southee, OUT Southee walks slightly across his stumps and tries to work it through the leg side and it sneaks past his pads and takes leg stump and New Zealand sink further into trouble! Harris with another breakthrough Johnson to Bond, OUT full and straight and Bond drives and edges through to Haddin and Australia wrap up the innings quickly. Southee to Haddin, 1 leg bye too straight from Southee and Haddin gets a pad on it and they take a leg bye into the leg side Guptill to Hussey, 1 wide drifts down the leg side and called wide Vettori to Haddin, OUT 76 kph, well flighted and Haddin tries to hammer it out of the ground but misses and Hopkins has plenty of time to remove the bails. The end of a great innings from Haddin, not a bad replacement at the top of the order... Haddin (110) and Ponting (69) added 151 for the second wicket and the match was over pretty early in that sense with both players looking in total control at the crease. Australia win by the comfortable margin of six wickets with 16 balls to spare. Australia outplayed New Zealand in all departments today and will take a lot of momentum into the 4th ODI in Auckland on Thursday. Australia won by 6 wickets (with 16 balls remaining) Player of the match is Brad Haddin, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 248 for 4 (Haddin 110, Ponting 69) beat New Zealand 245 (Taylor 62, Johnson 3-41, Harris 3-48) by 6 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Brad Haddin's best ODI score buried New Zealand Getty Images Brad Haddin's second one-day international century gave Australia a 2-1 lead and the most one-sided victory of the tour, as they chased down their target with 16 balls to spare. Haddin's 110 was his highest ODI score and he ended Daniel Vettori's hopes of winning what he said before the match was "the most important game of the series". Ricky Ponting was annoyed in the opening two games at his batsmen's inability to capitalise on their starts, and they resolved that problem at Seddon Park. Ponting made 69 and combined with Haddin for a matchwinning 151-run partnership that justified Ponting's rare decision to send New Zealand in. It is a gamble he has taken 24 times in his ODI captaincy career for a remarkable 20 victories.

Commentary_Highlights: Welcome to Eden Park for the second ODI. Australia have won the toss and are batting first. No changes for the visitors, Daniel Vettori is back for Jacob Oram and Ross Taylor has missed out Bond to Watson, 1 wide and it's well wide of off stump, Billy Bowden calls it a wide and there's no doubt about that decision Tuffey to Haddin, SIX runs what a great shot! Outstanding strike from Haddin as he walks a couple of paces down the pitch and lifts this one from off stump over wide midwicket, he's g Tuffey to Watson, 1 wide tight call there from Rudi Koertzen, Watson tries to lash Tuffey through point but misses and it is pretty much on the line that guides the umpires regarding Tuffey to Watson, OUT gone! Watson tries to go over midwicket but he hasn't timed that well enough. There's a man on the boundary, it's Martin Guptill, and he takes a safe catch. Vettori to Ponting, OUT oh Ricky, what was that? So much for getting his eye in, Ponting tries for a big slog over midwicket but gets a thick top edge that flies high and is taken by Vettori to Haddin, OUT what a catch! Magnificent return take from Vettori! Haddin has positively laced that drive after taking a couple of steps down the pitch, it flew wide of Vettor Bond to Clarke, OUT short and Clarke tries to pull, with both feet off the ground the ball lobbing to mid on for a simple catch Bond to Hussey, 1 wide short outside off, Rudi Koertzen says it's a wide and on replay it looks a poor call Southee to Hussey, 1 wide short and tries to hook, a big shout for caught behind perhaps to con the umpire into not calling a wide, which Bowden does eventually call Tuffey to White, SIX runs short and hooked it away flat and somehow for six! Good shot but I'd doubt if that would be six at any other venue in the world Southee to Hussey, 1 wide short down leg side, obvious wide Bollinger to McCullum, SIX runs short and hooks it in the deep square leg construction site - McCullum seeing them very well early Johnson to McCullum, OUT tries to work to leg, getting an edge and Haddin dives to his right, in front of slip and hangs onto a blinder of a catch. The end of a brief but entertaining Harris to Broom, OUT an appeal first up and he is gone - caught on the crease at this one looked pretty good - dead line, height not an issue Johnson to Franklin, OUT tries to pull and he gets a glove down the leg side, Franklin walks and he is gone -- Kiwis in all sorts of bother as Franklin limps off Johnson to Guptill, 1 wide wide of the batsman and swinging further away Watson to Guptill, OUT plays back to one that moves away slightly, the edge is found and taken by Haddin - Guptil goneski!!! Watson to Styris, 1 wide short and leg side, tries to pull missing it and gets a wide Hauritz to Styris, OUT same shot as the previous ball, but this time he hits it in the air and Ponting leaps up and takes a good catch - a vital wicket and the Kiwis chances take a bi Harris to Vettori, 1 wide leg side wide as Vettori slightly distracts him by moving the off side Watson to Hopkins, OUT bumper, hooks at it getting a top to long leg where Bollinger holds onto a catch. Might have been a fraction high for the shot, but when you need 8 an over to w Hauritz to Vettori, 1 leg bye tries to work to leg and gets a bit of bat onto it Johnson to Bond, OUT very full and he plays inside it and he loses his stump -- well bowled by Johnson, at last a bowler goes full and straight and it has paid off Johnson to Vettori, 1 leg bye late inswinger, hits him on the pad but angling down leg Harris to Vettori, OUT steps to the off side and he tries to glance it, but misses and loses his off stump - Australia wins the game and levels the series at one apiece What a finish - full credit to the Aussies for getting over the line, another great game of 50 over cricket in the battle for the Chappell Hadlee trophy. Smart bowling in the end from Harris Player of the match is Daniel Vettori, NZ
Match_Report: Injury doubts over Ross Taylor and James Franklin have led to the elevation of the uncapped Shanan Stewart to New Zealand's squad ahead of the third ODI in Hamilton on Tuesday. Stewart, the Canterbury batsman, is in the middle of an excellent season and has won some recognition following the hamstring problems of Taylor and Franklin. The pair is in doubt for the remainder of the five-match ODI series, with Taylor pulling out before the loss in Auckland and Franklin hobbling off during the game. Mark Greatbatch, New Zealand's coach, said they were unlikely to play on Tuesday but Taylor was the greater chance to return for the final fixtures. Stewart, 27, is in outstanding form after making 227 against Central Districts on Sunday and has been redirected to Hamilton.

Commentary_Highlights: Tuffey to Clarke, OUT Clarke comes down the track and Tuffey bends his back and surprises Clarke as he tries to guide it fine through third man but it takes the outside edge and through to McCullum to complete the catch Tuffey to White, OUT Tuffey strikes right away with the new-ish ball as he hits a good length, it seams back in just a fraction and White plays all around it. Big strike for New Zealand Southee to Hussey, 1 bye slower length ball from Southee and Hussey swings and misses but it bounces in front of McCullum and he can't pick it up cleanly and they take a bye Southee to Hopes, OUT Southee strikes with the yorker. If it ain't broke why fix it seems to be the mindset from Southee as Hopes tries to swing it over mid wicket but the ball cannons into middle stump Bond to Hussey, OUT Bond goes full but not quite yorker length and he looks to swing it over the leg side but misses and it clips the outside of off stump and the bails trickle off the stumps Tuffey to Hauritz, OUT Tuffey bowls a half volley and Hauritz gets under it and chips it to long off where Nathan McCullum dives low to catch it after initially misjudging it Right, well New Zealand will be rather pleased with their effort to restrict Australia to under 300. Most of the Australian batsmen got starts but they seemed to struggle with the pace of the wicket at times and were unable to push on. Some good death bowling from Southee Johnson to Ingram, OUT fullish delivery and Ingram drives in the air over mid off, Hussey moves back very quickly and takes a great catch over his shoulder and has to fall to the ground to complete the catch. Superb snare from Mr. Cricket Watson to Guptill, 1 wide angled down the leg side and called wide Hopes to Taylor, SIX runs just a fraction short and Taylor loves that length when he's in the right mood and he pull/slogs over mid wicket for a maximum! Hauritz to Franklin, OUT tossed up by Hauritz, Franklin tries to play inside the line and play the ball into the off side but it takes the outside edge and Haddin juggles it but takes it on the third attempt behind the stumps. Good catch and an important break thro Johnson to Taylor, 1 wide bumper from Johnson and it's just far too short this time Watson to Taylor, OUT Watson goes short and hurries Taylor for room and he pulls the ball high on the bat out to mid wicket where Hussey moves around safely to complete the catch. Great break through for Australia Bollinger to Broom, OUT Bollinger hustles in and bowls back of a length and Broom looks to cut but chops it back onto his stumps. The Aussie's are joyous and Bollinger strikes again! The momentum has really shifted since Taylor's dismissal Bollinger to Styris, SIX runs length ball from Bollinger and Styris just hits through the line and over mid off for six! What a finish and what an innings from Styris! New Zealand always looked on target for victory with Ross Taylor at the wicket but when he was out from the bowling of Watson at 204 for five in the 39th over, New Zealand needed an old hand to stand up. New Zealand win by two wickets with four balls remaining. The pressure was on him towards the death and Styris comes through with a fantastic innings under pressure. Styris was a late inclusion when Daniel Vettori had to pull out with a neck complaint and he has justified New Zealand won by 2 wickets (with 4 balls remaining) Player of the match is Ross Taylor, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 281 for 8 (Taylor 70, Styris 49*) beat Australia 275 for 8 (Hussey 59, Tuffey 3-58) by two wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Scott Styris launched a six in the final over to seal New Zealand's win Getty Images Scott Styris went from probable 12th man to match-winner after guiding New Zealand to a two-wicket victory in a tense chase of 276 in Napier. Styris began the day outside New Zealand's starting XI but was called in late due to Daniel Vettori's stiff neck, and the inclusion helped Ross Taylor start his international captaincy career on a high. Styris sealed the win with a six over long-off from the second ball of the 50th over from Doug Bollinger and finished unbeaten on 49 from 34 deliveries. He roared as the ball sailed over the boundary and was pumped up after he and Mitchell Johnson appeared to clash head and helmet in the 46th over, in which Styris slogged two boundaries. He and Shane Bond had combined for a 35-run stand that meant Jacob Oram did not have to bat after suffering a potentially serious injury to his left knee in the field.

Commentary_Highlights: 11.00am Right, first blood to Collingwood! England have won the toss and will bowl first. Collingwood reckons the pitch looks good but won't change in character as the day goes on. Both teams are unchanged so will line up like this: Sidebottom to Watson, OUT gone! Sidebottom strikes! Watson flashes at a short and widish ball, flies off the top edge to Kieswetter, who can't quite hold on, bounces off his gloves and Swann takes the rebound! Massive breakthrough for England. Sidebottom to Clarke, 1 wide another one shoved in down the leg side, Clarke attempted to fiddle it away, but misses and it's another wide Bresnan to Clarke, OUT Warner gone this time! England on fire, Clarke pushes a good-length ball to cover, and then attempts a single, Warner tares down but Lumb swooped in and under-armed his throw on to the stumps at the strikers end to leave Warner well short of his ground Sidebottom to Haddin, OUT Sidebottom strikes again! Australia lose another wicket! Short and down the leg side from Sidebottom, hardly a great ball, but Haddin swung hard at it and it came off what looks like the thigh, Kieswetter took an excellent catch high to his left. Great catch but very unlucky for Haddin Bresnan to Hussey, 1 leg bye Hussey can't quite find his range at the moment, this was arrowed down the leg side, but he couldn't get the flick away and it comes off the pads for a leg bye Swann to Clarke, OUT brilliant from Collingwood! Fantastic catch! Swann flighted it up, and beat Clarke in the air as he skipped down the wicket, in the end it's chipped into what looked a vacant straight midwicket, but Collingwood dived to his left from short midwicket, two-handed and plucked it out the air Wright to White, OUT White gone this time! Broad takes the catch! Really good from Broad, it was another fullish ball, White had a big swish and it came off the outside edge miles in the air, Broad called for it straight away from point and ran behind him to hold on to an excellent, crucial catch Yardy to Hussey, SIX runs well, finally the shackles are broken! Shorter and Hussey swiped it brilliantly, sending it miles over midwicket for six Sidebottom to Hussey, 1 wide this time it will be a wide, Hussey looking to edge leg side of the ball and swing through cover, Sidebottom shoving it outside off, but too far for the umpire A short wait is over, the players are out in the middle and we're all set for England's chase. Put your seatbelts on, kids! Johnson to Pietersen, 5 wide and the change of angle has done him. That started wide of leg and went further, beating a diving Brad Haddin and away to the boundary "When you want to be the best you've got to beat the best. When we got them three wickets down early doors, we gave ourselves a great opportunity. We want to kick on from this. This is the first trophy we've ever won, we're going to enjoy it, we'r going to savour it." So, hugs, handshakes and backslaps all round as England have won their first world title in cricket! They were picked out as the dark horses to win this tournament, and after a stuttering, rain-affected start to the group stages, they hit their stride superbly in the Super Eights, winning all their games in that stage, followed by a thumping win in the semi-finals over Sri Lanka. The England dug-out leapt as one when the w England won by 7 wickets (with 18 balls remaining) Player of the match is Craig Kieswetter, ENG
Match_Report: England 148 for 3 (Kieswetter 63) beat Australia 147 for 6 (D Hussey 59) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Hawkeye Kevin Pietersen was named Player of the Tournament after another irresistible display with the bat Getty Images Craig Kieswetter and Kevin Pietersen powered England to their first ICC global title with an irresistible 111-run stand for the second wicket, as Australia were outmuscled in a battle of the bowlers at Bridgetown. Despite a brave recovery led by David Hussey, who made 59 from 54 balls, Australia's hopes of claiming the only world title to have eluded them were devastated from the moment they lost three wickets in 13 legitimate deliveries in a stunning start to the contest. Chasing a target of 148, Kieswetter and Pietersen broke the back of the chase in an 11-over alliance, but fittingly it was left to England's captain, Paul Collingwood, to seal the victory with 18 balls to spare. At the moment of victory, he was mobbed by his jubilant team-mates as they poured out of the dug-out, with incredulity and triumph writ large on their features. Barely 12 months ago, Collingwood was leading England to defeat against the Netherlands in the opening contest of the 2009 event.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and chosen to bowl. Tait to Salman Butt, 1 wide And the third one arrives. This one sails high over Salman. Wide. Nannes hit the full length. Tait is bowling short. Nannes to Kamran, 1 wide Will it be short? Will it be a yorker? will it be a slower one? Well .. it's an overpitched delivery well down the leg side. Watson to Salman Butt, 1 wide bouncer just outside leg stump, Butt goes down under Johnson to Kamran, OUT What a catch from Warner! Stunning! Kamran falls after an awesome knock. He drove this one uppishly towards deep cover where Warner rushed forward and threw himself forward to take the catch Nannes to Afridi, 1 wide starts his spell with a wide down the leg side. Afridi walks towards square-leg. Nannes grimaces. Hussey to Afridi, OUT Big moment this. Afridi is gone. IT was a full delivery outside off and Afridi tried to heave it away but ended up slicing it towards point. WAtson came in, Haddin rushed out and both collided but Haddin takes it. He was the man with the gloves and it was his catch. Nannes to Khalid Latif, OUT Warner again. Simple catch this time. It was the short delivery around off stump, Latif tried to pull but was in no position for it. The ball lobbed of the edge to mid-off Hussey to Abdul Razzaq, 2 wide pushes this full and outside off and Haddin can't collect Hussey to Abdul Razzaq, 1 wide another wide down the off side. The wheels are coming off Tait to Abdul Razzaq, 1 bye full and well outside the off stump, just inside the wide line.. swing and a miss.. Haddin collects and under-arms the throw but by then they are across. Amir to Warner, 1 wide banged in short, Warner ducks and it has been called a wide. Afridi is surprised with that call. Amir to Warner, OUT Warner is gone for a duck. They are dancing in the aisles. It was the full length delivery going away from Warner who cuts it straight to backward point. That boy Umar again! What a start for Pakistan. What a tame dismissal. A very soft shot. Amir to Watson, OUT What a moment this. The openers are back in the hutch. Pressure. Watson has hit a full delivery straight to long-on! The Pakistan dug-out is celebrating. The fans are screaming in joy. Enter Pup. The Australian captain is in the middle. What can he do now? Abdur to Haddin, OUT Stumped! Haddin went dancing down the track but the ball curved past him. It dipped rapidly on the advancing Haddin, gripped the surface and broke away to Kamran who does the rest. Third wicket down and Australia are wobbling here in St Lucia. Afridi to White, SIX runs Violent thump! White is turning it on here. Again he went down on his knee, again he went for the slog sweep to a delivery outside off,and again he connected superbly Abdur to Hussey, OUT Another twist. Another wicket. Pakistan keep the heat on. This one was flighted on the leg and middle and Hussey thought .. I will push it to midwicket and get a single and give the strike to White. Mistake. The ball was slower in pace, it grips and straightens and perhaps stops a touch on Afridi to Hussey, SIX runs The drama continues here at St Lucia. Immense fun. Another short delivery from Afridi which is a surprise. Another fab pull shot from Hussey which is not a surprise. The game remains alive. Amir to White, OUT Is this the moment of the chase? And would you believe it, it was a full toss that did the trick for Pakistan. A full toss on the off stump line. White's eyes opens up and he tries to smash it through the line to long-off. Perhaps that was the mistake. He couldn't find enough power behind it Ajmal to Smith, OUT Ajmal can be such a difficult bowler to get away in these circumstances. Those tantalizing doosras. It landed on the middle stump line, Smith was down the track and actually tried to loft it over the off-side which perhaps indicates that he thought it might be the doosra. But no wood on leat Ajmal to Hussey, SIX runs Ajmal drifts to the leg side and Hussey jumps at the opportunity. He was well inside the crease and swings it over backward square-leg boundary Ajmal to Hussey, 1 leg bye full delivery, Hussey tries to heave it to the on side but doesn't connect. A leg bye will give him the strike though And that's it from us. Thanks for logging on. Good bye and good luck. Hussey let out a roar of joy as he hit that shot. Waqar Younis hung his head down. Joy and sorrow overlap on the field. Australia won by 3 wickets (with 1 ball remaining) Player of the match is Michael Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 197 for 7 (Michael Hussey 60*, White 43) beat Pakistan 191 for 6 (Umar 56, Kamran 50) by three wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Michael Hussey pulled off a sensational run-chase to send Australia into the final Getty Images This is what makes a champion side and don't Pakistan know it. In 40 overs Australia re-taught their opponents the lessons of four days in Sydney from earlier this year, the moral of which remains that till the precise moment Australia are out, they are never out. Pakistan were on top for three days in Sydney, and 39 overs here, but Australia hunted away, gripped in, stuck at it. And with one ball to go, they pulled off an astonishing chase of 192 to enter Sunday's final, leaving on Pakistan the deepest kind of scars in an already abusive relationship. On this form, England needn't bother turning up.

Commentary_Highlights: Hello and welcome to the last match of the Super Eights. It's West Indies and Australia in St Lucia, and the news from the middle is West Indies have won the toss and elected to bat. Nannes to Gayle, OUT oh dear! He's gone! Angled in and this ball doesn't swing at all, and rattles Gayle's stumps. The ball jagged back a little off the seam, Gayle has played the wrong line. Johnson to Sarwan, 1 leg bye pushes a single to the off side Johnson to Sarwan, OUT oh, that's extremely unfortunate. What a shocking piece of luck for Dwayne Bravo. Sarwan drives fast and straight - too straight - as the ball clips Johnson's fingers and rockets into the stumps at the non-striker's end with Bravo backing up out of his ground Smith to Deonarine, OUT Deonarine's inclusion hasn't helped West Indies, he's gone for the glory shot over deep midwicket but straight to the man on the boundary Johnson to Ramdin, 1 wide wrong line from Johnson this time, down leg and called wide Johnson to Ramdin, OUT gone, straightforward dismissal with a ball angled across Ramdin, who looks to dab the ball away and simply gets a thick edge behind Clarke to Pollard, SIX runs and this time Pollard goes for it, he's got down on one knee to slog sweep, he had no intention of keeping that ball down and lifted it high over midwicket for six Hussey to Sarwan, OUT and it goes from bad to worse for West Indies. Sarwan, the last of the specialist batsmen, has tried to clear the boundary at long-off but has simply found the man in the deep Hussey to Taylor, OUT two wickets in the over for Dave Hussey, Taylor goes for a big swipe and gets a thickish edge that is taken at gully Smith to Pollard, OUT gone! Lovely piece of bowling from Smith, he's turned the ball just past the bat of Pollard, who is trying to get forward and work through leg, and Haddin whips the bails off, no need for the third umpire there Smith to Sammy, OUT first ball! Smith is on a hat-trick! Tossed up on leg and turning back to off, Sammy has gone for the drive but straight back to the bowler, who takes a good catch Watson to Benn, OUT gone, and that's the end of the innings. Watson goes full and straight and Benn can't get bat on that, it rattles his stumps So, West Indies have failed to bat out their overs and have crawled to 105. They need a miracle, now, to get through to the semi-finals. Steven Smith and Mitchell Johnson bowled really well, and of course Dirk Nannes got the all-important wicket of Chris Gayle in the first over. Australia will chase 106 - join us shortly for their reply. Australia are about to start their chase - they cannot be knocked out now. West Indies need to keep Australia to 81 to progress. Here's Jerome Taylor Taylor to Warner, SIX runs that is a massive six!
