Broad to Smith, OUT some joy here for England, Smith forehand-slaps a short ball but straight down to Anderson at long off Broad to Hussey, OUT gone this time! Broad gets another, Hussey slicing a drive down to long off, but it has been a superb innings, completely flipped this game on its head Brydon Coverdale has furiously typed out his bulletin to tell you more, so check that out. Hello folks, the players are back out in the middle and we're all set for what should be a cracking chase. I'm Liam Brickhill, and Sahil Dutta and I will be your commentators for the second innings. Tait to Strauss, 1 wide very quick again, but misdirected down the leg side this time and called wide Tait to Strauss, OUT clatter! That's the dismissal every fast bowler wants to see! Tait fires one in on a length, gets some nice shape in to the left-hander to beat his defensive poke and smash into the top of the off stump. That's a real sta Tait to Yardy, 1 wide speared down the leg side, that's a wide. So Yardy will have to face up to that delivery again... Tait to Yardy, OUT nope. I don't know what the thinking was sending Yardy in to face Tait, but it really hasn't worked. Tait fires one in fuller and Yardy simply leaves it - I don't think he quite picked the ball up - and the ball smashes int Bollinger to Morgan, 1 wide left-hander messes up the radar as he spears one down the leg side Bollinger to Morgan, 1 leg bye sharp yorker! Morgan is struck on the foot to cries of anguish from the Australian fielders, but that was slipping way down leg Hopes to Morgan, 1 wide pushed too far down leg, that's a wide Hopes to Morgan, OUT gone! What a catch! Morgan nailed a pull shot, smashing it flat towards a straightish midwicket, the Marsh in the deep ran round and dived, juggling the ball as he landed to clasp on to the catch Smith to Pietersen, OUT gone! Maybe that thigh won't get much of a testing then. It was short and slightly wide, Pietersen went back to cut but ends up with a bottom edge on to his foot which goes on to the stumps leaving England in a bit of Hussey to PD Collingwood, 1 wide flung well wide of the stumps, that's a huge wide Tait to Bresnan, OUT Ponting strikes! Brilliant from the Australian captain! Bresnan pushed towards him and set off for one, Ponting collected, spun and threw at the non-striker's end, direct hit has Bresnan miles short. Big strike that, sho Tait to PD Collingwood, OUT over and out! Tait strikes! Stumps clattered! Collingwood advanced down the track, bit of inswing beats the batsman and uproots the leg stump. Defiant knock from Collingwood, but all over now. Bollinger to Broad, OUT Duggie has done it! Terrific caught and bowled! Broad mistimed a check-drive back down the wicket, Bollinger stuck out a hand and found the ball in it! That should finally settle this game Tait to Swann, OUT that'll be all! Tait finishes it off, which is apt, with a slower ball, which isn't! Swann backed away and tried to carve it over mid off but he couldn't time it and ended up gifting a catch to mid off. Australia have come back very strongly from 3-0 down - they've beaten England comfortably in the last two games. It was Mike Hussey and Shaun Marsh's partnership that first turned the game towards Australia, but Shaun Tait nailed home the advantage Player of the match is Shaun Tait, AUS
Match_Report: Marker of the day Everything about this series has been viewed through an Ashes-shaped prism. At Cardiff England were delighted when their short-ball plan worked against Michael Clarke, and here a similar method proved successful against Ricky Ponting. Australia's captain has had problems against the short ball in recent times - stemming from a tasty head-to-head with Kemar Roach - and on this occasion he got into an awful tangle against Broad's bouncer and gloved a catch to Craig Kieswetter. Both sides will store that memory away for Brisbane. Timely wicket of the day Tim Paine has struggled for fluency throughout the series and it came to a head at Lord's with a laborious 90-ball 54.

Commentary_Highlights: 5.05pm Australia have won the toss and will bat. Malinga to Clarke, (no ball) oops! That's a chest-high full toss from Malinga, which is a scary prospect, but it was well down leg and the slower ball, which came out of the hand all wrong Malinga to Warner, 1 wide well wide of off stump, David Warner couldn't reach that and it's called a wide Fernando to Warner, OUT gone! Fernando breaks through Perera to Watson, OUT skied and taken by Murali at long-off! Watson tries to go over the top but it's another one off the toe of the bat, and Murali makes no mistake - what a start by Sri Lanka! Randiv to Hussey, OUT Randiv strikes first ball! Hussey looks to cut but is surprised by the bounce from Randiv's topspinner, an edge is well taken by Sangakkara. This is really unravelling for Australia. Randiv to Smith, OUT oh, good bowling from Randiv! Smith dances down the pitch and Randiv holds that ball back a little, doesn't impart much spin and it beats the bat, Smith is comprehensively stumped Randiv to Haddin, OUT two wickets in the over! Haddin's gone for the slog sweep and hasn't quite got enough on that, Mathews at deep midwicket takes a comfortable catch, Randiv gets another one Murali to Haddin, 1 wide wrong line, down leg side and called a wide Malinga to Hastings, 1 wide short and fast, Hastings hasn't much idea about that and lets it go through to Sangakkara. Oh, that's been called a wide, that's simply not the right decision, it was only head height Malinga to McKay, 1 wide oops, down leg side and that's justifiably called a wide The Australians are out on the field, Peter Siddle is warming up for his first ball in an international match since January. But it's Clint McKay to bowl the first over from the Prindiville Stand End. Nannes to Sangakkara, 1 wide short again, but this one is called wide, and rightly so as it's quite a way over head height Smith to Dilshan, OUT Smith gets a wicket, Dilshan has rather thrown it away there. He's danced down the pitch and tried to slog it over midwicket, his eyes already heading in the direction of his intended shot, but it's turned past him and Haddin whips off the bails Smith to Perera, SIX runs massive! That's easily the biggest six of the match, Perera has launched that one over long-on, just got to the pitch of the ball and then used all his muscle That's a comprehensive victory for Sri Lanka, they really did outplay Australia for the whole match. Early wickets had the Australians on the ropes and Randiv and Perera in particular ensured the target wasn't too high; then Sangakkara and Dilshan guided the chase. Sri Lanka won by 7 wickets (with 21 balls remaining) Player of the match is Suraj Randiv, SL
Match_Report: Sri Lanka 3 for 135 (Sangakkara 44*, Dilshan 41) beat Australia 8 for 133 (Haddin 35, Randiv 3-25) by 7 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Tillakaratne Dilshan's 41 off 34 balls helped swing Sri Lanka to victory AFP A brutal Sri Lankan performance delivered Australia their first Twenty20 defeat at home as Tillakaratne Dilshan and Kumar Sangakkara thrust the tourists to a commanding seven-wicket victory. The hosts were first overwhelmed by a stunning bowling display, dropping to 5 for 43 in the 11th over and finishing at 8 for 133, before becoming the victims of an explosive batting effort. The opener Dilshan guided the small chase with 41 off 34 balls while the captain Kumar Sangakkara registered a delightful 44 off 43 and the game was over 21 balls early. With the English squad staying a short walk away as they prepare for the Ashes - Kevin Pietersen was in the stands - Australia suffered their fourth Twenty20 loss in a row and their first in 11 games at home. The defeat felt as severe as the result inflicted by England in Southampton at the start of Australia's failed 2005 Ashes tour.

Commentary_Highlights: Yuvraj to Clarke, 1 leg bye huge appeal for lbw turned down. Full from Yuvraj, on middle and off as Clarke bounds out of the crease. Hits him on and around off stump as he misses the flick. Was he too far down? Was he outside the line? Leg bye taken towards third man. It landed on leg and was straightening. Might have hit middle and off, or might not have. Clarke was well for Ashwin to Hussey, OUT this time the lbw appeal is upheld, Hussey looked to be tiring over the past few overs, a short of length ball, Hussey looks to pull that one, he misses and is struck on the thigh pad on the back leg in front of middle and leg, that was going on to hit, no doubt, the umpire didn't have any either Vinay to White, SIX runs Wow, White gets a gift from his Royal Challengers Bangalore team-mate, a juicy full toss and White has the spectators scurrying by depositing that in the second tier beyond long-on 6.25pm: Still 20 minutes to go for the chase to start. Time enough for you to check out our free Chrome extension. Starc to Yuvraj, 1 wide slower one bowled short but down the leg side, called a wide Hauritz to Kohli, 1 leg bye got across and tried to work it into the leg side, goes off the pad, they steal a leg-bye Hastings to Kohli, 1 wide slow bouncer down the leg side, Kohli goes for a flamboyant pull, he misses and it is called a wide McKay to Kohli, SIX runs he wants to finish things off quickly now, slower one bowled on a length and he smashes it high and handsome into the stands over long-on India won by 5 wickets (with 7 balls remaining) Player of the match is Virat Kohli, INDIA
Match_Report: India 292 for 5 (Kohli 118, Raina 71*, Yuvraj 58) beat Australia 289 for 3 (Clarke 111*, White 89*, Hussey 69) by five wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Virat Kohli's calm century shepherded the chase AFP The target of 290 appeared to be stiff, especially when India were wobbling at 35 for 2 in the ninth over, but Virat Kohli and Yuvraj Singh maintained their sangfroid to get India close before the adventurous Suresh Raina sealed the win in style. Kohli, in particular, impressed. He not only lost Yuvraj in the 34th over with India still 118 runs adrift of the target but also, by then, was suffering from severe cramps and was forced to bat with a runner. If those hurdles fazed him, he didn't show it and went on to clinch the game in the company of Raina. The chase mirrored Australia's innings to an extent.

Commentary_Highlights: 10.00am Strauss calls heads, England have won the toss and will bowl first. What's more, it's confirmed that Tim Bresnan comes in for Steven Finn. Australia field an unchanged team, Punter says he wasn't sure what he was going to do first thing this morning - his instinct told him bat, but with the grass and moisture in the wicket the bowlers are likely to control proceed Tremlett to Watson, OUT third time lucky for England, Tremlett strikes with a cracker of a delivery, climbed from a length and rapped the glove, it looped gently to gully, simple enough chance for England to finally hold one Anderson to Ponting, 1 leg bye this time Anderson jumps wider of the crease and angles it in before swinging it away, the bowler was probably looking for too much though and it thuds off the pads for a single Bresnan to Hughes, OUT Bresnan has his first Ashes wicket and Hughes has gone. Full and wide, inviting a slash but Hughes didn't get enough of it, instead the edge flew straight to Pietersen who made no mistake in the gully Tremlett to Ponting, OUT gone! Tremlett strikes again, what a delivery. Spitting off a length and going away off the seam, Ponting is rooted to the crease and pushes at the delivery. A thick edge flies straight to Graeme Swann Tremlett to Clarke, 1 leg bye off the pad and trickling down to short fine leg, and they're through for a leg bye Anderson to Hussey, OUT edged! Anderson strikes straight away, and what a delivery to do it with. Landing on middle and off and shooting towards the slips, the length was full and Hussey was drawn into the drive, getting a good, healthy edge that flies through to Prior Anderson to Smith, OUT Smith gone now, always looked a matter of time, pushed very hard at this outside off, touch of nibble away off the pitch found the edge and Prior did the rest Anderson to Clarke, OUT brilliant bowling from Anderson, he's just worked Clarke over with consistent, probing away swing and this time it finds the edge, Clarke pushing at the ball, feathered edge and Prior collects the simple chance. Australia in total disarray Bresnan to Haddin, OUT Bresnan has another and Haddin has gifted him this, flat-footed waft of a drive, flicked the edge and went through to Strauss. Pretty miserable stuff this from the home side Anderson to Johnson, OUT Anderson has his man! Johnson's gone for a duck, this is a cracking delivery, seams away off a full length, finds the edge and Prior has his fourth catch Tremlett to Siddle, OUT there we go, another one is on his way and Australia are nine down. Tremlett pitches one up invitingly outside off, a touch of movement through the air and off the pitch takes the ball away from the bat and a regulation edge lands safely in Prior's gloves. His fifth catch today Tremlett to Hilfenhaus, OUT all over, Australia are out for 98 as Hilfenhaus feathers a sixth catch through to Prior That's tea in Melbourne. The hosts are all out for their lowest score against England at the MCG since Test cricket's very first game, way back in 1877. They've simply been blown away by seam and swing bowling of the highest standard. There are no real demons in this pitch - it's not hooping around corners. England were just the more disciplined team out there today. They Johnson to Prior, 1 leg bye nudged close on the leg side, there is some hesitation before the single is taken ... Johnson charges through and aims the ball towards the stumps with his right boot, but it goes wide. Would've been in all the same Hilfenhaus to Swann, OUT what a catch! The crowd were quiet for a good few seconds before they realised a wicket had actually just fallen. Banged in short again by Hilfenhaus, Swann hooks and a thick edge flew fast and straight and looked to be going over Haddin's head ... but he timed his salmon-leap to perfection and got both hands to it "Praveen Singh is forgetting about Hauritz who has made 2 centuries in his last 2 state test matches and a 50 in his last state ODI as well as taken quite a few wickets. Why is he off the cards?" Who knows, Bryce. For some reason they've felt they can't pick him. Lunch So, finally Australia work their way through England's line-up. One man they didn't get past is Jonathan Trott, who finishes with a majestic, unbeaten 168. Siddle bowled with real heart and finishes with a deserved 6 for 75, but England have a lead of 415 - which is, as Miller points out, an Ashes record margin for a team batting second - and Australia will have to Player of the match is Jonathan Trott, ENG
Match_Report: Match abandoned Australia v India Scorecard The ground staff couldn't beat the weather in Kochi AFP The opening match of the three-game India-Australia series was abandoned without a ball being bowled in Kochi. Heavy rain before the one-dayer saturated the ground and while the weather was clear at the scheduled start time, the clouds returned to send everyone home. It was an unfortunate result for the thousands of locals who were filling the stadium in their blue shirts. Both teams are fielding inexperienced squads so the expectation was high, but everyone will have to wait for the second match in Visakhapatnam on Wednesday. The Kerala Cricket Association has been criticised by former BCCI secretary SK Nair, who said better arrangements with respect to drainage and scheduling could have been made to prevent an abandonment.

Commentary_Highlights: Bhuvneshwar to Carey, OUT gone, Carey's nicked off to second slip Some inconsistent bounce playing on the minds of the batsmen here. Beautiful bowling by Bhuvi as well. Short of good length, kicks up a little more than he may have anticipated, and it straightens just enough to shave the outside edge. This time, because of the bounce, it carries to Kohli. Even so, he had to get down full tilt to hold onto it Bhuvneshwar to Finch, 1 leg bye this one moves back in and lobs away towards third man off the pad as Finch misses the flick Bhuvneshwar to Finch, OUT and after all that, Bhuvneshwar has his man. Finch's hardwork comes to an end. It's the inswinger again. It's given him a miserable tome and continues to do so. He's way forward and crouching to defend but the ball finds a way to nip in and hit him on the kneeroll Shankar to Marsh, 1 wide short of a length, skips down leg as he looks to glance it away Shankar to Marsh, 1 leg bye 124kph, half-volley outside leg, he tries to whip and misses, it comes off pad and rolls away for a leg bye Jadeja to Marsh, 1 wide fired down the leg side, called wide Jadeja to Marsh, 1 wide pitching on leg, spinning down, he misses a pull, called wide Jadeja to Khawaja, 1 wide another one fired down leg Chahal to Marsh, 1 wide, OUT Stumped off a wide down leg! Leg break wide down leg, he skipped early, missed it by a long way trying to whip it behind square, Dhoni gets down the leg side, takes it, doesn't get the bails off as quick as normal but he gets them off in time! Marsh was just short of getting back! Chahal to Khawaja, OUT caught and bowled! Soft leading edge! Shorter length leg break down leg, he is back and trying to work it behind square, closed the face too early, gets a thick leading edge that just lobs back to the bowler. Khawaja just watches it painfully as it slowly lands in Chahal's waiting hands! Chahal to Stoinis, OUT caught at slip! Brilliant leg spin bowling! This was a fizzing leg break, drifting into middle and leg, it spun, Stoinis was back, closing the face trying to push into the leg side, it catches the edge and Rohit dives low to his right at slip to pouch the catch! Superb bowling Shami to Maxwell, OUT Maxwell's holed out here. India went in with a clear plan to him. Shami played on his natural instincts to pull and bangs this in short again. Maxwell can't control the hook, gets another thick top-edge, this one sails fine and Bhuvneshwar Kumar latches on brilliantly, sprinting forward from the deep and diving in front for a well-judged catch Chahal to Jhye Richardson, OUT pays the price for playing against the turn. Nicely looped in towards leg stump, temping him to close the face against the turn. Lands just short enough to muster up some turn and results in the batsman chipping it tamely to short midwicket as he closes the face Chahal to Handscomb, OUT shifts back to a length ball and tries to turn it away into the on side with the angle. But the ball skids on and straightens late to beat the closing face of the bat before pinning him in front of middle. That's plumb as a duck. Handscomb reviews. He's the last recognised batsman and so goes for it. Smashing middle of middle. Five wickets for Chahal. Chahal to Zampa, OUT and another one goes. Sixth wicket for Chahal, equals Agarkar's record for most wickets at the MCG by a visiting bowler. This one's nicely looped up and inviting him to come forward. Zampa charges down and swipes big without getting entirely underneath it and holes out to long-on Shami to Stanlake, OUT and that will be a wrap. Shami pitches it full and straight on a leg stump line, Stanlake closes the face against the line and the ball goes straight through the bat, pings the pad and deflects onto the stumps Stanlake to Jadhav, 1 wide 133kph, bouncer wide of off, inside the guideline but it's called wide because it's too high Siddle to Jadhav, 1 wide full toss fired wide down leg Stoinis to Jadhav, 1 leg bye slower ball, hits him on the thigh, bounced into the off side Alright then. That finally brings us to the end of this long, and engrossing tour of Australia. Easily India's best, and most successful tour ever, across formats. India have sent out some great teams in Australia in the past, produced great performances from great players, and pushed Australia. But never before have they dominated them in the manner they have on this tour. They had their stars in each of the three legs, but the team has p India won by 7 wickets (with 4 balls remaining) Player of the match is Yuzvendra Chahal, INDIA
Match_Report: India 3 for 234 (Dhoni 87*, Jadhav 61*) beat Australia 230 (Handscomb 58, Chahal 6-42) by seven wickets Regardless of the result in Melbourne, India's tour of Australia would have been triumph. But it was given the perfect ending as Yuzvendra Chahal's career-best 6 for 42, the joint best ODI figures in Australia, set up a seven-wicket victory to take the series. Chahal's haul left a modest target but a slow pitch made scoring tricky as MS Dhoni, whose role has dominated the narrative of the series, scored his third half-century in three innings - while being given three lives - and the recalled Kedar Jadhav produced an excellent hand. It's the depth of players available that marks out the best teams and the success of Chahal and Jadhav, playing their first matches of the series in place of the rested Kuldeep Yadav and Ambati Rayudu, slotted in seamlessly. Chahal's second ball of the match began Australia's downfall when he had the in-form Shaun Marsh stumped, and he claimed three wickets in each of his two spells, surpassing his previous best of 5 for 22 against South Africa at Centurion.

Commentary_Highlights: Swann to Hussey, OUT Swann strikes! What a breakthrough as Hussey gets a thin edge behind and Prior takes the catch. Initially the umpire gives it not out, but Prior races down the pitch to Swann and signals for the revie Anderson to Haddin, OUT Anderson strikes but it looks a horrid shot. If it came off we'd be cheering but as it is, this is a gift. Well outside off stump at a drive-me length, Haddin threw his arms at it, leaning back, he Finn to Johnson, OUT gone! Finn gets the breakthrough with another shortish one tempting Johnson to pull, but his shot flies straight to Anderson at square leg, where he takes a simple catch. Swann to Hilfenhaus, OUT ah, there's the last wicket as Hilfenhaus gets an inside edge onto the thigh and it's taken by Cook at short leg Australia have managed to get their total up to 268, which is well below par but given their horrid start, isn't too bad a finish. And if their fast bowlers can get a few early wickets, who knows what could happen. But good luck Johnson to Cook, OUT gone! There's the breakthrough for Australia and it goes to Johnson. Full outside off, brings Cook into the drive and it flies low to gully where Hussey picks up a good low catch. Johnson to Trott, OUT gone! Johnson strikes again. Full on off stump, hint of swing back into the right hander and that's plumb. Trott driving and is beaten by the movement, superb stuff from Mitchell. Johnson to Pietersen, OUT another one! Pietersen is gone for a duck! Beautiful bowling from Johnson as this one swings back down the line, Marais Erasmus gives it lbw and Pietersen wants a review. The bat was nowhere near Harris to Strauss, OUT Harris joins the party! Strauss is gone! An edge behind and Haddin takes the straightforward catch! That was just a good line and length - across Strauss and with the swing that has been around he f Johnson to PD Collingwood, OUT another lbw shout as this one swings in, but it's given not out. Ponting asks for a review, but that looked high and off-side. But wait, the replays show that shape was enough to straighten Harris to Bell, 1 wide huge swing, and terribly wide of off, Haddin does well to dive in front of Watson at first slip and take it, but that's clearly a wide Siddle to Prior, OUT gone! Well, the short ball has worked in the end but probably not quite as they expected. The ball after getting hit, Prior moves across his stumps to work it away, but it deflects off his body, back Siddle to Bell, (no ball) stays round the wicket, short of a length and pushed outside off which is left alone...and he overstepped Harris to Swann, OUT Harris strikes! Swann is gone, prodding forward and getting an edge through to Haddin, it was another good ball that just straightened enough, well deserved by Harris Johnson to Tremlett, OUT gone! Johnson gets five, with a cracking inswinger that takes the off stump out of the ground. Really well bowled and Johnson has deserved that haul - now, can Australia finish England off before Johnson to Anderson, OUT it's all over. Johnson has six. Anderson hangs his bat out at a short ball outside off and the edge flies comfortably to Watson at first slip The Australians have a lead of 81 and they get into a huddle, savouring the moment. Johnson receives massive cheers from the WACA crowd as he leads his team-mates off the ground. He's been terrific today. The players will take t Innings Start Ben Hilfenhaus will start things off to Andrew Strauss. Three slips and a gully wait...
Match_Report: Australia 268 (Johnson 62, Hussey 61) and 309 (Hussey 116, Watson 95, Tremlett 5-87) beat England 187 (Bell 53, Strauss 52, Johnson 6-38) and 123 (Harris 6-47) by 267 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Ryan Harris collected his first five-wicket haul in Tests to seal a massive win for Australia Getty Images Australia wasted no time in levelling the Ashes series with a crushing 267-run victory at the WACA as Ryan Harris tore out the remaining resistance with a Test-best 6 for 47 to humble England. He finished off the visitors in a hurry as they were blown away in 10 overs on the fourth morning to set up a potentially thrilling conclusion to this series over the Christmas and New Year period. Harris collected the rewards that eluded him in Adelaide as he finished with nine in the match, while Mitchell Johnson claimed the other wicket to fall as he, too, picked up nine. Johnson's revival in this match reflects Australia's upward curve, leaving England with much to ponder before the MCG Test starts on Boxing Day. This was Australia's first Test victory in six matches since beating Pakistan at Lord's.

Commentary_Highlights: Finn to North, OUT Finn strikes! North is caught behind! What was he trying to do here? A shot of some sort was on, there was width on offer, but he pushed limply at it - barely moving his feet - to send a thin edge through to Prior Swann to Hussey, OUT he's gone! Hussey is gone in the 90s, and Swann has finally spun one appreciably! Hussey was forward and across, leaning into a drive, and the ball took a thick edge to land in Collingwood's lap at slip Swann to Harris, OUT Huge appeal for lbw, Harris is totally done in the flight and the ball thumps into the back pad. He wasn't too far forward, the umpire raises the finger but Harris asks for the review. Has he hit that? Is it missing leg? Nope, he's given out! Anderson to Siddle, OUT this time he's gone! Haddin's gamble doesn't come off as this is again clipped off the legs uppishly, but this time reaching Cook who pouches the chance to give Anderson his fourth Broad to Haddin, OUT All over now! Broad finally gets a deserved wicket as he digs in a short ball that Haddin top-edges it sails high down to Finn on the fine leg boundary who makes no mistake Look out Alastair Cook! Pietersen's last hundred was against West Indies in March last year. Harris to Cook, OUT Alastair Cook is out! Finally. Harris deserved that, sharp ball on a good length, Cook was back when he should have been forward and it came back between bat and pad, clipping a faint inside edge and Haddin took a good catch diving to his right Doherty to Pietersen, SIX runs up, up and over long-off! Is that England's first six of the series? You'd have backed KP to hit it. Slapped inside-out over the infield after a confident shimmy down the track Doherty to Pietersen, OUT all over! Pietersen falls to left-arm spin again. But not before he'd made 227. Doherty finally tosses up a really slow, widish one outside off, Pietersen aims another almighty heave but it spins away, comes off the toe-end and goes very gently to slip And there it is, Strauss is up on the team balcony to wave them back in and England declare with a lead of 375. England's dominance has been clear in this innings. Player of the match is Kevin Pietersen, ENG
Match_Report: England 5 for 620 dec beat Australia 245 and 304 (Clarke 80, Watson 57, Hussey 52, Swann 5-91) by an innings and 71 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details James Anderson and Steven Finn combined for the first breakthrough, the big wicket of Michael Hussey Getty Images England have one hand on the Ashes after Graeme Swann bowled them to victory with a five-wicket haul in Adelaide, where neither rain nor the lower order could save Australia on the fifth morning. The significance of the win cannot be underestimated, as it gives England a 1-0 advantage heading in to the third Test in Perth, which starts in a week and a half. The triumph came when Swann turned a ball through the gate to bowl Peter Siddle, completing his five-for and confirming the margin of an innings and 71 runs. It was a devastating morning for Australia, who began the day hopeful that they could survive for a draw with six wickets in hand, but it took England less than 90 minutes to skittle the remaining Australians. Last time England took a series lead in Australia, it was 1986-87, and they did not give it away.

Commentary_Highlights: Let's cut to the chase and get straight to the news that is coming to us from Perth. South Africa have won the toss and chosen to bat. Bracken to Gibbs, 1 leg bye drifts down the pads, Gibbs jumps up and gets a bit of pad on ball Bracken to Amla, 1 wide pitches full and angles away and he watches it go Hilfenhaus to McKenzie, 1 leg bye drifts down McKenzie's pads and he tickles it around the corner Hopes to McKenzie, OUT edged and gone! Success for Hopes in his first over, courtesy another walk down the track from McKenzie, playing a loose flash and getting a genuine outside edge to Haddin Clarke to de Villiers, 1 wide drifts down leg stump Hopes to Amla, 1 wide drifts too far from the stumps Hopes to de Villiers, 1 wide slides down the pads and AB cannot get bat on it Hopes to de Villiers, OUT caught in the deep ! Hopes bangs it in short, AB again swats it off one leg but straight to Warner at deep square leg, and thats the end of a positive innings from him Hopes to Amla, OUT edged and taken and Amla goes for 97! A nothing stroke from Amla, standing his ground and trying to poke the short ball down to third man but the execution is poor and the faint nibble is snapped up by Haddin Johnson to Morkel, OUT just like that! After the short stuff comes a full delivery on the stumps, Albie again makes room and swings, misses, and the ball takes out the base of leg stump Johnson to Duminy, 5 wide ah what rubbish, Johnson sends down a slower ball that drifts a mile down the pads and beats a poor Haddin too Bracken to Duminy, SIX runs holy smokes he's spanked the pants off that one! Bracken holds back the length and has to crane his neck to look after the ball as it sail away flat over midwicket, spanking shot Hilfenhaus to Duminy, 1 leg bye swings at a full one and gets an inside edge, Botha urges him on Morkel to Ponting, 1 wide too wide of the sticks and Ponting needn't chase those Morkel to Warner, SIX runs bang, what a hit! Do not bowl on that length to Warner, because he will most likely punish you ... a super shot to one bowled just short of a length, flat-batted over midwicket Parnell to Hussey, 1 wide pitches too far from the stumps on the off side Morkel to Haddin, 1 wide swing and another miss to one served up wide of the stumps Parnell to Haddin, 1 wide poor bowling from Parnell, sliding it well down the leg stump Parnell to Hopes, 1 leg bye slower ball down the stumps, Haddin sweeps a leg bye to square leg Tsotsobe to Johnson, OUT well now, a bit of confusion and Tsotsobe has four on debut! Clever bowling, fires in a yorker on leg stump, Johnson closes the face early and the ball pops back to Tsotsobe, who collects it and then feigns a throw back to Johnson, suddenly from backward point Gibbs appeals and gets Tsotsobe interested, it is referred, and yes indeed Johnson scooped a clean catch back to the bowler Lonwabo Tsotsobe snapped up his ODI wicket in his first over and came back to finish with four on debut. Botha was, as he has been all series, hard to score off because he fired them in quick and flat. The South Africans clamber on to the field and celebrate. They have rounded off an epic tour with victory in the final ODI. Australia have been displaced from the top spot. South Africa batted well to post 288 and then reduced Australia to 4 for 53, from which they never really recovered. Hussey and Haddin tried to keep them in the hunt with half-centuries, but the home side always faced a massive salvage operati Player of the match is Hashim Amla, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 6 for 288 (Amla 97, Duminy 60*, de Villiers 60, Hopes 3-44) beat Australia 249 (M Hussey 78, Haddin 63, Tsotsobe 4-50) by 39 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Hashim Amla scored his second consecutive half-century ? AFP South Africa's near-perfect tour began with a Test win in Perth and fittingly it finished with a one-day triumph at the same venue as Australia conceded the No. 1 ranking to Johan Botha's men. JP Duminy, Hashim Amla and AB de Villiers, all of whom contributed to the Test successes, finished the trip strongly and the debutant Lonwabo Tsotsobe picked up four wickets to give the tourists one more happy story to recount on the flight home. When South Africa arrived in Australia in December, they fancied their chances in the Tests but felt they still had a lot of improving to do in the shorter format. It's not unusual for holidaymakers to head back to their own country with a fresh perception of the world and that's exactly what South Africa will take home thanks to their 4-1 result and new No.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss: Australia have won the toss and there are no surprises, they will be batting. Cameron White comes back for Nathan Hauritz, and Ben Hilfenhaus replaces Nathan Bracken. For South Africa, the injured Mark Boucher is replaced by Ntini to Warner, 1 wide pitches full to invite the drive, Warner chases and gets beat on the shot Ntini to Warner, 1 wide another swing and miss, pitched up full and wide and Warner wafts Ntini to Warner, OUT chipped straight to mid-on! Ntini continues to mix up his deliveries well, slipping one in full and straighter and swinging it back into Warner, who goes for a flick but finds Morne Morkel stationed insid Botha to Hussey, OUT lbw! Botha tosses it up on the stumps, purchases some drift, Hussey gets across to paddle it around the corner, but there's no bat on that and after an imploring appeal the umpire raises the finger of fa Ntini to Ponting, OUT Ntini strikes, pitching the slower offcutter on a length and Ponting chases it on the rise, hitting it straight to McKenzie stationed at short catching cover Ntini to Hussey, 1 wide slides down the pads and de Villiers does the collecting Botha to Haddin, OUT and he throws it away with a stupid shot! Botha gets a second, lobbing it up to tempt the big shot, Haddin cannot resist and miscues the slog out to Kallis who settles under it at deep midwicket just in Morkel to Hussey, OUT slower ball does the trick! Albie pitches it up to draw a loose drive from Hussey straight into the lap of Gibbs at short cover, who makes no mistake when holding it Steyn to White, OUT Steyn strikes, inviting the big shot and White chases the wide one from the crease and edges a simple catch to de Villiers, sashaying to his right Ntini to Johnson, OUT a nothing shot, just leaning in and hitting straight to Morne at mid-off Steyn to Hopes, SIX runs smacked! Hopes picks the slower ball, backs away to leg stump, and goes through with a lovely flick over midwicket for half a dozen Steyn to Hopes, OUT backs away one time too many and slices the ball off the toe end of the bat to McKenzie, taking a step back at cover to pouch the offering just at the circle Morkel to Hilfenhaus, OUT and its all over, as Hilfenhaus pokes at one outside off stump and gets a faint edge back to de Villiers, moving to his left South Africa bowl Australia out for 222 in 48 overs. Real bad from Australia, who failed to see out their alloted overs. South Africa need 223 to win the series. It was a disciplined effort from them. We will be back in a while for Tait to Gibbs, 1 wide bad ball, sprayed a mile down the pads and Haddin has to hustle Tait to Amla, 1 wide errant delivery slides down the leg side and more work for Haddin Hilfenhaus to Gibbs, OUT and Gibbs finally plays a false stroke, steps out, Hilfenhaus pulls the length back, Gibbs is short of the pitch and he still goes ahead with the shot, top-edging it to mid-off where Michael Hussey ta Hopes to Kallis, OUT neat catch at short midwicket! Kallis walks down and across and flicks the ball, but he fails to keep it down and Marsh cups his hands in front of his face to take the catch Hopes to de Villiers, 1 leg bye pitched up again and AB pinches an easy single, just pushed away Johnson to de Villiers, 1 leg bye short down the pads and he swings it wide of square leg Hilfenhaus to Amla, 1 leg bye slides down the pads and he cant get bat on it, ball flies to point Well then, South Africa are enjoying the moment. They have taken an unassailable 3-1 lead with one game to go. AB and Amla whoop it up and grab stumps for souvenirs. Hats off to South Africa. The Adelaide Oval cheers them on. South Africa won by 8 wickets (with 71 balls remaining) Player of the match is AB de Villiers, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 2 for 223 (de Villiers 82*, Amla 80*) beat Australia 222 (Ponting 63, Steyn 3-49) by 8 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Hashim Amla sealed the series victory with a stylish 80 as South Africa controlled the hosts ? Getty Images A rebuilding South Africa sealed a series victory over an Australian outfit struggling with the same phase during a dominating performance in Adelaide that earned a 3-1 lead. The tourists arrived last month hoping for some success against the world champions in the Test and one-day formats, but they will leave with commanding victories in each arena after wrapping up this five-match contest before Friday's final fixture in Perth. While South Africa's order has gained confidence, from Herschelle Gibbs at the top to Albie Morkel and Johan Botha towards the bottom, the Australians are in worse shape than when they began. Throughout the series their batting has struggled to build on strong platforms and they wasted another chance on Monday as they dropped from the comfort of 2 for 110 in the 20th over to 222 in the 48th. The visitors have conquered much bigger totals than that this month and there was little to worry about once Gibbs determined to hit as many boundaries as possible.

Commentary_Highlights: Kallis to Warner, 1 wide thats a wide, sliding down the pads, no contact from Warner, Boucher takes Steyn to Warner, 5 wide sloppy, too much swing down leg stump, beating poor Boucher as well Steyn to Warner, OUT you miss, I hit, mate! Full, fast and straight on the stumps, Warner swings across the stumps and cannot connect and Steyn flattens his leg stump, terminating a fun innings Steyn to Marsh, 1 wide slides down the pads, there's a faint noise, Boucher collects and asks Botha to Marsh, OUT smart work from Boucher, who collects the ball as it pitches and straightens to beat Marsh's attempted sweep to one outside off stump, Marsh drags his back leg just over the line and in a flash Boucher breaks the stumps, so Botha gets some succe Botha to Ponting, OUT what a simple dismissal, its gently tossed up and Ponting just plays across his pads to short midwicket, who stumbles a couple feet forward and accepts the offering, easy as can be Botha to Haddin, OUT Haddin's gone, and Botha has a third! Tossed up, lures Haddin out of his crease, he drives it low and flat back to Botha, who holds it very well and then throws it up Ntini to Hussey, OUT hah, he's missed a rank waist high full toss! Ntini slips it out and Hussey just does not pick it as he opens the face to steer it fine, makes no contact and back goes middle stump Duminy to Hussey, 1 wide slides down leg stump for a wide, Boucher collects cleanly Duminy to Johnson, OUT dragged on! Johnson dances down, making room, and swings and misses and gets a faint under edge that cannons back into the base of the stumps Steyn to Tait, OUT whats happening here? Tait hops away toward square leg and drops the short delivery to the off side, Bracken sets off but there is no reaction from Tait, who is ball watching, suddenly both men are at one end and Tait had no chance to get back as Johnson to Gibbs, 4 byes Haddin is having a tough time out there, failing to collect one that stays low and beats the bat and then doesn't carry properly to the wicketkeeper Hauritz to Gibbs, 1 wide moves across and paddles, misses and the ball nearly hits leg stump, Haddin shuffles across and cannot connect cleanly so the ball deflects away Hauritz to Gibbs, 1 wide pitches and flights down leg stump, and thats wide Johnson to Gibbs, OUT finally Australia hold one, its just catching practice from Gibbs, not moving as he reaches out and plays it off the face of the bat smack to first slip, who cups it in front of his face Johnson to Kallis, 1 wide very, very full and wide and Kallis resists having a go, smartly Hauritz to Duminy, OUT bowled em! This one is tossed up outside off and purchases a bit of turn from the rough, cramping Duminy as he goes for a cut, stays low and a faint inside edge disturb off stump and thats an ODI wicket for Hauritz for the first time since Ma Hauritz to Boucher, 2 wide drifts down the stumps and brushes away off Haddin's pads Tait to Botha, 1 wide too wide this time, wobbling away, Botha chases and misses Just a quick recap for anyone who was late to join in. Australia batted first and set a target of 270. Despite a quick start, they were bowled out for 269 in 49.s overs. Botha was in the thick of things, taking 3 for 32 in his 10 overs and two smart catches. In reply for South Africa won by 3 wickets (with 21 balls remaining) Player of the match is Albie Morkel, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 7 for 270 (Gibbs 64, Kallis 60, Morkel 40) beat Australia 269 (Warner 69, Botha 3-32) by three wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out David Warner impressed in his first Twenty20 international and now he has transferred that form to the ODI arena ? PA Photos Albie Morkel destroyed Australia in the dying stages for the second time in the series as he powered South Africa to a three-wicket win and a 2-1 lead. Morkel built on the solid work of Herschelle Gibbs and Jacques Kallis to guide the highest successful ODI chase at the SCG and put a slight dampener on the Sydney crowd's day after the fans had been thrilled by their local hero David Warner during the Australian innings. Morkel fell five short of the target of 270 when he skied Nathan Hauritz to long-on but his 40 from 22 balls had done the job and he had already slammed Hauritz for a six and a pair of fours over midwicket in the same over. Again it was the batting Powerplay that haunted Australia as Morkel and Mark Boucher took 1 for 41 from the five overs beginning at the start of the 41st. They were so productive that they got home with 21 balls to spare, despite a superb return of 1 for 29 from nine overs for Nathan Bracken.

Commentary_Highlights: Botha to Ponting, OUT stumped! No, caught! Ponting pushed forward to a defend a straight delivery outside off stump but edged it, Boucher didn't realise at first for he whipped off the bails but eventually appealed for caught behind, Ian Gould raised the finger immediately Botha to Clarke, 1 leg bye scampered single, Clarke came down, was beaten in the flight, lucky to get pad onto it, and Marsh is alert for a single Morkel to Clarke, OUT caught in the deep! The pressure was building on Clarke and he went for it, lofting a length ball off the front foot towards long-on, Amla was on the boundary and he had to take several steps back to hold the catch, he took a quick look behind to see where the rope was, it was a few feet away from him Morkel to Marsh, OUT caught! Good length from Morkel, he pitches in line with the stumps and moves the ball off the seam away from the left-hander, Marsh tries to close the face and play the ball on the leg side, the ball hits the hilly side of the bat and goes through to Boucher Morkel to Hopes, OUT van Jaarsveld finally catches one! He has relief written all over his face and he turns to the MCG crowd and gives them a stare. Hopes made room to hit over the off side but didn't get enough muscle behind the shot, he lofted the ball towards long off, van Jaarsveld ran in from the boundary and judged it well Botha to White, OUT bowled him! That was a fast ball in the blockhole, 106 kmh! White tried to swat the ball towards midwicket but missed, Botha hit off stump Morkel to Hussey, OUT knocked him over! Albie bowls a good length ball on off and middle stump with a hint of swing into the right-hander, Hussey tries to hit across the line towards midwicket but misses, the ball crashes into off and middle stump Morkel to Bracken, 1 bye Bracken makes room and swings but misses, that was the slower one, Hilfenhaus is quick enough to steal the bye Morkel to Hilfenhaus, 1 wide what an absurd ball! It was miles down leg side and Boucher did extremely well to dive to his left and save five wides I'll be back in 40 minutes for the chase. You could spend the break trying our quiz, or by checking out Cricinfo 3D. "I've got an answer to the question asked back in over # 2 about two sets of brothers on opposing teams. There was a response that the last time was the Waugh and Flower brothers in 2001 - I have found (don't ask how) that on October 19 2008, that brothers Lamech Onyango and Nehemiah Odhiambo turned out for Kenya against Nial and Kevin O'Brien for Ireland. Hardly earth shattering teams, but it's an international Right, we're moments away from South Africa's chase. Gibbs and Amla will begin their pursuit of 272. Bracken will open the bowling, from over the wicket. Who's your money on? Tait to Kallis, 1 wide Tait's fired the ball down leg side at 150kmh, Haddin does supremely well to move to his left and collect Tait to Kallis, 1 wide he's up above 150 kmh this time - 151 - but the line is still down leg side, Kallis misses the glance but that's wide Clarke to McKenzie, 1 wide Clarke strays down leg side this time, wide called Hilfenhaus to Duminy, 1 wide Hilfenhaus concedes a wide by straying down leg side Hilfenhaus to Duminy, 1 leg bye loud shout for lbw after Duminy misses the flick against a full ball and gets hit on the pad, that looked like it pitched outside leg stump, Hilfenhaus is bowling from over the wicket Hopes to Duminy, 1 leg bye Duminy tries to flick but misses and gets hit on the pad Hilfenhaus to Botha, 1 leg bye Botha gets down on one knee to paddle the ball down to fine leg, he misses and gets hit on the pad, Hilfenhaus appeals but the ball hit the pad outside off Bracken to Morkel, SIX runs that's hammered several rows back! Albie gets under a length delivery and clobbers it with a perfectly straight bat over the bowler's head, terrific strike! The next game is on Sunday in Hobart. That one is a day game. That's about it from us at Cricinfo today. Thank you for all your emails, it's been fun. This is George Binoy signing off, good night! South Africa won by 3 wickets (with 3 balls remaining) Player of the match is Albie Morkel, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 7 for 272 (Duminy 71, McKenzie 63, A Morkel 40*) beat Australia 8 for 271 (Marsh 79, D Hussey 52) by three wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Shaun Marsh posted his third half-century from his past four ODI innings ? AFP JP Duminy and Neil McKenzie set up South Africa's sixth win from six ODIs against Australia at the MCG before Albie Morkel finished the job with a magnificent unbeaten 40 from 18 balls. The loss of McKenzie and Duminy left South Africa in big trouble as they needed 50 from six overs with three wickets in hand, but Morkel and Johan Botha used the batting powerplay to perfection to get them home with three balls to spare. The powerplay was taken at the start of the 45th over and Morkel used it to destroy Australia, particularly Ben Hilfenhaus, with four fours and a six. They picked up 51 from the powerplay and it was a frenetic end to a chase that had meandered through the middle overs, when Duminy showed more self-control than some Trappist monks, as he compiled 71 without a boundary. He nudged and guided while Ricky Ponting relied on the medium and slow offerings of James Hopes, David Hussey and Michael Clarke through the middle overs, yet somehow he maintained a healthy strike-rate of 76.

Commentary_Highlights: South Africa have won the toss and will bat. AB de Villiers, who copped a nasty blow to the midriff from Shaun Tait on Sunday, has been replaced by Neil McKenzie, the Twenty20 specialist. Amla and Parnell also enter. This is Parnell's debut. Kallis misses out. Aust Bracken to Gibbs, 1 wide starts off with a wide, full and swinging down leg stump Tait to Amla, SIX runs there's half a dozen, and the first six of the innings! Short and wide, very quick and steeping, and all Amla has to do is throw the bat and gets six over third man Tait to Amla, 4 leg byes 149.5ks says the speedometer, but methinks its a bit quicker than that! A nasty short ball dug in to get Amla hopping to take evasive action, he does very well to get his head out the way of that ripper and the ball beats Ronchi as Hilfenhaus to Amla, OUT pulled straight to White at short midwicket! The short ball works for Hilfenhaus, Amla tries to collect from outside off stump but plays it high off the bat to the fielder Hussey to Vaughn, OUT and it works! Hussey floats that up full on the stumps, van Jaarsveld doesn't get far enough across as he goes for the sweep, and cops it flush on the pad in front of middle and leg Tait to Duminy, 1 wide poor stuff, full and down the pads again, this time its called wide Hopes to Boucher, OUT swipes across the line and sends a top edge to Tait at backward point Hilfenhaus to Morkel, 1 wide slow bouncer, 113ks, and Paul Reifel calls it a wide Hilfenhaus to Morkel, SIX runs sweet shot, Morkel! On the pads and swung over long-on for a flat six Steyn to Marsh, SIX runs bang, thats a beauty! Marsh swings the shorter ball of one leg and strikes it off the middle of the bat for a flat six over deep square leg Steyn to Ponting, 1 wide that will be wide, too full and swinging and Ponting chases it again Steyn to Ponting, 1 wide slower ball, 116ks, but sliding down the pads for another wide Steyn to Marsh, 1 leg bye pitches full just outside leg stump, swinging through the air, Marsh misses the flick and scampers a leg bye as the ball rolls wide of Boucher Steyn to Ponting, 1 wide again Steyn drifts down the pads and bowls another wide Morkel to Ponting, SIX runs lovely shot! Ponting! Down he comes, just flicking the slower ball over midwicket for six, thats well held too by a fan in a South African tee shirt Morkel to Hussey, OUT freat reflexes from the bowler! Hussey inside-edges the ball toward the on side, Morne sprints forward and collects, then flicks a direct hit onto the base of the stumps to get Ponting short by some distance Morkel to Hussey, OUT oh well held, Duminy! Thats one for the ages! You aren't going to see much better in the outfield than that gem of a catch! Hussey takes a hand off the bat as he chips the ball over mid-off, the ball beats Duminy by some distance but he Morkel to White, 1 leg bye fired in on leg stump, White mistimes the flick, Albie steams in, there is some hesitation, but Hussey wants the single, bowler collects and misses the stumps We've been Jamie Alter and Binoy George, glad to have your company. Bye for now. White sees the ball go over the ropes and breaks into a jig. He and Hussey embrace. Superb half-century from Hussey, back in some form. Australia have won by six wickets with seven deliveries remaining. They bowled well to keep South Africa to under 160, and chased Australia won by 6 wickets (with 7 balls remaining) Player of the match is Michael Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Wayne Parnell: "There was a green flash and it was pretty bright and the light seemed to be pointing towards me" ? Getty Images Cricket Australia has apologised to the South Africans for members of the crowd who used a green laser to put off Wayne Parnell in the closing stages of Australia's six-wicket win in Brisbane on Tuesday night. In the 18th over of Australia's pursuit of 5 for 157 Michael Hussey hit a catch to Parnell at long-off, which he dropped, but television replays showed lights flashing from the stands that might have distracted him. "There was a green flash and it was pretty bright and the light seemed to be pointing towards me," Parnell told the Herald Sun. "It was all a bit strange. I only saw it then, but maybe it was flashed around at other times, I am not sure.

Commentary_Highlights: Ntini to Warner, SIX runs Warner does it again! Ntini gives him another short one and Warner pulls again, he hits it squarer this time and clears the deep-square leg boundary by a yard or two Tsotsobe to Marsh, OUT caught! It's Morkel again! Tsotsobe bowls a poor ball on Marsh's pads, he whips it hard but it's in the air and in the vicinity of Morkel lurking at short fine leg, he dives to his right and pulls off a low catch, that's Tsotsobe's first international wicket! Steyn to Warner, SIX runs what a shot! That was bowled at 149.8 kmh and Warner merely turned around and helped the ball over the fine-leg boundary with an audacious paddle shot, fine leg was in the circle, Steyn can't believe it Botha to Warner, SIX runs that's many many rows back! Warner charges Botha, he doesn't get to the pitch but never mind that, he winds up and swings his bat hard to send the ball over the long-on boundary, there's a fielder on the fence too! Morkel to Ponting, OUT caught! Ponting tries to clear the long-on boundary but doesn't quite make it, he holes out to Dale Steyn in the deep, it was a length ball and he hit it well, just not well enough for the MCG Ntini to Hussey, OUT caught! Hussey makes room by moving towards leg and eventually has to reach out for the ball outside off stump, he hits it with the bottom of the bat and the ball lobs towards de Villiers at cover, that's a pretty easy catch to take Ntini to Warner, OUT Warner's gone! He won't get his hundred on debut but he's done enough to get a standing ovation from the massive MCG crowd. Warner tried to lift Ntini off his pads but didn't quite get the power or the placement, he lofted the ball towards deep midwicket where de Villiers settled under the ball Steyn to Ronchi, OUT caught! Terrific effort from Ntini! Ronchi makes room again and slashes the ball high in the air towards third man, I think Ntini mis-judged it a bit and the ball looked like it was going to fall short off him. But he came in, dived forward and held the catch centimeters off the grass Morkel to Hussey, OUT slower ball from Morkel at 112 kmh, Hussey pushes towards mid-off and sets off for the single, Gibbs sprints from extra cover and intercepts, he throws himself into a full-length dive and hits the stumps direct at the bowler's end, there's no need for a replay Steyn to Hopes, OUT caught! Steyn bowls another slower one at 119 kmh, Hopes makes room to hit inside out over cover but gets beaten by the change of pace, he lobs a simple catch towards Botha Steyn to Hilfenhaus, 1 bye another swing and a miss, Bracken sets off for another bye and Boucher misses the stumps again Steyn to Bracken, OUT bowled him! Bracken moves outside leg stump to make room, Steyn bowls the ball fast, full and dead straight, he beats Bracken for pace and hits middle stump I'll be back in 15 minutes for the chase. Until then check out Cricinfo's wallpapers of Australian and South African players . Bracken to Gibbs, 1 wide Bracken pitches outside leg stump, Gibbs gets down on one knee and tries to paddle past fine leg, he doesn't make contact Tait to Kallis, 1 leg bye 155 kmh!! Kallis manages to work it off his pads behind square Tait to de Villiers, OUT de Villiers is in pain! And he's out! Tait bowls a short of a length ball at 155.6 kmh, de Villiers tries to pull but is beaten by the pace of the ball, it crashes into his hip off the bottom edge and he winces in pain, he loses balance as he moves back and the bat hits the stumps, he's in a lot of pain and he hobbles back to the dug out, I hope he isn't bad Hussey to Vaughn, 1 leg bye van Jaarsveld tries to sweep but misses, he gets hit on the pad outside off Hussey to Morkel, 1 wide that's too far down leg side, Morkel misses the sweep South Africa's chase was wrecked after Gibbs fell in Bracken's first over and Tait knocked the wind out of de Villiers. Duminy played a superb innings but he had little support from the other batsmen. Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 9 for 182 (Warner 89, Steyn 3-38) beat South Africa 130 (Duminy 78, D Hussey 3-25) by 52 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out David Warner launched six sixes, including a couple of monsters over midwicket ? PA Photos David Warner made one of the most memorable international debuts imaginable as he lit up the MCG with 89 from 43 balls to set up Australia's 52-run win over South Africa. Not even a superb 78 from JP Duminy could rescue South Africa's chase and he watched his partners fall around him as they fizzled out for 130 in the 18th over. The crowd appreciated Duminy's brilliance, particularly when he scooped a Shaun Tait half-volley over the wicketkeeper's head for six, but it was Warner who was undeniably the star of the show. It was an incredible situation for a man previously so unknown that the scoreboard operators didn't have a photo of him when the teams were displayed. Warner, 22, had already created history by simply playing the match; he was the first man to debut for Australia in any format without first-class experience since 1877.

Commentary_Highlights: Harris to Johnson, 1 wide thats real, real wide and the umpire spreads his wings Duminy to Clarke, OUT oh he's held him! Duminy strikes in his first over, and with a full toss as well, one that Clarke drives back in the air to his left and he pouches it as he falls over Steyn to Johnson, OUT soft dismissal, and Steyn strikes quickly into his reappearance! He pitches full and wide, angles it away, and Johnson gets a thick edge into Smith's waiting palms at first slip Harris to Siddle, OUT the fun ends as Harris gets into the action, flighting one on about middle stump, straightening it , and catching Siddle in front after he misses a big heave Harris to Hauritz, OUT and he's gone, skipping down and swiping across the line to midwicket "According to the ABC radio commentators out here at the SCG, Steyn has a badly bruised left heel. Trouble for their second innings?" says Ed McGregor. Johnson to Duminy, OUT good delivery to get Duminy! After the short ball comes the fuller delivery, swinging in quite late from outside off stump and raps him on the back leg in line with the sticks Siddle to Harris, OUT simple decision, Siddle strikes again with a fullish delivery angling back in to catch Harris hopping about his crease, it stays low and ramrod straight and he's a sitting duck Siddle to Boucher, OUT the sound of timber! Siddle gets five at the SCG, his first such effort at this level, once more succeeding with the full and fast delivery, Boucher clips across the line and middle stumps is flattened If you're the sort who likes cricket news to be delivered to you, check out the Siddle is mobbed by his team-mates. He raises the ball to the crowd and leads his team off. A great spell from him and he will cherish this moment. Australia have bowled kept South Africa to 327, thereby securing a lead of 118. Boucher played well f Innings Start Siddle comes around the stumps
Match_Report: Australia 445 and 4 for 257 dec beat South Africa 327 and 272 (Amla 59, de Villiers 56, Siddle 3-54) by 103 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Australia pulled off a last-minute victory despite a courageous and painful batting effort from the injured Graeme Smith ? PA Photos For the second consecutive year Australia have pulled off a last-minute victory in the Sydney Test, this time despite a courageous and painful batting effort from the injured Graeme Smith. Last season it was Michael Clarke who bowled Australia home nine minutes from stumps and on this occasion Mitchell Johnson picked up the final wicket with five minutes remaining to give Australia a consolation win that left the series ledger a little less lopsided at 2-1. The last breakthrough came when Johnson nipped a ball back off a crack in the wearing pitch to bowl Smith, who had been incredibly gutsy in coming to the crease at No. 11 with a broken left hand and a right elbow so sore he said he could barely brush his teeth in the morning. Smith survived for 29 minutes with Makhaya Ntini as he aimed to salvage a draw but every fast ball he faced drew winces around the ground as he quickly released his left hand and gritted his teeth.

Commentary_Highlights: Jadeja to Handscomb, OUT Stumped! Slick from Dhoni! Handscomb tried to sweep a very full ball, was beaten by length, it spun past off, Dhoni takes it well, Handscomb's back foot is out of the crease, he didn't realise. Dhoni did. He whipped the bails off and Handscomb looked down and saw his foot was out! Shami to Stoinis, OUT and he gets him next ball. Shortish outside off, doesn't climb as high as Stoinis expects as he goes for the pull. Only manages a bottom edge through to Dhoni Siraj to Maxwell, 1 leg bye 139kph, low full toss, inside edge onto pad, it rolls past off stump to short third man Bhuvneshwar to Maxwell, OUT caught at deep long off! Undone by a 119kph slower ball. It was a good length and wide, Maxwell tried to loft this over cover, but he dragged it to long off, DK stands 15 metres in off the rope and takes the catch easily Bhuvneshwar to Marsh, OUT caught at long off! Bhuvi does it again with a slower ball! Good length slower ball outside off, Marsh lofts this towards long off but doesn't nail it, Jadeja, like DK, camps 15 metres in off the rope and takes the easy catch! Superb innings from Marsh ends with 13 balls remaining Shami to Jhye Richardson, OUT caught at deep point! Another length off cutter slower ball wide off, he reaches out and slices this high to deep backward point, Shikhar Dhawan waits under it and takes the catch comfortably. Jhye Richardson to S Dhawan, 1 wide looks to angle it into the stumps again, ends up overdoing it and whanging it down the leg side Behrendorff to S Dhawan, OUT and that is that. He's played with a lot of freedom today, but now he's played one shot too many. Length ball, angling into off stump, not quite full enough for the pick-up shot over midwicket. Plays too early, and ends up spooning it high in the air, off the outside half of the bat. Khawaja Lyon to Rayudu, 1 leg bye good length down leg, it comes off pad as he tries to pull, ricochets off Carey's pad and rolls away Maxwell to Rayudu, OUT caught at deep midwicket! The pressure got to him! He skips down and tries to launch this with the spin high over midwicket, it was a touch slower, he got underneath it and skied it high to deep midwicket, Stoinis camped under it and took the catch! Siddle to Kohli, 1 wide bouncer, climbs loopily, well over Kohli's head, before dropping down tennis-ball style into Carey's gloves Siddle to Dhoni, 1 wide slower bouncer wide outside off, Dhoni leaves it alone Jhye Richardson to Kohli, OUT whoopsie. A huge moment for Australia, this. This is full, a half-volley on leg stump, and I don't know if Kohli was looking to hit this in the air, but he's flicked it, possibly a touch earlier than he wanted to, timed it perhaps better than he wanted to, and picked out the fielder at deep Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 leg bye back of a length, angling into Dhoni's left hip. Tucked away to long leg Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 wide back of a length, gets his line all wrong. With pretty much everyone in the circle on the off side, he doesn't want to give Dhoni any width, and he ends up whanging it down the leg side. Dhoni merely steps across and shoulders arms Behrendorff to Dhoni, SIX runs probably not. Back of a length on off stump, and MS Dhoni absolutely Dhonies this to bring up his fifty. Leans back, clears his front leg, and brings all that bottom-hand power into play to clear long-on as well. It'll be an interesting exercise to work out how many times he's hit this bal 10.00pm And that is that. The series is 1-1, the third ODI is on Friday at the MCG. Hopefully, we'll have a finale to remember. Until then, from Alex, Thilak and me, good night! India won by 6 wickets (with 4 balls remaining) Player of the match is Virat Kohli, INDIA
Match_Report: India 4 for 299 (Kohli 104, Dhoni 55, Maxwell 1-16) beat Australia 9 for 298 (Marsh 131, Maxwell 48, Bhuvneshwar 4-45) by six wickets Virat Kohli set it up and, for the first time in a while, MS Dhoni was there to finish it although India were grateful to a cameo from Dinesh Karthik to secure a six-wicket win with four balls remaining. The victory set up a series decider in Melbourne on Friday. When Kohli found deep midwicket shortly after reaching his 39th ODI hundred - one he celebrated in animated fashion - India still needed 57 off 38 balls and Dhoni had played a very sedate second fiddle to the captain. He launched Nathan Lyon for six and had just enough in the tank and the legs to ensure a meltdown on social media was perhaps avoided for now. He ensured the victory when he swung Jason Behrendorff over long-on with the first ball of the final over.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.12 pm QLD: Great guys, the news from Brisbane is that New Zealand have won the toss and opted to bowl. The match has been reduced to 22 overs-a-side. Game On!! Southee to Hopes, 1 wide down the leg side, tries to flick it away fine, misses, given a wide Mills to Hopes, OUT gone! Goes for a wild swing over long-on, fraction full on the off stump, is not to the pitch, the ball sails high and Vettori at mid-off takes a well judged catch after waiting for ages for it to get to him Mills to Ponting, OUT Gone!! Full outside off and moves away, Ponting's fishing for it off the front foot, gets a thin edge straight to the keeper. New Zealand have struck early here O'Brien to Hussey, OUT gone, wild swing and pays the price! Full on middle and leg, Hussey makes room to smash it over mid-on, it came back in a a touch and crashed into leg stump. Australia in a spot of bother now at 30 for 3 Vettori to Hussey, OUT gone! What an inspired bowling change!! Short on middle and off, there to hit, he pulls it away straight to Diamanti stationed perfectly at deep midwicket. Big wicket for New Zealand The small cover is on, presumably to keep the pitch dry after a slight drizzle during the break. The Australians are having fielding drills in the outfield. The covers are off, and the pitch is being rolled. The New Zealand openers have come out - McCullum and Guptill. Hilfenhaus to Fulton, 1 wide full toss down the leg side, Fulton misses an opportunity there, given a wide Johnson to Taylor, OUT he's gifted his wicket here after a superb shot the previous ball! Good length outside off, tries to swat it over the bowler's head, gets the top-edge and Hussey at cover takes a well-judged catch as it takes forever to come down It has started raining pretty heavily in Brisbane now. Bucknor shakes his head, has an elaborate consultation with his partner. Under normal circumstances, the players would have gone off. No result Player of the match is
Match_Report: No result - New Zealand 6 for 123 (Guptill 64*) Australia 4 for 168 (Haddin 88*, Ferguson 55*) Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Brad Haddin led Australia with a fine half-century in a match decided by the weather ? Getty Images Australia clung to the Chappell-Hadlee Series despite a brave push from New Zealand after the final game was spoilt by rain. Martin Guptill's fighting half-century was in vain as the visitors finished at 6 for 123; they were ahead on Duckworth-Lewis but needed to make the target of 156 in 20 overs to qualify the contest as a match. The result left the series drawn at 2-2 and Australia kept the prize after their win in 2007-08. It was a sad end for New Zealand after a day that swung from saturated to soggy and slippery. New Zealand started their innings after Australia's 4 for 168 and relied on Guptill, who blasted his half-century from only 24 balls.

Commentary_Highlights: New Zealand have won the toss and elected to bat first. Brendon McCullum will open the batting and keep wicket, Cumming comes into the NZ side for Jeetan Patel while the Australian team is unchanged. Johnson to Guptill, OUT gone! Johnson pitches one short on the middle and leg stump this time around and hurries Guptill into the stroke. He manages to get some wood on the ball as he pulls it straight into the hands of Bracken, positioned at fine-leg exactly for this Hopes to Fulton, OUT one more! Fulton falls now as he does not manage to keep the ball down as he plays an intended drive on the off side to Bracken at mid-on and Kiwis slip further now Johnson to Elliott, OUT short on the middle stump. Elliot does the pre-meditated shuffle and swats it in the gap between fine-leg and sweeper on the leg side. David Hussey, covers a lot of ground as he takes a good catch. It was more of a good catch from Hussey than a poor shot from El Hopes to Cumming, OUT gone! Cumming just manages to chip it to mid-off, where Johnson takes a straight-forward catch. It means Cumming has fluffed his chances in his first ODI in four years. Australia are in the driver's seat now Bracken to Taylor, 1 wide and begins with a wide delivery outside the off stump. He laughs it off but bet Ponting wont see the funnier side in it Hilfenhaus to Broom, 1 wide short and wide down the leg side and rightly called so Hilfenhaus to Broom, OUT it's all over for Broom. Hilfenhaus, pitches it short and Broom, spontaneously goes for the pull and ends up top edging it to Hopes, stationed at cover. Just when it looked like a partnership was coming on, a wicket falls Bracken to Taylor, 5 wide wide, far too wide outside the off stump. And what adds to Bracken's misery is the fine-leg fielder being inside the circle . He ends up conceding five wides Johnson to Taylor, OUT gone! Full-toss on the off stump. Taylor, moves across and looks to get cheeky as he wants to paddle it to fine-leg but the ball comes in faster than he expects. Taylor, manages to get a top edge which flies high. Haddin is calling for it right from the moment it Hilfenhaus to Taylor, 1 wide wide outside the off stump to begin the over Bracken to Mills, OUT timber! Mills is backing away even before the ball is bowled. Bracken notices it and bowls a yorker on the middle stump. Mills has a swing and there is only place where the ball can go- stumps- if he misses and it does go there Southee to Haddin, 1 wide wide down the leg side Mills to Ponting, 1 wide wayward delivery down the leg side Southee to Ponting, OUT and for the umpteenth time this summer we see Ponting top-edging a pull shot. Only difference this time being he does it to the cover fielder as Guptill takes it comfortably. Ever heard of a strength turning into a weakness Hussey brothers make sure that the series goes to Brisbane with everything to play for. They were helped in good part by Haddin too Australia won by 6 wickets (with 10 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 4 for 247 (D Hussey 79, M Hussey 75*) beat New Zealand 8 for 244 (Taylor 76, Johnson 3-51) by six wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out David Hussey made his highest ODI score ? Getty Images The Hussey brothers ensured the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy would be decided by Friday's final match in Brisbane after they helped Australia to a six-wicket win that levelled the series 2-2. For the first time in the series New Zealand batted first and they posted a moderate 244, which on a good pitch was not enough against an Australian batting order starting to find form. The game was to some degree overshadowed by the Victorian bushfire appeal that surrounded it, with contributions from players, sponsors, spectators and administrators totalling just over $6 million. But while Australia had failed to beat South Africa at the same venue on Australia Day, this time they did get over the line at Adelaide on another special, if more sombre, occasion. Fittingly Michael Hussey brought up the win with a six over long-on, adding another $5000 to the tally after the Commonwealth Bank pledged that amount for every six in the game.

Commentary_Highlights: Elliott to Haddin, SIX runs in the slot for Haddin there, a hapless slower delivery bowled full on middle and leg, he gets down on one knee and plays a lofted sweep well wide of deep square leg for another big one Elliott to Clarke, 1 wide wide down the leg side but brilliantly kept by McCullum Elliott to Clarke, OUT slower one bowled full outside off, Clarke makes room and drives it powerfullu but straight to Martin Guptill at short cover. Finally a wicket but not after an excellent start by the Australian openers Elliott to Ponting, OUT top-edge and excellent catch at fine-leg by Mills, short of a length on middle and off, tries to pull it away over square leg, gets the leading edge and Mills, despite the sun being being in his eyes, pouches it superbly Vettori to Haddin, SIX runs Haddin is looking in great form here, tossed up on middle and leg, inviting the batsman to charge forward, lofts it cleanly over long-on for a big six. No sign of nerves here in the nineties for Haddin O'Brien to White, OUT poor shot, bowled on a good length on the off stump, he goes for a blind loft over mid-off, mistimes it completely, gets a lot of elevation on it, Vettori takes a couple of steps back and takes a well-judged catch Vettori to Ferguson, OUT plumb in front! Tossed up on middle, bowled really slow at 78 kmph, he is into the sweep shot really early, is done is by the pace, strikes him on the back leg on line with the stumps and Bucknor makes a straightforward decision O'Brien to Hopes, OUT full and straight, and it's timber! Yorker length on middle, Hopes makes room to slice that over point, misses it completely and hears the death rattle behind him Mills to Hussey, OUT Hussey holes out in the deep, slower ball bowled full on middle and leg, he gets forward and slogs it straight to Ross Taylor at deep midwicket. End of a cruical innings after the openers had given the hosts a sound start Mills to Johnson, OUT gone! Slower ball on middle and leg, slogged away straight to Jeetan Patel at deep midwicket. Hilfenhaus to Taylor, OUT he's given him! Good length on middle, and held its line this time. Taylor came forward to defend, missed it completely and was struck in line. Correct decision there, Taylor showed his bat to the umpire immediately upon being struck on the pads, but Bucknor is having none of the nonsense Hopes to Fulton, 4 leg byes appeal for lbw, good length on middle and off, tries to drive that wide of midwicket, clips the pads on the way to the third-man boundary. Huge appeal for lbw, and it seemed as though it struck him in line. Bucknor shakes his head and Hopes is unlucky Johnson to Elliott, 1 wide wide down the leg side, tries to flick it away fine, misses, given a wide Bracken to Southee, SIX runs that's disappeared! SLower ball bowled full on middle and leg, he picked and slogged it away well over the deep midwicket boundary for a massive six Hilfenhaus to McCullum, 1 wide wide down the leg side, given Hilfenhaus to McCullum, OUT that's it, almost all over for New Zealand, full toss outside off stump, tries to smash it over the covers, mistimes it straight to Ponting who's standing there at the edge of the circle. The bat slips out of McCullum's hands as he goes for the shot Bracken to Patel, SIX runs big one! Excellent shot, he got stuck into that one, slower ball bowled full on middle, swung away off the front foot over deep midwicket for a six New Zealand batted well to reach where they did, and when Elliott and McCullum were going strong, a win could not have been ruled out. Partnerships were the key for New Zealand as their middle order put together productive stands at a fairly good rate, despite a poor start. Brad Haddin has been adjudicated as the Man of the Match, and A Player of the match is Brad Haddin, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 9 for 301 (Haddin 109, Clarke 64, Hussey 51) beat New Zealand 269 (Elliott 115) by 32 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Brad Haddin picked an ideal time for his maiden ODI century and his 109 put Australia on target for a crucial victory ? Getty Images Australia's influx of youth has dominated discussion of late, but it was the team's mainstays who completed a successful series-salvaging mission at the SCG. Brad Haddin's maiden one-day international century was complemented by half-centuries to Michael Clarke and Michael Hussey, propelling Australia to an intimidating 9 for 301 that proved just beyond the grasp of the hard-finishing New Zealand. The hosts appeared set for a comfortable victory at the fall of Tim Southee's wicket in the 37th over, but a brilliant partnership of 69 from 49 deliveries between Grant Elliott, who struck 115 from 124 balls, and the injured Brendon McCullum (36 from 27) raised hopes of a stunning upset. McCullum, playing with the assistance of a pain-killing injection after hurting his shoulder in the field, punished Nathan Bracken from the uncustomary position of No. 9, while Elliott adopted a more measured approach in compiling his maiden limited-overs hundred.

Commentary_Highlights: O'Brien to Hussey, OUT direct hit and David Hussey's got to go! He pushes a good length ball in front of mid-off and takes a chance with a sharp single to Vettori, unfortunately he taps it to Vettori's left and that enables him to gather the ball quickly and fire it on the stumps with his throwing arm O'Brien to Hussey, 1 leg bye plays all around it to the off side very close to the pads and O'Brien appeals thinking it hit the pad first O'Brien to Clarke, OUT and Clarke misses out on a century!
