O'Brien bowls an inswinging yorker down the leg side, Clarke steps down the track and tries to clip it wide of midwicket, the ball hits his pad and deflects on to the stumps O'Brien to Ferguson, 2 wide he slides down the leg side but it's way too wide and he can Mills to White, 1 wide slides wide down the leg side and he tries to flick it away with his pad Bracken to McCullum, 1 wide down the leg side, McCullum fails to glance it down fine, given a wide anyway Clarke to McCullum, 2 wide Hahaa, Haddin takes off the bails with his gloves again, its fired down the leg side and his gloves flick the bails as he tries to collect White to Elliott, 1 leg bye tossed up on middle, takes it on the full and paddles it down to fine leg Johnson to Elliott, 1 wide full down the leg side, tries to glance it down fine, misses Bracken to Taylor, 1 leg bye pitched full outside leg and swung into the right hander, struck him on the pads as he tried to flick it away towards square leg Johnson to Taylor, OUT momentary loss in concentration and Taylor pays the price!! Short outside off and he slashes at it blindly, played away from his body, gets a thin edge and Haddin makes no mistake. There was no need for that shot, and it's cost him his wicket. Australia have slid to their fifth consecutive defeat, that too at home. 226 was a competitive target on a slow pitch but New Zealand paced their innings brilliantly. They started patiently and McCullum was involved in two 40-plus partnerships with Fulton and Taylor to ensure his team didn;t lose early wicke New Zealand won by 6 wickets (with 7 balls remaining) Player of the match is Michael Clarke, AUS
Match_Report: New Zealand 4 for 226 (Elliott 61*) beat Australia 5 for 225 (Clarke 98, M Hussey 75) by six wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Michael Clarke scored 98 opening the innings ? Getty Images Michael Clarke's 98 could not stop his unthinkable series loss from coming a step closer after Grant Elliott kept a cool head to complete a six-wicket victory for New Zealand, who were solid without being spectacular. Despite making hard work of a less than imposing chase of 226, New Zealand got home with seven balls to spare to take a 2-0 lead in the five-match series. On a day when the glitzy IPL auction caught the attention of much of the cricketing world, Australia and New Zealand combined to produce a distinctly unglamorous match that was hardly the best advertisement for the 50-over format. It was a throwback to the 1980s, when 220 was considered a good target and top-order men like Geoff Marsh and John Wright were commended for compiling 50 off 90 balls. The lack of prettiness did not worry New Zealand, who gave their countrymen another reason to celebrate Waitangi Day when Elliott brought up the win with a pull for four off Ben Hilfenhaus.

Commentary_Highlights: Mills to Clarke, 1 wide digs in the bouncer, Clarke is well out of its way, that was so high it was called a wide Patel to Hussey, OUT strikes first ball, David Hussey's caught behind down the legside, short and angling down, goes for a paddle-pull, McCullum moves over to the leg side to take the catch, David Hussey's furious with the decision Patel to Haddin, SIX runs oh shot, Haddin! Lovely use of the feet, just a shimmy down the track and then an effortless chip straight back down the ground and its into the crowd, where a fan drops it Mills to Haddin, OUT dragged on! Haddin advances to a full one just outside off stump and goes for a drive but can only succeed in inside-edging back onto his stumps and Mills celebrates Patel to Hussey, 1 wide sliding down the legside, well taken by the keeper O'Brien to Hussey, OUT first ball of the Powerplay gets a wicket, Hussey has to go, he tried to chip a length ball over the infield, mid-off was on the edge of the circle, and it's a simple catch for him, Hussey's innings ends at 49 O'Brien to Hopes, OUT Hopes is gone, both the settled batsmen are dismissed in the same over, he was trying to slam that over the covers, gets a top edge which balloons in the air for a dolly to Vettori to mid-off Southee to Bracken, OUT Bracken's lbw this time, he was attempting to work that towards midwicket, hit him in front of middle, looked out, though Hawkeye suggests it might have just gone down leg Mills to Johnson, OUT and that's the end of the innings, Johnson goes for a big swipe over midwicket, doesn't make contact with the ball, which homes in on the leg bail, Australia fold for 181 We'll be back in just about 40 minutes. You could spend the break checking out Cricinfo's Mills finishes with 4 for 35 and Australia have failed to bat out their alloted overs. Their struggles continue from the South Africa series, and New Zealand need 181 to take a lead in the series. Tait to Fulton, 1 wide starts off with a full ball down the leg side, he'll have to bowl that one again Tait to Fulton, 1 wide goes to the other extreme of the previous ball, 151.5 kmh bouncer way outside off now Johnson to Fulton, 1 leg bye On Fulton's legstump, called a legbye after Haddin fails to collect the ball, but that was actually a wide down the leg side Bracken to Guptill, OUT bowled em! Bracken strikes with a full delivery that pitches on off stump and hurries Guptill into a loose defensive push, but he's very late on the shot and the ball nips back in and draws the faintest of inside edges back onto the stumps Johnson to Fulton, OUT well held, Mitchell! A very scratchy innings comes to an end courtesy a superb reflex catch from Johnson, who pitches it up on off stump and then sticks out his left hand as he tumbles down in his followthrough, plucking the checked off-drive back in the a Johnson to Elliott, 1 wide bounces well down the leg stump and a wide is called Johnson to Elliott, 1 wide thats really overpitched, sliding out the hand, well past off stump Tait to Taylor, 1 leg bye overpitched down the stumps, 144ks, flicked to square leg Hussey to Broom, 1 wide fires it down the leg side and the batsman misses the sweep, wide called, his back foot is back at the crease Clarke to Broom, OUT Australia claw back, now there's a bit of controversy here, Clarke gets it to skid through on a good length, Broom makes a lot of room to cut but he's beaten for pace, the ball appears to clip the top of the off bail but replays indicate that Haddin had his Tait to Taylor, 1 leg bye bowls it short of a length and the ball clips his pads and rolls to short square leg off the hips Tait to Taylor, 1 leg bye he takes his eyes off a bouncer and the ball clips his body and rolls to the off side Bracken to Taylor, OUT a fabulous catch by Clarke and we have a twist in the tale here, Bracken pitches it up outside off, he walks across his stumps, reaches forward and slices it on the up to backward point, Clarke flings himself to his left and cups it with both hands Bracken to Southee, 1 bye beaten outside the off stump, they steal a bye New Zealand won by 2 wickets Player of the match is Kyle Mills, NZ
Match_Report: New Zealand 8 for 182 (Taylor 64, Bracken 3-38) beat Australia 181 (Hussey 49, Mills 4-35) by 2 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Ross Taylor's clever innings gave New Zealand hope and ended in a sweet success ? Getty Images Ross Taylor showed calm class and Kyle Mills combined with bat and ball, but New Zealand had to wait until the last delivery to hand Australia their fourth loss in a row and gain a 1-0 lead in the Chappell-Hadlee Series. Taylor guided the tentative chase of the home team's below-par 181 and carried an order of novices before Daniel Vettori sealed the success with a glide behind point. The timing of New Zealand's batting Powerplay was crucial - it came with eight overs to go - as they went from heading towards a troubling loss to redirecting course. Mills, who had already earned four wickets, picked up consecutive boundaries off Nathan Bracken (3 for 38) in a 12-run over that was followed by 11 from Shaun Tait, including a brave six swiped over midwicket by Taylor. There was a late shift when Mills went for 26 from 35 balls and Taylor was caught by Michael Clarke for 64 off 97.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss Australia have won the toss and they will bowl first. Bracken to Gibbs, 1 wide lands it wide down the legside and Gibbs doesn't want to chase it Bracken to Gibbs, OUT timber! And Bracken has his revenge! He cleverly bowls the slower ball and Gibbs fails to read it as he swings early and misses, the ball clips the top of the off stump and he's got to go Laughlin to de Villiers, OUT doesn't take too long for Laughlin to strike, not really a wicket-taking ball, it was full and wide and waiting to be hit but de Villiers gets forward and ends up slamming it straight to White at short cover Hopes to Peterson, OUT Peterson gives himself way too much room and exposes the stumps too much for his liking, Hopes fires it on the blockhole and the ball cannons onto the stumps, the bails are splattered Harwood to Duminy, OUT lucky strike for Harwood! He bowls a full toss on the stumps and Duminy moves across his stumps to paddle it away but misses and his leg stump is flattened Laughlin to van der Merwe, SIX runs he's a lucky bloke as yet another mishit manages to clear the rope! Amazing! He tries to deposit him over deep midwicket but the ball sails over deep point instead, what bat speed Harwood to van der Merwe, OUT he goes for 48, Harwood drops it short and van der Merwe makes room to slice it through the off side, the short length foxes him and he has no room to work with and as a result he gets a faint edge to Haddin Laughlin to Boucher, 1 leg bye bangs it in short and Boucher takes his eyes off the ball as he shapes to pull and the ball rolls off the body, Laughlin attempts an athletic under arm flick The players are out in the middle, and Johann Louw is set to open the proceedings Louw to Clarke, 1 wide He starts off with a very wide one outside offstump Abdulla to Warner, 1 wide follows that up with one down the leg side, that's a wide Morkel to Warner, OUT Morkel gets the breakthrough South Africa needed so badly, Warner is bowled by a full delivery on middle and off, Warner comes down the track and tries to loft it down the ground, misses the ball and his stumps are shattered Abdulla to Ponting, OUT Ponting's gone this time, caught behind pushing at a length ball, he was ill at ease in his first two deliveries as well, and this one comes in a fraction after pitching outside off, Ponting took a big stride forward to drive, feathered it throu Morkel to Clarke, 1 wide wide down the leg side from Albie Morkel van der Merwe to Hopes, 1 leg bye Hopes goes for the sweep to a full ball outside off, doesn't make contact and the ball cannons off the pads towards backward point Morkel to Hopes, SIX runs Hopes provides them with one of those, swats the final ball of the over into the crowd behind midwicket Louw to Hopes, OUT Hopes is gone, deceived by the slower one, good thinking from Louw, Hopes was coming down the track, he sent in a shorter, slower one, which Hopes mishits to midwicket, Albie takes a diving catch to send Hopes on his way Louw to Haddin, SIX runs swatted to the long-on boundary, could have been another wicket if Duminy had held on to that, he only manages to push the ball over the boundary Player of the match is Roelof van der Merwe, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 156 for 5 (van der Merwe 48, Peterson 34, Harwood 2-21) beat Australia 139 for 8 (Hussey 27, Clarke 27, Botha 2-16) by 17 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out South Africa were saved by the brutal contribution of Roelof van der Merwe in the twilight overs AFP The South Africans continue to dominate the limited-overs formats. Having usurped Australia for top place in the 50-over rankings last year, South Africa now head to the World Twenty20 brimming with confidence after a second consecutive 20-over victory over Ricky Ponting's men, this time by 17 runs. The Australians seldom appeared comfortable in pursuit of South Africa's 156 for 5 on a pitch that troubled batsmen from both sides of the Indian Ocean. Michael Clarke (27 runs from 33 balls) struggled to combat South Africa's disciplined lines, while Ricky Ponting was dismissed for a solitary run for the second time in three days; this time to a well-angled delivery from debutant paceman Yusuf Abdulla. Hardly an ideal start.

Commentary_Highlights: The news from the Wanderers is that South Africa have won the toss and opted to field. Parnell to Clarke, OUT timber! Parnell gets one, fullish on the off stump, held its line, Clarke had decided he would go after that one, bowled at 143 kmph, he makes room to smash that over extra cover, misses and the stumps take a beating! Morkel to Ponting, OUT poor shot really, hit a good length on middle and leg, Ponting stayed in his crease and tried to clear mid-on, wasn't to the pitch at all, ended up mistiming it towards Johan Botha who ran a few steps back and pouched it gleefully. Morkel to Warner, SIX runs change of pace but Warner picked the slower one, landed full on middle, he took a step forward, got under it nicely and lofted it cleanly over the long-on boundary Botha to Hussey, SIX runs that's disappeared, timely hit, flighted on the off stump, much slower through the air, Hussey's eyes light up, he gets under it and dismisses it over the long-on boundary Peterson to Warner, OUT excellent reflexes by Peterson! Bowled full on the off stump, Warner picks the length and swats it firmly but straight towards the bowler, Peterson reacts well, bends down and takes it low. Peterson to Haddin, OUT he's thrown it away! Flighted on the off stump, lands on a good length, Haddin lofts it lazily, no intent whatsoever in that stroke, finds Albie Morkel at long-off positioned exactly for some poor batting like that Parnell to Hussey, SIX runs gets hold of it this time, bowled round the wicket, full outside off, reaches for it and creams it over the extra-cover boundary, went about 10-15 rows into the crowd Peterson to Hussey, SIX runs slogged away and it's over the ropes, full and straight on the off stump, bowled quick, heaves it over the deep midwicket boundary, reaches his 50 in style Peterson to White, OUT identical stroke but not the result, struck it well but the ball was bowled much slower through the air, heaved it, but straight to deep midwicket where Duminy judges it to perfection Morkel to Hussey, 1 wide straying down the leg side, given a wide, the first one in a long time Parnell to Johnson, OUT bowled 'im! Good stuff from Parnell, in the blockhole on middle, Johnson tries to dig it out on the leg side but is a little too late in bringing his bat down, misses and the stumps are rattled Harwood to Amla, 1 wide bouncer outside leg stump, erring in line here, given a wide Harwood to Gibbs, SIX runs Harwood's being punished, bowled on a good length outside off, Gibbs charges down the track and smashes it over the extra-cover boundary Harwood to Amla, 1 wide driving length outside off and Amla goes for it, moves away after pitching, the batsman misses, and the bowler is awarded with a wide called by the umpire, a little too harsh there Hopes to Duminy, 1 wide slower ball outside leg stump, cut back in to miss the leg stump but it's still down the leg side, given a wide Hopes to Duminy, OUT big wicket! Just when it seemed Duminy was helping his team claw back, Hopes has uprooted his off stump. Short of a length and Duminy is tempted to go for a cross-batted pull over midwicket, the ball keeps a little low, he misses and the sticks behind him take a beating. Johnson to Morkel, 1 wide starts with a wide down the leg side, Australia can afford one every now and then with the position they are in Johnson to Boucher, 1 wide bouncer banged in short on middle, called a wide, rightly so, it's too high Harwood to Morkel, 1 leg bye full on the leg stump, should have glanced it down fine but misses, is struck on the pads and they get a leg bye Johnson to Botha, 1 wide wide down the leg side, only just though, short of a length on the leg stump and moved down, Botha let it go Johnson to Botha, 1 leg bye full on leg stump, swung in to strike him on the pads, they get a leg bye towards third man, would have gone down South Africa were in deep trouble at one stage - they were 83 for 5 - but Boucher and Morkel sparked a revival with a stand of 58 for the sixth wicket. Morkel fell for a superb 19-ball 37 but Boucher stayed till the end, repeating his feat in that famous chase of 434, to guide his team to a thrilling four-wicket win. South Africa won by 4 wickets (with 4 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Johan Botha, the South Africa captain, praised the performances of Mark Boucher and Albie Morkel after they showed why they get paid "the big bucks" in the tight four-wicket Twenty20 win over Australia. Boucher and Morkel concluded the hosts' recovery from 83 for 5 to reach 168 for 6 with four balls remaining. "It got a bit tight but you know with those two out there, that's why they get paid the big bucks," Botha told AAP. "They do it under pressure and they did it again tonight. "With those two in with a long way to go, we knew we still had a chance.

Commentary_Highlights: Jadeja to Khawaja, OUT LBW! He's given out sweeping! Khawaja has reviewed it. It was fired in flat and straight, it did turn a touch, he tried to sweep from a length, no hot spot, no spike on RTS, he has missed it, he was hit on the knee infront of middle and off, Hawkeye has i Bhuvneshwar to Marsh, 1 leg bye length ball, pitching outside leg and keeping a bit low to rap the batsman near the knee rolls, an appeal for lbw but not out, says the umpire. They sneak in a leg-bye though Kuldeep to Marsh, OUT flighted on the stumps, Marsh skips down and looks to clear long-on, doesn't middle it and Shami comes forward and takes a low tumbling catch Shami to Handscomb, 1 wide a full toss but down the leg side, lucky for Shami that Handscomb didn't any bat on it Shami to Handscomb, 1 wide comes down the track but Shami sees that and slips in a bouncer, Handscomb looks to pull but that's too high Bhuvneshwar to Stoinis, 1 wide slower one outside off, but way too wide, needs to be bowled again Behrendorff to S Dhawan, OUT LBW! Given out and Dhawan walks off! Behrendorff gets his first. Fuller length, it nipped back off the seam, Dhawan's head falls over, it beats the inside edge and hits him plumb on the shin in front of off! No doubt about that one. Jhye Richardson to Kohli, OUT caught at square leg! Oh no! He's nailed this off his pads straight to Marcus Stoinis at forward square! It was 138kph, nearly a half-volley on leg stump, he pinged it off his pads but in the air, waist high, straight to Stoinis, he sucked his stoma Jhye Richardson to Rayudu, OUT LBW! Rayudu has a long chat with Rohit and he decides to review. This was full and fast, it angled in and didn't swing, beat the inside edge, nothing on hot spot, hit below the knee roll. It was smashing into leg stump! OUT! Three reds light up on Behrendorff to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs 133kph, full on leg stump, he flicks this high and long to deep square, Marsh on the rope catches it and parries it back in but his heel was touching the padding of the rope! After a long delay it's signalled six! Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 wide 137kph, sprayed down the leg side, and called wide Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 wide 138kph, short and swinging way wide of off stump, he leaves, it's too wide Lyon to Dhoni, SIX runs here we go, he skips down and launches this way back over long on! MS Dhoni of old, he just got down to the pitch and thumped it way over the fence, 25 rows back! Stoinis to Dhoni, 1 wide an attempted bouncer, down the leg side and balloons over Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 leg bye fuller in the stumps, goes back and flicks it behind square leg Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 wide a bouncer this time, but down the leg side and called a wide Jhye Richardson to Dhoni, 1 leg bye length on middle and leg, flicked towards fine leg Lyon to Dhoni, 1 leg bye length again, Dhoni uses his feet and misses, hits on the pads, but way too down the wicket, a leg-bye to extra cover Behrendorff to Dhoni, 1 leg bye length on middle and leg, tucked away towards square leg Lyon to Rohit Sharma, SIX runs he stands still, it's in the arc, and he launches it over long on and into the crowd! Great strike! Jhye Richardson to Jadeja, OUT caught at deep backward point! He bowled a quick short ball, Jadeja backs away and upper cuts, he flushes it but gets it too square, it goes all the way to Marsh on the rope, he settles and takes the catch! Four for Richardson Stoinis to Rohit Sharma, 1 wide 126kph slower ball, gets it wrong, sprays way wide of off and called a wide Siddle to Kuldeep, OUT caught at deep backward square! Khawaja holds one! Slower ball, shorter, he steps outside off and pulls this in the air to deep backward square, Khawaja waits again, but he clings onto this one and Siddle has a wicket! Australia go 1-0 up in the three match series. The next game is in Adelaide on Tuesday. On behalf of all the team thanks for your company tonight. Look out for Andrew McGlashan's post-game coverage from the SCG. For now goodbye, and hopefully we see you Tuesday. Player of the match is Jhye Richardson, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 5 for 288 (Handscomb 73, Khawaja 59, S Marsh 54) beat India 254 for 9 (Rohit 133, Dhoni 51, Richardson 4-26) by 34 runs They just needed a new kit. Despite a fine century from Rohit Sharma, Australia ripped up the form book with a 34-run victory in the first ODI at the SCG. Jhye Richardson bowled superbly to take 4 for 26, which ensured a solid if unspectacular display from their Test match turned one-day top order was enough for a much-needed win. After ODI debutant Jason Behrendorff struck with his sixth ball, Richardson claimed two wickets in three balls in his second over, the first of them Virat Kohli, as India crashed to 3 for 4 inside four overs in their chase of 289. Rohit kept them in the contest with his 22nd ODI century, adding 137 for the fourth wicket with MS Dhoni 28 overs.

Commentary_Highlights: Steyn to Clarke, OUT Clarke has been cleaned up by Steyn. What an awesome delivery. It landed slightly short in length on the off stump line and straightened to hit the off. Clarke pushed inside the line and heard the death rattle.Not so awesome on replay. It was a very good delivery indeed but it landed Harris to Katich, OUT Kato is gone. The readers have woofed him out I think. What an uncharacteristic shot. It was on a length outside off stump, Katich dragged it from there, attempting a sweep shot but could only top edge it to close on the leg side and Imraan Khan takes his first Test catch. Remember h Harris to Haddin, OUT Trapped in front but Haddin, after checking with the non-striker, has gone for the review. It landed on the middle stump line, skidded through quickly to rap him on the pad in front of middle and leg. That's dead duck. No inside edge and the height looks ok as well. Bucknor got it ri Ntini to McDonald, OUT Ntini's patience has paid off. McDonald walked across outside off again. Ntini kept it full and even further outside off. McDonald went for the cover drive but edged it into the bucket hands of Kallis at first slip. Ntini to Siddle, OUT Ntini takes out Siddle. He straightens a length delivery outside off and Siddle lunges forward to stab it to left of second slip where AB swallows it. Out for a duck. Eight for 190. Harris to McGain, 1 leg bye drifts towards the pad, rolls away to fine leg Steyn to Johnson, OUT Mitch is gone, going for a six. It was a length delivery and a tad slower as well and Johnson got under the ball more than he wanted and got elevation instead of distance. Prince ran to his left from long-on to hold on to the ball. Nine down. Steyn to McGain, OUT 209 all out. Full and straight outside off, McGain is caught at the crease and hangs his bat out and stabs it to third slip. Good disciplined show from South Africa to bowl out Australia for 209. How will their batsmen go about their task? Remember, they have new openers. Join us in a short while for the reply. Siddle to Boucher, 1 bye gets this to straighten outside off stump and Bad Hands days of Brad Haddin returns. He doesn't take it cleanly and this is no 53, the highest no of extras Australia have ever conceded in a Test. Johnson to Boucher, OUT Caught at second slip. Poor stuff from Boucher. He had just edged one through the cordon and he goes hard at another full delivery slanting across him. Edge and gone! Australia have done well today to take out three wickets. Hilfenhaus to Morkel, 1 leg bye fullish, tires to flick it and it rolls off the pad to square leg McGain to Morkel, SIX runs Flighted up, aiming for the rough but Albie waltzes down the track to the pitch of the ball and swings it high and long over long-on into the delirious crowd. Well .. I expect them to be delirious. Albie's first Test six. McDonald to de Villiers, SIX runs McDonald helps AB by pitching this one even shorter and de Villiers says thanks for the gift and rips it to the crowd behind deep midwicket. up up and over. McDonald to Morkel, OUT And a wicket to end the over where AB smoked 4 sixes. It landed on a length around middle and leg and moved towards middle and off, Albie had a lazy waft at it, missed it completely and was cleaned up. Not an attacking shot, just a defensive waft Johnson to Harris, 1 wide from round the stumps, hurls a wide delivery outside off stump. The extras keep piling up. McDonald to Harris, 1 leg bye yorker ,drifting outside leg and off the pad to fine leg. AB is on strike. Katich to de Villiers, OUT AB has holed out to deep midwicket. Short delivery, nothing special, could have disappeared out of the ground but AB pulls it straight to the fielder. What a fine entertaining innings from de Villiers. The crowd loved it and are now showing their appreciation with a generous th Katich to Steyn, OUT Lovely loopy slider from Katich who picks his second wicket. It looped up outside off, good rip on the ball and Steyn drove inside the line and edged it to slip. Questions will be asked why Ponting didn't bring Kato on earlier. Was the bowler reluctant or the captain? Press conferenc So South Africa all out for 651. They lead by 442. A mountain to climb. AB indulged himself, Albie had fun and even Harris threw his bat around. Much fun for the crowd. That's tea as well. Join us in a while for the final session. Player of the match is Paul Harris, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 651 (de Villiers 163, Prince 150, Kallis 102) beat Australia 209 (Katich 55, Steyn 4-56) and 422 (Johnson 123*, McDonald 68, Katich 54, Harris 6-127) by an innings and 20 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Mitchell Johnson's maiden century was a stirring affair and gave South Africa palpitations before they eventually won AFP Minor lapses in concentration were always going to be crucial on a day like this. For two sessions it was Australia who paid for erring, and in the final it was South Africa - having stuck to their task so well until tea - who relaxed and looked on in bewilderment as centurion Mitchell Johnson and Andrew McDonald thumped a rearguard of dizzying proportions. In the end, however, Australia were unable to overcome a massive deficit and fell to an innings defeat - 11 years and a day to the last time that happened. With the score reading 231 for 6 at tea, South Africa were in charge but things went pear-shaped after the interval. Truly, final sessions have seldom had so much packed in them.

Commentary_Highlights: Australia must have been eyeing a score of well above 400 after that opening stand but lost their way badly, particularly today. They lost their last six wickets for just 23 - and their last five for just 4 - as the South African seamers tore away at them, troubling their batsmen especially with the short ball. The pitch has helped the bowlers today so Johnson and Hilfenhaus will bank on some assistance. Siddle to Steyn, 1 leg bye well played by Steyn, short on leg stump, fends it away but uses his arm guard and not his gloves like the ones who preceded him Australia will bat on so no follow-on. They lead by 214, a massive one as they look to close out the series. It was all over before you could blink. Steyn flashed at a wide one and Ntini was trapped in front the following ball. Siddle will be on a hat-trick when he takes the new ball soon. It's been a superb turnaround by the Australians after they collapsed yesterday morning. They'll look to pile on the Innings Start North changes ends
Match_Report: Australia 352 (Hughes 115, Katich 108) and 331 for 5 dec (Hughes 160, Ponting 81) beat South Africa 138 (Duminy 73*, Johnson 3-37, McDonald 3-25) and 370 (Kallis 93, de Villiers 84, Siddle 3-61, Katich 3-45) by 175 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out AB de Villiers made a fine 84 before Peter Siddle ended his resistance AFP The transitional period is over. An emphatic series win in South Africa will imbue Australia with confidence that, after a harrowing six-month search, they have uncovered a crop of cricketers capable of competing with the world's best. The Australians sealed a comprehensive 175-run victory at Kingsmead shortly before tea on the fifth day, prompting scenes of jubilation from a team barely recognisable to that which last tasted series success on South African shores. In claiming an unassailable 2-0 series lead, Ricky Ponting's band of rookies defended the No. 1 Test ranking earned by their venerable forebears and created a difficult situation for Andrew Hilditch's selection panel when the likes of Brett Lee, Stuart Clark and Andrew Symonds return in the coming months.

Commentary_Highlights: Arafat to Clarke, 1 wide straying in line now, pushed it wide of leg stump, given a wide, Pakistan have a looked sloppy after that double-strike Malik to Haddin, OUT bowled'im! A conventional offpsinner, landed on the off and spun in, Haddin moves well across to turn it into the leg side, missed and the ball clipped the leg stump, exposed his stumps there and paid the price Afridi to Symonds, OUT trapped in front, held its line, landed on a good length on middle, was half-forward while playing at it, was expecting it to turn away but was beaten by the straighter one to be struck in line, big blow that, the spinners have done it again Malik to Ferguson, 1 leg bye on middle and leg, pushed away wide of midwicket Afridi to Clarke, OUT caught and bowled, stopped on him a little, dropped it short, spun away, stepped out of the crease and pushed at it, lobbed it straight to Afridi who took a dolly, went through with the shot there, didn't try to adjust to the spin, and paid the price Umar Gul to Ferguson, OUT was in the slot, struck it well, had a nice swing at it but there was fielder there perfectly positioned for that shot, hit towards long-on where Tanvir just had to take a couple of steps back to snap that one Ajmal to Hussey, 1 leg bye tossed up outside off, worked it away behind square for a single Umar Gul to Hussey, OUT gone! Slower one, bowled short on the off, an offcutter that, Hussey failed to pick it, struggled all the way through, tried to pull it over deep square leg, got the top edge as he was a little early into the shot, easy catch to Arafat Pakistan will fancy chasing this. Australia completely lost the plot in the middle overs, once the spinners came on. It was the combo of Afridi and Malik that did the damage, who kept the leash on Clarke and Haddin during their stand. Wickets kept falling at fairly frequent intervals, and even in the last ten, once the seamers came back on, It all went downhill from then on, as batsman after batsman either got out playing a needless shot, or was done in by some genuinely good bowling. Australia kept the pressure on as soon as they sniffed a chance at a comeback, and once they had seized the advantage, they didn't take too long to complete the formalities, despite a determined Player of the match is Michael Clarke, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 198 for 7 (Clarke 66, Ferguson 41, Gul 3-38, Afridi 2-31) beat Pakistan 171 (Butt 48, Shehzad 40, Clarke 3-15, Hauritz 2-25 ) by 27 runs Live scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Michael Clarke's return to form couldn't have come at a better moment Associated Press Pakistan's propensity to self-destruct cost them the lead in this series in dramatic manner, a batting collapse against spin handing Australia an improbable win. Michael Clarke, the Australian captain, turned in a superb all-round performance with a gritty 66 in the face of some penetrative spin bowling before picking up 3 for 15 amid Pakistan's middle-order chaos. His spin partners, Nathan Hauritz and Andrew Symonds, helped defend a below-par score of 198 as Pakistan fell short by 27 runs. Spinners have been making headlines in the IPL in South Africa and the story today wasn't any different in the northern hemisphere. Pakistan's own spin trio strangled the runs and picked up three wickets and, by the time their openers Salman Butt and Ahmed Shehzad added 95, the hosts looked set for a series lead.

Commentary_Highlights: 2.26 pm: We'll get you the details from the toss shortly. The news is that Pakistan have won the toss and opted to bat. Nasir Jamshed is out injured, and in comes Ahmed Shehzad, who makes his debut. Three changes for Australia. Shaun Marsh is replaced by David Hussey; Ben Hilfenhaus and Stuart Clark make way for Ben Laughlin and Doug Bollinger. So still no Hopes to Salman Butt, 1 leg bye tries to tuck it away behind square, gets a legbye as it brushes his thighs Laughlin to Younis, OUT he strikes immediately! A tame dismissal really, short and wide, goes for the cut, swings away as he plays the shot, takes the outside edge and Haddin makes no mistake Hauritz to Malik, OUT well caught by Haddin, bowled it a touch flat outside off, Malik charged down the pitch and had a massive swing at it, got the inside edge as it spun in, hit the boot and lobbed up in front of Haddin who dived to pluck it inches from the ground, it's been referred to the third umpire who rightly gives it OUT after taking ages to Hauritz to Misbah, OUT Misbah goes for the reverse-sweep and finds David Husey at short third, quicker on outside off and he tries to help it on its way, went really quickly towards Hussey to dived full length to his right to pluck a sharp one, stayed alert throughout Hauritz to Salman Butt, OUT Hauritz takes three, dipped into him and appeared to stop on him a little, chips it, with hardly any conviction, straight to Symonds who dives forward at cover Laughlin to Afridi, 1 leg bye slower ball, at 115.5 kmph, on leg stump, was probably going down as he missed a pull, should have dismissed that, will be ruing it now Laughlin to Afridi, SIX runs he's got under it nicely, was in the slot, slower ball bowled full on the off, meaty, and he smashed it over long-on, came off the middle Hopes to Afridi, OUT edged and Haddin flings himself to his right to snap that out of thin air, superb catch! Fraction full on the off, makes room while simultaneously stepping out, tries to launch it over the in-field on the off side, gets a thick edge and the keeper pulls off a beauty. Big blow that! Hopes to Kamran, OUT gone! Bowled on a length on middle, walks across and chips it straight to David Hussey at midwicket, mistimed there, had tried to clear him, six down. Symonds to Umar Gul, OUT flighted outside off, bent down, got down on one knee to sweep that over square leg, got the top edge and Hauritz ran well to his left from deep square leg, timed his dive well, and made amends for that drop earlier Symonds to Shoaib Akhtar, OUT superb catch by Clarke! Short on the off, gets back and punches it hard, almost clears cover but Clarke leaps and plucks it with his left hand out of thin air to send Shoaib back Pakistan will rue the fact that they didn't bat out 50 overs. 207 is competitive, but the Australians will back themselves to chase it down. Pakistan, on this pitch, will again bank on their spinners to do the job. Shoaib Akhtar to Haddin, 1 leg bye quicker, 146.3 kmph, but slightly misdirected, short on leg stump, tries to clip it fine, misses out, salvages another leg bye Umar Gul to Hopes, (no ball) oversteps, played to midwicket, gifts a freehit Shoaib Akhtar to Hopes, SIX runs that's flat and into the crowd, short and wide and cuts it away powerfully over point, leapt with both feet off the ground as he played that Australia paced their innings perfectly, first with the stand between Hopes and Watson, and then between Symonds and Clarke. Two quick wickets, one to Ajmal and the other to Afridi, put the two teams on even terms at one stage but a fluent Symonds, supported by a shaky, yet determined Clarke saw Australia through. The spinners, particularly Ajmal, were deal Australia won by 6 wickets (with 29 balls remaining) Player of the match is Andrew Symonds, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 208 for 4 (Symonds 58, Hopes 48, Afridi 2-38) beat Pakistan 207 (Butt 57, Afridi 41, Hauritz 3-41, Symonds 2-12) by six wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Andrew Symonds was easily the best allrounder on display Associated Press Andrew Symonds may have cut his Rastafarian beads, but he showed tonight there had been no cutback on his competitive spirit or his aptitude as Australia levelled the series 1-1. His two-wicket over, in the face of a marauding Shoaib Akhtar, had kept Pakistan down to a par total, but his bigger contribution came with the bat when Shahid Afridi and Saeed Ajmal threatened to run through Australia for the second time in a row. Afridi and Ajmal had undone James Hopes' good work at the top, bringing the game right back into the balance, when Symonds came in to bat. Hopes, filling in for the injured Shaun Marsh at the top of the order, had put Australia on their way to a chase of a tricky 207, before Ajmal and Afridi struck in back-to-back overs. The contest was always going to come to life when the spinners came on.

Commentary_Highlights: 2.30 pm: Time for the toss. Australia have won the toss and opted to bat. Shaun Marsh, Shane Watson, Stuart Clark, Andrew Symonds and Ben Hilfenhaus are all in. Younis Khan says he would have batted first had he won, and says a score of around 260-odd would be chaseable. Shoaib Akhtar is back! We'll get Umar Gul to Haddin, SIX runs that was coming, a touch too full from Gul and Haddin picks the length early, strikes it cleanly over long-on for a big one, was in the slot and he didn't waste the opportunity this time, that'll ease the pressure a little Afridi to Haddin, 1 wide fired in down the leg side, held its line,called a wide Afridi to Haddin, OUT Haddin goes! Gave it some air, Haddin was drawn forward and he went through with the drive, was not entirely committed to it and hit it straight to Younis who timed his jump to perfection to snap an easy one. Shoaib will be a little relieved there Afridi to Symonds, OUT Australia in a spot of bother now, the offcutter bowled from the back of the hand, short outside off, spin it, made way for a cut behind point, gloved it straight to the keeper Afridi to Watson, OUT He's a legpsinner, but that's actually a classic offspinner's dismissal, threw it up outside off, drawing him forward, he lunges forward to defend, the ball cuts back in sharply to beat him through the gate and the stumps are rattled Afridi to Ferguson, OUT Afridi's on a roll! Flighted outside off, Ferguson was sucked in, came forward to force it through cover, got a thick edge and Misbah snapped it well diving to his left, Australia slide further Ajmal to Hauritz, OUT bowled'im!! An embarassing dismissal that, spun in sharply from outside off, he shouldered arms to that one, not expecting it to spin as much, and hears the death rattle behind him as it clips off stump Afridi to Bracken, OUT five-for for Afridi! Done in by the googly again, tossed up outside off and Bracken's eyes lit up, got forward to drive it forcefully through cover, misread the spin and was bowled through the gate. His third five-wicket haul, and his first against Australia Afridi to Clark, OUT Afridi gets his best figures in ODIs! He's mastered the googly here, tossed it up outside off, landed on a good length and zipped back in take the off stump as Clarke was beaten through the gate as he came forward to defend Shoaib Akhtar to Hopes, 1 wide starts off with an absolutely horrendous wide outside off, why is Malik not being given a bowl? Umar Gul to Hilfenhaus, OUT gone! Cleaned him up, straight on middle, he played across the line to work that wide of midwicket, missed it, clipped the pads and crashed into middle and off Hilfenhaus to Salman Butt, OUT he's given him! Australia strike early, landed on a good length on middle and leg and came on quickly to Butt as it swung in to rap him on the pads on the back foot, struck him in line with leg stump and the umpire Nadeem Ghauri raised his finger immediately Clark to Kamran, OUT gone this time! Took a chance once too often, similar ball to the one that was edged for four earlier in the over, but gets some movement away from the batsman, Akmal goes after it, gets a thick edge and Haddin pouches it well moving to his right Hilfenhaus to Afridi, 1 wide called a wide, too high, banged in short and Haddin leapt to pluck it with one hand Pakistan won by 4 wickets (with 35 balls remaining) Player of the match is Shahid Afridi, PAK
Match_Report: Pakistan 171 for 6 (Akmal 48, Misbah 30*) beat Australia 168 (Hopes 48*, Haddin 40, Watson 40, Afridi 6-38) by four wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Shahid Afridi made the ball talk and picked up his best ODI figures of 6 for 38 AFP A team desperate to erase painful recent memories immediately settled in at their new, adopted venue, with a four-wicket win against a struggling Australian side in Dubai. The devastation caused by Shahid Afridi's career-best 6 for 38 had all but shut Australia out of the match before the halfway stage of their innings. A late recovery pushed them to 168 but it wasn't enough to seriously challenge an unpredictable Pakistan outfit. Pakistan stuttered, rebuilt, stumbled again and a late push by Afridi, contributing an adrenalin-filled yet brief 24, pushed them towards a win. The ultimate difference between the two sides was spin.

Commentary_Highlights: Morkel to Clarke, 2 leg byes landed on a good length outside off, gets way outside the line to turn it wide of mid-on, is struck on the pads, gets a couple of leg byes Morkel to Haddin, OUT he's got him! SA following up well on that maiden, full on the off stump, Haddin makes room to cart that over the infield on the off side, ends up slicing it really high and Duminy at deep cover, positioned perfectly, just had to take few steps to his right to complete an easy catch van der Merwe to Ferguson, OUT Fergie goes! An abrupt end to a good stand, quicker one the off stump, lands full, he drives through the line but ends up chipping it straight to de Villiers at short cover who takes a sharp chance Duminy to Ponting, OUT tossed up on the stumps this time and is tempted to go at it again, strikes it clean and high but not well enough as he fails to beat van der Merwe at long-on who takes a well-judged catch. Duminy does the trick. Duminy to Hussey, 1 wide, OUT a leg-side stumping, tossed up on middle and leg, drawing David Hussey out of the crease as he tries to work that away behind square, the ball spins down, the batsman misses and Boucher clips the bails to find him well short Duminy to Hopes, 1 wide another one, it's brought them a wicket but he's doing it too often Duminy to Johnson, OUT short on middle, pushes it back uppishly towards Duminy who dives forward and to his left to pluck it inches off the ground, or so it seemed. Duminy wasn't sure himself and asked the umpire to call for a replay, which then confirmed he had just about managed to get his hands around it. Steyn to Hauritz, 1 wide short of a length outside off, but a little too wide, chases it but fails to connect Steyn to Hussey, 1 wide and again, poor bowling this, attempted the slower one this time but got his direction totally wrong Ferguson proved an important wicket as he had brought the momentum back with the visitors with a fluent 41 and the openers had departed. Ponting got a start but never looked dominant; and Hussey, along with Hauritz, dealt some useful blows in the end to take his team past 300. South Africa, though, have the wherewithal to chase this down, but with the pitch getting a little slow, their Laughlin to Gibbs, 1 wide false start, full and wide and swinging away further, deservedly called a wide Laughlin to Kallis, SIX runs banged in short and Kallis is onto it quickly, spots the length early, gets back and pulls it away well wide of deep square leg for a six Hauritz to Gibbs, 2 byes straying on the pads, paddles it really fine, well wide of fine leg for two more Hauritz to Morkel, OUT Laughlin, you genius!! Tossed up outside off, and Albie goes for the slog-sweep, Laughlin's right at the edge of the ropes at deep midwicket and for a good while it appears the ball will clear him easily, but he waits, and times his jump to perfection to snap that over his head inches in front of the ropes, and celebrates kicking it Aussie-rules style back Spin had done the trick for South Africa when they bowled, but it was Bracken who turned things Australia's way with the wicket of Kallis. Not that the Australia spinners were ineffective; Hauritz chipped in with 2 for 34, including the important wicket of Albie towards the end, who was caught stunningly by Laughlin, a wicket that proved critical in the outcome. Australia have taken the No.2 spot with that win. They won it comfortably in the end, given the margin, but there was a time when Gibbs and Kallis were going strong, when it seemed South Africa could pull it off. Player of the match is Nathan Hauritz, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 303 for 7 (Clarke 66, Haddin 62, Duminy 3-48) beat South Africa 256 (Gibbs 82, Kallis 64, Johnson 3-58) by 47 runs Scorecard and ball-by-details How they were out Ben Laughlin's stunning catch to dismiss Albie Morkel turned the game firmly in Australia's favour Associated Press It may have been a dead rubber at the end of a long summer, but a resolute Australia scrapped hard in the field to secure a consolation win in Johannesburg and move up to No. 2 in the ODI rankings. Both innings in the match followed a similar pattern: significant contributions from the top four before the middle order collapsed. Michael Hussey remained unbeaten to make sure Australia capitalised on the batting Powerplay and shepherded them past 300, but none of the South African batsmen played that role, leaving the tail too much to do. South Africa appeared to be coasting towards victory when they had reached 186 for 2 after 34 overs, with Jacques Kallis and Man-of-the-Series AB de Villiers looking solid.

Commentary_Highlights: Hopes to Smith, OUT Hopes strikes! Just a fraction short outside off, Smith comes down the pitch while simultaneously giving himself some room, slashes hard but gets a thick edge, actually off the bottom of the bat straight to Haddin who accepts it gleefully Hopes to Gibbs, 1 leg bye slower ball bowled short on middle, fails to spot it and is already into an attempted pull behind square, is hit on the shoulder Harwood to Kallis, 1 wide calls it a wide, a patchy decision that, wasn't too wide of the off stump, swung away as Kallis let it go Harwood to Kallis, OUT Harwood gets his maiden ODI wicket! Banged in short outside off, Kallis times that a little too well for his liking, upper-cuts it straight to third man, who's right at the edge waiting for it and takes a well-judged catch bending forward Hauritz to Gibbs, 2 leg byes appeal for lbw, fired in quick and full on the off and it spun in, Gibbs got a long way across to sweep it fine, was struck on the pads but perhaps just a slightly outside the line, too close to call, the ball rolls down wide of short fine Hauritz to de Villiers, SIX runs was waiting for it for ages and cashed in when the opportunity presented itself, tossed up on middle, down the track, takes it on the full and deposits it over the long-on boundary with a golf swing Bracken to Gibbs, OUT he goes, after an excellent knock! Bracken pushed it full this time, on middle, Gibbs made room and attempted to loft that over long-on, timed it well but not well enough, found Clarke in the deep who took it comfortably Johnson to Morkel, OUT bowled'im! Came back in after landing on a good length outside off, Morkel tried to guide that to third man from the crease but was late into the shot, the ball jagged back in sharply to beat his bat and clip off stump Johnson to Boucher, 1 wide too wide, the batsman stretches to get his bat to it but doesn't connect Johnson to de Villiers, OUT bowled on a good length on middle and leg, not quite full for the waft over midwicket that de Villiers was attempting, mistimed it completely and Ferguson at mid-on ran a couple of yards to his left to snap a well-judged catch Johnson to Boucher, 1 wide straying down the leg side, given a wide The openers are out in the middle. Steyn will start the proceedings for South Africa, and facing him is Haddin. Two slips in place. Steyn to Haddin, 2 wide straying down the leg side, false start, Boucher dives full length to his left and does well to concede just two wides Parnell to Clarke, 1 leg bye good length on leg stump, tries to clip it fine, is struck on the thighs and they scamper a leg bye Morkel to Clarke, 1 wide bouncer, was in no control of it though, his fingers clipped the bails while he was bowling, went way over the batsman's head on the leg side Kallis to Haddin, 1 leg bye moved across quite a bit, landed on a good length on middle and struck him in line as he tried to work that behind square, would have probably knocked out leg stump but Kallis was the only one who appealed Botha to Haddin, OUT Parnell's snapped it this time, flighted on the off stump, Haddin is tempted and attempts to clear long-on again, doesn't strike this as well as the previous one, gets more elevation than he would have wanted and finds Parnell, who takes it gleefully just inside the ropes van der Merwe to Clarke, OUT he's gone now and South Africa have struck back with two quick wickets, forced much quicker through the air, landed on a good length on middle and spun away sharply, Clarke was beaten by the pace as well as the spin to watch is offstump pegged back van der Merwe to Ferguson, OUT spin does the trick again, van der Merwe has turned this game around, similar ball to the one that got Clarke but bowled outside the off stump this time, Ferguson stepped out of his crease to play it into the off side but was done in by the sharp spin away from him, Boucher collected it clean van der Merwe to Hussey, OUT van der Merwe you beauty! Flatter, following up on three flighted deliveries, landed just a fraction outside off stump and turned in towards Hussey to rap him on the pads as he got onto the back foot to work it behind square. Replays indicate he was struck in line with leg stump van der Merwe to Ponting, 1 wide fired in down the leg side, tries to sweep but misses van der Merwe to Hopes, 2 wide a wide down the leg side, Boucher can't collect and the batsmen jog through for a single Steyn to Ponting, OUT He's gone now! What an eventful over, could well be the decisive blow. Held it back this time and banged it in short on middle, tried to pull it over midwicket, struck it well but couldn't clear him, Albie Morkel times his jump to perfection and Australia are pegged back again Parnell to Hopes, OUT good length on middle and leg but moved a hint away from the batsman, Hopes tried to clip that over the in-field on the leg side, was into the shot a little too early, lobbed off the outside-half of the bat in the direction of backward point where Gibbs took a dolly Three successive wins have handed South Africa the series here. Australia were in the hunt with the kind of start they got from Clarke and Haddin, who added 129. But three wickets in fairly quick succession, all to spinners turned the tide in favour of South Africa. van der Merwe was the star for them with the ball, taking three Player of the match is Herschelle Gibbs, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 317 for 6 (Gibbs 110, de Villiers 84) beat Australia 256 (Haddin 78, Ponting 53, Clarke 50, Steyn 4-44, van der Merwe 3-46) by 61 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Herschelle Gibbs made his 21st ODI century Associated Press South Africa began the series as the world's No. 1 ODI side and they will finish it in the same position after Herschelle Gibbs' 21st one-day international century helped them to an unassailable 3-1 series lead in Port Elizabeth. Gibbs's near-even time innings of 110 repaid the faith placed in him by South Africa after a stint in rehab late last year, propelling them to a commanding 317 for 6. Australia, who again battled against the spin of Roelof van der Merwe, were seldom in the hunt. The 61-run victory ensured Graeme Smith's men the honour of becoming the first team to triumph in three successive bilateral ODI series against Australia - a streak that dates back to their historic victory in the 438 match in Johannesburg three years ago.

Commentary_Highlights: Geeves to de Villiers, 1 leg bye beaten by the slower one. It bounces in , AB goes for his signature short-arm pull ,misses and it goes off his thigh pad, bounces before Haddin who fumbles Geeves to Kallis, OUT Kallis falls after a fine innings. It was banged in short outside off stump, Kallis goes for the pull but hits it straight to midwicket! Johnson to de Villiers, OUT It was a length delivery on the middle and leg and it stops on AB who checks his across-the-line waft but gets a leading edge - a simple dolly- to mid-off. Fine innings from AB, who paced this one really well. Geeves to Morkel, 1 wide bangs in a high bouncer. Wide called and the crowd roar Geeves to Duminy, SIX runs similar delivery, Duminy clears the front foot, lunges out to bottom-hand it high over square leg. He got the timing right, there. Johnson to Duminy, OUT moves outside leg stump and flays a short-of-length delivery but crashes it straight to cover! Mitchell roars. Duminy falls after a 26-ball 32 Johnson to Morkel, 1 leg bye full in length, outside leg stump, tries to swing it to the on side and it rolls away off the pad to the off side Bracken to Morkel, 1 wide wide outside off stump this time and Rudi extends his arms Hopes to Boucher, SIX runs He has killed it. Brutal. It was full delivery outside off and Boucher hammers it over long-on. The crowd go mad. Johnson to Morkel, OUT backs away, Johnson round-arms a full delivery on the off stump line, Albie tries to swing to the cowcorner but misses. Timber! van der Merwe to Clarke, 1 leg bye drifts in from round the stumps, tries to flick it away but will pick up a leg bye van der Merwe to Hussey, OUT Rudi misses the big inside edge and Mike Hussey storms off towards the pavilion. It turned in quickly from outside off stump, Hussey pressed back and stabbed it off the inner edge to his pad. Rudi fails to see it and gives him the slow death. Clearly very unlucky. Botha to Johnson, SIX runs Mitch waltzes down the track and lifts it high over long-off for a six. He has been left with too much to do here, though. Botha to Johnson, 5 wide slips in well down the leg side and Boucher can't get across in time Morkel to Geeves, 1 leg bye shout for lbw but the point of impact was outside off stump. He leaned forward to drive through the on side and the yorker hit his boot just outside off Parnell to Geeves, 1 leg bye tries to swing it to the on side and it rolls away off the pad The players shake hands with each other and walk off. The crowd slowly start to clear away. Australia got off to a slow start in the chase with their openers Haddin and Clarke suffocated by some tight bowling from Steyn and Parnell. Then the spinners took over on this dry track and Australia lost their way further. Fergus Player of the match is Jacques Kallis, SA
Match_Report: South Africa 289 for 6 (de Villiers 80, Kallis 70, Johnson 4-34) beat Australia 264 for 7 (Ferguson 63, Hopes 63*) by 25 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Callum Ferguson tried to retrieve a lost cause but the pressure had already told on Australia Associated Press "We need to break the hoodoo," was how Graeme Smith went into this match with both teams 1-1 in the five-game series. After losing every toss against Ricky Ponting over the summer, Smith finally won one and South Africa piled up 289 on a track that wasn't always conducive to batting. Then the bowlers and fielders struck early in the piece and despite a spirited rear-guard effort took a one-game lead. Even a floodlight failure couldn't dim South Africa. Two days ago Ponting blamed himself for Australia's batting predicament, saying it was about time he scored another century.

Commentary_Highlights: Hello and welcome to Cricinfo's coverage of the second ODI between Australia and South Africa being played in Centurion. The news is that Australia have won the toss and opted to bat. The pitch looks dry and the sun is beating down hard, so we may well be in store for a high-scoring match. Australia have retained the same side. Steyn to Haddin, OUT timber! South Africa have struck early. Short and wide, gets on the back foot to punch it through the covers, gets a big inside edge bang onto the leg stump Steyn to Ponting, SIX runs what a way to start! It's in his zone though, banged in short on middle, gets gets back and pulls it away powerfully, it lands on the full on the deep square-leg boundary Parnell to Ponting, OUT excellent start from South Africa! Parnell got this to land on a good length outside off and it moved away after pitching, bowled at 138.1 kmph, Ponting attempted a drive on the up, got a thick edge and Boucher dived well to his right, stretching to pouch a sharp chance Parnell to Clarke, OUT Parnell is on a roll! Swinging into the right hander, full on middle, gets his front foot across to flick it away through the midwicket region, misses and is struck dead in front of middle and leg Steyn to Hussey, 1 wide they've been a little generous on the wides today, landed outside off and moved away beyond the white indicator Steyn to Hussey, OUT Australia are reeling here! Poor shot from David Hussey, good length outside off and the customary away movement, he stays rooted in his crease and without any foot-movement tries to force it through the off side, gets a faint nick and Boucher does the rest Parnell to Hussey, OUT the late movement does him in! It's Parnell's day! Full on leg stump and moved away really late, Hussey was already into the attempted push back towards the bowler, missed it as the ball left him and was struck plumb in front of middle Kallis to Ferguson, 1 wide down the leg side, false start, given a wide Kallis to Hopes, OUT what say now? Fraction short outside off, is on the back foot to force it through point, gets a thick edge and Johan Botha takes a dolly at first slip Botha to Johnson, SIX runs struck cleanly, tossed up on middle, comes down the track and deposits it into the stands over long-on Steyn to Ferguson, OUT superb catch, a fierce delivery bowled on a good length on the off stump, jumped off the pitch to catch Ferguson on the gloves as he tried to back away, de Villiers, sensing the opportunity, charged forward from point, dived full length and snapped it inches from the ground Steyn to Hauritz, OUT edged and gone! Four each for Parnell and Steyn! Full outside off and gets the late movement again, much closer to the off stump this time, Hauritz goes for the drive, gets a thin edge and Boucher takes a sitter Johnson to Kallis, 1 wide down the leg side, tries to help it on its way to the fine-leg boundary, misses, gets a wide Laughlin to de Villiers, 1 wide short of a length outside off and moving away, reaches for it to play a cut but misses Hauritz to Duminy, 1 leg bye tossed up outside leg, comes down the track to push it wide of midwicket, gets a leg bye on the off side A clinical win for South Africa who've returned the favour after that massive defeat in Durban. Parnell and Steyn did it for them, and their batsmen saw off the target with little difficulty. The series is now level 1-1, and we move to Cape Town for the third ODI on April 9. Do stay tuned in, we'll get you the presentation details very soon South Africa won by 7 wickets (with 142 balls remaining) Player of the match is Wayne Parnell, SA
Match_Report: Ricky Ponting called Australia's performance in the heavy loss to South Africa the worst in a long time, but has vowed to improve for the third game in Cape Town on Thursday. The tourists were dismissed for 131 in 40.2 overs after starting the match by dropping to 5 for 19. South Africa passed the target for the loss of three wickets and levelled the five-fixture contest that will determine the game's No. 1 side.

Commentary_Highlights: Morkel to Haddin, SIX runs not the best ball to bowl on a free-hit, length on middle stump, Haddin backs away and hammers that towards the sightscreen to bring up the first six of the match Morkel to Haddin, 1 wide wide down the leg side this time from Albie Morkel to Haddin, 1 wide attempts a split-finger slower ball, drags it down the leg side, that's a wide Botha to Haddin, 1 wide down the leg side, and that's a wide Duminy to Ferguson, 1 wide wide down the leg side Steyn to Ferguson, OUT Steyn strikes, short and pretty wide, Ferguson slashes at it, gets a top edge which flies to Johan Botha at third man, Botha back pedals a few steps to complete that catch, making sure that he doesn't cross the boundary Steyn to Hussey, 1 wide another bounce from Steyn, Hussey ducks under it, it was down the leg side and the umpire deems it a wide Morkel to Hopes, OUT Hopes is gone, he saw that the fine leg was up, so he walked across the stumps to pick up a middle stump ball and tried to chip it over fine leg, it looked pretty flamboyant but he didn't get enough on it, and Dale Steyn takes a simple catch to end Steyn to Johnson, 1 wide inches away from the legstump, but that's wide enough to be an illegal delivery Steyn to Johnson, OUT full ball from Steyn, not much footwork from Johnson as he tried to smear it through the offside, gets a faint edge through to the keeper, big appeal from Boucher, Johnson doesn't wait for the umpire's decision and decides to walk Ntini to Hussey, SIX runs he needn't have bothered, that was a massive six, it was a short of length ball, pitching middle and angling away, Hussey gets on the front foot and gets under that one, absolutely hammered over long-on, even bigger than the previous six Johnson to Amla, 1 wide whoah, that was very wide outside off Hopes to Gibbs, OUT Gibbs falls, not exactly the best of deliveries, short if a length and outside off, Gibbs throws his bat at that, hits it very well but Michael Clarke at point takes a good diving catch, that's the breakthrough Australia needed Johnson to de Villiers, OUT de Villiers goes lbw, Asoka de Silva rules de Villiers out, there was a big inside edge on that one, it was a back of a length delivery, hit his pads in front of middle but there was bat involved before the ball hit pads, de Villiers can't b Hauritz to Smith, OUT Smith falls, big wicket for Australia, Hauritz hasn't been afraid to toss the ball up and he gets his reward, Smith was looking to play to the on side, gets a leading edge which results in a simple caught and bowled Hopes to Duminy, 1 leg bye on the pads this time, Duminy tips it to the leg side and the batsmen steal a single Hopes to Botha, 1 wide bouncer down the leg side, Botha goes for the pull but misses Johnson to Botha, OUT ripping short delivery gets Botha! Johnson steams in and bangs in a brute of a short one that fairly kicks up off the track and though an airborne Botha rears his head out of harm's way he cannot drop the hands in time and the ball kisses his glov Laughlin to Steyn, OUT starts off yet another of his overs with a slower ball, full ball and pretty wide, Steyn was onto his shot early, checks and can only spoon it to Michael Hussey at short cover, that's Laughlin's first wicket in ODIs Ponting also says the wickets was slower than he expected, and is full of praise for Hauritz. Australia had also struggled initially when they batted but they managed to string together a bunch of partnerships, something South Africa were unable to do. Australia bowled well but a number of South African wickets were soft dismissals In hindsight, Boucher at No. 6 seems South Africa have received an absolute hiding here, the introduction of Nathan Hauritz completely transformed the game. None of the batsmen were really comfortable against him, who was unafraid to toss the ball up and got the rewards. James Hopes also did a sterling support j Player of the match is Michael Hussey, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 286 for 7 (Michael Hussey 83*, Haddin 53) beat South Africa 145 (Smith 52, Hauritz 4-29) by 141 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Nathan Hauritz and Michael Hussey: architects of a crushing Australian victory AFP Australia bossed South Africa in game one of the five-match contest, putting up an imposing score and then strangling wickets at regular intervals to win by 141 runs and reclaim, at least temporarily, the No. 1 one-day ranking. An assured half-century from Michael Hussey propelled Australia after a shaky start and then the bowlers performed as a tight unit to demolish South Africa's batting. Leading the rout in the field was Nathan Hauritz, with career-best figures in a testing spell of off spin. South Africa's chase was dented early.

Commentary_Highlights: Hello and welcome to Cricinfo's coverage of the Twenty20 game between Pakistan and Australia being played in Dubai. The news from the middle is that Pakistan have won the toss and opted to field. Younis Khan will not be playing, and Misbah-ul-Haq will step in as captain. Australia have included Brett Lee - Shoaib Akhtar to Haddin, 1 leg bye angling into the pads, pretty quick, 141.2 kmph, tried to clip it fine, was struck on the pads Umar Gul to Watson, OUT looked out but did he get an inside edge? Full on middle and leg, tried to force it through the leg side, is hit on the pads but replays showed he nicked it Afridi to Hopes, OUT wicket first ball, no doubt about this one, went on straight, Hopes went for the slog-sweep, missed, and was struck in line with leg stump on the back leg Afridi to Symonds, OUT gone first ball and he's on a hatrick! Straighter one again, holding its line, bowled on middle, he's half-forward and just dabs at it playing for the spin, misses and is struck dead in front of middle Malik to Hussey, 1 leg bye turned away awkwardly into the leg side behind square, brushed his pads Afridi to Hussey, OUT chopped it on!! Pakistan are on top, gave it some air, landed short, drifted into the batsman, went for the cut, got an inside edge straight onto the stumps, Afridi has three! Malik to Haddin, OUT Five down, slightly quicker through the air, bowled on middle, charged down the track to clear long-off, the bat turned in his hand as he went for it and ended miscuing it straight to Gul at long-on Malik to Ferguson, OUT missed a straight one, expected it to spin in and pushed at it hard, beat the outside edge but Akmal was quick with his hands, taking off the bails with Ferguson's foot still in the air Malik to Hauritz, 1 leg bye spun in sharply to catch him on the pads but he was outside the line, end of another successful over Umar Gul to North, OUT timber!! Straight on middle, had some movement on it as well, North was into the shot a little too early as he tried to hoick that over midwicket, missed, and the stumps were pegged back Ajmal to Hilfenhaus, OUT stopped on him a little, tried to turn it away into the leg side, mistimed it to lob it straight to Afridi on the circle at midwicket Australia have collapsed, squandering an excellent start provided to them by Watson. Ten wickets fell for 66, and like in the early part of the ODI series, the Australian batsmen were virtually clueless against spin, especially Afridi. Gul came back to wrap up the innings, dismissing North, Lee and Hauritz Bracken to Shehzad, 1 wide too wide, chased it but it kept leaving him, another wide Hopes to Kamran, SIX runs banged in short on the off, pulled it away powerfully over long-on, went off the middle and though for a while it seemed he hadn't struck it well enough, it cleared the ropes quite comfortably in the end A one-sided affair in the end, though it didn't look to be going that way when Watson was going strong in the Australian innings. But the spin of Afridi, and the accuracy of Gul saw to it that the Australians were kept down to a paltry score. Butt started well, but when both openers fell in fairly quick su Pakistan won by 7 wickets (with 22 balls remaining) Player of the match is Shahid Afridi, PAK
Match_Report: Brett Lee showed some speed during his return from injury in one of the few good signs from Australia during a heavy Twenty20 loss to Pakistan. Brad Haddin, the stand-in captain, felt his side was already on the plane home following the tough one-day series, and they were dismissed for 108 before going down by seven wickets. However, Haddin was pleased with the effort of Lee, who had figures of 1 for 22 from four overs in a promising start following five months out with foot and ankle problems. "It was good to see the return of Brett Lee and if tonight's any indication of how he's going to go it looks like he is going to come back with some pretty good pace," Haddin told AAP after the match. Lee's first ball was recorded at 149kph and gained an edge from Salman Butt, but it went for four when Marcus North couldn't hold the catch in the cordon.

Commentary_Highlights: Toss and teams: Australia have won the toss and they will bat first. They have made two changes - Nathan Bracken and Stuart Clark go out. The two Bens - Hilfenhaus and Laughlin - come in. Shoaib Akhtar to Haddin, 1 wide that's a poor delivery, really wide outside the leg stump and Akmal has an early workout Umar Gul to Watson, SIX runs that was worth driving miles to see! Gul pitches it up and it's a forward defensive scoop which sends it over wide long-off, excellent timing and a really good follow through Shoaib Akhtar to Haddin, OUT Sharp catch by the captain! Haddin makes room to a full ball and tries to scoop it over mid-off, the ball makes contact with the bottom half of the bat and travels quickly to Younis at short mid-off who leaps and takes the catch over his head Arafat to Watson, (no ball) he oversteps, Watson mistimes the pull to Afridi at midwicket Umar Gul to Clarke, OUT Gul finally gets a reward, he lands it on a good length on the corridor outside the offstump and Clarke gets a very thin leading edge as he shapes to clip it to the on side, Gul beat the bat on a few occasions in his first spell so it was a matter of tim Malik to Symonds, 1 wide tries to paddle it past the keeper but it was too wide Malik to Symonds, OUT tossed up outside off, it's a conventional offspinner and Symonds is a little lazy on the cut and he ends up chopping it onto the base of the offstump Afridi to Watson, 1 leg bye flighted on middle and leg, he clips it to the on side Malik to Ferguson, 1 wide loses his line and strays wide down the leg side Arafat to Ferguson, 1 wide strays too wide down the leg side, poor delivery Ajmal to Watson, 1 wide strays down the leg side Shoaib Akhtar to Watson, 1 wide strays too wide outside off, Watson tries in vain to get some bat on ball Bollinger to Shehzad, 1 wide strays down the leg side and wide called, Haddin does well to cover the movement Hauritz to Shehzad, 1 leg bye angled on the pads and he clips it towards short fine leg Laughlin to Younis, 1 leg bye shuffles across and he fails to get bat on ball for a yorker, the ball clips his pads and rolls away, the bowler appeals but the ball was missing leg Hauritz to Shehzad, OUT Hauritz really deserved it! The ball turns very sharply off the rough and Shehzad shapes to cut but the turn foxes him, the ball clips the top flap of his pad bang in front of the stumps, Aleem Dar is convinced, easy decision Sorry for the confusion over the scoring. It's been sorted. Pakistan won by 7 wickets (with 18 balls remaining) Player of the match is Kamran Akmal, PAK
Match_Report: Pakistan 254 for 3 (Akmal 116*, Misbah 76*) beat Australia 250 for 4 (Watson 116*, Ferguson 41*) by seven wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Kamran Akmal stroked 13 fours during his 115-ball innings Associated Press A scintillating century from Kamran Akmal helped guide Pakistan to book-ending victories in the five-match ODI series against Australia. Akmal's knock off 115 balls, his fifth ODI century, meant he top scored in both of Pakistan's successful run-chases this series and begged the question as to why he had not batted in the top four throughout. Akmal combined superbly with Misbah-ul-Haq to reel in Australia's total, the highest run-chase of this tough series, after being thrust together with Pakistan in trouble at 56 for 3. Their unbroken stand of 198 was an ODI record for the fourth wicket against Australia. Misbah was the ideal foil for Akmal, who was ignited by Misbah's energetic running, and the pair complimented each other perfectly to frustrate the Australian bowlers.

Commentary_Highlights: Hauritz to Shehzad, 1 leg bye on middle and off, tries to paddle it fine, didn't connect, lobbed up off his pads Clarke to Misbah, OUT plumb, tossed up on middle, went for the sweep after three dot balls, tried to get it behind square, it straightened, he missed and was struck on the back pad in line with the stumps. Bowden raised his finger immediately Hauritz to Shehzad, OUT his patience was tested and finally, when offered some flight, failed to resist the temptation. Landed full on the off stump, went for a mighty slog-sweep over midwicket, it spun in, took the top-edge and stuck safely in the palms of Ferguson at long-on Bollinger to Malik, OUT looked plumb, nipped back in from the off, he got forward to defend but was struck just in line, didn't get across enough and played with bat really close to pad Clark to Kamran, OUT kept low and pegged back the offstump, short of a good length bowled at 132 kmph, failed to get his bat down in time and timber! Bollinger to Afridi, OUT gone! Big wicket! Short on middle, gets more bounce and is pacy, bowled at 135 kmph, goes for a mighty pull, gets the top edge as it comes on a little too quickly and North takes an easy catch at mid-on Bollinger to Arafat, 1 leg bye short outside leg stump and cut back in, tried to shuffle and work it behind square, was struck on the pads and high Bracken to Tanvir, OUT gone this time! Identical shot, gets the top edge again but is unfortunate it's not Watson under it again, got it much straighter and Hauritz at mid-on shows his team-mate how it's done Bollinger to Ajmal, OUT Bollinger gets five!! The legcutter, bowled at around 135 kmph, landed on a good length on middle and cut away to beat the bat and clip off stump Bolly leads the team off the field, after taking a five-for in just his second ODI. Australia have the clear edge, and Pakistan, who had got themselves into a decent position at 116 for 3, lost their last seven wickets for 81. Malik to Clarke, 1 leg bye quicker ball bowled flat on middle and leg, tries to turn it away, brushes the pads and they get a leg bye Doug Bollinger is the Man of the Match for his five-wicket haul. A thumping in the end. 197 on this pitch, one felt, was still competitive but it took a lot of grit and concentration from both these batsmen to pull it off quite comfortably in the end. Australia won by 8 wickets (with 34 balls remaining) Player of the match is Doug Bollinger, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 200 for 2 (Clarke 100*, Watson 85*) beat Pakistan 197 (Ahmed Shehzad 43, Shahid Afridi 40, Bollinger 5-35) by eight wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details How they were out Doug Bollinger's five wickets set up Australia's series win, and earned him the Man-of-the-Match award Associated Press Stand-in Australian captain Michael Clarke produced a superb century to seal the five-match series with a game to spare after an eight-wicket win in Abu Dhabi. An unbeaten hundred, his fourth in one-day cricket and first as captain, was arguably his finest and was the key to Australia's comfortable pursuit of Pakistan's 197. Clarke and Shane Watson combined for a record-breaking 197-run partnership to lift Australia from its knees after Shoaib Akhtar wound back the clock with two early wickets in a blistering opening spell. Shoaib, on return after being left out of game three, claimed Brad Haddin and debutant Marcus North to leave Australia reeling at 3 for 2. But Clarke and Watson negotiated the rest of Shoaib's sharp four-over opening spell before flourishing under the floodlights.

Commentary_Highlights: Angelo Mathews to Warner, OUT got him! Slightly shorter by Matthews and Warner cuts and slaps it straight into the hands of point! Malinga to Ponting, 2 wide a full bunger down the leg side Mendis to Ponting, OUT bowled him! Ponting stepped outside leg trying to smite him over cover but loses his leg stump. Looked to me like a leggie from Mendis Mendis to Watson, OUT gone! Watson attempts a horrible sweep to this very full and straight delivery, and he's hit on the back pad. Poor stroke - quality bowling Malinga to Haddin, OUT bowled him! Comical cricket. A slower full-toss which Haddin seemed to pick, but it dipped late on him and splattered his stumps - the off stump and middle stump both flattened Udana to Clarke, OUT another one done by a slower delivery. Are you watching, England? Superb delivery on middle-and-leg which Clarke picked, but got a leading edge back to the bowler who took a great low catch with his left hand Udana to Hussey, 1 wide another very slow ball but it's too wide this time to the left-hander Mendis to Hussey, OUT what bowling. What belief and guile from Mendis. A quicker and fuller ball to Hussey who's rapped absolutely dead in front. Too quick, too straight Murali to Johnson, SIX runs sheesh, that is huge. A massive slog sweep - the noise of bat on ball was sweet as a nut! The timing perfect Udana to Hussey, OUT tries to repeat the shot but slices it high and point swallows it with ease Udana to Lee, SIX runs nailed it! Absolutely creamed this full toss over wide long-on. Huge, ugly power and great to watch Malinga to Lee, OUT what a yorker. Oh well bowled! Very, very fast and hit the base of the leg stump which is sent cartwheeling Malinga to Hauritz, OUT outside edge, another one for Malinga - well caught by Sangakkara low to his right Lee to Jayasuriya, OUT what a catch from Warner at deep square leg! Jayasuriya pulled this hard and flat, and Warner jumped up high to take it behind him, not two feet from the boundary edge. Oh yes! Johnson to Dilshan, 1 wide well wide of the off stump Johnson to Mubarak, 1 wide and Australia are out of the ICC World Twenty20 with a wide down the leg side Sri Lanka won by 6 wickets (with 6 balls remaining) Player of the match is Kumar Sangakkara, SL
