It's not happening for Pakistan today Malik to Warner, SIX runs leans back, hauls a freebie pull high over long-on! It plops over the rope, into and out of the hands of a Pakistani spectator ... standards are low either side of the rope today ... Shaheen Shah Afridi to Maxwell, OUT Bowled him! 141kph, full and straight and through the gaping gate! That's why you need pace to Maxwell. His feet were anchored, he was hanging back but exposing middle and off, he played outside the line, it went straight through the wide gate between bat and pad and crashed into the stumps! Shaheen Shah Afridi to Warner, OUT caught at deep point! Imam holds on finally! This was fuller outside off, Warner tried to launch it down the ground, he sliced it high off a thick outside edge, it flew very high to deep point, Imam came in off the rope and takes the catch clutching it to his chest Shaheen Shah Afridi to Marsh, 1 leg bye 141kph, angled into leg, it takes him on the pad and rolls behind square for a leg bye Hasan Ali to Khawaja, 1 wide 132kph, pushed way wide of off, too wide for Khawaja to reach Amir to Marsh, OUT caught at long off by Shoaib! Amir again! Cross seam delivery, length on off, he tried to launch it over long on, he got under it as it stopped in the surface a touch, he skied it to long on, Shoaib is in from the rope and takes a comfortable catch Amir to Khawaja, OUT caught at mid off! It was a full length, it just stops in the surface a touch, he drives in the air straight to Wahab on the circle at mid off and he clutches onto it awkwardly! He held it and that's all that matters Wahab Riaz to Coulter-Nile, OUT caught behind off the inside edge! Good catch by Sarfaraz low to his left. It was full outside off, Coulter-Nile had it feet anchored and played for more tail across, it held it's line, caught the inside edge, just missed off stump but Sarfaraz was sharp moving low to his left to claim it Hasan Ali to Cummins, OUT caught behind! 134kph but this rears off a length and catches the gloves on the way through to the keeper! Good short ball, Cummins was surprised, tried to lean back and cut but the bounce and pace was too much, it comes off the gloves and an easy catch for the skipper Amir to Carey, OUT LBW! Superb yorker! Carey reviews. It was full and tailed into the front shoe, he got it out of the way but it hit the back pad infront of leg. No bat involved by the looks. Nothing on ultra edge. Ball tracking says ... OUT. Pitched in line, hitting in line, smashing leg stump! Good decision. Even better bowling. Readers in India, while you wait for Pakistan to come out to bat, fancy having a look at that Warner innings once again? Here are the highlights, on Hotstar. 2.06pm Innings break Australia bowled out with six balls to go for 307 after they were 2 for 223 with 16 overs to go. Amir was outstanding. He pegged Australia back single handedly after David Warner's outstanding century. Coulter-Nile to Babar Azam, OUT short, and slapped straight to Richardson on the fence! That's a body blow! Babar's drives alone were going to win this game at a canter. But he's lured into a response to the bouncer, and doesn't come close to getting his wrists over the ball. Dragged down from way over his head like an amateur fly-fisherman, and backward square is in business again Kane Richardson to Imam-ul-Haq, 1 wide 130kph, angled well down the leg side and called wide Starc to Imam-ul-Haq, 1 wide 147kph, but slanting down the leg side and called wide Coulter-Nile to Hafeez, 1 wide 127kph, short and swinging too wide of off and rightly called Coulter-Nile to Wahab Riaz, SIX runs six more, heaved over cow corner! Sweetly struck, Pakistan getting a moooooooove on now! Starc to Wahab Riaz, OUT beats the bat, Wahab poking at it off the back foot, Carey and Starc like it! Not given by umpire Palliyaguruge, but Australia review with one second left on the countdown! Fencing off the back foot, well away from the body, if there was a sound it must have been bat... and there's a line on Ultra Edge! That's the breakthrough, Starc prises one out! Huge relief for Finch, who Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 307 (Warner 107, Finch 82, Amir 5-30) beat Pakistan 266 (Imam 53, Cummins 3-33) by 41 runs Watch on Hotstar (India only) - Match highlights A wild, seesawing game that always seemed just a little too far out of Pakistan's reach proved to be just that at the end, with Australia wrapping up a 41-run victory that was far nervier than the scorecard suggested. It came about thanks to a century from David Warner at the top end, coupled with generosity to the point of self-sacrifice from Pakistan both with the ball and in the field. Australia were so far on top in the first half of the first innings, talk of 350 and 400 rolled easily off the tongue, until a vintage performance from Mohammad Amir curtailed them to 307, his five-for bowling out a side that hadn't lost a single wicket for 22 overs. Pakistan, in response, oscillated between dismal and distinguished. Babar Azam looked princely for a knock that lasted all of 28 deliveries, before an 80-run partnership between Imam-ul-Haq and Mohammad Hafeez looked to have put Pakistan on top.

Commentary_Highlights: Starc to S Dhawan, 1 leg bye very full and darting into the pads, Starc cranks up to 144ks, but no swing for him yet. Tucked away towards square leg off the back foot Starc to S Dhawan, 1 leg bye full, on middle and angling into his pads. Tries to give this a whip over the leg side, but the ball hits his pads instead Coulter-Nile to Rohit Sharma, OUT first wicket! Length ball outside off, rising off the deck, and Rohit tries fishing for it. Takes the outside edge, and Carey moves swiftly to his left right to half-dive and complete the catch Cummins to Kohli, 1 wide length ball, on middle, and angling down leg. Virat is furious at himself for missing out on a pull Stoinis to S Dhawan, 1 wide bouncer, sails over the head, as Dhawan sways out of the way. Wide called Starc to S Dhawan, OUT Starc misses his yorker again, goes too full on middle and leg. Dhawan ventures an almighty hoick, gets more height as opposed to distance - these are bigger boundaries anyway - and holes out to deep midwicket. End of an excellent innings nevertheless. It has put India on top Cummins to Hardik, SIX runs straight over the non-striker! Full, on off, and he offers his bat's full face to earn another six. Wasn't a bad ball at all Cummins to Hardik, 1 wide full and wide outside off stump. And going further away Cummins to Hardik, OUT low full toss, outside off stump ,and he slices this to cover. Excellent pinch-hitting Starc to Kohli, SIX runs full outside off, and Kohli plays a stunning lofted drive over cover, and my oh my, this has gone over the boundary! Exquisite Stoinis to Dhoni, OUT catch of the tournament? Low full toss outside off, and Dhoni had flat-batted this straight, but Stoinis sticks his right-hand out to take a stunning reaction catch Stoinis to Rahul, SIX runs full toss on middle, and he swipes this off his hips over deep midwicket. What a ball to receive first up Stoinis to Kohli, 1 wide length ball, very wide outside off stump. Wide Stoinis to Kohli, OUT length ball, outside off stump, and Kohli tries to slap a cut over point. But it's not in the gap, and the person in the deep comfortably takes this catch Okay, Finch and Warner walk down the stairs and into the middle. The Indians, meanwhile, get into a huddle. Dhoni's gloves are in the spotlight. He will be wearing a new pair of gloves today without the dagger emblem. Bhuvneshwar has the new ball. Watch out Finch. But, it is Warner who'll take first strike. Let's go again Hardik to Finch, 1 wide lifter outside off, too high and that's a wide Bumrah to Warner, 1 leg bye Warner, standing on leg stump, shuffles across off stump and deflects a slower variation through square leg Jadhav to Smith, SIX runs tossed outside off, Smith dashes down the track, gets closer to the pitch, and launches it over midwicket Hardik to Khawaja, 1 bye back of a length, on leg stump, and he tries to pull but gets cramped up. Goes through to Dhoni. A proper short ball this Chahal to Maxwell, OUT Chahal gets rid of Maxwell (again). This was pushed through on middle, Maxwell dares to slog-sweep against the break. He is beaten in flight and does not get all of it. He splices a top edge. Jadeja tears in from deep midwicket and completes an excellent tumbling catch. He isn't in the XI today - but is making an impact as sub. 6.43pmSo, India secure their second successive victory this World Cup. It was set up by Dhawan who cracked 117 off 109 balls before mighty blows from Pandya, Kohli, Rahul and Dhoni propelled India past 350. Australia had a rather sluggish start; Warner laboured to his slowest ODI fifty. Fifty of Warner's 84 balls were dots. Smith made a more fluent fifty and Player of the match is Shikhar Dhawan, INDIA
Match_Report: India 352 for 5 (Dhawan 117, Kohli 82, Rohit 57, Hardik 48, Cummins 1-55) beat Australia 316 (Smith 69, Warner 56, Carey 55*, Bhuvneshwar 3-50) by 36 runs As it happened There was a masterclass in batting at The Oval. Shikhar Dhawan overcame a weakness to score 117. Steven Smith showed none as he made 69. Hardik Pandya was pure unfettered power. David Warner fought demons.

Commentary_Highlights: 10.00am Toss - West Indies won the toss and will bowl first. Thomas to Finch, OUT caught behind! Cracking delivery! Good length, angled in towards off stump, he's forced to defend half forward, it nipped off the seam, scratched the outside edge and a simple catch for Hope! What a beautiful piece of fast bowling! That first over is a distant memory now! Thomas to Khawaja, 1 wide 143kph, lifting delivery down leg, he went to glance and withdrew the bat, it's a wide but there's a plan Cottrell to Warner, 1 wide 141kph, bouncer outside off but too high and called wide Cottrell to Warner, OUT caught at backward point! He was hanging back a touch because of the bouncer, it was a length ball wide, he tried to square drive on the up, didn't get on top of the bounce and just bunted a catch to Hetmyer at backward point who is in quite close! Cottrell salutes! Thomas to Khawaja, 1 bye beaten by one that nips away off the seam, Hope fumbles the take and allows a bye Russell to Khawaja, OUT caught behind! A screamer from Hope! A one hander! The short barrage unsettled him. This was full angled across, he backed away to try and drive on the up, got a thick edge, Hope dived full length to his left in front of first and plucked it one handed! It would not have carried to Gayle at slip! Superb stuff from the Windies! Cottrell to Maxwell, OUT skied straight up! Caught by Hope! Maxwell out pulling second ball! This was another excellent bouncer, very high and well directed, he tried to pull and skied it straight up, Hope wanders underneath it and takes a simple catch! Another salute from Sheldon. Russell to Smith, 1 wide shorter length, 141kph, angled down leg and called wide Russell to Smith, 1 wide bouncer, too high and called wide Brathwaite to Smith, 1 wide angled way down the leg side and called wide Holder to Stoinis, OUT sucker ball snares a wicket for the captain! Holder bowled it a touch short on off stump angling into Stoinis. It sat up there for him waiting to be spanked but Stoinis neither rolls the wrists over it nor gets requisite elevation to clear Nicholas Pooran in the ring at midwicket. Straight to him at chest height. West Indies rollicking start with the ball continues. Thomas to Coulter-Nile, 1 wide 138kph, sprayed way down the leg side Thomas to Smith, OUT Cottrell with a screamer! No turf trolls eating him up this time at long leg! Fullish length on a fifth stump line. Smith shuffles across once more to flick this high over backward square, Cottrell made an absolute mess of a chance on 26 in an identical slot, this time sprints along the rope 20 yards moving left at full speed and stabs at it with his left hand, knifing it out of the air, then flicks it up before stepping over the rope before reclaiming it after reestablishing himself inside the field of Cottrell to Coulter-Nile, SIX runs dropped! Very harsh but it did ricochet off Brathwaite's hand at deep square leg and then hit the rope on the full for six. Shortish length on off stump, Coulter-Nile laces a scorching pull toward Brathwaite at deep square leg, just evades his grasp running to his left and sliding at the last moment. After the take that Cottrell just had in the previous over, the fans and teammate's must be wondering why Brathwaite couldn't match him! But it was 10/10 on the degree of difficulty scale. Cottrell to Coulter-Nile, SIX runs highest score now by a No. 8 in a World Cup! In the slot outside off, drives through the line 15 yards into the stands over long-on. Brathwaite to Cummins, OUT slower bouncer, Cummins struggles keeping his hands back going to pull, skies it to deep square leg, Cottrell settles under it 10 yards in from the rope. This was 3/10 on the difficulty scale compared to the absurd one-hander he took to dismiss Smith. Brathwaite to Coulter-Nile, OUT Coulter-Nile falls four short of breaking the record for a No. 8 in ODIs! It was in the slot outside off, he went for glory trying to clear Holder at wide long-off but got under it just a bit too much. The bat turned on connection too so wasn't timed as well as he wanted. In the air for awhile before coming down to the West Indies captain three yards inside the rope. Brathwaite to Starc, OUT Brathwaite rewarded for pitching it up again, in the slot on off, Starc tried to heave it over Holder at wide long-on but didn't get under it enough and the tallest man on the field has no issues claiming this one roving left a few yards inside the rope at chest height. In spite of that earlier misjudged chance by Cottrell, he made up for it later with this stunner to finally claim Smith at deep fine leg. Watch Sheldon Cottrell's sensational catch on the boundary. It came after Smith and Alex Carey initially led Australia's fightback to dig out of a major hole at 79 for 5. Watch how Smith and Carey put Australia back in the game (UK, IRE, AUS only). 2.18 pm Australia end an over short, but a brilliant fightback nonetheless led by Smith and Coulter-Nile. West Indies paid for some inconsistent fielding though. Smith arguably should have been caught at deep fine leg on 26 but Cottrell misjudged the chance and Coulter-Nile was also grassed on a much simpler effort by Hetmyer on 61 at deep midwicket. The wides were also costly too, releasing the pressure after West Indies had Australia under the pump. Can West Indies chase this down? See what our MatchDay studio panel has to say. Gayle and Lewis walk out to open the chase. Starc over the stumps to Gayle with two slips in place. West Indies were favorites on the UK high street oddsmakers from the fifth wicket through the majority of the rest of the innings, but that Coulter-Nile rearguard has put Australia at 4/5 at the start of this chase to defend 288, for people into that kind of thing.... Starc to Gayle, 1 wide short and wide outside off, too wide to play. Starc to Hope, 1 wide short and well down leg, Carey does well to save it from being five wides. Starc to Gayle, OUT stone dead this time around! Starc couldn't pierce Gayle with the yorker on the previous ball but this time around Gayle is late getting the bat down on an 86 mph delivery pitching very full and hitting him low on the shin in front of middle. After waiting 12 seconds while chatting with Hope, Gayle finally calls for the review.... Ball-tracking confirms it was clipping leg-stump on umpire's call. Three strikes (on DRS) and you're out! West Indies retain their review though. Cummins to Hope, 1 wide bouncer, wide called on height. Cummins to Hope, 1 wide bouncer again, another wide called. Stoinis to Pooran, SIX runs hooked fine off the top edge for six! This was a well directed bouncer, he hooked but got a top edge, fine leg is square and it carried all the way for six Zampa to Russell, SIX runs lift-off for Dre Russ! Floated full on off, Russell winds up and scorches this into the stands a good 20 rows back over long-on into the second tier. West Indies were in a series of winning positions in both innings but couldn't slam the door shut. The defending champions showed their mettle to keep fighting back before coming out on top. Along with the England v Pakistan match, this is right near the top of the heap in terms of the best contest of the tournament so far. Pleasure to have you join us for the ride. For Alex Malcolm, Ranjith and the rest of the scoring team, I'm Peter Della Penna. Make sure to come back tomorrow for live coverage of the showdown in Bristol between Player of the match is Nathan Coulter-Nile, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 288 (Coulter Nile 92, Smith 73, Brathwaite 3-67) beat West Indies 273 for 9 (Hope 68, Holder 51, Starc 5-46) by 15 runs As it happened Nottingham is where, for most of recent history, Australian teams have come to die. They fell narrowly short in a 2013 Test match, before being destroyed by the swinging ball on a crazed morning in 2015, then beaten to a pulp by England's batsmen in an ODI last year. Against West Indies they seemed destined for a similar fate, losing four early wickets as the ball pranced, swung and reared at helmets and throats. Somehow, though, Aaron Finch's men scrounged their way to a 10th consecutive ODI victory, something achieved through a combination of efforts that will please the coach Justin Langer no end. For all their top order woes, the Australians were resourceful in adversity.

Commentary_Highlights: Hosein to Philippe, OUT Philippe throws his wicket away after a solid start. It was a good ball from Hosein that needed to be respected with a simple forward defense but instead Philippe gets carried away backing away trying to cut and leaves his stumps very exposed. He mistimes the shot and drags on with a bottom edge. Joseph to Marsh, OUT big appeal for a catch down leg given not out! Looked like it came off the face of the bat or glove on the live shot. And Pollard goes for the review. Before they can even go to the third umpire, Marsh starts walking off, he knows he's hit it! Sharp take by Pooran diving down leg on this back of a length ball. Snicko shows it did indeed come off the open bat face. He was playing well away from his body so it could only have been an edge on the live camera shot down the pitch. Not sure what umpire Joel Wilson was looking at to think it could have come off the pad or thigh guard inst Joseph to McDermott, OUT edged, taken at slip! More reward for Joseph. Back of a length outside off, hint of away movement, McDermott playing well away from his body. A healthy edge and neatly grabbed at the lone slip. Reward for keeping the catch in Joseph to Carey, 1 wide pushed wide outside off to the left hander and called Holder to Turner, SIX runs back of the hand slower ball at 108 kph lands way too short on fifth stump, sits up there for Turner to clobber over wide long-on, over the rope and the fence as well 10 yards beyond. Walsh to Carey, OUT Walsh Jr gets a just reward for a disciplined spell! Flighted full on leg stump, tosses up to encourage a big heave with the spin over midwicket but the ball has been slow off the pitch all day and the lack of bounce coming onto the bat means Carey is through the shot a touch early and it beats the bat to clang into leg stump three-quarters of the way up. Walsh to Starc, OUT googly again lands short outside leg stump, another top edge pull against the spin as Starc tries to heave this over square leg but instead it climbs on him with a touch of extra bounce and swirls over backward square leg. Hosein jogs under it casually 10 yards inside the rope and clutches on reaching in front of his body at waist height. Walsh to Wade, OUT another googly. Another top edge! Another catch on the leg side rope! Walsh Jr pitches this one even shorter than the one he bowled to Starc a ball earlier, Wade rocks back very early but once more the pull shot against the turn does not come off the middle of the bat. It hangs in the air for some time toward Hetmyer coming in 15 yards off the rope at deep midwicket for a simple chest height catch. Walsh to Agar, 1 wide, OUT clever from Walsh Jr! Saw Agar charging and bowled this very wide outside the guidelines. Pooran was prepared for it and collected to get the bails off sharply. Wide called but they get the wicket. Maiden ODI five-for by Walsh Jr! He wasn't even in the named squad but thanks to his Player of the Series performance in the T20Is, he gets brought in and rewards Kieron Pollard's faith in him. Interesting stat on Hayden Walsh Jr. In 15 matches for USA in 50-over cricket during his career for them from 2018 to 2019, he never took more than two wickets in a match and finished with a total of nine wickets in his one-day career for them. His best was 2 for 24 against Oman at World Cricket League Division Three in November 2018. It shows how much his legspin has developed in the last 24 months where he has been utilized as a specialist bowler in the West Indies setup compared to when he was more of a batting allrounder playing for USA. 7.11 pm A half-century from stand-in captain Carey on his captaincy debut for Australia. But a lot of wasted starts otherwise on what was a two-paced pitch. Hard to score but also hard to get out. Walsh Jr though bowled very disciplined in his initial spell before finally getting the rewards at the death, taking a maiden ODI five-wicket haul with all five wickets all falling in his final three overs at the death. Still, this may be a bit difficult to chase down on a tricky and inconsistent wicket that has offered plenty of spin and turn for the slow bowlers too. Stay with us for the chase, which again will be Hetmyer out to open the batting with Shai Hope absent injured from this match due to an ankle injury. Evin Lewis opening as per usual. Starc has the new ball in hand. Slight delay as two golf carts drag a rope around the outfield to soak up some moisture. Hazlewood to Hetmyer, OUT another leading edge back to the bowler! West Indies batters still not adjusting to the sticky/two-paced nature of this wicket. Another full ball on leg stump, Hetmyer through his flick early and Hazlewood's eyes light up seeing this float back to his left at a very gentle pace. He changes his direction enough to get within arm's length to pluck this one-handed with his left hand at chest height. If Hazlewood had to he could have gone two-handed but it was coming back at a slow enough pace that he took the casual approach and clutched on with ease. Starc to Pooran, OUT full on middle and leg, Pooran late on a flick and is pinged on the pads. Huge lbw shout upheld. Pooran goes for the review but this is not going to be overturned. He was hit very full on middle and leg. Only a prayer on ball-tracking will take this past leg stump. Sure enough ball-tracking shows it was clipping leg stump. Umpire's call is what shows up on the screen. On-field call stands. He was falling across his stumps with his head unbalanced. Starc continues to be a menace in this spell by attacking that middle and leg stump line. Zampa to Pollard, SIX runs flights this googly full on fourth stump, Pollard slaughters this high and deep over wide long-on, this time clearing it all the way into the grandstand. He didn't middle it by any stretch but raw strength ensures it carries for maximum value. Agar to Joseph, 1 wide a bouncer, 134kph, ducks underneath and it's called wide on height Marsh to Pollard, 1 leg bye fuller, in at the pads, an appeal for lbw as Pollard misses his flick but that look comfortably leg side Marsh to Joseph, 1 wide full and down the leg side Marsh to Walsh, 1 wide short of a length down the leg side, the umpire ponders and then calls wide Australia move up to sole possession of third in the World Cup Super League table, having claimed 50 out of a possible 70 points from their seven matches so far. West Indies remain tied for seventh with New Zealand and Afghanistan on 30 points. However, Afghanistan and New Zealand have both taken three from three while West Indies have only won three of seven games in the Super League thus far. 10.08 pm So Hayden Walsh Jr's maiden ODI five-for winds up in vain as Mitchell Starc's new-ball bonanza, including a wicket off the first ball of the chase, ends in his eighth ODI five-for to demolish the West Indies top order at 27 for 6 and paves the way for a lopsided end result. Only captain Kieron Pollard's 56 off 57 balls spared the hosts from being bowled out for double-digits. Alex Carey wins on his Australia ODI captaincy debut standing in for Aaron Finch. Ten points scooped up by Australia in the World Cup Super League points table is a solid start after being dominated in the T20I series that prece Player of the match is Mitchell Starc, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 252 for 9 (Carey 67, Turner 49, Walsh Jr 5-39) beat West Indies 123 (Pollard 56, Starc 5-48, Hazlewood 3-11) by 133 runs (DLS method) Mitchell Starc took a five-wicket haul as he and Josh Hazlewood dismantled West Indies in the opening ODI to give Alex Carey, who had earlier played a key hand with the bat, a winning start as Australia's ODI captain. Carey, standing in for the injured Aaron Finch, had formed the backbone of Australia's innings with Ashton Turner in a fifth-wicket stand of 104 in 19 overs before Hayden Walsh Jr sparked a late collapse with a career-best five-wicket haul. However, Australia's 252 - which was adjusted to a target of 257 after three rain interruptions cut the match to 49 overs - quickly looked imposing as Starc and Hazlewood got to work with the new ball to leave West Indies in a heap at 27 for 6. Starc took three wickets in his first spell and then returned to end the aggressive rearguard of Kieron Pollard. Pollard hit a 41-ball fifty, but the West Indies captain had been left with far too much ground to regain.

Commentary_Highlights: 5.40pm Toss Sri Lanka has won the toss and will bat first. Kane Richardson to Mendis, 1 wide 133kph, shaping way down the leg side and called wide Stanlake to Gunathilaka, OUT Bowled him! Just knocked off the off bail! This was a good length, Gunathilaka backed away and tried swing this down the ground, he missed completely and it just knocked the bail off the stumps. Stanlake to Perera, 1 leg bye 143kph, shorter length into the hip, it comes off the thigh guard to short fine Stanlake to Shanaka, OUT big appeal for catch behind and a late signal from the umpire. Shanaka is caught down the leg side and he isn't going to review. A steep short ball starting at a middle stump line and going down leg. He has a swish at it from underneath and can only manage to get the high part of this outside edge on it. Quick feet from Carey before he holds on comfortably Cummins to Udana, OUT top edge straight out to deep square. Full speed short ball this time, up at his throat. He's on the front foot and has a swat at it with no control. Richardson hangs on low in front Zampa to Malinga, OUT stumped next ball. Fuller and flatter and wider outside off. A slider, it appears. He steps out and gets too far leg side of it to make contact 7.59pm The players are out in the middle. Warner and Finch hoping to pick up where they left off in Adelaide. Udana to Smith, 1 wide 103kph, slower ball, dragged way down leg and called wide Pradeep to Warner, 1 wide short ball pushed across off stump. Lets that go Pradeep to Warner, 1 leg bye slower ball at a length on leg stump. Looks to flick and he's beaten. Caught right in front of the stumps on the back thigh and a big appeal...and then a late decision to review the not out call. Did that pitch in line? He's bowling from over the wicket...no, pitching outside leg. Decision stands 9:05pm Australia go up 2-0, which means they've sealed a series win with seven overs to spare. Nothing really improved for Sri Lanka today. The difference in quality was just as wide as it was in the first game. The decisions from their batsmen didn't improve, the bowling wasn't all that better and there were poor moments on the field as well. For Australia, a minor glitch - Finch caught down leg side 9:18pm And that is all from us tonight. See you again for the final T20I. Australia won by 9 wickets (with 42 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 118 for 1 (Warner 60*, Smith 53*) beat Sri Lanka 117 (Kusal Perera 27, Zampa 2-20, Stanlake 2-23) by nine wickets At least there were no unwanted records this time. At least the team total broke through to triple figures. And at least two batsmen made more than 20. Having been thumped by 134 runs on Sunday, these were the only minor improvements for Sri Lanka in the second T20I. Yet again, however, they were emphatically outplayed from the very beginning.

Commentary_Highlights: 1.30pm Sri Lanka have won the toss and will bowl first. Malinga to Warner, 1 wide Warner walks at him, it is slung down the leg side and called wide Rajitha to Finch, SIX runs launched over square leg! 50 for Finch in style! Fuller length on middle and he picks up the length and launches it over square leg into the stands Sandakan to Finch, OUT taken at deep midwicket and the mayhem is broken (for now, at least)! Looks to go over deep midwicket again, just gets too far underneath it this time, and had to reach a little, Mendis settles well under the catch Sandakan to Warner, 2 wide pushed down the leg side, Warner misses the sweep and it's a wide as well Hasaranga de Silva to Maxwell, SIX runs that's HUGE as Maxwell slog-sweeps with immense power over (well over) deep midwicket and into the second tier of the stands Shanaka to Maxwell, OUT given caught behind off an inside edge as he looks to flick away a full delivery and Maxwell has called the review. Yep, he's inside-edge this between his legs to the keeper! A very Maxwell way to get out, the end of a brilliant innings. Kane Richardson to Fernando, 1 wide too short and wide of off and rightly called Starc to Shanaka, 1 leg bye that hits him on the helmet, I think, as the bouncer his through him too quickly as he goes for the pull...yep, flush on the side of the lid Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 2 for 233 (Warner 100*, Finch 64, Maxwell 62) beat Sri Lanka 9 for 99 ( Shanaka 17, Zampa 3-14) by 134 runs A yawning victory for Australia, a pugilistic century for David Warner, Steven Smith not even required to bat? Do not adjust your browsers. Aaron Finch's team set down a brutal marker for the start of their 12-month run to next year's Twenty20 World Cup by swatting Sri Lanka aside with their highest-ever total on home soil and fourth highest overall, as the captain and a promoted Glenn Maxwell provided the perfect complement to Warner's triumphant return home after a nightmarish tour of England. Smith, the single biggest reason for Australia's Ashes retention, was listed to bat at No. 3 but found himself demoted below Maxwell and Ashton Turner in recognition of their relative hitting power. But on a day where the bowlers followed up by holding the decidedly underwhelming visitors for a mere 9 for 99, in the process securing the home side's biggest ever T20I winning margin and Sri Lanka's biggest ever T20I defeat, the lack of reliance upon Smith augured well for the rest of Australia's summer.

Commentary_Highlights: 4pm Toss Aaron Finch has won the toss and Australia will bowl first. Starc to Babar Azam, 1 wide 140kph, fired down the leg side and called wide Starc to Babar Azam, 1 wide swinging way down the leg side and rightly called wide again. Carey has to dive a long way Starc to Babar Azam, OUT Given out LBW. He's been given and Babar reviews. This was full and shaping into the pad late. There was a big appeal and it carried to slip. There's no bat involved. Nothing on hot spot. RTS appears to say pad only. Daylight between bat and ball. Ball tracking is a little slow. We have to wait 30 seconds for ball tracking. Ball tracking s Starc to Rizwan, OUT Bowled him! Searing 140kph inswinger! This was like a heat-seeking missile. Started on off, swung late through a gaping gate as he tried to drive away from his body. His pads were outside leg, his bat outside off, the ball swerved through and crashed into middle and leg Abbott to Imam-ul-Haq, OUT top edge caught at midwicket! Short ball banged in outside off, he tries to pull but goes from low to high with his hands, gets a top edge that flies straight up to midwicket, McDermott camps under it and takes the catch very easily. That was a poorly executed stroke Kane Richardson to Khushdil, OUT this won't help improve their mood! Khushdil cleared his front leg and looked to tonk this into the stands behind midwicket. It went so high the keeper thought he might catch it, but in the end Starc at fine leg got himself into position and snared a swirling one. Pakistan lose half their side. Abbott to Imad Wasim, OUT gone! What a catch! Agar can't put a foot wrong today. Not a surprise, in truth. Nothing had been working for Imad in the short time he' Kane Richardson to Iftikhar, OUT massive blow for Pakistan! Heaved down to fine leg from Iftikhar. He'd been struggling with the short ball for much of the innings, and Starc at fine leg was secure as ever. Richardson, who copped such heavy punishment from Iftikhar last game, get's his revenge Kane Richardson to Shadab, no run swing and a miss. Shadab one off six now. Needs to kick on badly Kane Richardson to Shadab, OUT the miserable innings comes to an end! Well, colour me surprised! Shadab had been struggling badly all eight balls he was there, and this time, he got a thick edge. Mid-on made a bit of a meal of it, but that's it for the allrounder Starc to Amir, 1 wide dragged down legside Stanlake to Haris Sohail, 1 wide 140kph, bouncer, down the leg side and called wide Agar to Haris Sohail, OUT caught at long off! That was brilliant from Agar. Haris jumped down early, Agar dragged the length down, Haris went through with the shot, mistimed it trying to launch over long off, he clothed it straight down Richardson's throat at long off. Easy catch 15 metres in off the rope Amir to Finch, 1 wide 135kph, good length, but swinging down the leg side again Amir to Warner, 1 wide 135kph, predictable bouncer and it's too high Mohammad Hasnain to Warner, 1 wide 145kph, angled down the leg side and called wide "It's pleasing one of our top three batted really deep throughout the two series, and we can only kick on from here." Australia won by 10 wickets (with 49 balls remaining) Player of the match is Sean Abbott, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 0 for 109 (Finch 52*, Warner 48*) beat Pakistan 8 for 106 (Iftikhar 45, Richardson 3-18, Abbott 2-14, Starc 2-29) by 10 wickets At the home of the Perth Scorchers, Australia disposed of Pakistan with a brutal efficiency reminiscent of the West Australian Big Bash League club as coached by Justin Langer, completing a run of five wins in six T20Is that was only interrupted by inconvenient Sydney rain and posed ominous signs for the opposition ahead of next year's World Cup. In front of a crowd of 22,626, a gleeful Aaron Finch sent the tourists in to bat on a lively Perth Stadium pitch, and Pakistan never recovered from the loss of three wickets inside their Powerplay. Mitchell Starc, Kane Richardson, the recalled Sean Abbott, Billy Stanlake and Ashton Agar covered for the rested Pat Cummins with ease, sharing wickets and responsibility for strangling the batting in an innings that featured no fewer than 26 plays and misses. Additionally, the Australians fielded and caught with rare polish, ensuring that very few Pakistani mistakes went unpunished. A final tally of 106 was about all that can be expected of Pakistan on days when Babar Azam does not bail them out with a score, as they have fallen into a deep T20I hole that had also seen them whitewashed at home by Sri Lanka prior to this one.

Commentary_Highlights: 6.40pm Pakistan won the toss and bat (after a little bit of confusion) and have named an unchanged XI Cummins to Zaman, OUT finds mid-off! So another failure for Zaman as he tries to get going. Stayed leg-side of a full delivery, sliced across the delivery, sends a pretty straightforward catch to Warner Kane Richardson to Haris Sohail, OUT he's done it again! Another ugly swipe sees the downfall of Sohail. Back of a length, he swings to the leg side, takes a big top edge and Richardson settles under the simple catch Agar to Rizwan, OUT done all ends up! He started to move outside leg very early, Agar fired it in towards leg stump, it spears between bat and pad. Simple stumping for Carey Agar to Asif Ali, OUT slog sweep straight down long on's throat! Easy catch for Cummins. Babar will be furious. He should have been on strike. It was darted in outside off, he was down on one knee and slog sweeps trying to find the rope, he miscued hitting it straight to long on. Kane Richardson to Iftikhar, SIX runs thumped over square leg into the crowd! Bang! Short slower ball and he picked it, it was in the hitting zone and he smoked it over deep square Kane Richardson to Iftikhar, SIX runs smacked over long off! What a shot! Full outside off, he's hanging back and hammering it through the line, clearing the man on the rope! Kane Richardson to Iftikhar, SIX runs crunch over wide long on! McDermott on the rope parries it over! Length ball in the slot, he clears the front leg and smears it high over long on to the long boundary, McDermott jumps up but can't reel it in Wahab Riaz to Smith, (no ball) fuller, at the stumps, tucked to the midwicket and, oh dear, it's a no-ball. Looked a very tight call Wahab Riaz to Smith, 1 wide sends down a very short slower-ball bouncer, Smith let's it go and gets the wide...the free hit carries over Imad Wasim to McDermott, OUT LBW! Misses sweeping. He reviews after consulting Smith. He was out LBW in Melbourne against Sri Lanka and didn't review when it was missing leg. Nothing on hot spot. Nothing on RTS. No bat involved. There is no ball tracking available for that ball! The decision remains out. The only query was whether it hit in line. Australia win by seven wickets with nine balls to spare. That was a clinic from Steve Smith. That's why he's in this team. Nervy chases when they lose early wickets are his bread and butter. He took control and picked Pakistan apart. He didn't get much help but he didn't need it. Pakistan lost this with the bat in reality as 150 was nowhere near enough. That's it from Canberra. Smith too good and Australia go 1-0 up. Both sides head to Perth for the final match of the series on Friday at Perth Stadium. On behalf of our team, hope you can join us then. Australia won by 7 wickets (with 9 balls remaining) Player of the match is Steven Smith, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 3 for 151 (Smith 80*) beat Pakistan 6 for 150 (Ahmed 52*, Azam 50) by seven wickets It didn't take long for Steven Smith to clamp down on any whispers he might be surplus to the requirements of the Australian T20I side. A commanding half-century that combined pugnacity and poise in exactly the right doses steered Australia to what ended up being a stroll of a chase against Pakistan with victory by seven wickets. It needn't have been as easy as that, though, and didn't look nearly as comfortable when they lost David Warner and Aaron Finch inside the powerplay, more than a hundred runs still to get without the comfort blanket of an explosive Glenn Maxwell in the middle order. It was an innings every bit as modern as T20 cricket requires of its players, but the 51-ball 80 Smith struck contained shots that wouldn't have been out of place at this year's Ashes. Eleven fours and a six, exactly a half-century of them, came in boundaries, and by the final two overs, Smith was properly peaking.

Commentary_Highlights: Starc to Dickwella, OUT gone first ball! Gets a big leading edge into the off side, loops high towards point for a simple catch. Tried to close the face, was early on the stroke but it looked a poor option in the first place as the ball was full outside off Kane Richardson to Mendis, OUT picks out the man at deep square! Couldn't have found him any better. A short ball from Richardson, Mendis strikes it nicely but straight down McDermott's throat. Mendis is furious. Richardson has his first wicket of the series Cummins to Fernando, OUT chipped straight to deep backward square! Short of a length and cramping him up at the hips again. He stays on the front foot and looks to use the angle and pace to launch this behind square. But that's taken well inside Agar to Perera, 1 leg bye appeal for lbw as he's caught on the front leg trying to sweep. Agar is around the wicket, that probably pitched outside leg Cummins to Perera, OUT taken at extra cover. Finally manages to find that fielder after many close shaves. Short of a length at off. Backs into the leg side and pulls. Slices it right up for the fielder, he barely has to move Starc to Jayasuriya, OUT loses leg stump. Full ball headed into leg stump, the same kind that was lifted for a six earlier. Jayasuriya though has looked for a reverse ramp, while standing on his feet. No way he's going to pull that off from there Kane Richardson to Malinga, SIX runs smokes it over long-on! Wow! Richardson looks for the slower ball but drops it short. It sits nicely up at off stump and Malinga just lines up beside it and flat-bats it Kane Richardson to Rajapaksa, 1 leg bye slower short ball into the body. Looks for the slog but cops that on the body 8:43pm Sri Lanka finally get to a serviceable score. They lost their openers in the Powerplay and hopes of an acceleration seemed as dim as the last two games. But that partnership for the third wicket allowed some stability, and Kusal Perera got going towards the end of his fifty. A flourish from Rajapaksa and Malinga too at the end. But Pradeep to Warner, 1 leg bye tight single as this bobbles out to the off side...111kph slower ball to start with, takes the pad Pradeep to Finch, 1 leg bye another huge appeal for lbw, this time it's Finch missing a swinging yorker but it's sliding down the leg side Pradeep to Warner, 1 wide short down the leg side, swing and a miss Jayasuriya to Finch, SIX runs round the wicket, stand and deliver from Finch as he hoicks this over wide midwicket Lahiru Kumara to Finch, SIX runs what a stroke! That's a cracker from Finch. A full ball on off stump, it's a perfect lofted off-drive through the line over the rope Pradeep to Warner, 1 wide bouncer dug in too short. Let's that go over middle stump Malinga to McDermott, OUT looks plumb. And given. It did strike him in front of leg though, so they'll have a chat about it...and decided not to review. Full and sliding in at leg stump as he looks to drive. Rapped on the front leg with middle and off visible. Perhaps not plumb like it appeared at first, but just clipping leg stump Jayasuriya to Turner, SIX runs pumps it over deep midwicket! Length ball pushed in fast at middle stump. It's sliding on nicely and he slogs through the line to clear the ropes Malinga to Warner, 1 wide bouncer at a middle stump line. Let's that go 10:48pm And that is all from us. Thanks for joining. Australia won by 7 wickets (with 14 balls remaining) Player of the match is David Warner, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 3 for 145 (Warner 57*) beat Sri Lanka 6 for 142 (Perera 57) by seven wickets Sri Lanka were better, the crowd was bigger, but the result was the same. Australia's experienced campaigners led by David Warner, Aaron Finch and Pat Cummins, were once again clinical in their home comforts to whitewash Sri Lanka 3-0. They held Sri Lanka to a sub-par total of 6 for 142 before mowing it down with seven wickets and 14 balls to spare. The difference was Australia's power-hitting, placement and brilliant running in the post powerplay phase on the big expanses of the MCG. David Warner capped a prolific series Getty Images Sri Lanka failed to score a boundary for 39 balls after the powerplay in their innings.

Commentary_Highlights: Tye to Roy, OUT battered high in the air, and Hazlewood circles at mid-on to gather a steepling miscue! The knuckleball does the trick, Roy was deceived by the change of pace, was through his shot too soon, and an aggressive if at times streaky innings comes to an end Marsh to Hales, OUT short ball, Hales tries to wallop it over square leg... but skews a top edge to point! Think that deflected off the helmet, Australia have used his head and Marsh breaks the stand. There's pace in this deck, seemed to surprise Hales and he top-edged it straight into the badge Marsh to Buttler, 1 leg bye Buttler tries to come down, another short ball and it ricochets off his shoulder behind square on the off side Tye to Root, 1 wide off line Tye to Buttler, SIX runs in the slot, and slotted over long-on! Power and placement Tye to Buttler, OUT full, and Buttler holes out to mid-off! That's a critical breakthrough for Australia, Warner back-pedals to complete the catch, and once again, Tye's slower ball draws out the miscue from a well-set batsman Tye to Root, 1 wide short, aggressive, but rather harshly judged as a wide, Zampa to Ali, OUT that's a very soft dismissal from Moeen! Down the track, losing his shape, a wellied drive in the air to cover, and England's hopes of their habitual 300-plus total are looking bleak all of a sudden Tye to Willey, OUT a mow over the leg side, and another catch in the deep! And was that another Tye slower ball? Certainly looked as though Willey was through his shot early, flapping the ball much squarer than he might have intended. This is a fine collective bowling effort from Australia, and England just can't get any momentum back into their innings Tye to Tom Curran, 1 wide less exceptional this time, mind you... Tye to Root, OUT smashed high and hard, but not high enough! In the slot once again, Root got underneath his shot, much like Roy before him, and picks out the man right back on the fence Tye to Ball, OUT well bowled! And that is five for Tye! Yorker, straight and true, rattles the timbers, and England's innings has come to an ignominious end Tom Curran to Head, 4 leg byes strays on to the pads, Warner flicks at it and the ball diverts wide of Buttler, no bat involved Ball to Stoinis, OUT knocked into the covers, called through for a tight single, there's a direct hit and this could be tight... although they then try to pinch a second on the ricochet. It goes up to the third umpire and Head is struggling here, there's only a frame or two in it, but he's not managed to get his bat over the line - this is going to be out! Morgan was the fielder, he pretty much hit the bails wi Ball to Stoinis, 1 wide banged in short, gets up sharply, but there's no reaching that one Ali to Maxwell, SIX runs plants the front foot, and that's up, up and away! Tossed up, tempting the aggression, but expertly executed Rashid to Stoinis, SIX runs up and over... and over the head of long-off! It teased the man on the rope, but just kept on going! Tom Curran to Maxwell, 1 wide 130kph, sliding down the leg side first up Tom Curran to Maxwell, OUT rapped on the pads, nibbling in sharply... Buttler is appealing desperately for lbw and England decide to review Tom Curran to Starc, OUT angled across, nips late and takes the edge - Buttler swallows it going low to his left! Curran leaps to punch the air, brilliant bit of bowling and a catch to match! He was trying to tuck to leg when he needed to play straight, Starc heads off with Daddles for company and Australia are seven down, the chase getting trickier and trickier "Will we get the inflatable four fingers up for this ending?" wonders Simon. I suspect England might get a hand gesture or two... Player of the match is Tom Curran, ENG
Match_Report: England 259 (Root 62, Tye 5-46) beat Australia 247 (Stoinis 87, Curran 5-35) by 12 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details A shattering spell of reverse swing by Tom Curran foiled Australia's chase of a modest England total and in turn silenced a West Australian record crowd of 53,781 in the first ODI to be played at Perth's new stadium. A trio of players from out west - Mitchell Marsh, AJ Tye and Marcus Stoinis - had prospered earlier in the match, but it was the effervescent Curran who had the final say, years after he had been childhood friends with Marsh when growing up in Zimbabwe. Australia seemed to be travelling comfortably in pursuit of 260 for victory, after England's batsmen had squandered a series of starts, when Stoinis fell within sight of a hundred upon his promotion to No. 3 in the home side's batting order. Having earlier ended a poor series for David Warner with a lively yorker, Curran was called back by Eoin Morgan and had his second ball curling back to confound the recalled Glenn Maxwell.

Commentary_Highlights: 1.20pm: We've have a toss! And Australia have won it and will bowl, they are going to try and chase again. Travis Head returns to the top of the order, in Finch's absence, while Mitchell Starc is rested and Andrew Tye gets another crack. Just one change for England, with Tom Curran replacing the injured Liam Plunkett. Cummins to Hales, OUT bowled 'im! Superb ball from Cummins and England are two down for spit! There's been some nip off this fresh surface and Cummins locates the perfect length, it jags back appreciably as Hales presses forwards, flicks the front pad before rattling the off pole Cummins to Root, OUT dug in, Root wafts at a pull, gets a big, ballooning top edge... and Hazlewood pockets the catch at fine leg! Root bags a duck and England are four down! Good pace and bounce, the bumper got too big for Root and he sent it right down the fielder's gullet. This could get ugly Hazlewood to Buttler, OUT zips off a length, grazes the outside edge! ENGLAND ARE 8 FOR 5!!! (Or 5 for 8, if you're that sort...) Brilliant ball from Hazlewood, not too much fault with the batsman here: perfect length, seaming a fraction as Buttler felt for it in defence, flicks the bat and Paine swallows another! Cummins to Morgan, OUT short, down the leg side and Morgan has gloved through to the keeper! That would have been a wide had he let it go, but the pace drew him into a response, and a thin tickle does the rest! England's revival is dented by a familiar foe Tye to Ali, OUT panned out to deep midwicket and picks out the fielder! A sharp double take as Head senses the rope behind him, tosses the ball back into play, and gathers at the second attempt Cummins to Rashid, OUT back of a length, a simple nibble outside off, and Cummins strikes again! Tye to Tom Curran, 1 bye woof, that's gone through, 138kph and it cuts through Curran, misses the edge by a whisker and then defeats Paine, deflecting off the gloves for a bye Stoinis to Woakes, SIX runs short-arm jabbed into the stands! That is some strike from Woakes, who is in Ribena form right now... not a terrible ball from Stoinis, slightly short but just helped over the rope at deep midwicket 5.10pm: So, England bowled out early, which was pretty much what was expected when they were 8 for 5 (EIGHT for FIVE) in the seventh over. But not quite as early as you might have imagined, with their big-bottomed lower order helping them to within a sniff of 200. Chris Woakes continued his fine series with the bat by pulling and 8.53pm So, that is the end of that. So, the series moves to Perth for the finale ... and the start of a new era with the WACA put to mothballs and 60,000 people anticipated in the city's new purpose-built stadium. Join us there on Sunday for all the fun of the fair. Australia won by 3 wickets (with 78 balls remaining) Player of the match is Pat Cummins, AUS
Match_Report: Australia 197 for 7 (Head 96, Rashid 3-49) beat England 196 (Woakes 78, Cummins 4-24, Tye 3-33, Hazlewood 3-39) by three wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details For a match that appeared over inside 10 overs, Australia's first ODI victory since September did not come easy. The new-ball pair of Pat Cummins and Josh Hazlewood filleted England's top order, but Chris Woakes' doughty rearguard and Adil Rashid's variations allowed the Australia Day ODI to creep into floodlit hours while Travis Head guided his team close to home. A slimmer-than-expected Adelaide Oval crowd of 24,329 seemed destined to be filing out of the exits early when Cummins and Hazlewood combined to have Eoin Morgan's side a sickly 5 for 8 as the new ball swung and seamed, before Woakes delivered his latest outstanding display of a series England had already won. Woakes' innings ensured that Australia needed at least one score of note to register their first ODI win since last year's India tour and only their second since January 2017, and it was Head, returning to the top of the order in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch, who provided it. His calm presence, laced with regular boundaries, contrasted with less certain innings from David Warner, Cameron White and the captain Steven Smith.

Commentary_Highlights: Zampa to Bairstow, OUT oh beautifully bowled. The previous one was the legbreak, this one was the googly. They both were really full, the length allowed Bairstow to throw his hands at the line without his feet. What that did was create a big gap between bat and pad, the legbreak found the middle of the bat, the googly found a massive gap between bat and Hazlewood to Root, OUT 135 kph, the first today but may not be the last. Root chops on. Was just saying Root is so good at finding gaps, and his natural instinct of trying to do so kicks in. It's a good length delivery outside off that seams back in, with Hazlewood's natural angle. The safer shot would have been playing with a full face, but Root tries Hazlewood to Morgan, OUT gottim! Morgan tries to open the face but ends up gliding an edge to the keeper! Hazlewood makes the breakthrough, just as England were starting to look fluent again. Used the angle across Morgan, who played pretty well but is still searching for a major contribution Marsh to Buttler, 1 wide pushes down the leg side as Buttler moves across Marsh to Ali, OUT bowled him, Moeen drags on! He'll have to drag himself off, it's not been a fun tour with the bat for him... Back of a length, this time the ugly swipe goes down, rather than up, and raps the top of off stump - no chance for a fielder to mess things up and Marsh has a wicket Hazlewood to Woakes, 1 leg bye length ball, 138kph but drifting leg side, deflected off the pads for one more Hazlewood to Buttler, SIX runs maximum pain exacted moments later, Buttler creaming a flat six over long-off! The beast raises an eyebrow and bares its teeth Cummins to Woakes, SIX runs short ball, slugged over the ropes at deep square leg! Woakes connects with a meaty pull and it sails for six, bringing up the England 250 in the process Cummins to Buttler, SIX runs smoked into the boundary boards, a fierce, flat pull and it goes all the way! Cummins to Buttler, SIX runs clubbed straight down the ground for six more! Humpty from Buttler, he dumps a full ball into the crowd - and he's into the 90s! Wood to White, OUT edged and gone! A start for White but he perishes looking to force the ball through point. May have been done in by some extra bounce. Back of a length delivery outside off, White looks to hit the ball through point but all he can get is a thin outside edge. Was actually looking quite solid on a tricky surface Rashid to Finch, OUT tosses up the legbreak, Finch goes to sweep, hit on the pads - and given! Finch immediately signals for a review, seeming to suggest he got some bat on it... but there's no bottom edge on the replays, and Hawk-Eye has it clipping leg stump! It was very close to sliding by but umpire's call is all England needed. Huge wicket, no hund Wood to Smith, OUT throws the hands, thick edge and Buttler snaffles a terrific low grab! Wood is delirious as he charges off...but Smith isn't walking. This is going to the TV umpire, and the soft signal is out, which could be crucial. Has he got fingertips under it? This is going to be incredibly tight, it's a fantastic effort from Buttler, but is the Rashid to Stoinis, SIX runs that's a confident shot. And runs give you confidence. Runs down to a good wristspinner early in his innings, backs his ability, gets to the pitch and drills a drive over mid-on. All the way Rashid to Marsh, OUT taken at long-on. And Australia stumble further. This is a huge moment, the set man has picked out long-on. There have been so many dismissals where a batsman mistakes a flat legspinner for a long-hop. Happened to Guptill against Zampa at this ground, think it was last year. Marsh goes back and looks to pull over midwicket, but the Rashid to Stoinis, 1 bye bye? Flight outside off, Stoinis misses a drive, the ball deflects off Buttler's gloves for one to third man 10.08pm This England ODI juggernaut continues to roll. They have got to be one of the best in the world currently. They have beaten a strong Australia team thrice in succession away from home. And three convincing wins. The series is done. The Tests and the ODIs one-sided, but dominated by different teams. Player of the match is Jos Buttler, ENG
Match_Report: England 6 for 302 (Buttler 100*, Woakes 53*) beat Australia 6 for 286 (Finch 62, Stoinis 56, Marsh 55) by 16 runs Scorecard and ball-by-ball details Jos Buttler's stunning century and a composed all-round effort with the ball helped England clinch the ODI series with two matches to play. Although Marcus Stoinis kept Australia in the hunt until the final over, Mark Wood and Chris Woakes closed the game out with another smart display of death bowling. England had been struggling on 6 for 189 when Buttler and Woakes came together but they put on an unbroken 113-run stand to take the total beyond 300. Buttler reached his fifth one-day hundred from the last ball of the innings as England made far more than had looked likely. He then took a contentious catch to dismiss Steven Smith at a key point in the chase as England held on to go 3-0 up.

Commentary_Highlights: Plunkett to Warner, 1 wide down the leg side, Warner misses his flick but he'll get that ball again Ali to Warner, OUT edged, taken! Lovely stuff from Moeen. This is tighter to off stump, Warner looking to push into the off side, takes an outside edge and snaffled at slip Rashid to Finch, SIX runs that's high and handsome! A full delivery, Finch stays in the crease, and lofts it cleanly straight down the ground over long-on Plunkett to Smith, 1 wide attacking the tramlines on a full length outside off, but just a tick too far outside off for the umpire's liking Root to Smith, OUT huge appeal and Smith is pinned lbw! Unsurprisingly, he has reviewed... he was stretching onto the front foot, might it have hit him outside the line? Nope, that is trimming the top of the leg bail and what a breakthrough! Woakes to Marsh, 1 wide short, too short. Good aggression but there was no reaching that one Woakes to Finch, 1 leg bye short of a length, angled into the pad, deflects off the thigh guard behind square Plunkett to Finch, 1 wide slips this down the leg side, an angry cry from Plunkett Rashid to Marsh, OUT he's gone now! He knew he had to press the accelerator, he charges out of his crease, nowhere near the ball, has a swing across the line, misses and it's a simple stumping for Buttler Plunkett to Finch, OUT finds mid-on! Once again, England strike back-to-back...went to drive down the ground, think he wanted to go over top, got no sort of elevation and it's a simple catch on the edge of the circle Rashid to Stoinis, OUT given caught behind! That's a lovely piece of bowling, England on the charge. Floated up on off stump, draws Stonis forward, spins away as he drives and it's a thin snick Woakes to Starc, OUT this time he's taken at deep midwicket! Roy this time. Good length, bit of pace off, Starc tries to clear the leg side and can't get the distance needed Well, what do we make of that from Australia? Apart from Aaron Finch, it felt pretty ordinary. However, all credit to England. They bowled very impressively, spin playing a key role with Root chipping in with two wickets, and Eoin Morgan's captaincy and tactics were outstanding. England didn't have any problem chasing over 300 a few days ago so they'll be hugely confident Tye to Hales, 1 wide short and aggressive. Too short... Starc to Buttler, 1 wide down the leg side "Richo bowled pretty well, perhaps [we should have played a spinner]. This wicket is different to the one we had for the Test match." 9.02pm Right, that's your lot. Thanks for joining us today, have a read of Dan Brettig's report and join us again on Sunday for the third ODI in Sydney, where Australia desperately need a win to stay alive in the series. England won by 4 wickets (with 34 balls remaining) Player of the match is Joe Root, ENG
Match_Report: England 6 for 274 (Bairstow 60, Hales 57, Starc 4-57) beat Australia 9 for 270 (Finch 106) by 4 wickets Scorecard and ball-by-ball details "It was surrounded by Jason's incredible innings, but I've no doubt somebody else would've put their hand up if needed." With these words Eoin Morgan summed up England's confidence after an opening win in Melbourne. Five days later at the Gabba it proved a prescient assessment, as the visitors did without a Jason Roy special to again run rings around a desperately muddled Australia. Clearly, Australia's decision-makers had judged themselves to have not made enough runs in Melbourne - Adam Zampa was out and Cameron White in. As if to take the mickey out of that choice, England employed three spinners to bog down the hosts after Steven Smith won the toss, before taking a horrid toll on Travis Head when he was employed as the quasi-specialist Australian slow bowler.
